PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a complete recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the Village of New Lenox, Illinois. 
    Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1981 Village Code, as supplemented through Ordinance No. 1613, adopted February 8, 2005, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the board of trustees. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1981 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
    The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Chapter and Section Numbering System 
    The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. 
Page Numbering System 
    The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
CODE CD1:1 CODE APPENDIX CDA:1 CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES CCT:1 STATE LAW REFERENCE TABLE SLT:1 CODE INDEX CDi:1  
Index 
    The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
    Keeping this publication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    This publication was under the direct supervision of John Dombroski, Vice-President of Production and Elizabeth Butler, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publisher is most grateful to Ms. Marcia Englert, Village Clerk, for her cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the village readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the village's affairs.

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - Designation and citation of Code. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Village of New Lenox Code," and may be so cited. 
(Code 1981, § 1-1-1) 
State Law reference- Revision of ordinances and publication thereof in book form, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-3 et seq. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
(a)  In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances, the rules and definitions set out in this section shall be observed. The rules of construction and definitions set out in this section shall not be applied to any section of this Code which shall contain any express provision excluding such construction or where the subject matter or context of such section may be repugnant thereto. 
(b)  All general provisions, term, phrases and expressions contained in this Code shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of the president and board of trustees may be fully carried out. 
(c)  In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of this Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general provision imposed by this Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. 
(d)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this Code, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Administrative ticket. The term "administrative ticket" means a courtesy ticket used in the case of certain minor ordinance violations in lieu of arrest. 
    Agent. The term "agent" means a person acting on behalf of another. 
    Board, village board and board of trustees. The terms "board," "village board" and "board of trustees" mean the president and board of trustees of the Village of New Lenox. 
    Code. The terms "Code," "Village Code" and "the Village Code" mean the Village of New Lenox Code, Village of New Lenox, Illinois. 
    Computation of time. The time within which any act provided by law is to be done shall exclude the last day, unless the last day is Saturday or Sunday or a holiday, as defined or fixed in any statute in force in the state, and then it shall be excluded. If the day succeeding such Saturday, Sunday or holiday is also a holiday or a Saturday or a Sunday, such succeeding day shall also be excluded. 
    Corporate or village limits. The terms "corporate limits" and "village limits" mean the legal boundaries of the Village of New Lenox. 
    County. The terms "the county" and "this county" mean the County of Will in the State of Illinois. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department or some other village officer to do some act or make certain inspections, it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department or other officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or make the required inspection, unless the terms of the provision or section designate otherwise. 
    Fee. The term "fee" means a sum of money charged by the village for the carrying on of a business, profession or occupation. 
    Fiscal year. The fiscal year of the village commences on May 1 of each year. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations, as well as to males. 
    ILCS. The abbreviation "ILCS" means the Illinois Compiled Statutes, as amended. 
    Joint authority. All words giving a joint authority to three or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. 
    Keeper, proprietor. The terms "keeper" and "proprietor" mean and include persons, firms, associations, corporations, clubs and partnerships, whether acting by themselves or a servant, agent or employee. 
    License. The term "license" means the permission granted for the carrying on of a business, profession or occupation. 
    Mayor. The term "mayor" means the village president. 
    Misdemeanor. The term "misdemeanor" means any offense for which a sentence to a term of imprisonment in other than a penitentiary for less than one year may be imposed. 
    Month. The term "month" means a calendar month. 
    Municipal year. The term "municipal year" means the fiscal year. 
    Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. 
    Nuisance. The term "nuisance" means anything offensive or obnoxious to the health and welfare of the inhabitants of the village; or any act or thing repugnant to, or creating a hazard to, or having a detrimental effect on, the property of another person or to the community. 
    Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons and things, and words importing the plural number may include the singular. 
    Oath. The term "oath" includes an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the terms "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the terms "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Occupant. The term "occupant," as applied to a building or land, includes any person who occupies the whole or any part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. 
    Offense. The term "offense" means any act forbidden by any provision of this Code or the omission of any act required by the provisions of this Code. 
    Officers, departments, etc. Officers, departments, boards, commissions, committees and employees referred to in this Code shall mean officers, departments, boards, commissions, committees and employees of the village, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
    Operator. The term "operator" means the person who is in charge of any operation, business or profession. 
    Owner. The term "owner," applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or lessee, or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The term "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, clubs, societies, firms, companies, partnerships, and bodies politic and corporate, as well as to individuals, or any other group acting as a unit, as well as a natural person. 
    Personal property. The term "personal property" includes every species of property except real property. 
    Preceding, following. The terms "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    President. The term "president" means the president of the board of trustees of the Village of New Lenox. 
    Property. The term "property" includes real and personal property. 
    Real property. The term "real property" includes lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Retailer. The term "retailer," unless otherwise specifically defined, relates to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in small quantities direct to the consumer. 
    Shall, may. The term "shall" is mandatory; the term "may" is permissive. 
    Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" means any pavement between the curbline and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. 
    Signature, subscription. The terms "signature" and "subscription" include a mark when the person cannot write. 
    State. The terms "the state" and "this state" mean the State of Illinois. 
    Street. The term "street" includes alleys, lanes, courts, boulevards, public squares, public places and sidewalks. 
    Surety bonds. Whenever a surety bond to indemnify the village is required by ordinance, the surety or sureties shall be two individual freeholders and residents of the village or a duly licensed corporation authorized to do business in this state as a surety company. When additional sureties may be needed for any reason, the board may order new sureties to be secured, and if the new sureties are not procured within ten days of notice thereof to the principal or his assignee, the board shall declare the bond cancelled and void, and thereupon such principal or assignee shall be deemed to have surrendered all privileges and rights as a condition for which the bond was required. 
    Tenant, occupant. The terms "tenant" and "occupant," applied to a building or land, include any person holding a written or oral lease or who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with others. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future, as well as the past and present. 
    Time. If a time is given in a.m. or p.m., it means Central Standard Time, except that when the village is on daylight saving time it shall mean Central Daylight Saving Time. 
    Trustee. The term "trustee" means a member of the board of trustees. 
    Village. The terms "the village" and "this village" mean the Village of New Lenox in the County of Will in the State of Illinois. 
    Village president. The term "village president" means, and the president of the village may be referred to as, the mayor or president of the village. 
    Wholesale, wholesaler, wholesale dealer. The terms "wholesale," "wholesaler" and "wholesale dealer," unless otherwise specifically defined, relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in quantity to persons who purchase for purposes of resale, as distinguished from a retail dealer who sells in smaller quantities direct to the consumer. 
    Written, in writing. The terms "written" and "in writing" include printing and any other mode of representing words and letters; but when the written signature of any person is required by law on any official or public writing or bond, it shall be in the proper handwriting of such person, or, if he is unable to write, his proper mark, except as otherwise provided by law. 
    Year. The term "year" means a calendar year. 
(Code 1981, §§ 1-3-2, 4-7-6.A) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 5 ILCS 70/1 et seq. 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections and other headings. 
    The catchlines of the several subsections and sections and the headings of chapters, articles and divisions of this Code are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the subsection, section, chapter, article or division and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such subsections, sections, chapters, articles and divisions or as any part of the subsection, section, chapter, article or division, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such subsections, sections, chapters, articles or divisions, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(Code 1981, § 1-3-3) 
Sec. 1-4. - References and notes. 
    Cross references, state law references, editor's notes and history notes appearing throughout the Code are by way of explanation only and shall not be deemed a part of the text of any section. 
Sec. 1-5. - Amendments to Code. 
    Any ordinance amending this Code shall set forth the chapter and section number of the section or sections to be amended, and this shall constitute a sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to the amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this Code. All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code that amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion in this Code, or, if chapters, sections and subsections or any parts thereof are repealed by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby, and the subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed, or omitted in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code of Ordinances by the board of trustees. 
(Code 1981, § 1-1-3) 
Sec. 1-6. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by village personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the president and board of trustees. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive parts of permanent and general ordinances passed by the president and board of trustees during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages that have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code that have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _______ to _______" (inserting sections numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections or the alphabetical arrangement of new chapters inserted into the Code, but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
Sec. 1-7. - Unauthorized alteration of Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the village to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever that will cause the law of the village to be misrepresented thereby. 
(Code 1981, § 1-1-4) 
Sec. 1-8. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  When any ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause or provision shall be itself repealed, such repeal shall not be construed to revive such former ordinance, clause or provision unless it shall be therein so expressly provided. 
(b)  No section of this Code or new ordinance shall be construed to repeal any former ordinance, whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not, as to any offense committed against the former ordinance or as to any act done, any penalty, forfeiture or punishment incurred, or any right accrued or claim arising under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any such offense or act so committed or done or any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so incurred or any right so accrued or claim arising before the section of this Code or new ordinance takes effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform, so far as practicable, to the laws in force at the time of such proceedings. 
(c)  If any penalty, forfeiture or punishment be mitigated by any provision of this Code or new ordinance, such provision may, by the consent of the party affected, be applied to any judgment pronounced after the section of this Code or new ordinance takes effect. 
(d)  This section shall extend to all repeals, either by express words or by implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance adopting this Code or a new ordinance upon the same subject or in any other ordinance or act. 
(Code 1981, § 1-2-3) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 5 ILCS 70/3. 
Sec. 1-9. - General penalty for violation of Code; continuing violations. 
(a)  Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance of the village any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or whenever in such Code or ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no other specific penalty is provided, the violation of such provision of this Code or any ordinance shall be punished by a fine of not more than $750.00, or such other amount as provided by statute, for any one offense. The revocation of a license or permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other penalty being enforced. Every day that a violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  In addition, a penalty imposed for may include, or consist of, a requirement that the subject accused do one or more of the following: 
(1)  Complete an education program, except that a holder of a valid commercial driver's license who commits a vehicle weight or size restriction violation shall not be required to complete an education program under this section. 
(2)  Perform some reasonable public service work such as but not limited to the picking up of litter in public parks or along public highways or the maintenance of public facilities. 
(3)  Drug and/or alcohol test(s) to determine the presence or absence of specified parent drugs or their metabolites. 
(4)  Drug and/or alcohol evaluation and follow the recommendations of the evaluation. 
No imprisonment as authorized by 65 ILCS 5/1-2-9 for failure to pay any fine, penalty or cost shall exceed 6 months for one offense. 
(Code 1981, §§ 1-4-1, 1-4-3; Ord. No. 2192, § 2, 8-22-2011) 
State Law reference- Limitation on penalties imposed for violation of ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1, 5/1-2-1.1. 
Sec. 1-10. - Liability of officers to penalty for failure to perform designated duties. 
    No provision of this Code designating the duties of any officer or employee shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of the board of trustees to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the duty. 
(Code 1981, § 1-4-4) 
Sec. 1-11. - Issuance of citation. 
    Whenever a police officer of the village is authorized to arrest a person because of a violation of a village ordinance in respect to any of the following subjects: 
(1)  Prohibiting the parking of a vehicle in a designated area; 
(2)  Prohibiting double parking of vehicles; 
(3)  Prohibiting the parking of vehicles during designated times; 
(4)  Prohibiting the parking of vehicles on streets after specified snow conditions; 
(5)  Prohibiting the parking of vehicles facing contrary to the flow of traffic; 
(6)  Prohibiting the parking, stopping or standing of vehicles; 
(7)  Licensing and regulating dogs and cats; 
(8)  Regulating the dumping of garbage; 
(9)  Regulating the burning of garbage; 
(10)  Regulating the storage of garbage; 
(11)  Regulating the burning of leaves; 
(12)  Licensing and regulating the erection and maintenance of signs; 
(13)  Prohibiting the abandonment of vehicles (see chapter 90, article VIII); 
(14)  Requiring the display of assigned house numbers; 
(15)  Prohibiting the wilful defacing or removal of house numbers; 
(16)  Licensing and controlling motor vehicles (provided for in chapter 90, article VII); 
(17)  Pedestrian violations under the state vehicle code, 625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq., adopted by section 90-3; 
(18)  Nuisance violations (see section 54-133); 
(19)  Regulating the length of vehicles; 
the police officer may, in lieu of the filing of a complaint in the circuit court of the county, in the first instance issue to such alleged violator a citation advising the person that he has violated a specified village ordinance, requesting him to make payment as set forth in this chapter in an amount applicable to the alleged violation as set forth in section 1-15 as settlement of the violation claim, and informing him that upon failure to so settle a complaint will be filed in the circuit court of the county charging him with such violation. 
(Code 1981, § 4-7-1; Ord. No. 1805, § 2, 9-26-2006; Ord. No. 2384, § 2, 10-28-2013) 
Sec. 1-12. - Settlement of claim imposed pursuant to citation. 
(a)  Pursuant to a citation issued under section 1-11, the person so accused of the violation may settle and compromise the violation claim in respect to such ordinance by paying to the village the applicable amount set forth in section 1-15 applicable, within a period to be specified in the citation, not more than seven days of the time the citation is issued. 
(b)  Such payment shall be made in accordance with the instructions contained in the citation, at the office of the village clerk, who shall issue a receipt for the money so received and promptly remit such amount to the village treasurer to be credited to the proper municipal fund. 
(Code 1981, § 4-7-2) 
Sec. 1-13. - Failure to settle claim imposed pursuant to citation. 
    If the person to whom a citation is issued pursuant to section 1-11 fails to settle and pay the violation claim within the prescribed time set forth in the citation, then the police officer shall file a complaint and prosecute the violation in the manner prescribed by law. 
(Code 1981, § 4-7-3) 
Sec. 1-14. - Presumption of liability for violations involving motor vehicle. 
    The fact that an automobile or motor vehicle which is illegally operated or parked is registered with the secretary of state in the name of the alleged violator shall be considered prima facie proof that the alleged violator was in control of or was the operator of the automobile or motor vehicle at the time of such alleged violation. 
(Code 1981, § 4-7-4) 
Sec. 1-15. - Administrative tickets. 
(a)  Issuance. Administrative tickets may be used for those ordinance violations listed in subsection (b) of this section and issued by police officers, code enforcement officers, village zoning officers, inspectors, or any authorized village employee. 
(b)  Applicability; fee schedule. At the discretion of the officer or agent of the village authorized to issue such administrative tickets, an administrative ticket may be issued as a courtesy in lieu of arrest. Such administrative tickets shall only be used for those violations which are enumerated below:

(c)  Settlement of claim. When an administrative ticket is issued, the offender shall pay to the village the related fine as set forth in subsection (b) of this section within ten days of the date of issuance of the ticket, in addition to providing proof of compliance where applicable.

If the subject accused of the violation does not settle the claim within a ten-day period, a summons to appear before the magistrate or a notice to appear in the circuit court of the county will be issued for the violation, and the person shall be subject to costs plus the minimum fines and penalties as set forth in section 1-15(b) and all other applicable provisions of this code, with the maximum fines and penalties as set forth in section 1-9 and all other applicable provisions of this code. 
(e)  Every day that a violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1981, § 4-7-6.B, C; Ord. No. 1400, §§ 1, 2, 5-29-2002; Ord. No. 1418, § 2, 10-9-2002; Ord. No. 1454, § 2, 2-11-2003; Ord. No. 1720, § 2, 1-10-2006; Ord. No. 1805, § 3, 9-26-2006; Ord. No. 2384, § 3, 10-28-2013; Ord. No. 2549, § 2, 2-8-2016; Ord. No. 2761, § 3, 12-17-2018) 
Sec. 1-16. - Parties to an offense. 
    Every person who commits, attempts to commit, conspires to commit, or aids or abets in the commission of any act declared in this Code to be an offense, whether individually or in connection with one or more other persons, or as principal, agent or accessory, shall be guilty of such offense, and every person who falsely, fraudulently, forcibly or willfully induces, causes, coerces, requires, permits or directs another to violate any provision of this Code shall likewise be guilty of such offense. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/16-201. 
Sec. 1-17. - Election as to section under which to proceed in prosecution for violation. 
    In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or created by different clauses or sections of this Code or other ordinances of the village, the prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed, but not more than one recovery may be had against the same person for the same offense. 
(Code 1981, § 1-4-3) 
Sec. 1-18. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional, invalid or inapplicable by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality, invalidity or inapplicability shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
(Code 1981, § 1-2-4) 
Sec. 1-19. - Ordinances not affected by adoption of Code. 
    The repeal provided for in the ordinance adopting this Code shall not affect any of the following: 
(1)  Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. If any penalty, forfeiture or punishment is mitigated by any provision of a new ordinance, such provision may be, by the consent of the party affected, applied to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes effect. 
(2)  Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the village, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the village or any evidence of the village's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the village. 
(3)  Any ordinance dedicating, accepting the dedication of, naming, establishing, locating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street, alley, public way or public park in the village. 
(4)  Any appropriation or budget ordinance. 
(5)  Any ordinance levying or imposing taxes or special assessments, or authorizing tax fund transfers, not inconsistent with this Code. 
(6)  Any ordinance rezoning specific property, or any amendment thereto. 
(7)  Any ordinance establishing or prescribing grades in the village. 
(8)  Any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor. 
(9)  Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the village. 
(10)  Any ordinance extending or contracting the boundaries of the village. 
(11)  Any ordinance prescribing personnel rules or regulations or compensation for village officers or employees, not inconsistent with this Code. 
(12)  Any ordinance declaring certain property to be a public nuisance and authorizing procedures for the demolition of the property. 
(13)  Any ordinance adopted by reference by any section of this Code, or any amendments to such ordinances. 
(14)  Any ordinance establishing fire lanes on private property. 
(15)  Any ordinance respecting conveyance or acceptance of real property or easements in real property. 
(16)  Any ordinance relating to the conduct, duties, service or rates of public utilities, except as this Code may contain provisions for such matters, in which case this Code shall be considered as amending such ordinance in respect to such provisions only. 
(17)  Any ordinance calling an election. 
(18)  Ordinance No. 1125. 
(19)  Ordinance No. 1126. 
(20)  Any temporary or special ordinance. 
(Code 1981, § 1-2-2) 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Freedom of Information Act. 
    The Village of New Lenox Freedom of Information Act Rules and Regulations are attached to the ordinance from which this section derives as Exhibit A, and are hereby adopted and made a part of this section and shall be utilized by the village to carry out the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act. 
(Ord. No. 2085, § 2, 1-11-2010) 
Secs. 2-2-2-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BOARD OF TRUSTEES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Elections, ch. 30. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-31. - Membership; powers. 
    The board of trustees shall consist of the village president and six members elected for a four-year term. Three members shall be elected every two years. The board of trustees is the legislative body of the village and is the repository of all municipal powers which have not been specifically delegated to some other office, commission, committee or board. The appointment of all officers, commissions, committees and boards shall be subject to the approval of the board of trustees. The hiring and dismissal of all full-time employees of the village shall also be subject to approval of the board. 
(Code 1981, § 1-5-1) 
Secs. 2-32-2-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MEETINGS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Meetings, 5 ILCS 120/2.02, 120/2.03. 

Sec. 2-51. - Regular meetings. 
    The regular meetings of the board, to include dates, times and places will be announced, posted and advertised at the beginning of each calendar year. Any change to the regular schedule must be announced, posted and advertised as required by law. Village board meetings shall be held at 7:00 p.m. in the board's council chambers on the second, third, and fourth Monday of each month, with the exception that the two regular meetings held in the month of December of each year shall be held on the second and third Monday. 
(Code 1981, § 1-5-2.A; Ord. No. 1174, § 1, 12-10-1997; Ord. No. 1868, § 1, 8-14-2007; Ord. No. 2189, § 2, 8-8-2011; Ord. No. 2270, § 2, 7-9-2012) 
Sec. 2-52. - Special meetings. 
(a)  Notice. Special meetings of the board may be called at any time by the president or three board members upon giving not less than 24 hours' notice to all members of the village board; provided, however, that if a special meeting is called during a regular meeting and all members of the board are present at the regular meeting, then no notice of the special meeting shall be necessary. Notice of special meetings will also be given in the manner provided by law. 
(b)  Payment of costs of special meetings. The cost of each special meeting is hereby determined to be that amount which would be paid to the board as a whole for their attendance at a regularly held public meeting, and, as a condition precedent to the calling of the special meeting, that sum shall be paid to the village clerk prior to or simultaneously with the notice required by this section. 
(c)  Payment of costs of professional assistance. If the village board, in its sole discretion, determines that it requires professional assistance in order to ensure a full and fair evaluation of any matter, it may obtain such professional assistance from any qualified individual or association selected by the village board, and may incur expenses in respect thereof in any reasonable amount. The village shall be reimbursed by the person requesting the special meeting for any costs incurred for professional assistance. To ensure such reimbursement, the person, prior to being granted a hearing, shall execute and deliver to the village a binding commitment to reimburse the village for all reasonable costs incurred by the village in obtaining such professional assistance. Such costs shall be paid to the village within 30 days from the date the village submits a statement therefor to the person for payment. 
(Code 1981, § 1-5-2.B; Ord. No. 1371, § 2, 12-12-2001) 
State Law reference- Additional requirements, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-25, 5/3.1-45-5. 
Sec. 2-53. - Adjourned meetings. 
    If there shall be no quorum present at any regular or special meeting of the board, then the members present at the meeting may adjourn the meeting to a future date and fix the date and hour of the adjourned meeting. Notice of adjourned meeting shall be made in accordance with law. 
(Code 1981, § 1-5-2.C) 
State Law reference- Notice of adjourned meetings, 5 ILCS 120/2.03(a). 
Sec. 2-54. - Open and closed meetings. 
    All meetings of the board shall be open to the public, except that closed meetings may be held in accordance with the Open Meetings Act, 5 ILCS 120/1 et seq. 
(Code 1981, § 1-5-2.D) 
Secs. 2-55-2-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RULES OF PROCEDURE 

Sec. 2-71. - Generally. 
    The board of trustees shall be governed in its deliberations by the rules set out in this division. 
(Code 1981, § 1-5-3) 
Sec. 2-72. - Quorum. 
    A quorum for the transaction of business shall consist of a majority of all the board entitled by law to be elected. 
(Code 1981, § 1-5-3.A) 
Sec. 2-73. - Presiding officer. 
    The presiding officer shall preserve order and decorum and may speak to points of order in preference to other members, and shall decide all questions of order subject to appeal. If he refuses to allow the trustees to exercise their right to appeal a decision of the chair, the trustees may consider and pass upon the matter in spite of the chair's failure to grant them an appeal. In case of any disturbances or disorderly conduct, the presiding officer shall have the power to require the chamber to be cleared. 
(Code 1981, § 1-5-3.B) 
Sec. 2-74. - Petitions or communications. 
    All petitions or communications addressed to the board shall be reduced to writing and filed with the village clerk prior to the meeting. 
(Code 1981, § 1-5-3.C) 
Sec. 2-75. - Applicability of Robert's Rules of Order. 
    Robert's Rules of Order, except when otherwise provided by law, shall govern all questions of parliamentary procedure at meetings of the board. 
(Code 1981, § 1-5-3.D) 
Sec. 2-76. - Alteration, amendment or suspension of rules. 
    The rules may be altered, amended or temporarily suspended at any time by a majority vote of the board. 
(Code 1981, § 1-5-3.E) 
Sec. 2-77. - Order of business. 
    The order of business shall be as established from time to time by the village board. 
(Code 1981, § 1-5-3.F) 
Secs. 2-78-2-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance prescribing personnel rules, or regulations or compensation for village officers or employees, not inconsistent with this Code saved from repeal, § 1-19(11); local liquor control commissioner, § 6-130 et seq.; coordinator of emergency services and disaster agency, § 26-32; police department, § 50-31 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-101. - Applicability of division. 
    The provisions of this division shall apply to all officers and employees of the village, regardless of the time of creation of office, appointment or employment thereof. 
(Code 1981, § 1-9-1) 
Sec. 2-102. - Oath. 
    Every officer of the village shall, before entering upon the duties of his office, take the oath of office as prescribed by 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-25 at a public meeting of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1981, § 1-9-2) 
Sec. 2-103. - Bonds. 
    Every officer, and every employee when directed by the board or by law, shall, before entering upon his duties of office or position, execute a bond in such amount as may be determined by the village board or by law, with sureties as it may approve, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties of his office or position. The village will pay the premiums of such bonds. 
(Code 1981, § 1-9-3) 
Sec. 2-104. - Salaries. 
    All officers and employees of the village shall receive such salary as is provided for from time to time by law or ordinance. No officer or employee receiving a salary from the village shall be entitled to retain any fees, or portion thereof, collected by him in the performance of his duties. 
(Code 1981, § 1-9-4) 
Sec. 2-105. - Job descriptions. 
    A job description of all employee positions will be on file with the village clerk and the village administrator. 
(Code 1981, § 1-9-5) 
Sec. 2-106. - Ownership of records; inspection of records. 
    All records kept by any officer or employee in connection with his work are the property of the village and shall be subject to inspection by any member of the board at any time. 
(Code 1981, § 1-9-6) 
Sec. 2-107. - Receipt of money. 
    All moneys received by any officer or employee on behalf of the village shall be turned over to the village treasurer with a statement showing the source of the money. 
(Code 1981, § 1-9-7) 
Sec. 2-108. - Arrests. 
    The members of the village board and the village clerk shall have power to cause to be arrested persons they observe violating any ordinance or statute or persons whom they have probable cause to believe have violated an ordinance or statute. All members of the police department are declared to be conservators of the peace with such powers of arrest as are given conservators of the peace by statute. 
(Code 1981, § 1-9-8) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-15-25; police training requirements, 50 ILCS 705/1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-109. - Delivery of records and property to successor in office. 
    Every officer or employee, upon termination of his office or position for any cause whatsoever, shall deliver to his successor all books, records and other papers and things relative to his office or position, and if no successor has been appointed within two weeks after termination thereof, such property shall be delivered to the village clerk. 
(Code 1981, § 1-9-9) 
Sec. 2-110. - Participation in Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund. 
    The village hereby elects to participate in the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund (40 ILCS 5/7-101 et seq.), effective January 1, 1974. 
(Code 1981, § 1-9-10) 
Sec. 2-111. - Participation in Illinois Police Training Act program. 
    The village hereby elects to participate in the program provided for in the Illinois Police Training Act (50 ILCS 705/1 et seq.). Before an individual may commence regular employment as a police officer, he must have been certified by the state law enforcement officers training standards board as having successfully completed an approved training course as provided in the act. Such basic training must be completed by the trainee within six months of initial full-time employment. 
(Code 1981, § 1-9-11) 
Sec. 2-112. - Public water commission representative. 
(a)  The village president, with the approval of the board of trustees, shall appoint a commissioner, as provided by 65 ILCS 5/11-135-2, for the purpose of investigating intergovernmental water service delivery in conjunction with other area communities in a cooperative effort, referred to in this section as the "public water commission." 
(b)  The full and complete supervision, care, maintenance and management of the investment in the public water commission is hereby placed under the jurisdiction of the water commissioner, who shall act as such at the pleasure of the village president. 
(Code 1981, § 1-9-12) 
Sec. 2-113. - Annual budget; budget officer. 
(a)  Optional Budget Act adopted. The village hereby adopts 65 ILCS 5/8-2-9.1-5/8-2-9.10, commonly known as the Optional Budget Act. 
(b)  Budget officer. The position of budget officer is created, and the village administrator is hereby appointed to this position. 
(c)  Adoption of salaries. The salaries and salary adjustments for all officers and employees of the village as described in the annual comprehensive budget shall replace the annual salary ordinance provisions. 
(Code 1981, § 1-9-13) 
Sec. 2-114. - Removal of officers. 
    Except where otherwise provided by statute, the village president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, may remove any officer appointed by him in accordance with the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-10. 
(Code 1981, § 1-8-5) 
Sec. 2-115. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1551, § 1, adopted May 25, 2004, repealed § 2-115 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to the adoption of the State Gift Ban Act as enacted by Ord. No. 1244, §§ 1-4, adopted June 22, 1999. The user's attention is directed to Ch. 2, Art. VI, for similar provisions. 
Sec. 2-116. - Personnel policy and procedures manual. 
    There is hereby adopted a document known as the personnel policy and procedures manual containing the rules and regulations governing the operation of the personnel activities of the village, and a copy of said document will be kept in the office of the director of human resources. 
(Ord. No. 2277, § 2, 8-13-2012; Ord. No. 2416, § 2, 5-12-2014; Ord. No. 2585, § 2, 8-22-2016) 
Secs. 2-117-2-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PRESIDENT 

Sec. 2-131. - Election; term; authority. 
    The village president shall be elected for a four-year term and is the chief executive officer of the village. 
(Code 1981, § 1-6-1) 
Sec. 2-132. - Duties. 
(a)  Generally. The village president shall perform all of the duties which are prescribed by law and municipal ordinances, and he is required to see that such laws and ordinances are faithfully executed. 
(b)  Coordination of public affairs; conduct of negotiations. With the advice and consent of the board of trustees, the village president shall coordinate all matters pertaining to the public affairs of the village. He shall have the authority to conduct, when necessary, preliminary negotiations on village matters. In the areas mentioned of coordinating public affairs and conducting negotiations, the president shall give prior notice to the board of trustees. In any event, he shall disclose all such activities to the board of trustees no later than the next regular meeting of that board. The village president shall appoint one trustee and one alternate, on a rotating basis, to become a part of any preliminary negotiating team for any village business. 
(c)  Appointments. The village president shall appoint, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, such other officers, standing committees, special committees, commissions and boards as prescribed by law and municipal ordinances that may be necessary to the health, welfare and safety of the village. 
(d)  Other roles. A marriage may be solemnized and a civil union may be certified by the village president. 
(Code 1981, § 1-6-2; Ord. No. 2215, § 2, 10-24-2011) 
Secs. 2-133-2-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ADMINISTRATOR 

Sec. 2-151. - Appointment; qualifications. 
    The village administrator shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the village board of trustees. The village administrator chosen shall be of high moral character, and his administrative experience, along with his knowledge of municipal administration, should be of prime importance in his selection. He need not be a resident of the village. No trustee or village president shall hold the office of village administrator during his term of office or within one year after his term of office expires. 
(Code 1981, § 1-8-1.A) 
Sec. 2-152. - Designation of temporary administrator. 
    During the absence or disability of the village administrator, the village president, with the advice and consent of the village board of trustees, may designate some properly qualified village employee to act as temporary village administrator. 
(Code 1981, § 1-8-1.B) 
Sec. 2-153. - Employment contract; term of employment. 
    The administrator shall be employed by contract, the terms of which shall be agreed upon by both the administrator and a majority of the corporate authorities of the village. The term of the village administrator shall be no less than one year. The village administrator may not be employed by any other governmental body or business during the period of his contract unless specifically authorized by the village board of trustees. 
(Code 1981, § 1-8-1.C) 
Sec. 2-154. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The village administrator shall assist the village clerk and they shall jointly have custody of all village documents except as directed by law or by ordinance to be deposited elsewhere. 
(b)  The village administrator shall assist the treasurer in the issuance and sale of bonds, warrants and obligations. 
(c)  The village administrator shall supervise the accounting work of the village. 
(d)  On or before April 15 in each year and before the annual appropriation or budget ordinance is prepared by the corporate authorities, the village administrator shall submit to the corporate authorities a report of his estimates of the money needed to defray the expenses of the village during the next fiscal year, and in this report he shall classify and detail the purposes of expenditures, the aggregate income of the preceding year, the village liabilities, and such other information as necessary to assist the village board of trustees in adoption of an appropriation ordinance. For the purpose of preparing the estimate, he shall cooperate with each committee chairman in the preparation of statements of the condition and expenses of their respective responsibilities as well as a description of proposed village improvements and the probable expense thereof. He shall describe all unperformed contracts and shall prepare a statement listing the amount of all unused appropriations of the preceding year. He shall consult with each committee chairman and they shall jointly recommend to the village board of trustees the salaries to be paid each employee of the village, except the village administrator. 
(e)  With the approval of the village board of trustees, the village administrator may consolidate, combine or reorganize positions or units under his supervision. 
(f)  The village administrator shall purchase all materials, supplies and equipment subject to and pursuant to directives of the village board of trustees and within the bounds of the appropriations. These purchases shall be subject to and conform with the law as set forth in the statutes of the state, especially those laws pertaining to the creation of liabilities against the village and pertaining to the expenditure of moneys appropriated by the village. 
(g)  Each month, the village administrator shall be responsible for the preparation of a statement showing the exact financial condition of the village as of the end of the preceding month. A copy of this statement shall be delivered to each village trustee and to the village president. 
(h)  The village administrator shall provide such additional reports and information concerning fiscal matters of the village as directed by the village board of trustees. 
(i)  The village administrator shall be responsible to the village president and the village board of trustees for the supervision of all departments, with the exception that the technical supervision of the police department must be provided by the chief of police. In regard to the police department, the village administrator shall prepare the payroll and pay all bills legally contracted for by the police department and he shall assist the chief of police on all matters of administration except for technical police matters. 
(j)  The village administrator shall be responsible for the maintenance and operation of all properties of the village and shall supervise departments of the village as follows: 
(1)  The department of streets; 
(2)  The department of health, which includes the water department, and the department of sanitary sewers; 
(3)  The department of public works; 
(4)  The emergency services and disaster agency; and 
(5)  The general office of the village. 
If and when other departments are created, they normally will fall under the supervision of the village administrator, but only at the direction of the village board of trustees. 
(k)  The village administrator shall also coordinate the activities of the village building inspector and other administrative agencies and departments as directed by the village board of trustees. 
(l)  The village administrator shall administer all personnel requirements exactly as provided for in the New Lenox Personnel Policy and Procedure Manual. 
(m)  The village administrator shall recommend the removal or suspension of any officer or employee when such removal or suspension shall be consistent with the best interests of the village. 
(n)  The village administrator shall make all necessary purchases of supplies and equipment for all departments of the village, and for that purpose he is authorized to make expenditures of up to $5,000.00 without preliminary authorization of the village board of trustees. All expenditures must be subject to the confirmation or approval of the village board of trustees and must be limited to the budget or special appropriation. 
(o)  The village administrator shall conduct investigations into the affairs of the village when instructed to do so by the village board of trustees and shall investigate all complaints in relation to matters concerning village services and administration. After these investigations are made, a report shall be made to the involved standing committee chairman and to the village board of trustees. 
(p)  The village administrator shall attend all meetings of the village board of trustees unless excused by the board. He shall be given notice of all meetings except those regularly scheduled. He shall present the administrator's report and must be prepared to answer any questions regarding the administration of the village. 
(q)  The village administrator shall recommend to the village board of trustees the appointment or discharge of any part-time employee of the village. 
(r)  The village administrator shall perform such other duties as may be required of him by the corporate authorities consistent with village ordinances or the statutes of the state. 
(Code 1981, § 1-8-1.D) 
Sec. 2-155. - Relationship between administrator and standing committees. 
    It shall be the duty of the standing committees of the village board of trustees to watch the affairs of their respective departments and assume the responsibility of making recommendations to the administrator. Each committee chairman shall bring major items involving his respective department to the attention of the village board of trustees. However, the village administrator is charged with the general management and supervision of all departments, and he shall keep each committee chairman informed. 
(Code 1981, § 1-8-1.E) 
Secs. 2-156-2-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - ATTORNEY 

Sec. 2-171. - Appointment; compensation; term. 
    The village attorney shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the village board as provided by statute, shall receive such fee as fixed by ordinance, and shall hold office until his successor is appointed and qualified. 
(Code 1981, § 1-8-3.A) 
Sec. 2-172. - Duties. 
(a)  The village attorney shall prosecute and defend all suits at law or in equity when the village is a party or interested therein or against or by any official on behalf of the village whenever authorized to do so by the board; provided that, in all suits or proceedings before the circuit or county courts or commissions, he shall be paid a negotiated fee for such suits or proceedings commensurate with and as agreed with the village president and board of trustees for services performed. 
(b)  The village attorney shall be legal advisor to the board, and when requested shall render advice on all legal questions arising concerning the village or its officers or employees, and upon request shall reduce and submit such advice in writing. 
(c)  The village attorney shall attend all meetings of the village board, when required. 
(Code 1981, § 1-8-3.B) 
Secs. 2-173-2-190. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - CLERK[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Clerk, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-15-5. 

Sec. 2-191. - Appointment. 
    The village clerk shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the village board of trustees. 
(Code 1981, § 1-7-1; Ord. No. 1352, § 1, 8-22-2001) 
Sec. 2-192. - Duties. 
(a)  The village clerk shall attend all meetings of the board, and shall be the clerk thereof, and shall keep a full and complete record of its proceedings in the journal. 
(b)  The village clerk shall seal and attest all contracts and ordinances of the village and all licenses, permits and other documents requiring such formality. 
(c)  The village clerk shall keep accounts showing all moneys received, and the source and disposition of such moneys, and all other accounts and reports required by ordinance or statute. He shall forthwith turn over all money received for or on behalf of the village to the village treasurer with a statement of the source thereof. 
(d)  The village clerk shall keep a record of all ordinances and other documents which are required to be kept and preserved by statute, and shall also keep a register or record of all licenses or permits issued and payments thereof, a record of all officers and employees of the village, and all other such records as may be required by order of the board or by ordinance or by statute. 
(e)  The village clerk shall be custodian of the official village seal and shall also be custodian of all documents not otherwise assigned to another office. 
(f)  The village clerk shall properly index all documents and records in custody for easy access and use thereof and shall perform such other duties and services from time to time as may be required by statute, ordinance or order of the board. 
(Code 1981, § 1-7-2) 
Sec. 2-193. - Clerk to serve as village collector; duties, term and compensation of village collector. 
(a)  The village clerk shall hold the office of village collector. 
(b)  The duties of village collector shall be as provided by 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-120 et seq. The village board of trustees may provide for additional duties not in conflict with state law by resolution duly made. 
(c)  The term of the village collector shall be concurrent with the term of the village clerk. 
(d)  The person duly elected to the office of village clerk shall receive compensation for the office of village clerk and for the office of village collector. The compensation of the village collector shall be established by the annual appropriation ordinance. 
(Code 1981, § 1-7-3) 
Secs. 2-194-2-210. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - AUDITOR 

Sec. 2-211. - Appointment; duties. 
    The village auditor shall be appointed annually by the village president with the advice and consent of the village board, and shall perform the duties required by the Illinois Compiled Statutes. Upon completion of the annual audit of all village moneys, the auditor shall provide the village with sufficient copies of the audit and file certified copies with the appropriate state officials. 
(Code 1981, § 1-8-4.A) 
Sec. 2-212. - Compensation. 
    The rate of compensation of the village auditor shall be determined by the board prior to each annual audit. 
(Code 1981, § 1-8-4.B) 
Secs. 2-213-2-230. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - TREASURER 

Sec. 2-231. - Appointment; term. 
    The village treasurer shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the village board at the first meeting of the village board after its election and taking office, and he shall hold office until his successor is duly appointed and qualified. 
(Code 1981, § 1-8-2.A) 
Sec. 2-232. - Bond. 
    The village treasurer, before entering upon the discharge of the duties of his office, shall execute a bond in such sum as may be fixed by the board as provided by statute, to be secured by some corporate surety approved by the board, in such amount as may from time to time be fixed by the statutes of the state relative thereto, and the premium of the bond shall be paid by the village. 
(Code 1981, § 1-8-2.B) 
Sec. 2-233. - Compensation. 
    The compensation of the village treasurer shall be in such amount as may from time to time be fixed by the village board. 
(Code 1981, § 1-8-2.C) 
Sec. 2-234. - Duties. 
(a)  The village treasurer shall be custodian of all village funds and shall keep a true and correct account of all moneys belonging to the village. For all such moneys received by him, he shall execute receipts specifying the date of payment and on what account paid, with sufficient copies so that one copy thereof may be delivered to the person so depositing the funds and another copy shall be immediately delivered to the village clerk. 
(b)  The treasurer shall keep a full and complete account of all moneys received and disbursed by him and shall, as often as may be requested by the board, make a duly verified report to the board, showing all moneys received by him, paid out, and on hand, and shall, at the close of each fiscal year, make out and deliver to the village clerk a full and complete report of his acts and doings during the preceding year, and shall do and perform such other duties as may be required of him by the village board through ordinance or resolution. 
(Code 1981, § 1-8-2.D) 
Sec. 2-235. - Disbursements. 
    All disbursements drawn upon the village treasury shall be signed by a member of the finance committee and countersigned by the village treasurer. All disbursements, including payroll, general expenses and warrants, will be presented to the village board in the form of a disbursements register for approval at a regularly scheduled meeting of the village board. Such disbursement register shall state the particular funds and budgetary lines to which the disbursements are chargeable and the person to whom payable. Upon approval of the disbursements register, and the signing of such register by the village president and village clerk, checks will be prepared in the exact amount authorized by the village board and delivered to the respective payee. 
(Code 1981, § 1-8-2.E) 
Secs. 2-236-2-260. - Reserved.

DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Board of fire and police commissioners, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-281. - Established; composition. 
    There is hereby created a board of fire and police commissioners consisting of three members. They shall be officers of the village as provided by statute. 
(Code 1981, § 2-5-1) 
Sec. 2-282. - Appointment and term of members. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners shall be appointed by the president of the village, by and with the consent of the board of trustees. The terms of office of the members of the board of fire and police commissioners shall be three years and until their respective successors shall be appointed and qualified. No such appointments shall be made by any president within 30 days before the expiration of his term of office. The president shall appoint the first members of the board, one of whom is appointed to serve until the end of the current municipal year in which such appointment is made, another of whom shall serve until the end of the municipal year next ensuing, and the third of whom shall serve until the end of the municipal year second next ensuing; provided that each of the first members of the board shall serve until his successor is appointed and qualified. 
(Code 1981, § 2-5-2) 
Sec. 2-283. - Qualifications of members; removal of members. 
    The members of the board of fire and police commissioners shall have such qualifications as are now or may hereafter be required of them by law. The members of the board of fire and police commissioners shall be subject to removal from office in the same manner as other officers of the village. 
(Code 1981, § 2-5-3) 
Sec. 2-284. - Powers and duties. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners shall have such powers and duties as are now or as may hereafter be given to it by law. 
(Code 1981, § 2-5-4) 
Sec. 2-285. - Adoption of rules and regulations. 
    There is hereby adopted for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations to govern the board of fire and police commissioners, the rules and regulations of such board, including any and all amendments that may be enacted at a future date by the board of fire and police commissioners, the provisions thereof that shall be controlling in regard to the conduct of business of the board of fire and police commissioners of the village. 
(Code 1981, § 2-5-5) 
Sec. 2-286. - Compensation of members. 
    The members of the board of fire and police commissioners may serve with such compensation as the corporate authorities may determine and provide by ordinance. 
(Code 1981, § 2-5-6) 
Secs. 2-287-2-290. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PARKING AND TRAFFIC ADVISORY BOARD[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1498, adopted Sept. 10, 2003, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been included as div. 3, § 2-91, at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 2-291. - Parking and traffic advisory board. 
(a)  Created. There is hereby created a Parking and Traffic Advisory Board for the Village of New Lenox, Illinois. 
(b)  Membership. The parking and traffic advisory board shall consist of five members, three of whom shall be citizens of the Village of New Lenox, Will County, Illinois and appointed by the mayor, with consent of the Board of Trustees of the Village of New Lenox, Illinois, with terms expiring on June 1st. 
(c)  Term. All new appointments to the parking and traffic advisory board, except to fill unexpired terms, shall be for a three-year term. One member will be the village engineer, or his or her designee, who shall be a member of the parking and traffic advisory board. One member will be a police officer trained in traffic control who shall be assigned by the Chief of Police of the Village of New Lenox, Illinois, to offer technical assistance to the parking and traffic advisory board and a chairman shall be selected by the parking and traffic advisory board from its voting membership. 
(d)  Compensation. Voting members of the parking and traffic advisory board shall serve without compensation. 
(e)  Meetings. The parking and traffic advisory board shall meet at a time and place to be determined by the voting members and as often as deemed necessary by the voting members. 
(f)  Powers. The parking and traffic advisory board created hereunder shall have the power to: 
(1)  Submit recommendations in an advisory capacity to the board of trustees for official action that is aimed at improving parking and traffic conditions; 
(2)  Review and advise the board of trustees with respect to short-term and long-term traffic policies; and 
(3)  Review and make recommendations to the board of trustees on traffic studies prepared by consultants, hired by the Village of New Lenox. 
(g)  Appointment. The mayor is hereby authorized to appoint members to the parking and traffic advisory board with the consent of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 1498, 9-10-2003) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 90 et seq. 
Secs. 2-292-2-310. - Reserved.

Footnotes:

Cross reference- Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the village, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the village or any evidence of the village's indebtedness, contract or obligation assumed by the village saved from repeal, § 1-19(2); any appropriation or budget ordinance saved from repeal, § 1-19(4); any ordinance levying or imposing taxes or special assessments, or authorizing tax fund transfers not inconsistent with this Code saved from repeal, § 1-19(5); any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor saved from repeal, § 1-19(8); taxation, ch. 82. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-311-2-330. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PURCHASING PROCEDURES 

Sec. 2-331. - Appropriation prerequisite to purchase. 
    No purchase shall be made by the village unless an appropriation therefor has been made by the village board of trustees. The cost of the purchases by the village shall not exceed the budget ordinance made for that year. 
(Code 1981, § 1-13-1) 
Sec. 2-332. - Unauthorized purchases. 
(a)  Prohibited. No person is authorized to commit the village for any purchase without the prior approval of the village administrator. Purchases or agreements to purchase made without such approval from the village administrator will not be honored for payment by the village. 
(b)  Liability. Each officer or employee of the village who shall make a purchase on the credit of the village in any manner other than is authorized by ordinance shall be liable for the amount of such purchase, personally and on his bond. 
(Code 1981, § 1-13-2) 
Sec. 2-333. - Disposal of surplus property. 
(a)  The village administrator is hereby authorized to dispose of all personal property which cannot be used by any department of the village because of obsolescence, wear or unsuitability for public use when he has determined that such property has no other value than as scrap. 
(b)  When the village board has determined that any personal property with a remaining value is no longer necessary or useful to the village, the property shall be declared "surplus property" by resolution and may be disposed of in any of the following ways: 
(1)  Trade-in for a replacement item. 
(2)  Sale through competitive bidding at a public auction. 
(3)  Transfer to another governmental agency or not-for-profit organization. 
(4)  Contract sale through bidding procedure. 
(5)  Other manner as authorized by the village board. 
(Code 1981, § 1-13-3) 
Sec. 2-334. - Purchases under the bidding limit established by state statute. 
    The village administrator is hereby authorized to make purchases whose estimated cost does not exceed that threshold set for bidding purposes as may from time to time be set by state statute without approval of the village board. Bidding and written specifications will not be required of such purchases. The village administrator shall establish written procedures for purchases made pursuant to this section. 
(Code 1981, § 1-13-4; Ord. No. 1638, § 1, 4-26-2005) 
Sec. 2-335. - Purchases in excess of the bidding limit established by state statute. 
(a)  All purchases whose estimated cost exceeds that amount established from time to time by state statute to require competitive bidding shall be submitted to the village board for approval. Approval shall be by a majority of all members of the village board then holding office. 
(b)  All purchases whose estimated cost exceeds that amount established from time to time by state statute to require competitive bidding shall be based on written specifications and awarded in the following manner, unless the purchases are excepted pursuant to section 2-336: 
(1)  By written contract let to the lowest responsible bidder after advertising for bids; or 
(2)  In any other manner authorized by law. 
(Code 1981, § 1-13-5; Ord. No. 1638, § 2, 4-26-2005) 
Sec. 2-336. - Exemptions from written specifications and bidding requirements. 
    The following purchases whose estimated cost is in excess of that threshold established from time to time by state statute for bidding purposes may be awarded without written specifications or bidding: 
(1)  Purchases which may only be made from a single source. 
(2)  Purchases for additions to and repairs and maintenance of equipment owned by the village which may be more efficiently added to, repairs or maintained by a certain person. This must be clearly demonstrated to the village board prior to authorization of the expenditure. 
(3)  Purchases of equipment which, by reason of training of village personnel or an inventory of replacement parts maintained by the village, are compatible with the existing equipment owned by the village. 
(4)  Purchases which can be made at a public auction, close-out sale, bankruptcy sale or other similar sale at a cost below the market cost in the community. 
(5)  Purchases where an emergency immediately affects the public health, safety or welfare, if authorized by the village administrator or his designee. 
(6)  Purchases when authorized by a vote of two-thirds of all members of the village board then holding office. 
(Code 1981, § 1-13-6; Ord. No. 1638, § 3, 4-26-2005) 
Sec. 2-337. - Bid advertisements. 
(a)  Bid advertisements shall be published once, at least 15 days in advance of the date announced for the receipt of bids, in at least one official newspaper in circulation in the area. In computing the time for the notice so required, the first day shall be the date of publication of the notice, and the time shall run consecutively thereafter, including therein Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays. 
(b)  The newspaper notice required by this section shall include a general description of the articles to be purchased or sold or the work to be performed, the location where blank bid forms and specifications may be secured, the time by which bids must be submitted, the location where the bids must be submitted, and the time and place for opening bids. 
(Code 1981, § 1-13-7) 
Sec. 2-338. - Mayor and village board to be provided with copy of bid announcements. 
    A copy of the bid announcement shall be forwarded to the mayor and each member of the village board of trustees by the village administrator at the time that the first advertisement for bids is published. 
(Code 1981, § 1-13-8) 
Sec. 2-339. - Submission of bids; form of bids. 
    Bids shall be submitted in a sealed envelope to the village clerk. Each bid shall be addressed to the Village Clerk of the Village of New Lenox and shall bear on the face of the envelope the name of the bidder, a statement that it is a sealed bid to be opened on the day and hour mentioned in the advertisement for bids, and a statement of the contract for which the bid is made. Each bid shall be submitted on the printed form supplied by the village and shall be bound in the original binding. 
(Code 1981, § 1-13-9) 
Sec. 2-340. - Opening of bids. 
    Bids shall be opened by the village clerk (or his deputy) in public at the time and place specified in the public notice, in the presence of two of the following persons: 
(1)  The village administrator. 
(2)  The department head recommending the purchase. 
(3)  If none of the persons enumerated in subsection (1) or (2) of this section can be present, another village employee designated by the village administrator. 
(Code 1981, § 1-13-10) 
Sec. 2-341. - Inspection of bids. 
    Bids shall be made available for public inspection in the office of the village clerk. 
(Code 1981, § 1-13-11) 
Sec. 2-342. - Authority to waive technicalities and reject bids. 
    The village board shall have the authority to waive technicalities, and reject all bids, parts of bids, or all bids for any one or more supplies or contractual services when any bid fails to meet the requirements of this division or the bid documents, or when the public interest will be served thereby. 
(Code 1981, § 1-13-12) 
Sec. 2-343. - Award of contract to lowest responsible bidder; determination of lowest responsible bidder. 
(a)  Contracts which require bidding shall be awarded, after authorization from the village board, to the lowest responsible bidder. In determining the lowest responsible bidder, the village board shall consider the following: 
(1)  The ability, capacity and skill of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service required. 
(2)  The ability of the bidder to perform the contract, or provide the service promptly or within the time specified, without delay or interference. 
(3)  The character, judgment, experience and efficiency of the bidder. 
(4)  The quality of performance on previous contracts or service. 
(5)  The previous and existing compliance by the bidder with laws and ordinances relating to contracts, bidding or service. 
(6)  The sufficiency of the financial resources of the bidder to perform the contract to provide the service. 
(7)  The quality, availability and adaptability of the bidder's supplies, equipment or personnel to the particular use or service required. 
(8)  The ability of the bidder to provide future maintenance and service, if required. 
(9)  The number and scope of conditions attached to the bid. 
(10)  Any monies owed to the village by the bidder which have remained unpaid for a period of more than 45 days, whether for bills, taxes, licenses or otherwise. 
(11)  Whether the bidder is a local bidder as defined in paragraph (b) of this Section. 
(b)  Local bidder preference: 
(1)  "Local bidder" shall mean a contractor or vendor that: 
a.  Maintains a bona fide establishment for transacting businesses in the village corporate boundaries (hereinafter "village"); or 
b.  A contractor whose regular full-time workforce includes a majority of village residents. 
(2)  To be considered by the village as a "local bidder," the contractor or vendor must certify to the village that either:
