FOR SI: 1 POUND PER SQUARE FOOT=0.0479kPo, 1 SQUARE INCH=645 mm 3 , 1 POUND=4.45 N. 
    a. ELEVATED GARAGE FLOORS SHALL BE CAPABLE OF SUPPORTING A 2,000-POUND LOAD APPLIED OVER A 20-SQUARE-INCH AREA. 
    b. ATTICS WITHOUT STORAGE ARE THOSE WHERE THE MAXIMUM CLEAR HEIGHT BETWEEN JOISTS AND RAFTERS IS LESS THAN 42 INCHES, OR WHERE THERE ARE NOT TWO OR MORE ADJACENT TRUSSES WITH WEB CONFIGURATION CAPABLE OF ACCOMMODATING AN ASSUMED RECTANGLE 42 INCHES HIGH BY 24 INCHES IN WIDTH, OR GREATER, WITHIN THE PLANE OF THE TRUSSES. THIS LIVE LOAD NEED NOT BE ASSUMED TO CONCURRENTLY WITH ANY OTHER LIVE LOAD REQUIREMENTS. 
    c. INDIVIDUAL STAIR TREADS SHALL BE DESIGNED FOR THE UNIFORMLY DISTRIBUTED LIVE LOAD OR 300-POUND CONCENTRATED LOAD ACTING OVER AN AREA OF 4 IN 2 , WHICHEVER PRODUCES THE GREATER STRESSES. 
    d. A SINGLE CONCENTRATED LOAD APPLIED IN ANY DIRECTION AT ANY POINT ALONG THE TOP. 
    e. SEE SECTION R502.2 FOR DECKS ATTACHED TO EXTERIOR WALLS. 
    f. GUARD IN-FILL COMPONENTS [ALL THOSE EXCEPT THE HANDRAIL], BALUSTERS AND PANEL FILLERS SHALL BE DESIGNED TO WITHSTAND A HORIZONTALLY APPLIED NORMAL LOAD OF 50 POUNDS ON AN AREA EQUAL TO 1 FT 2 . THIS LOAD NEED NOT BE ASSUMED TO ACT CONCURRENTLY WITH ANY OTHER LIVE LOAD REQUIREMENT. 
    g. ATTICS WITH LIMITED STORAGE ARE THOSE WHERE THE MAXIMUM CLEAR HEIGHT BETWEEN JOISTS AND RAFTERS IS 42 INCHES OR GREATER, OR WHERE THERE ARE TWO OR MORE ADJACENT TRUSSES WITH WEB CONFIGURATIONS CAPABLE OF ACCOMMODATING AN ASSUMED RECTANGLE 42 INCHES IN HEIGHT BY 24 INCHES IN WIDTH OR GREATER, WITHIN THE PLANE OF TRUSSES. THE LIVE LOAD NEED ONLY BE APPLIED TO THOSE PORTIONS OF THE JOISTS OR TRUSS BOTTOM CHORD WHERE ALL OF THE FOLLOWING CONDITIONS ARE MET: 
    1. THE ATTIC AREA IS ACCESSIBLE FROM AN OPENING NOT LESS THAN 20 INCHES IN WIDTH BY 30 INCHES N LENGTH THAT IS LOCATED WHERE THE CLEAR HEIGHT IN THE ATTIC IS A MINIMUM OF 30 INCHES. 
    2. THE SLOPES OF THE JOISTS OR TRUSS BOTTOM CHORDS ARE NO GREATER THAN 2 INCHES VERTICAL TO 12 INCHES HORIZONTAL. 
    3. REQUIRED INSULATION DEPTH IS LESS THAN THE JOIST OR TRUSS BOTTOM CHORD MEMBER DEPTH. 
    THE REMAINING PORTIONS OF THE JOISTS OR TRUSS BOTTOM CHORDS SHALL BE DESIGNED FOR A UNIFORMLY DISTRIBUTED CONCURRENT LIVE LOAD OF NOT LESS THAN 10 LB/FT 2 . 
    h. GLAZING USED IN HANDRAIL ASSEMBLIES AND GUARDS SHALL BE DESIGNED WITH A SAFETY FACTOR OF 4. THE SAFETY FACTOR SHALL BE APPLIED TO EACH OF THE CONCENTRATED LOADS APPLIED TO THE TOP OF THE RAIL, AND TO THE LOAD ON THE IN-FILL COMPONENTS. THESE LOADS SHALL BE DETERMINED INDEPENDENT OF ONE ANOTHER, AND LOADS ARE ASSUMED NOT TO OCCUR WITH ANY OTHER LIVE LOAD. 
    COMBINED BUILDING SEWER shall be added to read as follows: 
R306.3.1 Combined building sewer. A combined building sewer is one which receives storm water and sewage. A combined sewer is prohibited within the Village of New Lenox. 
    AVOID POTENTIAL FREEZING shall be added to read as follows: 
R306.3.2 Avoid potential freezing. No plumbing traps shall be allowed in exterior walls, garage walls, garage ceilings or areas subject to potential freezing temperatures. 
Exception: Where PVC tub and/or shower traps are in a garage ceiling with at least three (3) inches of heat supply blowing on the trap. 
    SOLDERED JOINTS shall be added to read as follows: 
R306.3.3 Soldered joints. The surface to be soldered shall be cleaned bright. The joints shall be properly fluxed [lead free] and made with approved lead free solder conforming to ASTM Standard B32-1989. No part of a DWV (drain, waste and vent) system shall be joined or fitted with a solder or flux containing more than 0.2% lead. All excess solder and flux shall be wiped from copper tubing and copper sweat fittings. 
    GASOLINE, OIL AND FLAMMABLE LIQUIDS shall be added to read as follows: 
R306.3.4 Gasoline, oil and flammable liquids. Residential garages with a floor drain shall have a gas and oil interceptor. 
    DRAINAGE AND VENT PIPING BEDDING shall be added to read as follows: 
R306.3.5 Drainage and vent piping bedding. Where plastic materials are used underground for drainage and/or vent piping within a building, bedding of three (3) inch aggregate material will be required. 
    DUAL BRANCHES shall be added to read as follows: 
R306.3.6 Dual branches. Dual branches shall be prohibited within Village of New Lenox. 
    SANITARY BUILDING SEWER SERVICE LATERALS shall be added to read as follows: 
R306.3.7 Sanitary building sewer service laterals. All sanitary building sewer service laterals shall have a minimum of an eighteen (18) inch fall from the lowest point of gravity service in the building to the invert of the sanitary sewer main. In the event an eighteen (18) inch fall cannot be obtained, a pressure sewer system will be required. 
    SANITARY WASTES BELOW TOP OF FOUNDATION shall be added to read as follows: 
R306.3.8 Sanitary wastes below top of foundation. Wherever the point of influent disposal of sanitary waste such as, but not limited to floor drains, sink traps or commodes are located or proposed to be located below the top of foundation elevation, the waste disposal system shall include an ejection system and back-flow prevention. This system shall be approved by the Village of New Lenox Building Official, and no fixture connection will be allowed directly into the discharge pipe come from the ejector pump. This subsection shall apply to all new construction building permits. 
    FLOOR DRAINS shall be added to read as follows: 
R306.3.9 Floor drains. Floor drains shall be provided in all buildings. Such floor drains shall be utilized as to provide accessibility to fixtures with over spill, locating same in all utility/laundry type rooms and crawl spaces connected to the sanitary sewer. 
    STACK VENTS, VENT STACKS & MAIN VENTS shall be added to read as follows: 
R306.3.10 Stack vents, vent stacks & main vents. A stack vent, vent stack and/or main vent shall be installed with a soil or waste stack whenever back vents, relief vents or other branch vents are required. (SEE APPENDIX K: 890. ILLUSTRATION A.) All fixtures shall be individually vented except back-to-back fixtures. 
    BASEMENT WATER CLOSET VENTS shall be added to read as follows: 
R306.3.11 Basement water closet vent. Every dwelling or remodeling job involving additions to existing plumbing systems shall be provided with a vent to future water closet in basement, such vent to be dropped down to the basement ceiling and to enter the stack above the ceiling joists. Said vent shall be sealed in. 
    VENT TERMINALS shall be added to read as follows: 
R306.3.12 Vent terminals. The vent extension through and above the roof shall be not less than three (3) inches in diameter and shall have a diameter at least one (1) inch greater than that of the pipe of the roof. Vent terminals shall not be screened.

    OPENING PROTECTION shall be added to read as follows: 
R309.6 Opening protection. Openings from a private garage directly into a room used for sleeping purposes shall not be permitted. Other openings between the garage and residence shall have a one and one-half (11/2) hour door and wood frame with a door closure. 
    SEPARATION REQUIRED. Delete this section and replace with the following: 
R309.7 Separation required. The garage shall be separated from the residence and its attic with an assembly not less than a one (1) hour rating. Where the separation is a floor ceiling assembly, the structure supporting the separation shall also be protected by not less than a one (1) hour rating. Detached garages shall be located a minimum of ten (10) feet from any principal building plus 1 foot for each additional foot of the detached garage over 20 feet in length. 
    EMERGENCY ESCAPE AND RESCUE REQUIRED. Delete the Exception and it shall read as follows: 
R310.1 Emergency escape and rescue required. Basements and every sleeping room shall have at least one (1) operable emergency and rescue opening. Such opening shall open directly into a public street, public alley, yard or court. Where basements contain one or more sleeping rooms, emergency egress and rescue openings shall be required in each sleeping room, but shall not be required in adjoining areas of the basement. Where emergency escape and rescue openings are provided they shall have a sill height of not more than 44 inches (1,118 mm) above the floor. Where a door opening having a threshold below the adjacent ground elevation serves as an emergency escape and rescue opening and is provided with a bulkhead enclosure, the bulkhead enclosure shall comply with Section R310.3. The net clear opening dimensions required by this section shall be obtained by the normal operation of the emergency escape and rescue opening from the inside. Emergency escape and rescue openings with a finished sill height below the adjacent ground elevation shall be provided with a window well in accordance with Section R310.2. Emergency escape and rescue openings shall open directly into a public way, or to a yard or court that opens to a public way. 
    MINIMUM OPENING AREA. Delete the Exception and it shall read as follows: 
R310.1.1 Minimum opening area. All emergency escape and rescue openings shall have a minimum net clear opening of 5.7 square feet (0.530 m 2 ). 
    OPERATIONAL CONSTRAINTS shall read as follows: 
R310.1.4 Operational constraints. Emergency escape and rescue openings shall be operational from the inside of the room using normal operating procedures without the use of keys, tools or special knowledge. 
    LADDER AND STEPS shall read as follows: 
R310.2.1 Ladder and steps. Window wells with a vertical distance from the top of the window well to the bottom of the window of more than forty-four (44) inches shall be equipped with an approved permanently affixed ladder or steps usable with window in the fully open position. Ladders or steps required by this section shall not be required to comply with Sections R311.5 and R311.6. Ladders or rungs shall have an inside width of at least twelve (12) inches (305 mm), shall project at least 3 inches (76 mm) from the wall and shall be spaced not more than eighteen (18) inches (457 mm) on center vertically for the full height of the window well. 
    DRAINAGE delete the Exception and it shall read as follows: 
R310.2.2 Drainage. Window wells shall be designed for proper drainage by connecting to the building's foundation drainage system. 
    EMERGENCY ESCAPE WINDOWS UNDER DECKS AND PORCHES shall be deleted and replaced to read as follows:

    EGRESS DOOR shall be deleted and replaced to read as follows: 
R311.2 Egress door. At least one egress door shall be provided for each dwelling unit. The required egress door shall be a side-hinged door not less than three (3) feet in width and six feet eight inches (6'-8") in height. Egress doors shall be operational, from the inside of the dwelling, using normal operating procedures without the use of keys, tools, special knowledge or excessive effort. All doors to habitable spaces shall be side hinged, not less than two feet eight inches (2'-8") in width and not less than six feet eight inches (6'-8") in height. 
A basement door is required at either the top or bottom of the stairway. The door shall be side hinged, not less than two feet eight inches (2'-8") in width and not less then six feet eight inches (6'-8") in height. 
Exception: A complete finished basement.

Exterior landings, decks, balconies, stairs and similar facilities shall be positively anchored to the primary structure to resist both vertical and lateral forces or shall be designed to be self-supporting.     HEADROOM EXCEPTION shall be deleted and shall read as follows:

    HANDRAILS shall read as follows:

Required guards shall not be constructed with horizontal rails or other ornamental patterns that result in a ladder effect. 
Exception: The triangular openings formed by the riser, tread and bottom rail at the open side of the stairway shall not allow passage of a sphere of six (6) inches in diameter.

    LOCATION of smoke alarms shall read as follows: 
R314.3 Location. Smoke alarms shall be installed in the following locations: 
1.  In each sleeping room. 
2.  Outside of each separate sleeping area within ten feet of every bedroom. 
3.  On each additional story of the dwelling, including basements but not including crawl spaces. The alarm located in the basement shall be on the basement ceiling, within three (3) feet of all stairways. An alarm is not required in the uninhabitable attics. In dwellings or dwelling units with split levels and without an intervening door between the adjacent levels, a smoke alarm installed on the upper level shall suffice for the adjacent lower level provided that the lower level is less than one full story below the upper level. 
When more than one smoke alarm is required to be installed within an individual dwelling unit the alarm devices shall be interconnected in such a manner that the actuation of one alarm will activate all of the alarms in the individual units. 
    CARBON MONOXIDE ALARMS shall read as follows: 
R315.1 Carbon monoxide alarms. In new construction, the required carbon monoxide alarms shall receive their primary power from the building wiring when such wiring is served from a commercial source, and when primary power is interrupted, shall receive power from a battery. Wiring shall be permanent and without a disconnecting switch other than those required for overcurrent protection. Carbon monoxide detectors shall be permitted to be battery operated when installed in buildings without commercial power or in buildings that undergo alterations, repairs or additions without the opening of any walls or ceilings. 
    LOCATION of carbon monoxide alarms shall read as follows: 
R315.2 Location. Combination smoke alarms and carbon monoxide detectors are not permitted. Carbon monoxide detectors shall be placed within ten (10) feet of every bedroom. 
    Add Section R324.1 in its entirety. It shall read as follows: 
R324.1 Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this Chapter, shall have the meanings as ascribed in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
FIRST FLOOR. The area between the grade and the top of the ceiling joists or, where there is no ceiling, to the top of the roof rafters. All stories immediately resting upon the foundation of the structure shall be considered the first floor for the purpose of this Chapter. 
MASONRY. Masonry material means brick or stone with a minimum nominal thickness of 3", but does not include materials such as, but not limited to, painted or unpainted plain concrete blocks, mortarless brick, panel brick or stone, and any masonry product that is adhered directly to the exterior wall of the building. 
    Add Section R324.2 ENFORCEMENT and shall read as follows: 
R324.2 Enforcement. Issuance of building and occupancy permits. No building permit shall be issued for the construction of any building in the residential districts unless and until the provisions of this Chapter and all other relative ordinances are met.

R324.3 Applicability of this section. Any principle residence receiving a building permit on or after the effective date of this ordinance that is located in a subdivision which received final plat approval after May 1, 2002 shall comply with all terms and provisions of this Chapter. 
    Add Section R324.4 BUILDING MATERIAL REQUIREMENTS and shall read as follows: 
R324.4 Building material requirements. 
(a)  Single-family residences. All single-family residential structures constructed in any residential zoning district shall have one hundred percent (100%) of the first floor elevations, exclusive of doors, windows and trim, constructed of masonry veneer. 
(b)  Two-family and multi-family residential. All two-family and multi-family residential structures constructed in any residential zoning district shall have one hundred percent (100%) of the first floor elevations, exclusive of doors, windows and trim, constructed of masonry veneer.

R401.2 Requirements. Foundation construction shall be capable of accommodating all loads according to Section R301 and of transmitting the resulting loads to the supporting soil.     GENERAL - FOOTINGS shall delete the entire section and read as follows: 
R403.1 General. All exterior walls shall be supported on continuous solid concrete footings or other approved structural systems which shall be of sufficient design to accommodate all loads according to Section 301 and to transmit the resulting loads to the soil within the limitations as determined from the character of the soil. Footing shall be supported on undisturbed natural soils or engineered fill, except when erected upon solid rock or otherwise protected from frost, foundation wall piers and other permanent supports of all buildings and structures larger than six hundred (600 ft 2 ) square feet in area shall extend to the frost line of forty-two inches (42") and spread footings of adequate size shall be provided where necessary to distribute properly the load within the allowable bearing value of the soil. 
The placement of concrete in cold weather shall follow the requirements outlined below: 
Definitions and Requirements 
Cold Weather is defined as a period when one of the following conditions exist for more than three consecutive days: 
a.  Average air temperature is less than forty (40) degrees Fahrenheit; 
b.  Air temperature is less than forty (40) degrees Fahrenheit for more than one half of any 24-hour period. 
Average air temperature is the average of the highest and lowest temperature occurring during the period from midnight to midnight. After the first cold weather condition or after December 1st, whichever comes first, all concrete will be subject to the cold weather requirements until April 1st. 
Footings shall be poured only on frost free soil when the temperature is not less then twenty-five (25) degrees Fahrenheit and rising. Concrete must be protected in forms for not less than two (2) days, with insulation blankets only. 
Foundations shall be poured when the temperature is not less than twenty-five (25) degrees Fahrenheit and rising. Forms shall be kept in place for not less than three (3) days and completely covered by insulation blankets from the top of the wall to the base of the footings. Slab on grade foundations may be stripped after forty-eight (48) hours, provided that the foundation will be completely backfilled within six (6) hours of stripping forms. 
Flatwork: After the first frost, the Building and Zoning Administrator shall determine whether flatwork can continue. No flatwork is allowed on the outside of the buildings or garages from December 1st to April 1st without the approval of the Building and Zoning Administrator. Flatwork is allowed in the basement of a structure and in attached garage if the temperature is maintained at fifty (50) degrees Fahrenheit. U.L. Listed, vented type heaters to the exterior of the building. 
The use of salamanders (torpedo heaters) or other equipment that expel flue gases into the area above concrete floors are prohibited because of the carbonation to fresh concrete. 
Masonry: All masonry construction laid in temperatures of the outside air below forty (40) degrees Fahrenheit shall be enclosed and heated for not less than forty-eight (48) hours. Frozen materials shall not be used nor shall frozen masonry be built upon. 
    MINIMUM SIZE shall read as follows: 
R403.1.1 Minimum size. Minimum size for concrete footings shall be as set forth in Table R403.1 and Figure R403.1(1). The footing width, W, shall be based on the load-bearing value of the soil in accordance with Table R401.4.1. Spread footings shall be at least 16 inches thick. Footing projections, P, shall be at least 2 inches (51 mm) and shall not exceed the thickness of the footing. The size of the footings supporting piers and columns shall be based on the tributary load and allowable soil pressure in accordance with Table R401.4.1. In plain concrete footings, the edge thickness shall not be less than eight inches (8") for footings on soil. The minimum width shall not be less than sixteen inches (16"). 
    Figure 403.1(1) This figure applies to Sections R403.1.1, R404.1.2 and R506.1.

    FLOATING MAT shall be added to read as follows: 
R403.1.3.3 Floating mat. Detached accessory structure more than one hundred eighty square feet (180 ft 2 ) and less than six hundred square feet (600 ft 2 ) shall be permitted on a floating mat foundation with a minimum edge thickness of twelve inches by twelve inches (12" x 12") and a minimum slab thickness of five inches (5")with a 6 x 6 W.W.F. installed at the mid point of slab thickness. All concrete shall be a minimum of six (6) bag mixture with an air entrainment of four percent (4%) to seven percent (7%) and achieve a minimum compressive strength of three thousand five hundred (3,500 psi) pounds per square inch after twenty-eight (28) days. The six hundred square feet (600 ft 2 ) is measured using the dimensions of the slab on grade. Fibrous concrete reinforcement shall be permitted in lieu of welded wire fabric reinforcement when installed in accordance with manufacturer's specifications and field verification.

R403.1.9 Forming of concrete. All concrete footings shall be mechanically formed in accordance with ACI 318 and ACI 306. 
    R403.2 Footings for wood foundations. Delete in its entirety. 
    FROST PROTECTED SHALLOW FOUNDATIONS shall read as follows: 
R403.3 Frost protected shallow foundations. For buildings where the monthly mean temperature of the building is maintained at a minimum of 64°F (18°C), footings are not required to extend below the frost line when protected from frost by insulation in accordance with Figure R403.3(1) and Table R403.3. Foundations protected from frost in accordance with Figure R403.3(1) and Table R403.3 shall not be used for unheated spaces such as porches, utility rooms, garages and carports, and shall not be attached to basements or crawl spaces that are not maintained at a minimum monthly mean temperature of 64°F (18°C). Materials used below grade for the purpose of insulating footings against frost shall be labeled as complying with ASTM C 578. 
Exception: Additions to detached accessory structures may be permitted on a floating mat foundation provided the total combined area of the accessory structure does not exceed 900 square feet. The 900 square feet is measured using the dimensions of the slab on grade. The connections between the concrete slabs shall be reinforced with #5 rebar installed 24" on center with a minimum 12" horizontal penetration into each concrete slab.

    CONCRETE AND MASONRY FOUNDATION WALLS shall read as follows: 
R404.1 Concrete and masonry foundation walls. Concrete and masonry foundation walls shall be selected and constructed in accordance with the provisions of Section R404 or in accordance with ACI 318, ACI 332, NCMA TR 68-A or ACI 530/ASCE 5/TMS 402 or other approved structural standards. When ACI 318, ACI 332, or ACI 530/ASCE 5/TMS 402 or the provisions of Section R404 are used to design concrete or masonry foundation walls, project drawings, typical details and specifications are not required to bear the seal of the architect or engineer responsible for design, unless otherwise required by the state law of the jurisdiction having authority. 
Foundation walls that meet all of the following shall be considered laterally supported: 
1.  Full basement floor shall be 4 inches (101.6 mm) thick concrete slab poured tight against the bottom of the foundation wall. 
2.  Floor joists and blocking shall be connected to the sill plate at the top of wall by the prescriptive method called out in Table R404.1(1), or; shall be connected with an approved connector with listed capacity meeting Table R404.1(1). 
3.  Bolt spacing for the sill plate shall be no greater than per Table R404.1(2). 
4.  Floor shall be blocked perpendicular to the floor joists. Blocking shall be full depth within two joist spaces of the foundation wall, and be flat-blocked with minimum 2-inch by 4-inch (51 mm by 102 mm) blocking elsewhere. 
5.  Where foundation walls support unbalanced load on opposite sides of the building, such as a daylight basement, the building aspect ratio, L/W, shall not exceed the value specified in Table R404.1(3). For such foundation walls, the rim board shall be attached to the sill with a 20 gage metal angle clip at 24 inches (610 mm) on center, with five 8d nails per leg, or an approved connector supplying 230 pounds per linear foot (3.36 kN/m) capacity. 
The placement of concrete in cold weather shall follow the requirements outlined below: 
Definitions and Requirements 
Cold Weather is defined as a period when one of the following conditions exist for more than three consecutive days: 
a.  Average air temperature is less than forty (40) degrees Fahrenheit; 
b.  Air temperature is less than forty (40) degrees Fahrenheit for more than one half of any 24-hour period. 
Average air temperature is the average of the highest and lowest temperature occurring during the period from midnight to midnight. After the first cold weather condition or after December 1st, whichever comes first, all concrete will be subject to the cold weather requirements until April 1st. 
Footings shall be poured only on frost free soil when the temperature is not less then twenty-five (25) degrees Fahrenheit and rising. Concrete must be protected in forms for not less than two (2) days, with insulation blankets only. 
Foundations shall be poured when the temperature is not less than twenty-five (25) degrees Fahrenheit and rising. Forms shall be kept in place for not less than three (3) days and completely covered by insulation blankets from the top of the wall to the base of the footings. Slab on grade foundations may be stripped after forty-eight (48) hours, provided that the foundation will be completely backfilled within six (6) hours of stripping forms. 
Flatwork: After the first frost, the Building and Zoning Administrator shall determine whether flatwork can continue. No flatwork is allowed on the outside of the buildings or garages from December 1st to April 1st without the approval of the Building and Zoning Administrator. Flatwork is allowed in the basement of a structure and in attached garage if the temperature is maintained at fifty (50) degrees. Fahrenheit. U.L. Listed, vented type heaters to the exterior of the building. 
The use of salamanders (torpedo heaters) or other equipment that expel flue gases into the area above concrete floors are prohibited because of the carbonation to fresh concrete. 
Masonry: All masonry construction laid in temperatures of the outside air below forty (40) degrees Fahrenheit shall be enclosed and heated for not less than forty-eight (48) hours. Frozen materials shall not be used nor shall frozen masonry be built upon. 
    R404.1.1 Design of masonry foundation walls. Delete in its entirety. 
    R404.1.1.1 Masonry foundation walls. Delete in its entirety. 
    CONCRETE FOUNDATION WALLS shall read as follows: 
R404.1.2 Concrete foundation walls. Concrete foundation walls shall be constructed as set forth in Table 404.1.1(5) and shall also comply with the provisions of Section R404 and the applicable provisions of Section R402.2. In Seismic Design Categories D 0 , D 1 and D 2 , concrete foundation walls shall also comply with Section R404.1.4. The use of concrete blocks for footings and foundations is not allowed. All concrete footings and foundations shall be mechanically formed. 
    CONCRETE FOUNDATION WALL THICKNESS shall read as follows: 
R404.1.2.1 Concrete foundation wall thickness. The thickness of the concrete foundation walls shall not be less than the thickness of the wall supported except that concrete foundation walls shall not be less than eight inches (8") when supporting wood frame walls provided the requirements of Table 404.1.1a are met. A minimum ten-inch (10") foundation wall shall be required under brick veneered wood frame walls provided the requirements of Table 404.1.1a are met. All foundation walls shall be mechanically formed. 
    FOUNDATION WALL THICKNESS BASED ON WALLS SUPPORTED shall be deleted in its entirety and replaced to read as follows: 
R404.1.5 Foundation wall thickness based on walls supported. The thickness of concrete foundation walls shall not be less than required in Section R404.1.5.2. 
    R404.1.5.1 Masonry wall thickness. Delete in its entirety. 
R404.1.5.1 RESERVED

R404.1.6 Height above finished grade. Concrete foundation walls shall extend above the finished grade adjacent to the foundation at all points a minimum of four (4) inches where masonry veneer is used a minimum of six (6) inches elsewhere.

R404.5 Insulating concrete form foundation walls. Insulating concrete form (ICF) foundation walls shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the provisions of this section or in accordance with the provisions of ACI 318. When ACI 318 or the provisions of this section are used to design ICF foundation walls, project drawings, typical details and specifications are required to bear the seal of the architect or engineer responsible for design.

    FLAT INSULATION CONCRETE FORM WALL SYSTEMS shall read as follows: 
R404.5.1 Flat insulation concrete form wall systems. Flat ICF wall systems shall comply with Figure R611.3, shall have a minimum concrete thickness of 8 inches and shall have reinforcement in accordance with Table R404.4(1), R404.4(2) or R404.4(3). Alternatively, for 10-inch flat ICF wall systems, use of Table R404.1.1(5) shall be permitted, provided the vertical reinforcement is of the grade and located within the wall as required by that table. 
    R404.5.2 PRECAST CONCRETE FOUNDATION DESIGN DRAWINGS shall be deleted in its entirety and replaced with the following: 
    WAFFLE-GRID INSULATING CONCRETE FOR WALL SYSTEMS shall read as follows: 
R404.5.2 Waffle-grid insulating concrete for wall systems. Waffle-grid wall systems shall have a minimum nominal concrete thickness of 8 inches for the horizontal and vertical concrete members (cores) and shall be reinforced in accordance with Table R404.4(4). The minimum core dimension shall comply with Table R611.2 and Figure R611.4.

Screen-grid ICF wall systems shall have a minimum nominal concrete thickness of 8 inches for the horizontal and vertical concrete members (cores). The minimum core dimensions shall comply with Table R611.2 and Figure R611.5. Walls shall have reinforcement in accordance with Table R404.4(5). 
    HORIZONTAL REINFORCEMENT shall be added to read as follows: 
R404.5.4 Horizontal reinforcement. ICF foundation walls shall have horizontal reinforcement in accordance with this section. ICF foundation walls up to 8 feet (2438 mm) in height shall have a minimum of one continuous No. 4 horizontal reinforcing bar placed at 36 inches on center with one bar located within 12 inches (305 mm) of the top and bottom of the wall story. ICF foundation walls greater than 8 feet (3438 mm) in height shall have a minimum of one continuous No. 4 horizontal reinforcing bar placed at 24 inches on center with one bar located within 12 inches (305 mm) on the top and bottom of the wall story. The minimum lap splice shall be 24 inches. For walls with 50% or more of wall height exposed to wind, the wall shall be designed in accordance to the reinforcement requirements for above grade walls. 
    INSPECTION shall be added to read as follows: 
R404.5.5 Inspection. Inspection of the foundation shall be conducted after all required forms erected and all required reinforcing steel is in place and supported, prior to placing concrete. 
    CONCRETE OR MASONRY FOUNDATIONS AND EXCEPTION shall be deleted in its entirety and replaced to read as follows: 
R405.1 Concrete foundations. Drains shall be provided around all concrete foundations that retain earth and enclose habitable or usable spaces located below grade. Drain tiles, gravel or crushed stone drains and perforated pipe shall be installed at or below the area to be protected and shall discharge by gravity or mechanical means into an approved drainage system. Gravel or crushed stone drains shall extend at least one (1) foot beyond the outside edge of the footing and six (6) inches above the top of the footing and covered with an approved filter membrane material. The top of open joints of drain tiles shall be protected with strips of building paper. Perforated drains shall be surrounded with an approved filter membrane or the filter membrane shall cover the washed gravel or crushed rock covering the drain. Drainage tiles or perforated pipe shall be placed on a minimum of two (2) inches of washed gravel or crushed rock at least one sieve size larger than the tile joint opening or perforation and covered with not less than six (6) inches of the same material. 
    R405.1.1 Precast concrete foundation. This section shall be deleted in its entirety. 
    R405.2 Wood foundations. This section is deleted in its entirety.

    CONCRETE AND MASONRY FOUNDATION DAMPPROOFING & EXCEPTION shall be deleted in its entirety and replaced to read as follows: 
R406.1 Concrete foundation dampproofing. Except where required by Section R406.2 to be waterproofed, foundation walls that retain earth and enclose interior spaces and floors below grade shall be dampproofed from the top of the footing to the finished grade. The concrete walls will be dampproofed in accordance with one of the following: 
1.  Bituminous coating. 
2.  3 pounds per square yard of acrylic modified cement. 
3.  1/8 inch coat of surface-bonding cement complying with ASTM C 887. 
4.  Any material permitted fir waterproofing in Section R406.2. 
5.  Other methods or materials approved by the code official. 
Concrete walls shall be dampproofed by applying any one of the above listed dampproofing materials or any one of the waterproofing materials listed in Section R406.2 to the exterior wall. 
    CONCRETE AND MASONRY FOUNDATION WATERPROOFING shall be deleted in its entirety and replaced to read as follows: 
R406.2 Concrete foundation waterproofing. In areas where a high water table or other severe soil-water conditions are known to exist, exterior foundation walls that retain earth and enclose interior spaces and floors below grade shall be waterproofed in accordance with one of the following: 
1.  Two-ply hot-mopped felts. 
2.  55-pound roll roofing. 
3.  6-mil polyvinyl chloride. 
4.  6-mil polyethylene. 
5.  40-mil polymer-modified asphalt. 
6.  60-mil flexible polymer cement. 
7.  1/8 -inch cement-based, fiber-reinforced, waterproof coating. 
8.  60-mil solvent-free liquid-applied synthetic rubber. 
Exception: Organic-solvent-based products such as hydrocarbons, chlorinated hydrocarbons, ketones and esters shall not be used for ICF walls with expanded polystyrene form material. Use of plastic roofing cements, acrylic coatings, latex coatings, mortars and pargings to seal ICF walls is permitted. Cold-setting asphalt or hot asphalt shall conform to type C of ASTM D 449. Hot asphalt shall be applied at a temperature of less than 200°F. 
All joints in membrane waterproofing shall be lapped and sealed with an adhesive compatible with the membrane.

    MINIMUM HEIGHT DIMENSION shall read as follows: 
R408.8 Minimum height dimension. All above grade stories with habitable spaces for residential use shall be located over a basement or a useable crawl space with a minimum height dimension of thirty-four inches (34"). For the purpose of this section, all useable areas other than an attached garage shall be considered habitable space. 
    OTHER FLOOR JOISTS shall read as follows: 
R502.3.2 Other floor joists. Table R502.3.1(2) shall be used to determine the maximum allowable span of floor joists that support all other areas of the building, other than sleeping rooms and attics, provided that the design live load does not exceed 40 psf (1.92 kPa) and the design dead load does not exceed 20 psf (0.96 kPa). The maximum spacing for floor joists shall be sixteen inches (16") on center.

    ALLOWABLE SPANS shall read as follows: 
R503.2.2 Allowable spans. The maximum allowable span for wood structural panels used as subfloor or combination subfloor underlayment shall be as set forth in Table R503.2.1.1(1) or APA E30. The maximum span for sanded plywood combination subfloor underlayment shall be as set forth in the Table R503.2.1.1(2). The minimum sheathing thickness shall be 3/4 inch. 
    GENERAL CONCRETE FLOORS (ON GROUND) shall read as follows: 
R506.1 General. The thickness of concrete floor slabs in crawl spaces supported directly on the ground shall not be less than two (2") inches. The thickness of concrete floor slabs of basement floors shall not be less than four (4") inches. The minimum thickness of all concrete exposed to freezing and thawing conditions, including garage floors, shall be a minimum of five (5") inches with 6 x 6 W.W.F. installed at the mid-point of slab thickness. All exposed concrete shall be a minimum six (6) bag mixture with an air entrainment of four (4%) percent to seven (7%) percent and achieve a minimum compressive strength of three thousand five hundred (3,500) psi after twenty-eight (28) days. Fibrous concrete reinforcement shall be permitted in lieu of welded wire fabric reinforcement when installed in accordance with manufacturer's specifications and field verification. 
The placement of concrete in cold weather shall follow the requirements outlined below: 
DEFINITIONS AND REQUIREMENTS 
Cold Weather is defined as a period when one of the following conditions exist for more than three consecutive days: 
a.  Average air temperature is less than forty (40) degrees Fahrenheit; 
b.  Air temperature is less than forty (40) degrees Fahrenheit for more than one half of any 24-hour period. 
Average air temperature is the average of the highest and lowest temperature occurring during the period from midnight to midnight. After the first cold weather condition or after December 1 st , whichever comes first, all concrete will be subject to the cold weather requirements until April 1 st . 
Footings shall be poured only on frost free soil when the temperature is not less than twenty-five (25) degrees Fahrenheit and rising. Concrete must be protected in forms for not less than two (2) days, with insulation blankets only. 
Foundations shall be poured when the temperature is not less than twenty-five (25) degrees Fahrenheit and rising. Forms shall be kept in place for not less than three (3) days and completely covered by insulation blankets from the top of the wall to the base of the footings. Slab on grade foundations may be stripped after forty-eight (48) hours, provided that the foundation will be completely backfilled within six (6) hours of stripping forms. 
Flatwork: After the first frost, the Code Official having jurisdiction shall determine whether flatwork can continue. No flatwork is allowed on the outside of the buildings or garages from December 1 st to April 1 st without the approval of the Code Official having jurisdiction. Flatwork is allowed in the basement of a structure and in attached garage if the temperature is maintained at fifty (50) degrees Fahrenheit. U.L. Listed, vented type heaters to the exterior of the building. 
The use of salamanders (torpedo heaters) or other equipment that expel flue gases into the area above concrete floors are prohibited because of the carbonation to fresh concrete. 
Masonry: All masonry construction laid in temperatures of the outside air below forty (40) degrees Fahrenheit shall be enclosed and heated for not less than forty-eight (48) hours. Frozen materials shall not be used nor shall frozen masonry be built upon. 
    FILL CONCRETE FLOORS (ON GROUND) shall read as follows: 
R506.2.1 Fill. All excavated areas within attached or detached garages shall be filled with clean stone backfill. The backfill shall be a minimum three-quarter (3/4") inch, maximum of three (3") inches and placed on solid soil, free of vegetation. The use of washout or recycled material as backfill is prohibited. 
    ASPHALT DRIVES shal read as follows: 
R506.3 Asphalt Drives. Asphalt driveways shall be installed on a minimum 6" compacted CA 6 stone, free of vegetation and organic material. The asphalt surface material shall be a minimum 2" compacted hot mix asphalt Mix "D" N50. The minimum driveway width shall be 20'. The contractor shall provide the Village with load tickets verifying the mix design. 
    STUD SIZE, HEIGHT AND SPACING shall be deleted in its entirety and replaced to read as follows: 
R602.3.1 Stud size, height and spacing. The bearing wall studs and partitions shall be constructed of at least two-inch by four-inch (2"x4") material spaced a maximum of sixteen (16") inches on center with the wide dimension perpendicular to the load. This requirement supersedes the requirements provided in Table 602.3(5) SIZE, HEIGHT AND SPACING OF WOOD STUDS. 
Nonbearing wall studs and partitions shall be constructed of at least two-inch by four-inch (2" x 4") material spaced a maximum of sixteen (16") inches on center with the wide dimension perpendicular to the load. 
    BEARING STUDS shall be deleted in its entirety and replaced to read as follows: 
R602.3.3 Bearing studs. The bearing wall studs and partitions shall be constructed of at least two-inch by four-inch (2" x 4") material spaced a maximum of sixteen (16) inches on center with the wide dimension perpendicular to the load. This requirement supersedes the requirements provided in Table 602.3(5) SIZE, HEIGHT AND SPACING OF WOOD STUDS. 
    INTERIOR LOAD-BEARING WALLS shall be deleted in its entirety and replaced to read as follows: 
R602.4 Interior load-bearing walls. The bearing wall studs and partitions shall be constructed of at least two-inch by four-inch (2" x 4") material spaced a maximum of sixteen (16") inches on center with the wide dimension perpendicular to the load. This requirement supersedes the requirements provided in Table 602.3(5) SIZE, HEIGHT AND SPACING OF WOOD STUDS. 
    INTERIOR NONBEARING WALLS shall be deleted in its entirety and replaced to read as follows: 
R602.5 Interior nonbearing walls. The nonbearing wall studs and partitions shall be constructed of at least two-inch by four-inch (2" x 4") material spaced a maximum of sixteen (16") inches on center with the wide dimension perpendicular to the load. 
    R611.1.2 OTHER WALLS shall be deleted in its entirety and replaced as follows: 
R611.1.2 Other walls. Insulating concrete forms (ICF) walls shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the provisions of this section or in accordance with the provisions ACI 318. When ACI 318 or the provisions of this section are used to design ICF walls, project drawings, typical details and specifications are required to bear the seal of the architect or engineer responsible for the design. 
    R611.1.3 INSPECTION shall be added as follows: 
R611.1.3 Inspection. Inspection of the foundation shall be conducted after all required forms erected and all required reinforcing steel is in place and supported, prior to placing concrete. 
    R611.7.2.2.1 Horizontal reinforcement. Delete in its entirety and replaced as follows: 
R611.7.2.2.1 Horizontal reinforcement. Concrete walls with a minimum thickness of 6 inches shall have a minimum of one continuous No. 4 horizontal reinforcing bar placed at 32 inches (812 mm) on center with one bar within 12 inches (305 mm) of the top and bottom of the wall story. Concrete walls 8 inches thick or more shall have a minimum of one continuous No. 4 horizontal reinforcing bar placed at 48 inches (1219 mm) on center with one bar located within 12 inches (305 mm) of the top and bottom of the wall story. 
For townhouses in Seismic Design Category C, the minimum horizontal reinforcement shall be one No. 5 bar at 24 inches (610 mm) on center or one No. 4 at 16 inches (407 mm) on center. For all buildings in Seismic Design Categories Do, D1 and D2, the minimum horizontal reinforcement shall be one No. 5 bar at 18 inches (457mm) on center or one No. 4 at 12 inches (305 mm) on center. 
Horizontal reinforcement shall be continuous around building corners using corner bars or by bending the bars. In either case, the minimum lap splice shall be 24 inches (610 mm). For townhouses in Seismic Design Category C and for all buildings in Seismic Design Categories Do, D1 and D2 each end of all horizontal reinforcement shall terminate with a standard hook or lap splice. 
    TESTING AND LABELING shall be deleted in its entirety and replaced to read as follows: 
R612.3 Testing and labeling. Exterior windows and glass doors shall be tested by an approved independent laboratory and bear a label identifying manufacturer, performance characteristics and approved inspection agency to indicate compliance with ANSI/AAMA/WDMA/CSA 101/I.S.2/A440. All exterior windows and glass doors shall be designed to a minimum designed pressure (DP) of 30 lbs/ft 2 . 
Exception: Residential basement windows that are completely below grade, skylights, glass block windows and windows in accessory structures including but not limited to: screened porches, gazebos, sheds and detached garages. 
    R612.3.1 Comparative analysis. Delete in its entirety. 
    ALLOWABLE CEILING JOIST SPANS shall read as follows: 
R802.4 Allowable ceiling joist spans. Spans for ceiling joists shall be in accordance with Tables R802.4(1) and R802.4(2). For other grades and species and for other loading conditions, refer to the AF&PA Span Tables for Joists and Rafters. Tables R802.4(1) and R802.4(2) shall delete 19.2 inches and 24 inches for the ceiling joist spacing. The maximum spacing for ceiling joists shall be sixteen (16") inches on center. 
    ALLOWABLE RAFTER SPANS shall read as follows: 
R802.5 Allowable rafter spans. Spans for rafters shall be in accordance with Tables R802.5.1(1) through R802.5.1(8). For other grades and species and for other loading conditions, refer to the AF&PA Span Tables for Joists and Rafters. The span for each rafter shall be measured along the horizontal projection of the rafter. Tables R802.5.1(1) through R802.5.1(8) shall delete 19.2 inches and 24 inches for the rafter spacing. The maximum spacing for rafters shall be sixteen (16") inches on center. 
    ALLOWABLE SPANS FOR ROOF SHEATHING shall read as follows: 
R803.2.2 Allowable spans. The maximum allowable spans for wood structural panel roof sheathing shall not exceed the values set forth in Table R503.2.1.1(1) or APA E30. The minimum sheathing thickness shall be 7/16 inch. 
    SECONDARY (EMERGENCY OVERFLOW) DRAINS OR SCUPPERS shall read as follows: 
R903.4.1 Secondary (emergency overflow) drains or scuppers. Where roof drains are required, secondary emergency overflow roof drains or scuppers shall be provided where the roof perimeter construction extends above the roof in such a manner that water will be entrapped if the primary drains allow buildup for any reason. Overflow drains having the same size as the roof drains shall be installed with the inlet flow line located two (2") inches above the low point of the roof, or overflow scuppers having three times the size of the roof drains and having a minimum opening height of 4 inches shall be installed in the adjacent parapet walls with the inlet flow located 2 inches above the low point of the roof served. The installation and sizing of overflow drains, leaders and conductors shall comply with the Illinois Plumbing Code. 
Overall drains shall discharge to an approved location and shall not be connected to roof drain lines. 
International Residential Code &reg; for One- and Two-Family Dwellings/2012 Part VII - Plumbing Chapter 25 through Chapter 33 are deleted in its entirety and replaced with the State of Illinois Plumbing Code/2014. 
International Residential Code &reg; for One- and Two-Family Dwellings/2012 Part VIII - Electrical Chapter 34 through Chapter 42 are amended and replaced with the following: 
    MARKING shall read as follows: 
110.21 Marking. The manufacturer's name, trademark, or other descriptive marking by which the organization responsible for the product can be identified shall be placed on all electric equipment. Other markings that indicate voltage, current, wattage or other ratings shall be provided as specified elsewhere in this Code. The marking shall be of sufficient durability to withstand the environment involved. The circuit panel shall have a complete circuit chart showing the use and circuit number for all circuits and over-current protection. 
    WORKING SPACE shall read as follows: 
110.26(A) Working Space. Working space for equipment operating at 600 volts, nominal, or less to ground and likely to require examination, adjustment, servicing, or maintenance while energized shall comply with the dimensions of 110.26(A)(1), (A)(2), and (A)(3). In addition to the clearances shown in Table 11 0-26(A)(1), the work space shall not be less than thirty-six inches (36") measured from each edge of all electric equipment or as required or permitted elsewhere in this Code. 
There shall be no sump pits within the thirty-six inches (36") measured from both sides of the panel. 
    WIDTH OF WORKING SPACE shall read as follows: 
110.26(A2) Width of Working Space. The width of the working space in front of the electrical equipment shall be the width of the equipment or 36 inches, whichever is greater. In all cases, the work space shall permit at least a 90-degree opening of equipment doors or hinged panels. 
    CLEAR SPACES shall read as follows: 
110.26(B) Clear Spaces. Working space required by this section shall not be used for storage. There shall be no sump pits or other equipment in the required working space and clearance. When normally enclosed live parts are exposed for inspection or servicing, the working space, if in a passageway or general open space, shall be suitably guarded. 
    ELECTRICAL WIRING shall be added as follows: 
110-60 Electrical Wiring. All electrical wiring within residential, commercial, and industrial, and all accessory structures shall be enclosed in intermediate metal conduit (Article 342), rigid metal conduit (Article 344), liquidtight flexible metal conduit (Article 350), rigid nonmetallic conduit (Article 352) or electrical metal tubing (Article 358). 
Repairs and alterations: Where the cost of remodeling or repairs will not exceed fifty percent (50%) of the assessed valuation of the structure, non-metallic sheathed cable may be used in lieu of conduit, unless conduit is currently installed in the structure. 
    ISLAND COUNTER SPACES shall read as follows: 
210.52(C)(2) Island Counter Spaces. At least one receptacle shall be installed at each island counter space with a long dimension of 36 inches or greater and a short dimension of 12 inches or greater. Where a rangetop or sink is installed in an island counter and the width of the counter behind the rangetop or sink is less than 12 inches, the rangetop or sink is considered to divide the island into two separate countertop spaces as defined in 21 0.52(C)(4). 
    PENINSULAR COUNTER SPACES shall read as follows: 
210.52(C)(3) Peninsular Counter Spaces. At least one receptacle outlet shall be installed at each peninsular counter space with a long dimension of 36 inches or greater and a short dimension of 12 inches or greater. A peninsular countertop is measured from the connecting edge. 
    SERVICE SIZE shall be added as follows: 
230.62(C) Service Size. The minimum electrical service size for a single family residence shall be a 100 amp service for a single family home of up to and including 1500 square feet of habitable space. The minimum electrical service size for a single family residence over 1500 square feet of habitable space is a 200 amp service. 
    USES PERMITTED FOR RIGID POLYVINYL CHLORIDE CONDUIT shall read as follows: 
352.10 Uses Permitted. The use of Rigid Polyvinyl Chloride Conduit (PVC) shall be permitted in accordance with 352.10(A) through (I). 
FPN: Extreme cold may cause some nonmetallic conduits to become brittle and therefore more susceptible to damage from physical contact. 
(A)  RESERVED 
(B)  RESERVED 
(C)  RESERVED 
(D)  RESERVED 
(E)  RESERVED 
(F)  RESERVED 
(G)  Rigid Polyvinyl Chloride conduit (PVC) is permitted for interior concrete slab installations and exterior sub-grade locations only. The transition to metal conduit shall be below grade or within the concrete slab with a metallic fitting. 
(H)  RESERVED 
(I)  RESERVED 
Re: Existing installations and remodeling are permitted to use nonmetallic sheathed cable (NM) provided it is currently installed in the building. 
(a)  Any person who fails to comply with the provisions of the National Electric Code or amendments to the National Electric Code as set forth in this Article or who fails to carry out an order made pursuant to the National Electric Code or amendments to the National Electric Code as set forth in this Article or who fails to carry out an order made pursuant to the National Electric Code or amendments to the National Electric Code as set forth in this Article or violates any condition attached to a permit, approval or certificate shall be punished as prescribed by law and as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(b)  Abatement of violation. The imposition of penalties shall not prevent the building official from requesting the legal counsel of the village to institute the appropriate legal proceedings at law or in equity to restrain, correct or abate such violation. Administrative notices are attempts to secure voluntary compliance. and are not the start of prosecution for jurisdictional purposes. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014; Ord. No. 2478, § 2, 2-23-2015; Ord. No. 2496, § 2, 4-27-2015)

ARTICLE VIII. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE 

Sec. 18-151. - Adopted. 
    That certain documents three copies of which are on file in the office of the Village Clerk, being marked and designated as the Property Maintenance Code/2012 published by the International Code Council be and are hereby provided; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said codes, are hereby referred to as adopted and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this article, and each and all regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of such code are hereby referred to, adopted and made part of this article as if fully set out in this article, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 18-152. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-152. - Special provisions. 
    The following words, provisions, and paragraphs shall be added to the following designated sections of the code adopted in section 18-151. These provisions supersede the requirements of the indicated provisions of such code. 
101.1 Title. Village of New Lenox. 
102.3 Application of Other Codes. Repairs, additions or alterations to a structure, or changes of occupancy, shall be done in accordance with the procedures and provisions of the International Building Code, International Energy Conservation Code, International Fire Code, International Fuel Gas Code, International Mechanical Code, International Residential Code, Illinois State Plumbing Code & NFPA 70. Nothing in this code shall be construed to cancel, modify or set aside any provision of the New Lenox Municipal Code. 
103.5 Fees. See the Village of New Lenox Fee Schedule. 
    Delete sections 111.2-111.2.5 and replace with: 
111.2 Appeals Board: In order to protect existing structures in the jurisdiction by vigorous enforcement of this Code, there shall be and is hereby created a Property Maintenance Code Appeals Board, hereinafter referred to as the Board, consisting of the duly qualified and acting Mayor of the Village of New Lenox and the Village Board of Trustees of the Village of New Lenox. 
111.2.1 Membership: Said Board shall consist at all time of the then duly qualified and acting Mayor of the Village of New Lenox and the Village Board of Trustees of the Village of New Lenox who shall appoint a person as "Code Official" to perform the duties provided in this Code for the Code Official. 
201.3 Terms Defined in Other Codes where terms are not defined in this code and are defined in the International Building Code, International Fire Code, International Fuel Gas Code, International Mechanical Code, International Residential Code, Illinois State Plumbing Code, New Lenox Municipal Code or NFPA 70, such terms shall have meanings ascribed to them as stated in those codes. 
    Section 301.3.1 shall be added to read: 
301.3.1 It shall be unlawful for any person to dump or deposit or cause to be dumped or deposited, any grass, leaves, branches or parts of trees or any other things in any public right-of-way or public property within the village or on someone else's property other than as prescribed by this code or other applicable ordinances, rules and regulations of the village. 
    Section 301.3.2.A shall be added to read: 
301.3.2.A. It shall be unlawful for any person to dump, deposit or store material of any kind on any real property in the village except: 
1.  When dumping, depositing or storing is for a purpose which is customarily incidental to residential use; or, 
2.  When building materials are deposited on a site for which a building permit has been issued and the building materials are to be used for construction purposes thereon in conformance with the applicable codes of the village; or, 
3.  Where the building materials are deposited on a site used in accordance with the applicable codes of the village for the purposes of storing building materials. 
    Section 301.3.2.B shall be added to read: 
301.3.2.B. In the event that building materials are deposited on a site in the village, for which a building permit has been issued, and such building permit expires, the continued existence of building material on such site shall be prohibited. 
302.4 Weeds. Change ten inches (10") to eight inches (8"). 
303.2 Enclosures. Change 48" to 60". 
304.14 Insect Screens. Insert the dates May 1 to Oct 1. 
    Section 304.2 shall be added to read: 
304.2 Screening and Fencing. All screening and fencing materials shall be maintained in good repair, structurally sound and free from defect. Every owner of a multi-family, commercial or industrial building required to provide screening shall be responsible for maintenance of the required screening and fencing. 
305.3 Interior Surfaces. Interior surfaces and structural members shall be free of mold, and conditions that promote mold growth shall be corrected. 
505.2 Public Toilet Facilities. Change International Plumbing Code to Illinois Plumbing Code 
505.1 General. Change International Plumbing Code to Illinois State Plumbing Code. 
602.3 Heat supply. Every owner and operator of any building who rents, leases or lets one or more dwelling units or sleeping units on terms, either expressed or implied, to furnish heat to the occupants thereof shall supply heat during the period from October 1 to May 1 to maintain a temperature of not less than 68°F (20°C) in all habitable rooms, bathrooms, and toilet rooms. 
Exceptions: 
1.  When the outdoor temperature is below the winter outdoor design temperature for the locality, maintenance of the minimum room temperature shall not be required provided that the heating system is operating at its full design capacity. 
2.  In areas where the average monthly temperature is above 30°F (-1°C), a minimum temperature of 65°F (18°C) shall be maintained. 
602.4 Occupiable work spaces. Indoor occupiable work spaces shall be supplied with heating during the period from October 1 to May 1 to maintain a temperature of not less than 65°F (18°C) during the period the spaces are occupied. 
Exceptions. 
1.  Processing, storage and operation areas that require cooling or special temperature conditions. 
2.  Areas in which persons are primarily engaged in vigorous physical activities. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014)

ARTICLE IX. - FUEL GAS CODE 

Sec. 18-171. - Adopted. 
    That certain documents, three copies of which are on file in the office of the village clerk, being marked and designated as The International Fuel Gas Code&reg; 2012 published by the International Code Council be and are hereby provided; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said codes, are hereby referred to as adopted and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this article, and each and all regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of such code are hereby referred to, adopted and made part of this article as if fully set out in this article, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 18-172. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-172. - Special provisions. 
    The following words, provisions, and paragraphs shall be added to the following designated sections of the code adopted in section 18-171. These provisions supersede the requirements of the indicated provisions of such code. 
    TITLE shall read as follows: 
101.1 Title. These regulations shall be known as the Fuel Gas Code of the Village of New Lenox, hereinafter referred to as "This code." 
    FEE SCHEDULE shall read as follows: 
106.6.2 Fee schedule. The fees for work shall be indicted in the Village of New Lenox Fee Schedule. 
    FEE REFUNDS shall read as follows: 
106.6.3 Fee refunds. The code official shall authorize the refunding of fees as follows: 
1.  The full amount of any fee paid hereunder which was erroneously paid or collected. 
2.  When no work has been done under a permit issued in accordance with this code the Village of New Lenox Fee Schedule shall prevail regarding the return of the permit fee paid. 
The code official shall not authorize the refunding of any fee paid, except upon written application filed by the original permittee not later than 180 days after the date of the fee payment. 
    UNLAWFUL ACTS shall read as follows: 
108.1 Unlawful acts. It shall be unlawful for a person, firm or corporation to erect, construct, alter, repair, remove, demolish or utilize an installation, or cause same to be done, in conflict with or in violation of any of the provisions of the International Fuel Gas Code or amendments to the Fuel Gas Code as set forth in this Article. 
    NOTICE OF VIOLATION shall read as follows: 
108.2 Notice of violation. The building official shall serve a notice of violation or order to the person responsible for the erection, installation, alteration, extension, repair, removal or demolition of work in violation of the provisions of the International Fuel Gas Code or amendments to the International Fuel Gas Code as set forth in this Article, or in violation of a detail statement or the approved construction documents thereunder, or in violation of a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of the International Fuel Gas Code or amendments to the International Fuel Gas Code as set forth in this Article. Such order shall direct the discontinuance of the illegal action or condition and the abatement of the violation. Administrative notices are attempts to secure voluntary compliance and are not the start of prosecution for jurisdictional purposes. 
    PROSECUTION OF VIOLATION shall read as follows: 
108.3 Prosecution of violation. If the notice of violation is not complied with promptly, the building official is authorized to request the legal counsel of the Village of New Lenox to institute the appropriate legal proceedings at law or in equity to restrain, correct or abate such violation, or to require the removal or termination of the unlawful occupancy of the structure in violation of the provisions of the International Fuel Gas Code or amendments to the International Fuel Gas Code as set forth in this Article or of the order or direction made pursuant thereto. 
    VIOLATION PENALTIES shall read as follows: 
108.4 Violation penalties. Persons who shall violate a provision of the International Fuel Gas Code or amendments to the International Fuel Gas Code as set forth in this Chapter or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who shall erect, install, alter or repair mechanical work in violation of the approved construction documents or directive of the building official, or of a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of the International Fuel Gas Code or amendments to the International Fuel Gas Code as set forth in this Chapter, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as prescribed by law and as provided in Section 1-9 of this Code. Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offense. 
    STOP WORK ORDERS shall read as follows: 
108.5 Stop work orders. Upon notice from the building official that work is being done contrary to the provisions of the International Fuel Gas Code or amendments to the International Fuel Gas Code as set forth in this Article or in a dangerous or unsafe manner, such work shall immediately cease. Such notice shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property, or to the owner's agent, or to the person doing the work. The notice shall state the conditions under which work is authorized to resume. Where an emergency exists, the building official shall not be required to give a written notice prior to stopping the work. Any person who shall continue any work on the system after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be punished as prescribed by law and as provided in Section 1-9 of this Code. 
    ABATEMENT OF VIOLATION shall read as follows: 
108.6 Abatement of violation. The imposition of the penalties herein prescribed shall not prevent the building official from requesting the legal counsel of the Village of New Lenox to institute the appropriate legal proceedings at law or in equity to prevent unlawful construction, restrain, correct or abate a violation, prevent illegal occupancy of a building, structure or premises, or stop an illegal act, conduct business or utilization of the installations on or about any premises. 
    UNSAFE INSTALLATIONS shall read as follows: 
108.7 Unsafe installations. An installation that is unsafe, constitutes a fire or health hazard, or is otherwise dangerous to human life, as regulated by the International Fuel Gas Code or amendments to the International Fuel Gas Code as set forth in this Article, is hereby declared an unsafe installation. Use of an installation regulated by the International Fuel Gas Code or amendments to the International Fuel Gas Code as set forth in this Article constituting a hazard to health, safety or welfare by reason of inadequate maintenance, dilapidation, fire hazard, disaster, damage or abandonment is hereby declared an unsafe use. Such unsafe installations are hereby declared to be a public nuisance and shall be abated by repair, rehabilitation, demolition or removal. 
    AUTHORITY TO CONDEMN INSTALLATIONS shall read as follows: 
108.7.1 Authority to condemn installations. Whenever the building official determines that any installation or portion thereof, regulated by the International Fuel Gas Code or amendments to the International Fuel Gas Code as set forth in this Article has become hazardous to life, health or property, he or she shall order in writing that such installations either be removed or restored to a safe condition. A time limit for compliance with such order shall be specified in the written notice. A person shall not use or maintain a defective installation after receiving such notice. When such installation is to be disconnected, written notice as prescribed in Section 108.2 of the International Fuel Gas Code as amended shall be given. In cases of immediate danger to life or property, such disconnection shall be made immediately without such notice. 
    AUTHORITY TO DISCONNECT SERVICE UTILITIES shall read as follows: 
108.7.2 Authority to disconnect service utilities. The building official shall have the authority to require disconnection of utility service to the building, structure or system regulated by the technical codes in case of emergency where necessary to eliminate an immediate hazard to life or property. The building official shall notify the serving utility, and wherever possible, the owner and occupant of the building, structure or service system of the decision to disconnect prior to taking such action. If not notified prior to disconnection, the owner or occupant of the building, structure or service system shall be notified in writing, as soon as practicable thereafter. 
    CONNECTION AFTER ORDER TO DISCONNECT shall read as follows: 
108.7.3 Connection after order to disconnect. A person shall not make energy source connections to installations regulated by the International Fuel Gas Code or amendments to the International Fuel Gas Code as set forth in this Article which have been disconnected or ordered to be disconnected by the building official until the building official authorizes the reconnection and use of such installations. When an installation is maintained in violation of the International Fuel Gas Code or amendments to the International Fuel Gas Code as set forth in this Article, and in violation of a notice issued pursuant to the provisions of this section, the building official is authorized to request the legal counsel of the Village of New Lenox to institute the appropriate legal proceedings at law or in equity to prevent, restrain, correct or abate the violation. 
    MEANS OF APPEAL: MEMBERSHIP OF BOARD, QUALIFICATIONS, ALTERNATE MEMBERS, AND CHAIRMAN shall be deleted in its entirety and replaced with the following: 
109.2 Membership of the board. The Village of New Lenox Board shall serve as the Board of Appeals. 
    PLUMBING CONNECTIONS shall read as follows: 
301.6 Plumbing connections. Potable water supply and building drainage system connections to appliances regulated by this code shall be in accordance with the Illinois Plumbing Code/2014. 
    Appendices A, B, C & D are adopted. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Secs. 18-173-18-180. - Reserved.
