ARTICLE XI. - FIRE CODE 

Sec. 18-191. - Adopted. 
    That certain documents, three copies of which are on file in the office of the village clerk, being marked and designated as The International Fire Code/2012 published by the International Code Council be and are hereby provided; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said codes, are hereby referred to as adopted and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this article, and each and all regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of such code are hereby referred to, adopted and made part of this article as if fully set out in this article, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 18-192. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-192. - Special provisions. 
    The following words, provisions, and paragraphs shall be added to the following designated sections of the code adopted in section 18-191. These provisions supersede the requirements of the indicated provisions of such code. 
    Section 101.1 Title shall read as follows: 
101.1 Title. These regulations shall be known as the Fire Code of the Village of New Lenox, hereinafter referred to as "the code." 
108.1 Board of Appeals. In order to hear and decide appeals of orders, decisions or determinations made by the Building Official relative to the application and interpretation of this code, there shall be and is hereby created a board of appeals. The Building Official shall be an ex officio member of said board but shall have no vote on any matter before the board. The board of appeals shall consist of the Village Board for the Village of New Lenox. The Village Board shall adopt rules of procedure for conducting its business and shall render all decisions and findings in writing. 
    108.3 Qualifications. Delete and reserve number. 
109.3 See the Village of New Lenox fee schedule. 
109.4 Violation penalties. Any person who violates a provision of the International Fire Code or amendments to the International Fire Code as set forth in this article or fails to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who erects, constructs, alters or repairs a building or structure in violation of the approved construction documents or a directive of the Building Official or of a permit issued under the provisions of the International Fire Code or amendments to the International Fire Code as set forth in this article shall be subject to penalties as prescribed by law and as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. Each day a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
    Section 110.5 shall be added to read: 
110.5 Fire Watch. Where conditions exist that is deemed hazardous to life and property by the Fire Official, a fire watch shall be implemented. The Fire Official shall determine the number of personnel required and the duration necessary for the fire watch. A fee of $75 per hour for each New Lenox Fire Protection District personnel assigned to the fire watch shall be charged. Conditions that may require a fire watch shall include, but are not limited to the following: 
A.  Newly constructed building opened for occupancy prior to completion of the fire safety equipment and supervision. 
B.  Building in which the fire safety equipment and supervision is placed out-of-service and will not be restored within two (2) hours. 
C.  Building with an occupant load greater than the posted occupancy. 
D.  Special programs or events where there will be space for standing room over the seating area and the exits will handle both seated and standing occupants. 
E.  Situations where the fire load is greater than the normal day-to-day operation. 
111.4 See The Village of New Lenox fee schedule. 
General Definitions. 
The following shall be added to the definitions: 
Certificate of Use and Occupancy. The certificate issued by the Building Official which permits the use of a building or tenant space in accordance with the approved plans and specifications and which certifies compliance with the provisions of law for the use and occupancy of a building or tenant space in its several parts together with any special stipulations or conditions of the building permit. 
Change of Occupancy. The change in purpose for which a building or part thereof is used or intended to be used including a change in tenants or tenant space. 
Change of Use. An alteration by change of a use in a building or tenant space to a new use group which imposes other special provisions of law governing building construction, equipment or means of egress. 
Fire Watch. A temporary measure intended to ensure continuous and systematic surveillance of a building or portion thereof by one (1) or more qualified New Lenox Fire Protection District personnel, for the purpose of identifying and controlling fire hazards, detecting early signs of fire and raising an alarm of fire and notifying the fire department. 
    Section 506.2.1 shall be added to read: 
506.2.1 Type of Key Box. The type of key box approved for use by the New Lenox Fire Protection District is the Knox Box brand key vault rapid entry system. The New Lenox Fire Protection District shall be in complete control of key box and rapid entry system authorization and operation. The size of the required Knox Box will be based upon the number of keys to be secured in the box and will be at the discretion of the Fire Official. 
    Section 506.2.2 shall be added to read: 
506.2.2 Location and Number. The installation of the Knox Box shall be approved by the Fire Official. The Knox Box shall be mounted no higher than five (5) feet above the finished floor. All Knox Boxes shall be supervised in the trouble mode of the fire alarm system. The Fire Official shall determine the total number of Knox Boxes required. 
    Section 507.5.1 shall be deleted and replaced with: 
507.5.1 Where Required. Fire hydrants shall be located along a fire apparatus access road so that no portion of a building or facility will be more than three hundred (300) feet from any fire hydrant. At least two (2) fire hydrants shall be located within three hundred (300) feet of each building. Additional fire hydrants and mains shall be provided where required by the Fire Official. 
    Section 507.5.7 shall be added to read: 
507.5.7 Fire Hydrant Installation. Fire hydrants shall be installed in accordance with the following: 
A.  Access. Access to fire hydrants shall be by any approved roadway as specified by this code. 
B.  Distance to Roadways. Fire hydrants shall be located approximately 10-feet from all other roadways. 
C.  Pumper Outlet Location. Each fire hydrant shall have the pumper connection facing the primary roadway and shall be accessible so that a connection can be made between the hydrant and the apparatus located in the street within twenty (20) feet of the suction hose. 
D.  Hydrant Outlet Spacing. Fire hydrant outlets shall be a minimum of eighteen (18) inches and no more than thirty (30) inches above the finished grade. 
E.  Hydrant Type. Fire hydrants used in conjunction with water supplies shall be of a type acceptable to the Village of New Lenox Public Works Department. 
    Section 607.1.1 shall be added to read: 
607.1.1 Elevator Car to Accommodate Ambulance Stretcher. Where elevators are provided in buildings, at least one (1) elevator shall be provided for Fire Department emergency access to all floors. The elevator car shall be of such a size and arrangement to accommodate a twenty-four (24) inch by eighty-four (84) inch ambulance stretcher in the horizontal, open position and shall be identified by the international symbol for emergency medical services, (star of life). The symbol shall not be less than three (3) inches high and shall be placed inside on both sides of the hoistway door frame. 
Exception: In buildings where all levels including basements have direct access to grade. 
    Section 607.1.1.2 shall be added to read: 
607.1.1.2 Elevator Phone. All required emergency elevator phones shall directly dial the New Lenox Fire Protection District Communication Center via a phone number designated by the Fire Official. 
706.3.5 All attached single family structures and multi-family structures containing two or more dwelling units or one or more dwelling units in a structure containing any other use shall have 2-hour fire rated wall/floor/ceiling assemblies between uses. All fire-rated walls shall be constructed of masonry or gypsum when designed in accordance with U-336 of the U.L. fire resistance directory. All fire-rated floors, floor/ceiling assemblies shall be of pre-cast concrete or poured in place concrete. 
903.3.5 Water Supplies. Water supplies for automatic sprinkler systems comply with this section and the standards referenced in Section 903.3.1. Hydrant water flow data used for the design of any sprinkler system shall be less than 1 year old. The potable water supply shall be protected against backflow in accordance with the requirements of this section and the Illinois Plumbing Code. 
903.3.7 Fire Department Connections. The location of the fire department connection shall be approved by the fire prevention code official. The fire department connection shall consist of one five inch Storz coupling with a 30-degree elbow mounted between 18 inches and 42 inches above the finished floor. 
    Section 903.3.8 Safety Factor shall be added to read as follows: 
903.3.8 Safety Factor. Hydraulically calculated sprinkler systems shall maintain a minimum of 10% of five (5) pounds per square inch safety factor (whichever is greater) between the seasonal low water supply and the total sprinkler demand. The total sprinkler demand shall include the sprinkler demand and the hose stream demand. 
    Section 903.4.1 Monitoring shall be deleted and replaced to read follows: 
903.4.1. Monitoring. Alarm, Supervisory and Trouble signals shall be distinctly different and shall be automatically transmitted to Lincolnway Public Communication Center in a method approved by the code official or to an approved listed central station providing full central station service in accordance with NFPA 72. 
903.4.3 Floor Control Valves. Approved supervised indicating control valves shall be provided at the point of connection to the riser on each floor of a multi story building. 
    Section 903.7 Fire Pump Test Header shall be added to read as follows: 
903.7 Fire Pump Test Header. An OS & Y control valve is required on all fire pump test headers. All test headers shall be located outside of the building. 
    Section 903.8 Separation shall be added to read as follows: 
903.8 Separation. Provide a minimum 1 hour separation of the sprinkler valve room and/or the fire pump room. 
    Section 905.3.1.1 Building Area shall be added to read as follows: 
905.3.1.1 Building Area. Class 1 standpipe systems shall be installed in all building two stories or greater and/or where any portion of the building's interior area is more than 150 feet of travel, vertically and horizontally, from the main entrance of the building of the fire department vehicle access. 
    Section 906.3 Size and Distribution shall read as follows: 
906.3 Size and Distribution. The minimum size fire extinguisher for use in all occupancy groups shall be 4A60BC. 
    Section 906.3.1-906.3.4 should be deleted in its entirety. 
    Section 906.5 Conspicuous Location shall be deleted and replaced to read as follows: 
906.5 Conspicuous Location. Fire extinguishers shall be located within five (5) feet of each exit door. 
    Section 907.2 Where required - new building and structures shall be amended to read as follows: 
907.2 Where required - new building and structures. An approved manual, automatic or manual and automatic Addressable Fire Alarm System installed in accordance with the provisions of this code and NFPA 72 shall be provided in new buildings and structures in accordance with Section 907.2.1 through 907.2.23 and provide occupant notification in accordance with Section 907.5, unless other requirements are provided by another section of this code. Where automatic sprinkler protection, installed in accordance with Section 903.2 is provided and connected to the building fire alarm system, automatic heat detection required by this section shall not be required. Fire Alarm Panels shall have single button silence and reset functions. A remote full function annunciator panel shall be required by the Fire Prevention Code Official if the main fire alarm panel is not located by the front entrance of the occupancy/structure. 
    Section 907.2.1 Group A shall be amended to read as follows: 
907.2.1 Group A. A manual fire alarm system that activates the occupant notification system in accordance with Section 907.5 shall be installed in Group A occupancies where the occupant load due to the assembly occupancy is 300 or more. Group A occupancies not separated from one another in accordance with Section 707.3.10 of the International Building Code shall be considered as a single occupancy for the purposes of applying this section. Portions of Group E occupancies occupied for assembly purposes shall be provided with a fire alarm system as required for the Group E occupancy. 
    Section 907.2.2 Group B shall be amended to read as follows: 
907.2.2 Group B. A manual fire alarm system shall be installed in Group B occupancies where one of the following conditions exists: 
1.  The combined Group B occupant load of all floors is 500 or more. 
2.  Group B occupant load is more than 100 persons above or below the lowest level of exit discharge. 
3.  The fire area contains an ambulatory care facility. 
    Section 907.2.3 Group E shall be amended to read as follows: 
907.2.3 Group E. A manual fire alarm system that initiates the occupant notification signal utilizing an emergency voice/alarm communication system meeting the requirements of Section 907.5.2.2 and installed in accordance with Section 907.6 shall be installed in Group E occupancies. When automatic sprinkler systems or smoke detectors are installed, such systems or detectors shall be connected to the building fire alarm system. 
    Section 907.2.4 Group F shall be amended to read as follows: 
907.2.4 Group F. A manual fire alarm system that activates the occupant notification system in accordance with Section 907.5 shall be installed in Group F occupancies where both of the following conditions exist: 
1.  Group F occupancy is two or more stories in height; and 
2.  Group F occupancy has a combined occupant load of 500 or more above or below the lowest level of exit discharge. 
    Section 907.2.7 Group M shall be amended to read as follows: 
907.2.7 Group M. A manual fire alarm system that activates the occupant notification system in accordance with Section 907.5 shall be installed in Group M occupancies where one of the following conditions exists: 
1.  Combined Group M occupant load of all floors is 500 or more persons. 
2.  Group M occupant load is more than 100 persons above or below the lowest level of exit discharge. 
    Section 907.2.8.1 Manual fire alarm system shall be amended to read as follows: 
907.2.8.1 Manual Fire Alarm System. A manual fire alarm system that activates the occupant notification system in accordance with Section 907.5 shall be installed in Group R-1 occupancies. 
    Section 907.2.9.1 Manual fire alarm system shall be amended to read as follows: 
907.2.9.1 Manual fire alarm system. A manual fire alarm system that activates the occupant notification system in accordance with Section 907.5 shall be installed in Group R-2 occupancies where: 
1.  Any dwelling unit or sleeping unit is located three or more stories above the lowest level of exit discharge; 
2.  Any dwelling unit or sleeping unit is located more than one story below the highest level of exit discharge of exits serving the dwelling unit or sleeping unit; or 
3.  The building contains more than 16 dwelling units or sleeping units. 
    Section 907.2.10.1 Manual fire alarm system shall be amended to read as follows: 
907.2.10.1 Manual fire alarm system. A manual fire alarm system that activates the occupant notification system in accordance with Section 907.5 shall be installed in Group R-4 occupancies. 
    Section 907.3.1 Duct smoke detectors shall be deleted in its entirety and replaced to read as follows: 
907.3.1 Duct Smoke Detectors. Duct smoke detectors shall be connected to the building's fire alarm control panel when a fire alarm system is provided. Activation of a duct smoke detector shall initiate a visible and audible fire signal and shut down the individual units. Duct smoke detectors shall not be used as a substitute for required open area detection. Duct smoke detectors shall be required in all air handling units greater than 2000 CFM. 
All test switches shall be labeled and installed in a proximate area near the Fire Alarm panel or as determined by the Fire Prevention Code Official. All rooftop units will be visibly marked from the roof/scuttle access point. 
    Section 907.6.3 Zones shall be deleted and replaced to read as follows: 
907.6.3 Zones. Each floor shall be zoned separately and a zone shall not exceed 10,000 square feet. The length of any zone shall not exceed 200 feet in any direction; a zoning indicator panel and the associated controls shall be provided in an approved location. The visual zone indication shall lock in until the system is reset and shall not be cancelled by the operation of a public alarm-silencing switch. A separate zone by floor shall be provided for the following types of alarm initiating devices where provided: 
A.  Detection devices 
B.  Sprinkler water-flow alarms 
C.  Manual fire alarm boxes. 
D.  Each tenant space in multi-tenant occupancies, and 
E.  Other approved type of automatic fire detection or suppression systems. 
    Section 907.6.5 Monitoring shall be deleted in its entirety and replaced to read as follows: 
907.6.5 Monitoring. Fire alarm systems required by this chapter or by the International Building Code shall be monitored by the Lincolnway Public Communication Center in a method approved by the code official or by an approved listed central station providing full central station service in accordance with NFPA 72. 
    Section 912.1.1 Storz Connections is added to read as follows: 
912.1.1 Storz Connections. All fire department connections shall be a five (5) inch Storz connection with Knox locking cap and a 30-degree downturn. 
    Section 912.2 Location was deleted in its entirety and replaced to read as follows: 
912.2 Location. With respect to hydrants, driveways, buildings and landscaping, fire department connections shall be so located that fire apparatus and hose connected to supply the system will not obstruct access to the buildings for other fire apparatus. Fire department connections shall be located within 100 feet of a fire hydrant at a location approved by the code official. 
    Section 912.5 Backflow protection shall read as follows: 
912.5 Backflow Protection. The potable water supply to automatic sprinkler and standpipe systems shall be protected against backflow as required by the Illinois Plumbing Code. 
    Section 1011.1.1 Floor proximity exit signs is added to read as follows: 
1101.1.1 Floor Proximity Exit Signs. The installation of low-level exit signs to supplement regular exit signs shall be placed in all R-1 & R-2 occupancies. Such exit signs may be approved luminescent, photo luminescent, self-luminous, or self-illuminated types. They are not intended to replace standard exit signs but are designed as a supplementary aid for a building occupancy seeking egress in a smoke-filled environment at a location that is the last to become obscured. 
Such signs shall be located near the floor level in addition to those signs required for doors or corridors. The bottom of the sign shall be not less than six (6) inches, but not more than eighteen (18) inches above the floor. For exit doors, the sign shall be mounted on or adjacent to the door with the nearest edge of the sign within four (4) inches of the door frame. Photo luminescent signs may be used in place of externally illuminated signs. 
    Adopt D 
    Amend Section D102.1 
D102.1 Access and Loading. Facilities, buildings or portions of buildings hereafter constructed shall be accessible to fire department apparatus by way of an approved fire apparatus access road with an asphalt, concrete or other approved driving surface capable of supporting the imposed load of fire apparatus weighing at least 85,000 pounds. 


(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Secs. 18-193-18-200. - Reserved 
ARTICLE XII. - CONSTRUCTION REGULATIONS-COMMERCIAL OR INDUSTRIAL DISTRICTS 

Sec. 18-201. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases when used in this Article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
    Architectural pre-cast concrete panel: A concrete sheet comprised of a natural slate, or stone granules/powder, or calcium carbonate granules/powder, polyester resin, glass fibers pigments and fire retardant with color throughout the material. These panels shall meet the following minimum criteria: thickness of minimum of five inches: ASTM C150, Type I or III, Aggregate: ASTM C33 and ASTM C40, Pigments: ASTM C979, Air Entrainment: ASTM C260, Water-reducing: ASTM C494, Type A, Retarding: ASTM C494 Type B or Type D or Type G and tested per methods described in ACI-301. A minimum Design Compression Strength of 5000 psi at 28 days and increased as required to meet the design requirements. All products shall be a PCI MNL-117 and plant producing the products shall be a PCI Certified Plant with an A1 certification. 
    Exposed aggregate: Natural stone chips, embedded in an epoxy matrix which has been applied to poured concrete or to pre-cast concrete sections. 
    Front elevation: Includes those side portions of a structure, which face or are contiguous with a public street or streets, thoroughfare(s) or way(s). 
    Glass: A transparent, translucent or opaque glazing material. 
    Rear elevation: Includes that portion of a structure which faces away from all public streets and which is not visible to the traffic on any public way. 
    Side elevation: Includes that portion or portions of a structure that do not face or are not contiguous with a public street, thoroughfare or way. 
    Solid finish veneer: Brick or stone. This does not include materials such as, but not limited to painted or unpainted concrete or plain concrete blocks, plywood, wood veneers or imitation type materials of any nature. 
    Solid masonry: Brick, concrete block, stone or exposed aggregate, or combination of these materials. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-202. - Enforcement; penalty. 
(a)  Issuance of building permits and occupancy certificates. 
(1)  Commercial districts. No building permit shall be issued for the construction of any building in the commercial district unless and until the building and zoning administrator of the village is satisfied that the provisions of this article are to be complied with, and no occupancy certificate for any such building shall be issued unless and until the provisions of this article have been complied with and the building and zoning administrator is satisfied with compliance. 
(2)  Hospital districts. No building permit or occupancy certificate shall be issued for any building on property zoned hospital until the provisions of this article and all of the relative ordinances are met. 
(3)  Industrial districts. No building permit or occupancy certificate shall be issued for any building on property zoned industrial until the provisions of this article and all of the relative ordinances are met. 
(b)  Authority of the board to vary requirements. The village board of trustees may vary the terms of this article for industrial districts. 
(c)  Penalty. In addition to all other remedies, any person, who violates any provisions of this article, shall be fined not less than $25.00 and not more than as provided in section 1-9 of this Code for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-203. - Applicability of article. 
    Any building or improvements constructed on real property zoned and classified as a commercial district, hospital district or industrial district under the official zoning map of the village and its zoning regulations (chapter 106) shall comply with all terms and provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-204. - General construction requirements. 
(a)  Commercial district: All buildings or improvements designed or intended to be constructed in any commercial district must have: 
(1)  A poured concrete footing with minimum dimensions of ten inches deep and 24 inches wide, extending to a depth below the standard frost line of 42 inches; together with a poured foundation wall having a minimum thickness of ten inches. 
(2)  Except as provided in subsection (3) below, all buildings must be constructed of: 
a.  An architectural pre-cast concrete product that contributes to the structure's architectural expression with a surface finish of: exposed aggregate, acid etched, polished, honed, thin brick facing, stone veneer facing or similar finish as approved by the village board of trustees; or 
b.  Solid masonry construction, with face brick, stone or exposed aggregate on all front and side elevations. Rear elevations may be constructed of common brick. 
(3)  Any freestanding building built in a commercial district may be of frame construction with face brick or exposed aggregate, provided. 
a.  The exterior construction attains a two-hour fire rating. 
b.  When a residential use is incorporated in the structure, a two-hour fire rating must be obtained at all points between the residential and commercial use. 
c.  All side yard and rear yard requirements of the commercial zoning district that allow the side yard and rear yard requirements of less than ten feet shall be permitted to have frame construction as long as the side yard and the rear yard requirements are maintained at ten feet or more. 
(b)  Hospital district: All buildings or improvements designed or intended to be constructed on any hospital zoned property shall have: 
(1)  A poured concrete footing with minimum dimensions of ten inches deep and 24 inches wide, extending to a depth below the standard frost line of 42 inches, together with a poured foundation wall having a minimum thickness of ten inches. 
(2)  All buildings must be constructed of architectural wall panels, solid masonry construction, with face brick, stone or exposed aggregate on all front and side elevations. Rear elevations may be constructed of common brick. 
(c)  Industrial district: All buildings or improvements designed or intended to be constructed on any industrial zoned property shall have: 
(1)  Structures that meet or exceed all International Building Code (IBC &reg; ) design parameters. 
(2)  A continuous poured concrete footing extending to depth below the standard frost line of 42 inches, together with a continuous concrete foundation wall which shall support all structural members of the building. Precast exterior walls shall be permitted on a 24-inch wide concrete trench foundation: The trench foundation shall extend to a depth below the standard frost line of 42 inches. Such foundations and footings shall meet the IBC &reg; specifications. 
(3)  The total surface area of the front elevation shall be constructed of solid finish veneer, masonry or glass, with the exception of mansard roofs which shall be no lower than ten feet from the top of the foundation. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-205. - Accessory buildings. 
(a)  The terms and provisions of this article shall apply to "accessory building" as that term is defined in chapter 106, of the zoning ordinance. 
(b)  On industrial zoned property, an "accessory building," as that term is defined in chapter 106 of the zoning ordinance, which is set back a minimum of 200 feet from the front lot line with the total front yard landscaped with grass, trees bushes, shrubs and the like, may have the solid finished veneer and glass requirement reduced by action of the village board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-206. - Compliance with International Building Code ; review of plans; review and inspection fees. 
(a)  In addition hereto, all commercial, hospital or industrial buildings or structures shall comply with the IBC &reg; and the building and zoning administrator or the village board may require any plans to be submitted to a review agency as shall be approved by the village board of trustees for written approval at the expense of the party requesting a building permit. 
(b)  In addition, the party requesting the building permit shall submit a site plan to the village engineer for review and approval for conformance with applicable sections of this code. The cost of said review by the village engineer shall include periodic construction inspections and shall be paid by the party requesting the building permit prior to issuance of the building permit. The aforesaid fees shall be as follows: 
Size in Acres Cost in Dollars 0 to 3 acres $500.00 3+ to 8 acres 800.00 8+ to 12 acres 1,200.00 12+ to 20 acres 2,000.00 Over 20 acres To be determined by the village engineer  
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Secs. 18-207-18-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - SPOT SURVEY REQUIRED; CERTIFICATE OF OCCUPANCY 

Sec. 18-221. - Survey prerequisite to issuance of certificate. 
    All spot surveys required by section 18-222 of the Municipal Code shall be submitted to the building and zoning administrator for approval. All final grading surveys, as required by section 18-223 of the Municipal Code, shall be submitted to the village engineer, or the village administrator's designee, for approval. This approval will be a requirement for the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. Review of any such surveys will be treated in the same manner as a building inspection request, and will be subject to the timeframe as may be set forth from time to time by resolution of the village board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-222. - Spot survey. 
(a)  A spot survey will be required after the foundation is completed and only the first level of deck may be completed prior to approval of this survey. 
(b)  Said survey shall consist of a spot survey by a registered land surveyor of the State of Illinois depicting all lot lines, building lines, side yard lines and easements. The survey shall indicate all improvement on the lot and shall include top of foundation elevation as reference to U.S.G.S. datum. If this survey indicates an error in setback requirements for said parcel or top of foundation elevation, all work on the building shall be halted until such time as said error is corrected. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-223. - Final grading survey and installation of landscaping. 
(a)  A final grading survey shall be required after the lot has been final graded and topsoil is in place. This survey shall be a topographic survey by a registered land surveyor of the State of Illinois depicting final grade spot, elevations at all lot corners at 25-foot intervals along perimeter of the lot and at all locations of spot elevations shown on the approved grading plan. These elevations shall be referenced to U.S.G.S. datum. 
(b)  This survey shall be accompanied by a final grading survey certification completed by the surveyor certifying that the elevations were taken on topsoil, are true and accurate results of said survey, and conform to the approved grading plan. Forms for this certification are available from the building commissioner. 
(c)  The survey shall be accompanied by a property owner certification of final grading survey certifying that said owner has received a copy of the final grading survey and will maintain the elevations shown on the survey. The property owner shall further certify that erosion control measures will be provided and maintained, if necessary, until such time as final germination and/or landscaping is developed to stabilize the soil so that final grade elevations along the perimeter of the lot are not altered. Forms for this certification are available from the building commissioner. 
(d)  Property owners shall install landscaping consisting of seed or sod on the entire lot, including the adjacent parkway, not containing other final landscaping material no later than six months after the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. As a condition of certificate of occupancy, a property owner certification acknowledging the requirement to install seed or sod within the specified timeframe shall be submitted to the community development director or designee. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014; Ord. No. 2625, §§ 1, 2, 2-27-2017) 
Sec. 18-224. - Temporary certificate. 
    A temporary certificate of occupancy may be issued between October 1 of any year and April 30 of the next succeeding year to any applicant not able to meet the requirements of the final grading survey above, provided that a deposit of $2,500.00 be placed with the village and accompanied by a property owners certification of pending final grading requirements certifying that said requirements will be completed by August 1 following the date of the temporary certificate of occupancy. A non-refundable administration fee of $100.00 will be required to process the temporary certificate of occupancy. Failure to provide the final grading survey requirements above by the aforesaid August 1 deadline may result in forfeiture of said deposit. Forms for this certification are available from the building and zoning administrator. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Secs. 18-225-18-230. - Reserved 
ARTICLE XIV. - CONTRACTORS[2] 
Footnotes:
