DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 18-231-18-250. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REGISTRATION 

Sec. 18-251. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Contractor means any person engaged in the business of constructing, altering or repairing buildings or other structures or sidewalk or street pavements, including but not limited to general building contractors, cement or concrete contractors, masonry contractors, carpentry contractors, acoustical contractors, electrical contractors, dry wall contractors, excavating contractors, fencing contractors, flooring contractors, garage contractors, glazing contractors, heating, air conditioning and refrigeration contractors, painting contractors, plastering contractors, plumbing contractors, porch and deck contractors, roofing contractors, sewer and drain layers, sheetmetal contractors, tuckpointing and cleaning contractors, window contractors, wrecking contractors, blacktop sealer contractors, landscape contractors, swimming pool contractors, insulation contractors, waterproofing contractors, siding contractors, soffit and fascia contractors, gutter contractors, sign contractors, and all other contractors. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, firm, association, corporation, trust or other legal entity. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-252. - Penalty. 
    In addition to all other remedies to the village at law or equity, any contractor who violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this division shall be fined not less than $50.00 and not more than as provided in section 1-9 for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-253. - Registration required. 
(a)  No person shall be a contractor within the village without first having obtained a certificate of registration therefor as provided in this division. Any person who engages in the construction, repair or alteration of any building, structure or street or sidewalk pavement within the village, for which a building permit is required, is presumed to be a contractor and must be registered under this division unless such presumption is rebutted. 
(b)  A homeowner engaged in constructing, altering or repairing his personal residence or lot shall not be considered a contractor for purposes of this division, but must provide proof of homeowner's liability insurance prior to receiving a building permit. 
(c)  Any contractor seeking an exemption from registration where state law has preempted local authority shall produce appropriate documentation demonstrating compliance with state law, including but not limited to a state license, certificate of registration, certificate of insurance and/or current bond. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-254. - Application for certificate. 
    Application for a certificate of registration under this division shall be made, in writing; to the building department upon forms furnished thereby. Each application shall state the name of the applicant, the applicant's address, individual persons to be operating under such registration, type of contracting performed, and a statement that the applicant agrees to comply with this division and all other village ordinances relating to or regulating such activities. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-255. - Bond. 
    Before receiving a certificate of registration as provided in this division, each applicant shall deposit with the building department a bond with surety to be approved by the corporate authorities to indemnify, keep and save harmless the village against loss, cost, damage, judgment or liability of any kind whatsoever which the village may suffer or be put to, or which may accrue against, be charged to or be recovered from the village or any of its officials, by reason of any act or thing done or neglected to be done under or by virtue of the authority given in such registration, and further conditioned that the applicant shall well and faithfully observe all the provisions of this division and other ordinances and other regulations of the village relating to the activities engaged in under or by virtue of the authority given in such a registration. Such bond shall extend over the registration period and be in the penal sum of $10,000.00. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-256. - Liability insurance. 
(a)  No person shall act as a contractor or subcontractor within the village, nor shall be registered, unless the contractor or subcontractor deposits with the village building department a certificate of insurance issued to the contractor or subcontractor by a company approved and authorized to issue such insurance by the state, for the full period of the registration period, in the following amount: General liability, $500,000.00 single limit. 
(b)  The certificate of insurance shall provide that the insurance is not cancelable during the policy period without 90 days' prior written notice to the village. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-257. - Workers compensation insurance. 
    No person shall act as a contractor or subcontractor within the village, nor shall be registered, unless the contractor or subcontractor shall show proof to the village building department of workers compensation insurance issued to the contractor or subcontractor by a company approved and authorized to issue such insurance by the state, for the full period of the registration period, in the following amounts: 
(1)  Each accident: $500,000.00. 
(2)  Disease, policy limit: $500,000.00. 
(3)  Disease, each employee: $500,000.00. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-258. - Issuance of certificate; term. 
    The building department shall issue a certificate of registration under this division upon proper application and compliance with this division. All certificates of registration shall expire annually on the anniversary date of issuance. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-259. - Fee. 
    The annual registration fee under this division shall be $150.00. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-260. - Duties of contractors. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of all contractors registered under this division to comply with all ordinances relating to or regulating the activities engaged in, and, in addition thereto, to at least once each week remove or cause to be removed from the site of the contractor's activities all trash, refuse and waste materials. 
(b)  Contractors shall at all times keep the site of activities in an orderly condition, free from standing water, unguarded dangerous implements and health and safety hazards, and contractors shall not obstruct traffic on streets or sidewalks or permit dirt or waste materials to fall or be carried onto such public ways. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-261. - Inspections and enforcement. 
    The provisions of this division are declared to be of a regulatory nature, and it shall at all times be the duty of the police department and the building department to regularly inspect the site of contractors' activities to see that such activities are being conducted and operated in accordance with the requirements of all laws and ordinances applicable thereto. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Secs. 18-262-18-280. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PUBLIC WORKS PROJECTS CONTRACTORS 

Sec. 18-281. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Person includes the singular and the plural, and shall mean and include any person, firm, corporation, association, club or copartnership, or any other organization. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-282. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this division shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not less than $10.00 and not more than as provided in section 1-9. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-283. - Permit required for work on public property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to perform work of any kind in, on or which involves public property in the village, including but not limited to any type of construction work in, on or involving the digging, installing and repairing of water mains, storm sewers or sanitary sewers, the construction, repair or maintenance of public streets, alleys, sidewalks, curbs and/or gutters, or the construction or repair of connections to any municipally owned utility, together with any other type or any kind of construction, repair or maintenance of any public property within the village, without first obtaining a permit therefor as provided in this division. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-284. - Application for permit. 
    Applicants for a permit under this division must file with the public works superintendent in the case of all existing improvements, and the building commissioner in the case of all new construction, a sworn application in writing (in duplicate) on forms to be furnished by the building commissioner, which shall give the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the applicant. 
(2)  A brief description of the nature of his business, if any. 
(3)  A brief description of his experience and the length of time engaged in business. 
(4)  A brief description of equipment owned by the applicant. 
(5)  A brief description of the work to be performed, the location of the work and the proposed date of commencement of construction and the date of proposed completion of construction. 
(6)  A sketch of the location showing lot lines and utility lines such as sewer, water, power, gas, electricity and the like. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-285. - Permit fee; time limit for commencing work. 
    A fee of $25.00 for each permit shall be paid at the time the application is filed with the public works superintendent or building commissioner under this division. Work for which a permit is issued shall commence within 30 days of issuance of the permit; otherwise, such permit shall be void unless delay is due to cause beyond control of the person to whom it is issued. Fees shall be paid to the village collector. The permit fee may be waived by the public works superintendent if work to be performed is covered under a letter of credit for a subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-286. - Evidence of financial responsibility. 
    At the time of filing an application for a permit under this division, each applicant shall also file with the public works superintendent in the case of existing improvements, or the building commissioner in the case of all new construction, the following documents evidencing his financial responsibility: 
(1)  Bond requirements. A $10,000.00 bond, either cash or surety bond, for the purpose of protecting the property rights of the village, or other cash or surety bond amount as determined by the public works superintendent. The bond may be waived by the public works superintendent if work to be performed is covered under a letter of credit for a subdivision. 
(2)  Insurance requirements. A certificate of insurance showing that the applicant has and, during the performance of the work for which a permit is sought, will continue to have in full force and effect with a reputable insurance company an insurance policy for $500,000.00 single limit, covering the applicant's liability for personal and bodily injury to or death of any and all persons, and for damage to any and all property owned by any person, when such injury or death or damage to property arises out of or in connection with or incidental to the work involving any public property within the village, and the necessary workers compensation insurance required by the laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-287. - Issuance of permit; record of permits. 
    Upon receipt of the application and permit fee as set forth in this division, and upon filing with the public works superintendent or building commissioner the documents of financial responsibility set forth in this division, a permit shall be issued to such applicant. The public works superintendent and the building commissioner shall keep a permanent record of all permits issued. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-288. - Exceptions. 
    No person who is a resident of the village and the record fee title owner of the property for which a permit is applied for to construct a sidewalk adjacent to the property shall be required to evidence the required financial documents set forth in section 18-286 or pay the permit fee required by section 18-285. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-289. - Transfer of permit; posting of permit. 
    No permit issued under the provisions of this division shall be transferred to any other person. The permit shall at all times be visibly posted at the site of the work performed thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-290. - Enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of the public works superintendent and the building commissioner of the village to enforce the provisions of this division against any person found to be violating such provisions. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-291. - Revocation of permit. 
(a)  Grounds. Permits issued under the provisions of this division may be revoked by the president and board of trustees of the village after notice and hearing for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statements contained in the application for the permit. 
(2)  Failure to keep an insurance policy in effect as provided in this division. 
(3)  Failure to perform any contract in a good and workmanlike manner. 
(4)  Any negligent, wilful or malicious act resulting in serious damage to public property. 
(5)  Any violation of this division or any other ordinances of the village or laws of the state. 
(b)  Procedure. Notice of the hearing for revocation of a permit shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the person to whom the permit was issued at the address set forth on the application therefor, at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing. The decision and order of the president and board of trustees shall be final and conclusive. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Secs. 18-292-18-320. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XV. - ANTI-MONOTONY CODE 

Sec. 18-321. - Purpose of article. 
    The purpose of this article is to preserve the aesthetically pleasing character of the village's residential districts by promoting such character, protect and enhance property values, and promote the easy identification of houses, by encouraging new dwelling unit construction of distinctive design and discouraging excessive similarity among adjacent dwellings. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-322. - Excessive similarity prohibited in residential construction. 
(a)  No building permit shall be issued for any new single-family detached dwelling unit which is similar in appearance to any dwelling on the same street which is within two lots distance of it. However, those single-family dwellings with a signed sales contract or application for building permit bearing a date prior to December 1, 1993, shall be exempt from the provisions of this article. 
(b)  A dwelling on a corner lot may be considered dissimilar to another if the two dwellings face different streets. On cul-de-sac turnarounds, no dwelling shall be similar in appearance to another dwelling on the turnaround. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-323. - Standards for determining excessive similarity. 
(a)  Distinguishing characteristics. For the purpose of this article, the term "similar in appearance" shall mean a dwelling which is identical, or nearly identical, to another in any three of the following characteristics: 
(1)  Roof type (gable, hip, mansard, gambrel, flat, or combination). 
(2)  Roof height. 
(3)  Approximate dimensions (height and length) of the front wall closest to the front lot line. 
(4)  Shape of the front elevation silhouette. 
(5)  Relative locations and sizes of windows in the front elevation. 
(6)  Relative location and dimensions of garage door, if included on the front elevation. 
(7)  Type of siding (e.g., brick veneer, lapped horizontal siding, half-timber, board and batten, shakes, etc.) on the front elevation. 
(b)  Housing styles. If adjacent lots as defined in this article contain different housing styles as described in this subsection, the similarity standards delineated in subsection (a) of this section do not apply. Housing style is in and of itself a significant enough characteristic to constitute dissimilarity. Housing styles shall consist of the following: ranch, bi-level, tri-level, 11/2-story, two-story and three-story. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-324. - Administration and enforcement; appeals. 
(a)  If the building and zoning administrator, or person acting in that capacity, finds that the dwelling for which a building permit is requested is similar in appearance to a dwelling for which a building permit has been issued within two lots distance and facing the same street, the building and zoning administrator shall deny the permit request for noncompliance with this article. 
(b)  An applicant for a building permit that has been denied based on the provisions of this article may: 
(1)  Alter the dwelling plans so that the proposed dwelling is no longer similar to another adjacent dwelling, according to the criteria specified in this article. 
(2)  Appeal the decision of the building and zoning administrator to the village board of trustees. 
(c)  In appealing the interpretation of this article to the village board of trustees, an applicant for a building permit shall present evidence sufficient to demonstrate conformity with this article, such as architectural drawings. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-325. - Exceptions. 
(a)  This division shall not apply to dwellings for which building permits have been approved before the effective date of Ordinance No. 939, from which this division is derived, including dwellings that are being remodeled, reconstructed or replaced after fire, windstorm or other catastrophe. 
(b)  These regulations may be waived in cases where the applicant for a building permit could not be expected to anticipate the design of a neighboring dwelling for which a building permit has already been issued but is not yet built. In such instances, the builder shall request, and the village board of trustees may grant, an exception from this article. 
(c)  These regulations may be waived for residential planned unit developments in which similarity of architectural form and style among dwellings is integral to the success of a unified plan, in which the high quality of building materials, building plans and site plan details overcome the presumed deficiencies of similarity. In such cases, the developer shall request, and the village board of trustees may grant, an exception from this article as a condition of a planned unit development 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
ARTICLE XVI. - SITE PLAN REVIEW 

Sec. 18-326. - Authority. 
    The village board has the authority to approve or disapprove site plans required to be submitted for approval under this section in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-327. - Purpose. 
    Plan review and approval is required to ensure that the use and development of land is undertaken in a manner that furthers the public health, safety, and welfare of the village, and makes adequate provisions for public and private services and amenities that minimize the adverse effects of such development. The design, orientation, and location of buildings, parking areas, signs, and landscaping visible to the public realm has a material and substantial relationship to property values and the taxable values of property in the village, and the cost of the municipal services provided thereto. Many neighborhoods in other communities have deteriorated due to the lack of planning, neglect of proper maintenance standards, and the erection of buildings and structures that are incompatible with the character of the area, resulting in a reduction in property values. 
    Therefore, it is the policy of the village that these regulations be adopted to avoid and prevent deterioration of the function, character, and appearance of the village, and provide a favorable environment for residents and businesses, and to preserve and enhance the property values and the general public welfare. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-328. - Approved plan; when required. 
    Site plan approval shall be required for multiple-family and non-residential development in the following situations: 
(1)  Application to construct a new principal structure intended and designed for non-residential or multiple-family occupancy; 
(2)  Application to completely redevelop any site for non-residential or multiple-family uses; 
(3)  Application to expand an existing principal structure, erected prior to the date of the adoption of this ordinance, for which the sum total of the gross floor area of the proposed expansion(s) is (are) equal to or greater than 25 percent of the existing gross floor area of said structure; 
(4)  Application to modify any new or existing building(s) and/or site improvement(s) that have previously received site plan approval under this article. Reapproval is required for components of the plan which depart from the approved site plan. The extent of changes to be incorporated in the submittal for reapproval shall be determined by the building and zoning administrator; 
(5)  A site plan shall be required along with any application for a special use permit or a special use permit amendment for any non-residential or multiple-family development; 
(6)  A site plan shall not be required exclusively for a change of use unless such change of use results in increased off-street parking requirements equal to or greater than 25 percent of the existing off-street parking; 
(7)  The requirement for site plan review excludes the reconstruction of legally nonconforming buildings, when such buildings and related improvements are substantially restored to their prior condition; 
(8)  Site plan review is not required as part of planned unit development approval, but may apply to development of individual sites following approval of a planned unit development, as controlled by the ordinance granting approval of the planned unit development. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-329. - Initiation. 
    Site plan approval shall be initiated by the owner of the property, or owner's agent, for which plan approval is sought. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-330. - Procedure for initiation. 
(a)  The owner of the property for which a zoning map amendment or a special use permit is sought (and requiring site plan approval under section 18-328, above) shall file an application for site plan approval along with such application for an amendment or special use permit. 
(b)  The owner of the property for which a building permit is sought (and requiring site plan approval under section 18-328, above) and which has not been previously approved under the requirements of this section, shall file an application for site plan approval along with an application for such building permit. 
(c)  The owner of the property, or duly authorized representative of the owner, shall file an application for site plan approval with the building and zoning administrator. It shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name, address, and telephone number of the applicant including the name and address of each person or entity owning an interest in the subject property. For purposes of this section, the term ownership interest shall include any legal or equitable interest held at the time of the application in the property that is the subject of the application. The application shall include the signature(s) of the owner(s). 
(2)  A site plan of the size and containing the information required by section 18-331 of this chapter. 
(3)  The application shall be accompanied by a non-refundable fee of $250.00. 
(4)  The application shall further be accompanied by a non-refundable fee for landscape plan review in an amount determined as follows: 
a.  Properties containing 0-3 acres ..... $500.00 
b.  Properties containing 3.01-5 acres ..... 500.00 
Plus, per acre or fraction thereof ..... 50.00 
c.  Properties containing 5.01-10 acres ..... 750.00 
Plus, per acre or fraction thereof ..... 25.00 
d.  Properties containing 10.01 acres or more ..... 1,000.00 
Plus, per acre or fraction thereof ..... 10.00 
(5)  In addition, the party submitting the application for a site plan shall be responsible for the following: 
a.  In the event the village incurs expenses for outside professional services, the village shall bill each developer or applicant on whose behalf the village has incurred such expenses on a monthly basis, the balance due 30 days from the date of billing. 
b.  In the event village staff reviews the plans and/or conducts periodic construction inspections, the village shall bill each developer or applicant on whose behalf the village has reviewed plans and/or conducted inspections, the balance due 30 days from the date of billing, fees calculated as follows: 
1.  Village engineer, per hour ..... $150.00 
2.  Civil engineer or development manager, per hour ..... 120.00 
3.  Public improvements inspector or engineering technician, per hour ..... 95.00 
c.  All payments required pursuant to section a. or b. above shall generally be made in full upon completion of each of the following stages; optional sketch plan review, preliminary site plan review, final site plan review, inspection of site improvements and acceptance of site improvements, before proceeding with work on a subsequent stage. The village shall reserve the right to stop all review and inspection procedures, including plan commission, zoning board of appeals and village board reviews, and such work as is being inspected, until all fees are paid. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-331. - Contents of a site plan review application. 
    All applications for site plan review shall include the following information: 
(1)  Site plan application. 
a.  A completed application form provided by the building and zoning administrator. 
b.  Each application shall include 15 copies of all full-sized documents and drawings. For all graphic and plan drawings, a scale of not less than one inch equals 100 feet shall be used. In no event shall individual sheets or drawings exceed 30 inches by 42 inches. All sets of drawings submitted shall be folded to a size no larger than nine inches by 12 inches. 
c.  The names and addresses of the persons responsible for preparing the plan. 
d.  The present zoning of the site and adjoining property. 
e.  Any other information that may reasonably be required by the village board or building and zoning administrator as the case may be, which may include, but is not limited to, the following: 
1.  A traffic study. 
2.  In the case of a map amendment or special use, an analysis of the need and demand for the proposed use and the impact of the proposed use on the value of adjoining and nearby properties. 
3.  A fiscal impact analysis. 
(2)  A map depicting existing conditions showing the location, dimensions, size and height of the following, as applicable. 
a.  Streets, alleys, easements, and utilities, including street lighting. 
b.  Buildings and structures. 
c.  Septic fields, wells, and public sewer and water systems. 
d.  The topography of the existing ground, drawn at a minimum of two-foot contours, particularly slopes in excess of 15 percent. 
e.  Terraces and retaining walls. 
f.  Driveways, entrances, exits, parking areas and sidewalks. 
g.  Water mains and fire hydrants. 
h.  Recreation areas, if any. 
i.  Natural and artificial watercourses, bodies of water, and wetlands, if any. 
j.  Limits of flood plains, if any. 
k.  Hydric soils, if any. 
l.  Significant geological features, if any. 
m.  Areas that can reasonably be expected to, or which do contain, contaminated soils or materials contaminated with toxic or hazardous materials. 
n.  Underground storage tanks, if any. 
o.  General alignment and lengths of all streets and all property lines. 
p.  All building restriction lines, highway setback lines, easements, covenants, reservations, and rights-of-way. 
q.  Date, scale, and north arrow. 
(3)  A separate site plan shall be prepared to show the general location, dimensions, size, and height of the following elements of the proposed development, and shall include all of the items outlined in paragraph (2) above, plus: 
a.  For a site plan which includes any existing structure or other improvements, an indication of those improvements that are to remain and those which will be removed. 
b.  Buildings and structures with entrances and exits identified. 
c.  Utility plan for water, and wastewater disposal. 
d.  Methods to control erosion on slopes of 15 percent or more. 
e.  Distances between buildings. 
f.  Calculations of the following, as applicable: 
1.  Number of dwelling units or square footage of non-residential uses. 
2.  Number of parking spaces. 
3.  Number of loading spaces. 
4.  Total land area. 
5.  Total landscaped area. 
6.  Total open space. 
7.  Total impervious surface. 
g.  Tentative plans for collecting and depositing stormwater, and the method of treatment of natural and artificial watercourses, including a delineation of proposed limits of floodplains, if any. 
h.  A general indication of proposed grading, surface drainage, terraces, retaining wall heights, grades on paved areas, and ground floor elevations of proposed buildings and structures, shown at a minimum of two-foot contours, and approximate elevations. 
i.  A landscape plan showing the location, species, size, and area coverage of trees, shrubs, and ground cover to be planted, and the areas to be retained in natural vegetation, in accordance with chapter 106, article IX, landscape requirements. 
j.  Any location intended for the outdoor display or storage of goods and merchandise. 
k.  Plans to remediate, remove, or control on-site any contaminated soils, materials, underground storage tanks, combustible gases, or old landfills, dumps, or disposal areas. 
l.  Plans for minimizing the impact on existing wetlands and/or hydric soils. 
m.  A lighting plan indicating all exterior building-mounted and freestanding lights and structures including overall height, type of lamp, luminaries, foot-candles, and a statement that such lighting plan will meet the Standards of the Illuminating Engineering Society of North America. 
n.  Exterior building elevations of all proposed structures and existing buildings when existing buildings are proposed to be structurally altered. Elevations shall indicate the materials to be used in the design of the structure and proposed color scheme. 
o.  Elevations of proposed free-standing signs, as well as the intended sign message/display, and the materials and colors intended for the sign. Typical elevations shall be provided for wall-mounted signs including color renderings of all sign faces; views of supporting members, poles, bases and pedestals; side views which indicate both signage depth and projections; method of illumination, colors samples, materials indications, and dimensions of all sign elements. 
p.  A location map identifying the site in relation to the nearest intersection of two or more streets at a scale that can be easily traced. 
(4)  Combined existing conditions map and site plan. The requirements for each the existing conditions map and site plan under subsections (2) and (3) above may be combined in a single map upon approval of the building and zoning administrator. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-332. - Agreement of owner. 
    All documents and information submitted as part of an application for site plan approval shall be construed to be a statement by the applicant that he or she intends and agrees to develop the site in accordance with such information upon approval. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-333. - Notice requirements. 
    Site plans do not require any form of public notice, however, a site plan application filed concurrently with an application for a zoning map amendment or an application for a special use permit shall state that site plan approval is sought as part of the public notice in addition to the requested map amendment and/or special use permit. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-334. - Procedure for decision; village board action. 
    Plans that are filed with an application for a zoning map amendment or with an application for a special use permit shall be processed as part of the amendment or special use. All other site plans shall be approved or denied by the village board. Approval shall be given by adoption of a resolution authorizing such site plan and any conditions thereon. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-335. - Standards for plans. 
    In reviewing and determining whether to approve or disapprove a plan, the village board and building and zoning administrator shall consider those factors listed below which they determine to be applicable to a given plan. 
(1)  The application shall comply with the provisions of this ordinance and all other ordinances of the village and any other applicable laws. 
(2)  The plan shall be in reasonable conformity with the comprehensive plan. 
(3)  Reasonable provisions shall be made to ensure that development will be served by essential public facilities and services such as highways, streets, parking spaces, police and fire protection, drainage structures, refuse disposal, water and sewer, or septic systems, and schools. 
(4)  Any building or structure shall be reasonably accessible to fire, police, emergency, and service vehicles. When deemed necessary for access, emergency vehicle easements shall be provided. The access for fire, police and emergency vehicles shall be unobstructed at all times. 
(5)  Adequate provision shall be made to ensure the compatibility of the proposed development, including mass, scale, site layout, and site design with the character of the surrounding property and the neighborhood, including: 
a.  Relationship of buildings to sites. 
1.  The site shall be planned to achieve a desirable transition to the street, provide for adequate planting, safe pedestrian movement, and off-street parking areas. 
2.  Parking areas should include innovative ways to significantly screen the parking areas from views from public ways. 
3.  Without restricting the permissible limits of the applicable zoning district, the height and scale of each building shall be compatible with its site and existing (or anticipated) adjoining buildings. 
b.  Building design. 
1.  Structures shall be in scale and harmonious with adjoining buildings and other defined plans for adjacent buildings. 
2.  Materials shall be selected for their harmony with the building and adjoining buildings. Materials shall also be selected for suitability to the type buildings and the design in which they are used. 
3.  Materials shall be of durable quality. 
4.  Exterior lighting shall be part of the architectural concept and fixtures, standards, and exposed accessories shall be harmonious with the building design. 
c.  Signs. 
1.  Every sign shall be designed as an integral architectural element of the building and site to which it principally relates. 
2.  The colors, materials, and illumination of every sign shall be compatible and harmonious with the building and site to which it principally relates. 
3.  Each sign shall be compatible with signs on adjoining premises and shall not compete for attention. 
(6)  Open space provided is configured to make that open space usable, functional, and appropriate to the development proposed. 
(7)  Streets and sidewalks shall provide access and good traffic circulation to and from adjacent lands, existing streets, sidewalks, and other proposed adjacent buildings. 
(8)  Provision shall be made to ensure that adequate access roads or entrance or exit drives will be provided and will be designed so as to prevent traffic hazards and to minimize traffic congestion in public streets. 
(9)  Adequate water mains and fire hydrants shall be provided in accessible places in accordance with good fire fighting and fire prevention practice. 
(10)  Adequate provision shall be made for the collection and disposition of all on- and off-site stormwater and natural water, including but not limited to on-site drainage retention or detention facilities. 
(11)  Adequate provision shall be made for the collection and disposition of wastewater. 
(12)  Adequate provision shall be made to avoid an increase in hazard to adjacent property from flood, increased run-off or water drainage. 
(13)  The obstruction of natural watercourses shall be prohibited. 
(14)  Adequate provision shall be made to avoid glare of vehicular and stationary lights that would affect the established character of the neighborhood, and to the extent such lights will be visible across from any property line, the performance standards for illumination shall be met. 
(15)  Adequate provision shall be made to ensure that the location, lighting, and type of sign and the relationship of signs to traffic control is appropriate for the site and will not have an adverse affect on any adjacent properties. 
(16)  Adequate provision shall be made to minimize the impact on existing or developing wetlands and hydric soils. 
(17)  The requirements of chapter 106, article IX, landscaping requirements have been met. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-336. - Conditions on plans. 
    The village board, in consideration of any site plan, may impose certain conditions in granting plan approval to minimize any negative impacts or minimize any adverse impacts due to the development. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-337. - Modification of plans. 
    Changes to site plans require reconsideration and reapproval by the village board as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-338. - Lapse of approval. 
    Unless the village board provides otherwise by resolution, or unless the village board has extended the term of site plan approval, plan approval shall automatically lapse one year after the date of approval of the plan, unless a building permit has been issued and construction commenced. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-339. - Village's authority to retain outside professional services. 
    In accordance with applicable state and local law, the village may require the applicant to execute and deliver to the village a professional fee agreement and a security deposit as set forth in section 18-5. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-340. - Masonry materials. 
    Masonry material means brick or stone with a minimum nominal thickness of three inches, but does not include materials such as, but not limited to, painted or unpainted plain concrete blocks, mortarless brick, panel brick or stone, and any masonry product that is adhered directly to the exterior wall of the building. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-341. - Surety for public improvements. 
    In all cases where an approved site plan includes the installation of any public improvements, the applicant receiving site plan approval shall provide the village with a form a surety approved by the village to guarantee the satisfactory completion of all public improvements in the amount as determined as follows: 
(1)  Construction costs - approved engineer's estimate of public improvements; 
(2)  Warranty contingent equals ten percent of (1); 
(3)  Inflationary contingent equals 15 percent of (1); 
(4)  Surety amount equals (1)+(2)+(3). 
    Such surety shall be provided to the village prior to the issuance of any building permit for the property for which the site plan was approved. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014; Ord. No. 2665, § 1, 10-9-2017) 
Sec. 18-342. - Warranty for public improvements. 
    The village shall retain a warranty for all defects and failures in the public improvements associated with approved site plans for a period of two years following issuance of a certificate of occupancy for the final building on the property for which the site plan was approved. The amount of such warranty shall be calculated as follows: 
(1)  Warranty contingent as calculated in section 18-341 above. 
(2)  Warranty amount equals (1). 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Secs. 18-343-18-349. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVII. - INTERNATIONAL ENERGY CONSERVATION CODE 

Sec. 18-350. - Adopted. 
    That certain documents, one copy of which is on file in the office of the village clerk, being marked and designated as The International Energy Conservation Code/2012 published by the International Code Council be and are hereby provided; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of such codes, are hereby referred to as adopted made part of this article as is fully set out in this article, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 18-351. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-351. - Special provisions. 
    The following words, provisions, and paragraphs are to be added to the following designated sections of the code adopted in section 18-350. These provisions supersede the requirements of the indicated provisions of such code. 
    TITLE shall read as follows: 
C101.1 Title. These regulations shall be known as the Energy Conservation Code of the Village of New Lenox, hereinafter referred to as "this code." 
    PHASED APPROVAL shall read as follows: 
C103.3.3 Phased Approval. Delete in its entirety. 
    AUTHORITY shall read as follows: 
C108.1 Authority. Whenever the building and zoning administrator and/or other duly appointed agent of the village finds any work regulated by this code being performed in a manner either contrary to the provisions of this code or dangerous or unsafe, the building and zoning administrator and/or other duly appointed agent is authorized to issue a stop work order. 
    ISSUANCE shall read as follows: 
C108.2 Issuance. The stop work order shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property involved, or to the owner's agent, or to the person doing the work. Upon issuance of a stop work order, the cited work shall immediately cease. The stop work order shall state the reason for the order, and the conditions under which the cited work will be permitted to resume. 
    EMERGENCIES shall read as follows: 
C108.3 Emergencies. Where an emergency exists, the Building and Zoning Administrator and/or other duly appointed agent shall not be required to give a written notice prior to stopping the work. 
    FAILURE TO COMPLY shall read as follows: 
C108.4 Failure to comply. Any person who shall continue any work after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable to a fine of not more than as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
    BOARD OF APPEALS shall read as follows: 
C109.1 Board of Appeals. In order to hear and decide appeals of orders, decisions or determinations made by the building official relative to the application and interpretation of this code, there shall be and is hereby created a board of appeals. The building official shall be an ex officio member of said board but shall have no vote on any matter before the board. The board of appeals shall consist of the village board for the Village of New Lenox. The village board shall adopt rules of procedure for conducting its business, and shall render all decisions and findings in writing. 
    QUALIFICATIONS shall read as follows: 
C109.3 Qualifications. Delete and reserve the number. 
    TITLE shall read as follows: 
R101.1 Title. These regulations shall be known as the Energy Conservation Code of the Village of New Lenox, hereinafter referred to as "this code." 
    PHASED APPROVAL shall read as follows: 
R103.3.3 Phased Approval. Delete in its entirety. 
    AUTHORITY shall read as follows: 
R108.1 Authority. Whenever the building and zoning administrator and/or other duly appointed agent of the village finds any works regulated by this code being performed in a manner either contrary to the provisions of this code or dangerous or unsafe, the building and zoning administrator and/or other duly appointed agent is authorized to issue a stop work order. 
    ISSUANCE shall read as follows: 
R108.2 Issuance. The stop work order shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property involved, or to the owner's agent, or to the person doing the work. Upon issuance of a stop work order, the cited work shall immediately cease. The stop work order shall state the reason for the order, and the conditions under which the cited work will be permitted to resume. 
    EMERGENCIES shall read as follows: 
R108.3 Emergencies. Where an emergency exists, the building and zoning administrator and/or other duly appointed agent shall not be required to give written notice prior to stopping the work. 
    FAILURE TO COMPLY shall read as follows: 
R108.4 Failure to Comply. Any person who shall continue any work after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable to a fine of not more than as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
    BOARD OF APPEALS shall read as follows: 
R109.1 Board of Appeals. In order to hear and decide appeals of orders, decisions or determinations made by the building official relative to the application and interpretation of this code, there shall be and is hereby created a board of appeals. The building official shall be an ex officio member of said board but shall have no vote on any matter before the board. The board of appeals shall consist of the village board for the Village of New Lenox. The village board shall adopt rules of procedure for conducting its business, and shall render all decisions and findings in writing. 
    QUALIFICATIONS shall read as follows: 
R109.3 Qualifications. Delete and reserve the number. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-352. - Applicability of article. 
(a)  This code shall be the minimum requirements for commercial buildings, applying to the construction of, renovations to and additions to all commercial buildings, and the minimum and maximum requirements for residential buildings, applying to the construction of all residential buildings. 
(b)  This code shall apply to any new building or structure for which a building permit application is received. In the case of any addition, alteration, renovation, or repair to an existing commercial structure, this code applies only to the portions of that structure that are being added, altered, renovated, or repaired. Further, additions, alterations, renovations, or repairs to an existing building, building system, or portion thereof shall conform to the provisions of this code as they relate to new construction without requiring the unaltered portion of the existing building or building system to comply with this code. 
(c)  The following need not comply with this code, provided that the energy use of the building is not increased: 
(1)  Storm windows installed over existing fenestration. 
(2)  Glass-only replacements in an existing sash and frame. 
(3)  Existing ceiling, wall, or floor cavities exposed during construction, provided that these cavities are filled with insulation. 
(4)  Construction where the existing roof, wall, or floor is not exposed. 
(5)  Reroofing for roofs where neither the sheathing nor the insulation is exposed. Roofs without insulation in the cavity and where the sheathing or insulation is exposed during reroofing shall be insulated either above or below the sheathing. 
(6)  Replacement of existing doors that separate conditioned space from the exterior shall not require the installation of a vestibule or revolving door, provided, however, that an existing vestibule that separates a conditioned space from the exterior shall not be removed. 
(7)  Alterations that replace less than 50 percent of the luminaires in a space provided that such alterations do not increase the installed interior lighting power. 
(8)  Alterations that replace only the bulb and ballast within the existing luminaires in a space provided that the alteration does not increase the installed interior lighting power. 
(d)  The following buildings shall be exempt from this code: 
(1)  Buildings otherwise exempt from the provisions of a locally adopted building code and buildings that do not contain a conditioned space. 
(2)  Buildings that do not use either electricity or fossil fuel for comfort conditioning. For purposes of determining whether this exemption applies, a building will be presumed to be heated by electricity, even in the absence of equipment used for electric comfort heating, whenever the building is provided with electrical service in excess of 100 amps, unless this code enforcement official determines that this electrical service is necessary for purposes other than providing electric comfort heating. 
(3)  Historic buildings. This exemption shall apply to those buildings that are listed on the National Register of Historic Places or the Illinois Register of Historic Places, and to those buildings that have been designated as historically significant by a local governing body that is authorized to make such designations. 
(4)  Other buildings specified as exempt by this code 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-353. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who fails to comply with the provisions of the International Energy Conservation Code or amendments to the International Energy Conservation Code as set forth in this Article or who fails to carry out an order made pursuant to the International Energy Conservation Code or amendments to the International Energy Conservation Code as set forth in this article or violates any condition attached to a permit, approval or certificate shall be punished as prescribed by law and as provided in section 1-9 of this Code. 
(b)  Abatement of violation. The imposition of penalties shall not prevent the building official from requesting the legal counsel of the village to institute the appropriate legal proceedings at law or in equity to restrain, correct or abate such violation. Administrative notices are attempts to secure voluntary compliance and are not the start of prosecution for jurisdictional purposes. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Secs. 18-354-18-370. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVIII. - VACANT BUILDINGS 

Sec. 18-371. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building means any business or commercial structure or any single-family or multi-family residential structure occupied or intended for supporting or sheltering any occupancy. 
    Building and zoning administrator means the building and zoning administrator or his or her designee. 
    Evidence of vacancy means any condition that on its own or combined with other conditions present would lead a reasonable person to believe that the property is vacant. Such conditions include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Substantially all lawful residential or business activity has ceased. 
(2)  The percentage of the overall square footage of occupied to unoccupied space or the overall number of occupied and unoccupied units. 
(3)  The building is substantially devoid of contents. 
(4)  The condition and value of fixtures or personal property in the building. 
(5)  Lack of utility services (water, sewer, electric or natural gas). 
(6)  The building is the subject of a foreclosure action. 
(7)  The presence or recurrence of uncorrected code violations. 
(8)  Overgrown and/or dead vegetation. 
(9)  Accumulation of newspapers, circulars, flyers and/or mail. 
(10)  Abandonment by owner. 
    Owner means any person, operator, firm, or corporation having a legal or equitable interest in the property; or recorded in the official records of the state, county, or village as holding title to the property; or otherwise having control of the property, including the guardian of the estate of any such person, the executor or administrator of the estate of such person if ordered to take possession of real property by a court; or any person maintaining, operating or collecting rent. 
    Person means a corporation, a partnership, or other entity as well as an individual. 
    Unoccupied means any business or commercial structure or any single-family or multi-family residential structure which is vacant, lacks the habitual presence of human beings who have a legal right to be on the premises, and is not maintained pursuant to the minimum standards as set forth in the property maintenance code. 
    Vacant building means any business or commercial structure or any single-family or multi-family residential structure which is: 
(1)  Unoccupied and unsecured; or 
(2)  Unoccupied and secured by boarding or other similar means; or 
(3)  Unoccupied and a dangerous structure; or 
(4)  Unoccupied and condemned by the building and zoning administrator pursuant to applicable law; or 
(5)  Unoccupied and has multiple code violations; or 
(6)  Unoccupied and the building or its premises has been the site of unlawful activity within the previous six months; or 
(7)  Condemned by the building and zoning administrator and unlawfully occupied; or 
(8)  Unoccupied for over 90 days and during which time the building and zoning administrator has issued an order to correct public nuisance conditions and said conditions have not been corrected in a code compliant manner; or 
(9)  Unoccupied for more than six consecutive months; or 
(10)  Abandoned by persons who surrender their claim, right, or interest in the property. 
A vacant building shall not include unoccupied buildings which are undergoing construction, renovation, or rehabilitation and which are in compliance with all applicable village ordinances, codes, and regulations, and for which construction, renovation or rehabilitation is proceeding diligently to completion. 
The building and zoning administrator may evaluate buildings in the village which do not meet the definition of a vacant building as set forth above and, based on evidence of vacancy factors; make a declaration of a vacant building. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-372. - Declaration of vacant buildings. 
(a)  Evaluation. The building and zoning administrator may evaluate buildings in the village which do not meet the definition of a vacant building by means of any lawful inspection and, based on evidence of vacancy factors, make a declaration of a vacant building. The declaration shall be in writing and shall state the factual basis. 
(b)  Notice. Within seven days of making a declaration, the building and zoning administrator shall send notice of the declaration with the factual findings to the owner. The notice of declaration shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, or by personal or substitute service, and posted in a conspicuous location on the building. The notice shall contain a statement of the obligations of the owner of a building determined to be a vacant building, a copy of the vacant building registration application, and a notice of the owner's right to appeal the building and zoning administrator's declaration. 
(c)  Appeal of declaration. An owner of a building deemed by the building and zoning administrator to be a vacant building as provided for in this section may appeal the declaration to a committee of the village board. Such appeal shall be in writing and shall be filed with the village clerk within 21 days of the date of mailing of the notice of declaration. The filing of an appeal stays the owner's obligation to register the building. The appeal shall contain a complete statement of the reasons the owner disputes the declaration, shall set forth specific facts in support thereof, and shall include all evidence the owner relies upon to support the appeal. The village clerk shall set the matter for hearing and notify the owner of the date of the hearing. 
(d)  Grounds for appeal. An appeal shall be based solely on whether the building is deemed to be a vacant building. 
(e)  Decision. A committee of the village board shall decide the appeal after a hearing. The village clerk shall send written notice of the decision to the owner within 15 days after the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-373. - Obligation to register vacant building. 
(a)  An owner of any vacant building shall, within 30 days after the building becomes vacant or declared vacant, or within 30 days after the effective date of this article, whichever is later, complete a vacant building registration application and register the vacant building with the building and zoning administrator. 
(b)  Registration does not exonerate the owner from compliance with all applicable codes and ordinances, and shall not be construed to prevent the enforcement of other applicable ordinances, codes, legislation, and regulations which prescribe standards other than as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-374. - Application for vacant building. 
    Each vacant building registration application shall be made in writing to the building and zoning administrator on a form provided for that purpose, accompanied by the applicable registration fee, and shall contain: 
(1)  The property identification number (PIN), common address, and lot number of the site of the vacant building, and physical description of the vacant building, including but not limited to construction materials and color. 
(2)  The name, street address, and telephone number of a person 21 years of age or older, designated by the owner, as the authorized agent for receiving notices in connection with the enforcement of this article. 
(3)  An emergency contact name and telephone number. 
(4)  The case name and number of any litigation pending concerning or affecting the building, including bankruptcy or foreclosure cases. 
(5)  The name, street address, and telephone number of all persons with any legal interest in the building. 
(6)  Type and location of any toxic, flammable or hazardous materials stored or used at said location, if applicable. 
(7)  Any other relevant information about the vacant building for police, paramedics, the fire department, or other emergency responders, if applicable. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014; Ord. No. 2765, § 1, 12-17-2018) 
Sec. 18-375. - Validity of registration; annual re-registration. 
(a)  The registration shall be valid for a period of one year from the date of registration. 
(b)  An owner shall be required to annually re-register the vacant building on the anniversary of the date of registration as long as the building remains a vacant building as defined in this article. A reminder letter shall be sent by the chief building inspector prior to the expiration date regarding the requirement to re-register the vacant building. However, failure to receive an expiration notification is not a defense for the failure to re-register the vacant building. 
(Ord. No. 2765, § 2, 12-17-2018) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2765, § 2, adopted December 17, 2018, amended the Code by repealing former § 18-375, and adding a new § 18-375. Former § 18-375 pertained to fees, and derived from Ord. No. 2455, adopted October 27, 2014. 
Sec. 18-376. - Changes in registration information. 
    An owner shall notify the building and zoning administrator within 21 days of any change in the registration information by filing an amended registration statement on an application provided by the building and zoning administrator. A new registration is required for any change in ownership whatsoever. The registration statement shall be deemed prima facie proof of the statements therein contained in any administrative enforcement proceeding or court proceeding instituted by the village against the owner of the building. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-377. - Responsibilities of the owner. 
    An owner of any vacant building shall enclose and secure the building and maintain the building in a secure and closed condition until the building is no longer a "vacant building" as defined herein. A building shall be deemed secured and closed if the building is maintained pursuant to the minimum standards as set forth in the property maintenance code. 
    An owner of any vacant building shall also: 
(1)  Keep the premises on which a building is located clean, safe and sanitary, maintained free of weeds, dead vegetation, trash, junk, debris, building materials, junk cars, furniture, clothing, appliances and litter, including but not limited to the accumulation of newspapers, circulars and flyers. 
(2)  Keep the property maintained free of graffiti, tagging, or similar markings. 
(3)  Keep the yard landscaped and maintained. 
(4)  Keep pools and spas in working order so the water is not stagnant and remains clear and free of pollutants, debris, and insects, or drained and kept dry. 
(5)  Disconnect water at the buffalo box. 
(6)  Maintain an operable sump pump, if applicable. 
(7)  Provide and maintain winterization of the building between November 1 and March 31. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-378. - Promulgation of rules and regulations. 
    The building and zoning administrator may issue lawful, usual and customary rules and regulations for the administration of this article. These rules may designate materials and methods which must be used to secure a building. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014) 
Sec. 18-379. - Enforcement and penalties. 
(a)  The village shall send a notice to the owner by certified mail, return receipt requested, or by personal or substitute service, for the failure to complete a vacant building registration application and/or register the vacant building. The owner shall have 21 days in which to complete a vacant building registration application and register the vacant building as set forth in the notice; if the violation is not resolved within 21 days, the fine amount shall be $100.00, and each day after that in which the violation continues, there shall be a fine of not less than $25.00 per day and not more than as provided in section 1-9. If the village is required to perform a search to ascertain the owner, the owner is also responsible to reimburse the village for said costs. An owner who fails to re-register the vacant building shall be subject to a fine of not less than $25.00 per day and not more than as provided in section 1-9. 
(b)  Any person who violates any other provision of this article shall be fined not more than as provided in section 1-9 of this Code for each offense, in addition to any other legal or equitable remedies available to the village. Such other remedies include, but are not limited to, injunctive relief, application to a court of competent jurisdiction for a receiver, demolition, or condemnation, contracting for the repair or purchase of the premises, or foreclosure of any lien the village may have thereon. Every day that a violation of this article shall be permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  Nothing herein contained shall prohibit the village from condemning a vacant building as provided by applicable law or taking other actions upon a determination that the building is a public nuisance or poses an imminent danger to the occupants of the building, or the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014; Ord. No. 2765, § 3, 12-17-2018) 
Sec. 18-380. - Discharge of obligation to register vacant building. 
    Prior to the removal of a vacant building from the registration requirement, the condition(s) which initially compelled registration of the vacant building must be resolved, and an inspection to determine compliance with the minimum levels of habitability as set forth in sections 302.1, 304.1, 305.1, 307.1, 308.1, 402.1, 403.1, 502.1, 504.1, 505.1, 506.1, 602.1, 603.1 & 604.1 in the 2012 International Property Maintenance Code, and payment in full of all village fees, fines, and costs, is required. 
(Ord. No. 2455, § 2, 10-27-2014)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
