    Enclosed or partially enclosed sports arena means any sports pavilion, stadium, gymnasium, health spa, boxing arena, swimming pool, roller rink, ice rink, bowling alley, or other similar place where members of the general public assemble to engage in physical exercise or participate in athletic competitions or recreational activities or to witness sports, cultural, recreational, or other events. 
    Gaming equipment or supplies means gaming equipment/supplies as defined in the Illinois Gaming Board Rules of the Illinois Administrative Code. 
    Gaming facility means an establishment utilized primarily for the purposes of gaming and where gaming equipment or supplies are operated for the purposes of accruing business revenue. 
    Healthcare facility means an office or institution providing care or treatment of diseases, whether physical, mental, or emotional, or other medical, physiological, or psychological conditions, including, but not limited to, hospitals, rehabilitation hospitals, weight control clinics, nursing homes, homes for the aging or chronically ill, laboratories, and offices of surgeons, chiropractors, physical therapists, physicians, dentists, and all specialists within these professions. "Healthcare facility" includes all waiting rooms, hallways, private rooms, semiprivate rooms, and wards within healthcare facilities. 
    Place of employment means any area under the control of a public or private employer that employees are required to enter, leave, or pass through during the course of employment, including, but not limited to entrances and exits to places of employment, including a minimum distance of 15 feet from entrances from entrances, exits, windows that open, and ventilation intakes that serve an enclosed area where smoking is prohibited; offices and work areas; restrooms; conference and classrooms; break rooms and cafeterias; and other common areas. A private residence or home-based business, unless used to provide licensed child care, foster care, adult care, or other similar social service care on the premises, is not a place of employment. 
    Private club means a not-for-profit association that (1) has been in active and continuous existence for at least three years prior to the effective date of P.A. 95-0017, whether incorporated or not, (2) is the owner, lessee, or occupant of a building or portion thereof used exclusively for club purposes at all times, (3) is operated solely for a recreational, fraternal, social, patriotic, political, benevolent, or athletic purpose, but not for pecuniary gain, and (4) only sells alcoholic beverages incidental to its operation. For purposes of this definition, "private club" means an organization that is managed by a board of directors, executive committee, or similar body chosen by the members at an annual meeting, has established bylaws, a constitution, or both to govern its activities, and has been granted an exemption from the payment of federal income tax as a club under 26 U.S.C. 501. 
    Private residence means the part of a structure used as a dwelling, including, without limitation: a private home, townhouse, condominium, apartment, mobile home, vacation home, cabin, or cottage. For the purposes of this definition, a hotel, motel, inn, resort, lodge, bed and breakfast or other similar public accommodation, hospital, nursing home, or assisted living facility shall not be considered a private residence. 
    Public place means that portion of any building or vehicle used by and open to the public, regardless of whether the building or vehicle is owned in whole or in part by private persons or entities, the state, or any other public entity and regardless of whether a fee is charged for admission, including a minimum distance of 15 feet from entrances, exits, windows that open, and ventilation intakes that serve an enclosed area where smoking is prohibited. A public place does not include a private residence unless the private residence is used to provide licensed child care, foster care, or other similar social service care on the premises. A public place includes, but is not limited to, hospitals, restaurants, retail stores, offices, commercial establishments, elevators, indoor theaters, libraries, museums, concert halls, public conveyances, educational facilities, nursing homes, auditoriums, enclosed or partially enclosed sports arenas, meeting rooms, schools, exhibition halls, convention facilities, polling places, private clubs, gaming facilities, all government owned vehicles and facilities, including buildings and vehicles owned, leased, or operated by the state or state subcontract, healthcare facilities or clinics, enclosed shopping centers, retail service establishments, financial institutions, educational facilities, ticket areas, public hearing facilities, public restrooms, waiting areas, lobbies, bars, taverns, bowling alleys, skating rinks, reception areas, and no less than 75 percent of the sleeping quarters within a hotel, motel, resort, inn, lodge, bed and breakfast, or other similar public accommodation that are rented to guests, but excludes private residences. 
    Restaurant means (i) an eating establishment, including, but not limited to, coffee shops, cafeterias, sandwich stands, and private and public school cafeterias, that gives or offers for sale food to the public, guests, or employees, and (ii) a kitchen or catering facility in which food is prepared on the premises for serving elsewhere. "Restaurant" includes a bar area within the restaurant. 
    Smoke or smoking means the carrying, smoking, burning, inhaling, or exhaling of any kind of lighted pipe, cigar, cigarette, hookah, weed, herbs, or any other lighted smoking equipment. Further, "smoke" or "smoking" means the use of any alternative nicotine product or vapor product, as defined in this section. "Smoke" or "smoking" does not, however, include smoking that is associated with a native recognized religious ceremony, ritual, or activity by American Indians that is in accordance with the federal American Indian Religious Freedom Act, 42 U.S.C. 1996 and 1996a. 
    Vapor product means any non-combustible product that employs a heating element, power source, electronic circuit, or other electronic chemical or mechanical means, regardless of shape or size, that can be used to produce vapor from nicotine in a solution or any other form. "Vapor product" includes any electronic cigarette, electronic cigar, electronic cigarillo, electronic pipe, or similar product or device, as well as any vapor cartridge or other container that is intended to be used with or in an electronic cigarette, electronic cigar, electronic cigarillo, electronic pipe, or similar product or device. "Vapor product" does not include any product regulated as a drug or device by the United States Food and Drug Administration under chapter V of the Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. 
(Ord. No. 2176, § 3, 6-20-2011; Ord No. 2547, §§ 2-4, 2-8-2016) 
Sec. 56-32. - Smoking in public places, places of employment, and governmental vehicles prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall smoke in a public place or in any place of employment or within 15 feet of any entrance to a public place or place of employment. No person may smoke in any vehicle owned, leased, or operated by the state or a political subdivision of the state. An owner shall reasonably assure that smoking is prohibited in indoor public places and workplaces unless specifically exempted by section 56-36. 
(b)  No person shall smoke in certain areas of the village commons, including but not limited to the performing arts pavilion, gazebo, concession stand and restrooms, grassy areas, and walking paths. Smoking is allowed on the exterior sidewalks. 
(Ord. No. 2176, § 3, 6-20-2011) 
Sec. 56-33. - Posting of signs; removal of ashtrays. 
(a)  "No Smoking" signs or the international "No Smoking" symbol, consisting of a pictorial representation of a burning cigarette enclosed in a red circle with a red bar across it, shall be clearly and conspicuously posted in each public place and place of employment where smoking is prohibited, by the owner, operator, manager, or other person in control of that place. 
(b)  Each public place and place of employment where smoking is prohibited by this chapter shall have posted at every entrance a conspicuous sign clearly stating that smoking is prohibited. 
(c)  All ashtrays shall be removed from any area where smoking is prohibited by this chapter by the owner, operator, manager, or other person having control of the area. 
(Ord. No. 2176, § 3, 6-20-2011) 
Sec. 56-34. - Smoking prohibited in student dormitories. 
    Smoking is prohibited in any portion of the living quarters, including, but not limited to, sleeping rooms, dining areas, restrooms, laundry areas, lobbies, and hallways, of a building used in whole or in part as a student dormitory that is owned and operated or otherwise utilized by a public or private institution of higher education. 
(Ord. No. 2176, § 3, 6-20-2011) 
Sec. 56-35. - Designation of other nonsmoking areas. 
    Any employer, owner, occupant, lessee, operator, manager, or other person in control of any public place or place of employment may designate a non-enclosed area of a public place or place of employment, including outdoor areas, as an area where smoking is also prohibited provided that such employer, owner, lessee or occupant shall conspicuously post signs prohibiting smoking in the manner described in section 56-33. 
(Ord. No. 2176, § 3, 6-20-2011) 
Sec. 56-36. - Exemptions. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, smoking is allowed in the following areas: 
(1)  Private residences or dwelling places, except when used as a child care, adult day care, or healthcare facility or any other home-based business open to the public. 
(2)  Hotel and motel sleeping rooms that are rented to guests and are designated as smoking rooms, provided that all smoking rooms on the same floor must be contiguous and smoke from these rooms must not infiltrate into nonsmoking rooms or other areas where smoking is prohibited. Not more than 25 percent of the rooms rented to guests in a hotel or motel may be designated as rooms where smoking is allowed. The status of rooms as smoking or nonsmoking may not be changed, except to permanently add additional nonsmoking rooms. 
(3)  Common smoking rooms in long-term care facilities operated under the authority of the Illinois Department of Veterans' Affairs or licensed under the Nursing Home Care Act (210 ILCS 45/1-101 et seq.) that are accessible only to residents who are smokers and have requested in writing to have access to the common smoking room where smoking is permitted and the smoke shall not infiltrate other areas of the long-term care facility. 
(Ord. No. 2176, § 3, 6-20-2011) 
Sec. 56-37. - Injunctions. 
    In addition to any other sanction or remedy, the department, a state-certified local public health department, the village, or any individual personally affected by repeated violations may institute, in a circuit court, an action to enjoin violations of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2176, § 3, 6-20-2011) 
Sec. 56-38. - Discrimination prohibited. 
    No individual may be discriminated against in any manner because of the exercise of any rights afforded by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2176, § 3, 6-20-2011) 
Sec. 56-39. - Entrances, exits, windows, and ventilation intakes. 
    Smoking is prohibited within a minimum distance of 15 feet from entrances, exits, windows that open, and ventilation intakes that serve an enclosed area where smoking is prohibited under this chapter so as to ensure that smoke does not enter the area through entrances, exits, open windows, or other means. 
(Ord. No. 2176, § 3, 6-20-2011; Ord. No. 2547, § 5, 2-8-2016) 
Sec. 56-40. - Violations. 
(a)  A person, corporation, partnership, association or other entity who violates this chapter shall be fined. Each day that a violation occurs is a separate violation. 
(b)  A person who smokes in an area where smoking is prohibited under this chapter shall be fined in an amount that is not less than $100.00 and not more than $250.00. A person who owns, operates, or otherwise controls a public place or place of employment that violates section 56-32 shall be fined (i) not less than $250.00 for the first violation, (ii) not less than $500.00 for the second violation within one year after the first violation, and (iii) not less than $2,500.00 for each additional violation within one year after the first violation. 
(c)  A fine imposed under this section shall be allocated as follows: 
(1)  One-half of the fine shall be distributed to the state department of public health; and 
(2)  One-half of the fine shall be distributed to the village. 
(d)  A person who owns, operates or controls a public place or place of employment who otherwise commits four or more violations of this chapter in any 12-month period may also have their business license or liquor license suspended or revoked. 
(Ord. No. 2176, § 3, 6-20-2011) 
Chapter 58 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1613, § 2, adopted Feb. 8, 2005, amended art. I in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, said article pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of repeal and inclusion. 

Sec. 58-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Charitable organization means any benevolent, philanthropic, patriotic, or eleemosynary person or one purporting to be such which solicits and collects funds for charitable purposes and includes each local, county, or area division with Illinois of such charitable organization, provided such local, county, or area division has authority and discretion to disburse funds or property otherwise them by transfer to any parent organization. 
    Convicted means and shall include a disposition of court supervision, probation, adjudication, or conditional discharge. 
    Hawker means any person who shall sell or offer for sale, barter, or exchange any goods, wares, merchandise or other commodities and cries his wares or exhibits them for sale. 
    Itinerant vendor means any person who transports tangible personal property for retail sale who does not maintain in an established office, distribution house, sales house, warehouse, service center or residence from which such business is conducted. However, this does not apply to any person who delivers tangible personal property who is fulfilling an order for such property which was solicited or placed by mail or other means. This does not apply to any person holding a valid license, issued by a county or municipality, to engage in retail sales. 
    Mobile merchant means a transient merchant or business operator who sells or serves prepared, pre-packaged or unprepared, unpackaged food or foodstuffs of any kind, non-alcoholic beverages or seasonal items (as defined below) from a vehicle upon privately owned property. The subject property shall contain an existing permanent business that operates in a fixed building with a valid certificate of occupancy or shall contain a business under construction with a valid building permit. A mobile merchant shall not be permitted to operate upon public streets, sidewalks, alleys or other public ways of the village. A mobile merchant shall not be permitted on the same site for more than one hour in any consecutive four-hour period. 
    Peddler means any person who shall sell or offer for sale, barter, or exchange any goods, wares, merchandise or other commodities while traveling from residence to residence on, along or upon the streets and sidewalks of the village. 
    Residence means every separate living unit occupied for residential purposes by one or more persons, contained within any type of building or structure. 
    Seasonal items means flowers; fireworks; pumpkins, gourds and decorative corn; and Christmas trees and decorations. 
    Solicitation means and includes any one or more of the following activities: 
(1)  Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs or services of any kind, character or description whatsoever, for any kind of consideration whatsoever; 
(2)  Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application for or purchase of insurance of any type, kind or character; 
(3)  Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals, newspapers or any type of publication; 
(4)  Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing or any other valuable thing for the support or benefit of any charitable or nonprofit association, organization, corporation or project; 
(5)  Seeking to enlist support for or against a particular religion, philosophy, ideology, political party, issue or candidate, whether accepting donations of money or not, or distributing handbills or flyers advertising any event or service; 
(6)  Seeking to advertise, promote, sell and/or explain any product, service, organization or cause; and 
(7)  Includes hawkers, itinerant vendors, peddlers, and transient merchants. 
    Stationary merchant means a transient merchant or business operator who sells or serves prepared, pre-packaged or unprepared, unpackaged food or foodstuffs of any kind, non-alcoholic beverages or seasonal items (as defined above) from a vehicle or other conveyance upon privately or publicly owned property. The subject property shall contain an existing permanent business that operates in a fixed building with a valid certificate of occupancy. A stationary merchant shall not be permitted to operate upon public streets, sidewalks, alleys or other public ways of the Village. A stationary merchant shall not be permitted upon a vacant parcel or stand-alone parking lot. 
    Transient merchant means any person who is engaged temporarily in the retail sale of goods, wares or merchandise and who, for the purpose of conducting such business, occupies any building, room, vehicle, structure of any kind, or vacant lot, and includes mobile merchants and stationary merchants. However, this does not apply to any person selling goods, wares or merchandise which are raised, produced or manufactured by him, to any person selling vegetables, fruit or perishable farm products at an established city or village market, to any person operating a store or refreshment stand at a resort, to any person operating a stand or booth on or adjacent to property owned by him or upon which he resides, to any person operating a stand or booth at a state or county fair, or to any person operating a stand or booth at a trade show, exposition, convention or similar event. This does not apply to any person holding a valid license, issued by a county or municipality, to engage in retail sales. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 2, 2-8-2005; Ord. No. 2064, § 1, 9-14-2009) 
Sec. 58-2. - Soliciting generally. 
    All solicitors must comply with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 2, 2-8-2005) 
Sec. 58-3. - General policy on soliciting. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy of the corporate authorities of the village that the occupants of the residences in the village shall make the determination of whether solicitors shall be, or shall not be, invited to their respective residence. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 2, 2-8-2005) 
Sec. 58-4. - Posting of notice by occupant. 
(a)  Every person desiring to secure the protection intended to be provided by the regulations pertaining to soliciting contained in this article shall comply with the directions set forth in this section. 
(b)  Notice of the determination by the occupant of the refusal of invitation to solicitors to any residence shall be given in the manner following: 
(1)  A weatherproof card or decal, at least three inches by four inches (eight centimeters by ten centimeters) in size, shall be exhibited upon or near the main entrance door to the residence, indicating the determination by the occupant, containing the applicable words, as follows: 
NO SOLICITORS INVITED 
or 
NO SOLICITORS 
(2)  The letters shall be at least one-third inch (eight millimeters) in height. 
(c)  Such card so exhibited shall constitute sufficient notice to any solicitor of the determination by the occupant of the residence of the information contained thereon. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 2, 2-8-2005) 
Sec. 58-5. - Duty of solicitors to comply with request of occupant. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every solicitor, upon going onto any premises in the village upon which a residence is located, to first determine whether the notice provided for in this article, if any, is attached, and to further be governed by the statement contained on the notice. If the notice states "NO SOLICITORS INVITED" or "NO SOLICITORS," then the solicitor, whether registered or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises. 
(b)  Any solicitor who has gained entrance to any residence, whether invited or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when requested to do so by the occupant. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 2, 2-8-2005) 
Sec. 58-6. - Uninvited soliciting prohibited. 
    It is hereby declared unlawful and a trespass for any person to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engage in soliciting, in defiance of the notice exhibited at the residence in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 2, 2-8-2005) 
Sec. 58-7. - Soliciting prohibited during certain hours and days. 
    It is hereby declared unlawful and a nuisance for any person, whether or not licensed under this chapter, to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door of a residence located thereon, or rap or knock upon any door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engaging in soliciting, prior to 9:00 a.m. or after 7:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday, or prior to 12:00 p.m. or after 5:00 p.m. on Sundays, or at any time on State or Federal holidays. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 2, 2-8-2005) 
Sec. 58-8. - Fraud or misrepresentation. 
    No solicitor shall engage in any fraud, misrepresentation or imposition. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 2, 2-8-2005) 
Sec. 58-9. - Penalty. 
    In addition to all other remedies, any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with any provision of this chapter shall be sentenced as provided in section 1-15 of this Code for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 2, 2-8-2005; Ord. No. 2192, § 18, 8-22-2011 
Secs. 58-10-58-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSE REQUIRED[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1613, § 3, adopted Feb. 8, 2005, amended art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, said article pertained to solicitors. See the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of repeal and inclusion. 

Sec. 58-31. - License generally. 
    All solicitors requiring a license shall comply with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 3, 2-8-2005) 
Sec. 58-32. - License issuance; denial. 
(a)  Application. All applicants shall submit, in addition to a completed application, a nonrefundable application processing fee of $50.00, a certificate showing liability insurance, the department of the treasury employer identification number, and a health department food service establishment inspection report, if applicable. 
(b)  Issuance of license. Within ten business days of filing the application, after consideration, investigation and review of the application, each solicitor who is found to be fully qualified, shall be issued a license, and shall deposit the sum of $50.00 for said license. Upon return of the license to the police department, the licensee shall be refunded the deposit by mail within 60 days. 
(c)  Persons ineligible for certificate. No license shall be issued to any person who, within five years of the date of the application: 
(1)  Has made a false material statement in a soliciting application; 
(2)  Has been convicted of the commission of (i) a felony, or (ii), a misdemeanor involving dishonesty or false statements, under the laws of the state or any other state, or under the laws of the United States; 
(3)  Has violated any of the provisions of this chapter, any other provision of this Code applicable to the activities of a solicitor, or the ordinances of any other municipality regulating soliciting, within one year of the date of the application; 
(4)  Has had his license issued under this chapter revoked as provided in this article; 
(5)  Is required to register as a sex offender under the Illinois Sex Offender Registration Act, 730 ILCS 150/3, under the laws of any other state, or under the laws of the United States; 
(6)  Perpetrated a fraud or misrepresentation in the course of conducting solicitation, distribution or peddling activities; 
(7)  Conducted solicitation, distribution or peddling activities in such a manner as to create a public nuisance; or 
(8)  Does not otherwise meet the requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 3, 2-8-2005; Ord. No. 2269, § 2, 7-9-2012) 
Sec. 58-33. - Display of license. 
    Each licensee shall at all times while soliciting within the village carry upon his person the license as required by this chapter which shall be worn in such a way as to be conspicuous. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 3, 2-8-2005) 
Sec. 58-34. - License revocation. 
    Any license issued under this article shall be revoked by the chief of police if the licensee: 
(1)  Violates any of the provisions of this chapter; 
(2)  Has made a false material statement in the application; 
(3)  Perpetrates a fraud or misrepresentation in the course of conducting solicitation, distribution or peddling activities; 
(4)  Conducts solicitation, distribution or peddling activities in such a manner as to create a public nuisance; or 
(5)  Otherwise becomes disqualified for the issuance of a license under the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 3, 2-8-2005; Ord. No. 2269, § 3, 7-9-2012) 
Sec. 58-35. - Appeal of license denial or revocation. 
(a)  Any person aggrieved by the denial or revocation of a license under the provisions of this article shall have the right to appeal to the village president within 21 days after the date of denial of the application or revocation of the license. The appeal must be in writing, and shall contain a specific request for or waiver of a hearing. 
(b)  If a hearing is requested, the hearing before the village president shall take place within 30 days of the written appeal. The village president shall not be bound by the rules of evidence in the courts of law, but shall, in ascertaining the conditions and practices involved in the decision appealed, take into account all reliable, probative and substantial evidence. The village president shall issue a written decision within 14 days of the hearing. 
(c)  Where a hearing is waived, the appealing party shall submit all supporting documentation with the written appeal. The village president shall issue a written decision within 14 days of the filing of the written appeal. 
(d)  The village president's determination as to the denial or revocation of a license shall be a final administrative decision and subject to review in the circuit court of Will County, Illinois. The provisions of the administrative review law, and the rules adopted pursuant thereto, shall apply to and govern. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 3, 2-8-2005; Ord. No. 2269, § 4, 7-9-2012) 
Sec. 58-36. - Operation generally. 
    All licensed solicitors shall offer for sale, barter or exchange only those goods, wares or merchandise specified in the license. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 3, 2-8-2005) 
Secs. 58-37-58-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TRANSIENT MERCHANTS AND ITINERANT VENDORS 

Sec. 58-61. - License required. 
    Every transient merchant or itinerant vendor desiring to engage in soliciting within the village is required to obtain a license. Stationary merchants must also obtain a temporary use permit. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 4, 2-8-2005; Ord. No. 2064, § 2, 9-14-2009) 
Sec. 58-62. - Application for license. 
(a)  Every transient merchant or itinerant vendor desiring to engage in soliciting within the village is required to make a written application upon a form provided by the chief of police of the village and filed with the chief. The application shall truthfully state in full the information required on the application, as follows: 
(1)  Name, address of the present place of residence and length of residence at such address, business address if other than the residence address, date of birth, and social security number. 
(2)  Address of the place of residence during the preceding three years, if other than the present address. 
(3)  Physical description of the applicant. 
(4)  Name and address of the person by whom the applicant is employed or whom he represents, and the length of time of such employment or representation. 
(5)  Name and address of each employer during the preceding three years, if other than the present employer. 
(6)  Description of the subject matter of the soliciting in which the applicant will engage and a description of the commodities or articles of merchandise in which the applicant intends to deal. 
(7)  The date, or approximate date, of the most recent previous application for a license under this article, if any. 
(8)  A list of all licenses or certificates of registration to conduct business as a transient merchant or itinerant vendor obtained by the applicant in Illinois in the 12 months preceding the date of filing of the application. 
(9)  A statement as to whether a license issued to the applicant under this article has been revoked within one year of the date of the application. 
(10)  A statement as to whether the applicant has been convicted of a violation of any provision of this article or the ordinances of any other municipality regulating soliciting within one year of the date of the application. 
(11)  A statement as to whether the applicant has ever been convicted of the commission of (i) a felony, or (ii), a misdemeanor involving dishonesty or false statements, under the laws of the State of Illinois or any other state, or under the laws of the United States, within five years of the date of the application. 
(12)  Fingerprinting of the applicant. 
(13)  Such additional information as the chief of police may deem necessary to process the application. 
(b)  Statements to be under oath. All statements made by the applicant under the application or in connection therewith shall be under oath. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 4, 2-8-2005) 
Sec. 58-63. - Fees. 
    The fee for a transient merchant or itinerant vendor license shall be $100.00 per year, nonrefundable, and shall expire on December 31 of the year it was issued. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 4, 2-8-2005) 
Sec. 58-64. - Bond required. 
    Upon issuance of the license, the licensee shall file with the police department a surety bond or shall make a cash deposit equal to 50 percent of the wholesale value of the merchandise that the licensee intends to offer for sale; however the amount of the bond or deposit shall be not less than $1,000.00 nor more than $10,000.00. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 4, 2-8-2005) 
Secs. 58-65-58-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - HAWKERS AND PEDDLERS 

Sec. 58-91. - License required. 
    Every hawker and peddler desiring to engage in soliciting within the village is required to obtain a license. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 5, 2-8-2005) 
Sec. 58-92. - Application for license. 
(a)  Every hawker and peddler desiring to engage in soliciting within the village is required to make a written application upon a form provided by the chief of police of the village and filed with the chief. The application shall truthfully state in full the information required on the application, as follows: 
(1)  Name, address of the present place of residence and length of residence at such address, business address if other than the residence address, date of birth, and social security number. 
(2)  Address of the place of residence during the preceding three years, if other than the present address. 
(3)  Physical description of the applicant. 
(4)  Name and address of the person by whom the applicant is employed or whom he represents, and the length of time of such employment or representation. 
(5)  Name and address of each employer during the preceding three years, if other than the present employer. 
(6)  Description of the subject matter of the soliciting in which the applicant will engage and a description of the commodities or articles of merchandise in which the applicant intends to deal. 
(7)  Period of time for which the license is requested. 
(8)  The date, or approximate date, of the most recent previous application for a license under this article, if any. 
(9)  A list of all licenses or certificates of registration to conduct business as a hawker or peddler obtained by the applicant in Illinois in the 12 months preceding the date of filing of the application. 
(10)  A statement as to whether a license issued to the applicant under this article has been revoked within one year of the date of the application. 
(11)  A statement as to whether the applicant has been convicted of a violation of any provision of this article or the ordinances of any other municipality regulating soliciting within one year of the date of the application. 
(12)  A statement as to whether the applicant has ever been convicted of the commission of (i) a felony, or (ii), a misdemeanor involving dishonesty or false statements, under the laws of the State of Illinois or any other state, or under the laws of the United States, within five years of the date of the application. 
(13)  Fingerprinting of the applicant. 
(14)  Such additional information as the chief of police may deem necessary to process the application. 
(b)  Statements to be under oath. All statements made by the applicant under the application or in connection therewith shall be under oath. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 5, 2-8-2005) 
Sec. 58-93. - Fees. 
    The fee for a hawker or peddler license shall be $25.00 for a daily license, or $50.00 for a weekly license, nonrefundable, and the license shall state the expiration date thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 5, 2-8-2005) 
Secs. 58-94-58-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SOLICITING ON HIGHWAYS 

Sec. 58-121. - Permit required. 
    Every soliciting agency desiring to stand on a highway for the purpose of soliciting from the occupant of any vehicle is required to obtain a permit. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 6, 2-8-2005) 
Sec. 58-122. - Application for permit. 
    Every soliciting agency desiring to stand on a highway for the purpose of soliciting from the occupant of any vehicle is required to make a written application upon a form provided by the chief of police of the village and filed with the chief. The application shall truthfully state in full the information required on the application, as follows: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization, and of the persons who manage such organization and who will oversee the activity for which the permit is requested. 
(2)  The exact use for which the permit is requested. 
(3)  The date and times for which such permit is requested. 
(4)  The locations of the intersections within the village for which such permit is requested. 
(5)  The number of solicitors expected. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 6, 2-8-2005) 
Sec. 58-123. - Limitations, soliciting agency. 
(a)  A soliciting agency requesting a permit shall be: 
(1)  Registered with the Attorney General as a charitable organization as provided by "An Act to regulate solicitation and collection of funds for charitable purposes, providing for violations thereof, and making an appropriation therefore", approved July 26, 1963 as amended (225 ILCS 460/1 et seq.). 
(2)  Engaged in a statewide fund raising activity. 
(3)  Liable for any injuries to any person or property during the solicitation which is causally related to an act of ordinary negligence of the soliciting agent. 
(b)  Other restrictions. Soliciting agencies shall also comply with the following: 
(1)  Liability insurance. The soliciting agency shall provide written evidence that it has obtained insurance providing coverage for bodily injury liability, as well as property damage liability, in the amount of $1,000,000.00 for any individual and $2,000,000.00 for any occurrence, and such evidence shall name the village as an additional insured. 
(2)  Solicitation is only allowed at the intersection of Illinois Highway and Cedar Road and other intersections to be identified by the applicant and approved by the village that are completely owned by the village and are not regulated by traffic signals but are regulated by stop signs in all directions. Solicitation shall not interfere with traffic flow. 
(3)  Any person engaged in the act of solicitation shall be 16 years of age or more and wearing a high visibility vest. 
(4)  Solicitation is allowed on Fridays and Saturdays between 7:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., April 1st through September 30th, and between 7:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m., October 1 st through November 30th. 
(5)  The soliciting agency shall sign a hold harmless agreement provided by the village. 
(6)  The soliciting agency shall be allowed to solicit not more than one weekend in a calendar year. 
(7)  Only one soliciting on a highway permit shall be issued per weekend. 
(8)  The village reserves the right to accept or reject any application, and the soliciting agency must comply with all other policies and provisions the village may require. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 6, 2-8-2005; Ord. No. 1702, § 2, 10-11-2005); Ord. No. 2690, § 2, 1-22-2018) 
Chapter 62 - PLANNING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 38; floods, ch. 46; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74; subdivisions, ch. 78; utilities, ch. 94; vegetation, ch. 98; zoning, ch. 106. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 62-1-62-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLAN COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-261 et seq. 
State Law reference- Plan commissions generally, 65 ILCS 5/11-12-4 et seq. 

Sec. 62-31. - Established; membership, staffing and organization. 
    A plan commission is hereby authorized to be established. The creation, membership, staffing and organization shall be in accord with the provisions of the statutes of the state. 
(Code 1981, § 2-2-1) 
Sec. 62-32. - Jurisdiction. 
    The plan commission is hereby vested with the jurisdiction and authority to: 
(1)  Hear, consider and recommend to the village board matters dealing with amendments to the village zoning regulations. 
(2)  Hear, consider and recommend to the village board matters dealing with the granting of special use permits. 
(3)  Hear, consider and recommend to the village board matters dealing with the granting of approval for planned unit developments, as regulated in chapter 106. 
(4)  Consider and decide upon all matters which it is required to act upon under the terms of chapter 106. 
(5)  Prepare and recommend to the corporate authorities a comprehensive plan for the present and future development or redevelopment of the village. 
(6)  Establish reasonable standards of design for subdivisions and for resubdivisions of unimproved land and of areas subject to redevelopment in respect to public improvements. 
(7)  Establish reasonable requirements governing the location, width, course and surfacing of public streets and highways, alleys, ways for public service facilities, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, streetlights, parks, playgrounds, schoolgrounds, size of lots to be used for residential purposes, stormwater drainage, water supply and distribution, sanitary sewers, and sewage collection and treatment. 
(8)  Designate land suitable for annexation to the village and the recommended zoning classification for such land upon annexation. 
(9)  Recommend changes, from time to time, in the official comprehensive plan. 
(10)  Prepare and recommend to the corporate authorities, from time to time, plans for specific improvements in pursuance of the official comprehensive plan. 
(11)  Give aid to the village officials charged with the direction of projects for improvements embraced within the official plan, further the making of these projects, and, generally, promote the realization of the official comprehensive plan. 
(12)  Initiate, study and make recommendations regarding matters dealing with the planning of the community. 
(13)  Initiate, direct and review, from time to time, studies of the provisions of chapter 106, and make recommendations to the village board regarding any changes to chapter 106. 
(Code 1981, § 2-2-2) 
Sec. 62-33. - Meetings; rules of procedure; records. 
    All meetings of the plan commission shall be held at the call of the chairman and at such times as the plan commission may determine. All hearings conducted by the plan commission under chapter 106 shall be in accordance with the Illinois Compiled Statutes. In all proceedings of the plan commission provided for in chapter 106, the chairman, and in his absence the vice-chairman, shall have the power to administer oaths. All testimony by witnesses at any hearing provided for in chapter 106 shall be given under oath. The plan commission shall keep minutes of its proceedings, and shall also keep records of its hearings and other official actions. A copy of every rule or regulation, every amendment and special use, and every recommendation, order, requirement, decision or determination of the plan commission under chapter 106 shall be filed in the office of the building commissioner and shall be a public record. The plan commission shall adopt its own rules and procedures, not in conflict with chapter 106 or with applicable state statutes. 
(Code 1981, § 2-2-3) 
State Law reference- Open meetings, 5 ILCS 120/1 et seq. 
Secs. 62-34-62-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ZONING BOARD OF APPEALS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-261 et seq.; zoning, ch. 106. 
State Law reference- Zoning boards of appeal, 65 ILCS 5/11-13-3. 

Sec. 62-61. - Established; membership; term of members; officers; compensation of members. 
    A zoning board of appeals is hereby authorized to be established. The board shall consist of seven members appointed by the village president and subject to confirmation by the village board. The present members of the board shall serve until the expiration of their current terms. The successor to each member so appointed shall serve for a term of five years, such term expiring September 30 of the fifth year and at such time as a successor has been duly appointed and qualified. One of the members of the board shall be designated by the village president as chairman of the board, and shall hold his office as chairman until his successor is appointed and qualified. The chairman may appoint a secretary of the board, who shall keep the minutes and maintain the records of the board. The village president shall have the power to remove any member of the board for cause, upon written charges having been submitted and after a public hearing. Vacancies upon the board shall be filled for the unexpired term of the member whose place has become vacant, in the manner provided in this section for the appointment of such member. The members of the board shall serve without salary. 
(Code 1981, § 2-3-1) 
Sec. 62-62. - Jurisdiction. 
    The zoning board of appeals is hereby vested with the jurisdiction and authority to: 
(1)  Hear and decide appeals in which it is alleged that there is error in any order, requirement, decision, interpretation or determination (all referred to collectively in this article as "decision") made by the building commissioner under chapter 106, in the manner and subject to the standards set out in section 106-47; 
(2)  Hear and decide applications for variations from the terms of chapter 106, in the manner prescribed by and subject to the standards set out in section 106-46; and 
(3)  Hear and decide all other matters referred to it or upon which it is required to pass under chapter 106. 
(Code 1981, § 2-3-2) 
Sec. 62-63. - Meetings; rules of procedure; records. 
    All meetings of the zoning board of appeals shall be held at the call of the chairman and at such times as the board may determine. All hearings conducted by the board shall be open to the public. Any person may appear and testify at a hearing either in person or by duly authorized agent or attorney. All testimony shall be given under oath. The chairman, or in his absence the acting chairman, shall administer oaths and may compel the attendance of witnesses. The board shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote of each member upon each question, or, if absent or failing to vote, indicating such fact, and shall also keep records of its hearings and other official actions. A copy of every rule or regulation, every amendment or repeal thereof, and every order, requirement, decision or determination of the board shall be filed immediately in the office of the building commissioner and shall be a public record. The board shall adopt its own rules and procedures, not in conflict with chapter 106 or with the applicable statutes, and may select or appoint such officers as it deems necessary. 
(Code 1981, § 2-3-3) 
Sec. 62-64. - Finality of decisions. 
    All decisions and findings of the zoning board of appeals on appeals or upon applications for a variation, after a hearing, shall, in all instances, be final administrative decisions and shall be subject to judicial review as the law may provide. 
(Code 1981, § 2-3-4) 
Secs. 62-65-62-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SMALL BUSINESS COMMISSION[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2428, § 2, adopted March 27, 2017, amended the Code by repealing former art. IV, §§ 62-91-62-96, in its entirety. Former art. IV pertained to the economic development commission, and derived from the Code of 1981, §§ 2-6-1-2-6-6. 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-261 et seq.; businesses, ch. 22. 
State Law reference- Authority to create, 20 ILCS 620/9(l). 

Sec. 62-91. - Established; purpose. 
    There is hereby established a citizen's commission, which shall be known as the small business commission of the village, for the purpose of advising the mayor and board of trustees of the village regarding matters that impact small business owners within the village, as well as the structuring of sound economic development programs that benefit small businesses and small business owners within the village. The commission shall meet quarterly, make such recommendations as are appropriate, and communicate the same to the mayor and board of trustees. 
    The small business commission shall be purely advisory in nature, and shall not have any powers other than those explicitly set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2629, § 2, 3-27-2017) 
Sec. 62-92. - Use of volunteer services. 
    Recognizing that broad community involvement will help to ensure broad community support, the small business commission is hereby authorized to enlist the volunteer services of such other members of the community who shall assist the commissioners in actualizing the commission's goal of advising the mayor and board of trustees of the best manner in which to promote the sound economic growth of the village while benefitting local businesses. 
(Ord. No. 2629, § 2, 3-27-2017) 
Sec. 62-93. - Membership; term of members; chairman. 
(a)  Membership. The membership of the small business commission shall be composed of five commissioners and two ex officio members. 
(b)  Composition. 
(1)  The five commissioners shall be local business owners within the village and shall be appointed by the mayor; and 
(2)  The two ex officio members shall be the village's mayor and economic development coordinator. 
(c)  Terms. Each commissioner shall serve a term of two years, provided however, that two of the commissioners initially appointed shall serve three-year terms such that future commissioners will be appointed on a rotating basis. Once appointed, each commissioner shall serve until the expiration of their term, or as soon thereafter as their successor has been duly appointed and qualified. All appointments contemplated by this section shall be made, as much as possible, in April of each calendar year. 
(d)  Chairman. The mayor shall designate one of the commissioners, appointed at the outset, as the chairman of the commission. Thereafter, the mayor shall select one commissioner each April, after any new commissioners have been appointed and qualified, to serve as chairman for that calendar year. 
(e)  Removal. The commissioners shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor. Vacancies upon the commission shall be filled for the unexpired term of the member whose place has become vacant in the manner provided in this section for the appointment of such manner. In the event that the position of chairman shall become vacant for any reason, the mayor shall designate another commissioner as chairman for the remainder of the year. 
(Ord. No. 2629, § 2, 3-27-2017) 
Secs. 62-94-62-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PROCEDURE FOR ANNEXATION AGREEMENTS AND FEES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Annexation agreements, 65 ILCS 5/11-15.1-1 et seq. 

Sec. 62-121. - Petition for hearing. 
    All proposed annexation agreements submitted to the village pursuant to the Illinois Compiled Statutes for consideration and hearing thereon by the village shall be accompanied by a petition requesting the appropriate municipal authorities to conduct the appropriate hearings thereon, such application or petition to be signed by the record fee title owner of the real estate being the subject matter of such proposed annexation agreement or the duly authorized agent of such owner. If title to the land is vested in a land trust, the petition must be accompanied by an affidavit setting forth the names and addresses of all those having any part of the beneficial interest and power of direction with respect to the land trust on the date of filing of the petition. 
(Code 1981, § 1-12-1) 
Sec. 62-122. - Fees. 
(a)  Generally. All such petitions submitted in accordance with section 62-121 shall be accompanied by fees in accordance with the following schedule: 
(1)  Annexation. 
a.  Property containing 0-5 acres: $700.00. 
b.  Property containing 5.01-10 acres: $1,000.00 plus $75.00 per acre. 
c.  Property containing 10.01-50 acres: $1,500.00 plus $50.00 per acre. 
d.  Property containing 50.01-100 acres: $2,500.00 plus $40.00 per acre. 
e.  Property containing 100.01-320 acres: $3,500.00 plus $30.00 per acre. 
f.  Property containing 320.01 acres or more: $25.00 per acre. 
(2)  Annexation agreement: $250.00. 
(3)  Pre-annexation agreement: $250.00. 
(b)  Special hearing dates. The filing fees in subsection (a) of this section shall be applicable if the appropriate hearing upon such submission is to be conducted on the same evening which is a regular meeting date of the appropriate village authority involved, whether the meeting is to be held before the plan commission or the zoning board of appeals. If the hearing is to be held before the appropriate village authority at any time other than a regular meeting date, then the filing fees shall be applicable and such petition shall be accompanied by a $400.00 special meeting fee for a preannexation agreement. The plan commission, at its sole discretion, shall determine the date on which it shall conduct a hearing on the proposed annexation agreement, and it shall cause appropriate legal notices and public meeting notifications to be published and posted as provided for in the Illinois Compiled Statutes, as revised. 
(c)  Hearings before more than one agency. If the village is required to conduct hearings before both the plan commission and zoning board of appeals with respect to multiple matters concerning the same tract of land, i.e., multiple zoning changes on a single tract, rezoning request for the same tract, etc., and the hearings can be held on the same date, the petitioner shall be entitled to have the hearings held upon his payment of the filing fee referenced in this section and the security deposit for one such hearing, provided that the plan commission and zoning board are composed of substantially the same members and the meetings are held on the same date. In all other circumstances, the petitioner will be required to make separate payment for each initial hearing. 
(Code 1981, § 1-12-2; Ord. No. 1141, § 1, 4-23-1997; Ord. No. 1479, § 2, 6-25-2003) 
Sec. 62-123. - Security deposit for expenses of professional assistance. 
    In addition to the filing fees required under this article, the developer or owner submitting a petition shall deposit with the village a security deposit as set forth in section 18-5. 
(Code 1981, § 1-12-3; Ord. No. 2150, § 4, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 62-124. - Reimbursement of village for expenses of professional assistance. 
    In accordance with applicable state and local law, the village may require the applicant to execute and deliver to the village a professional fee agreement as set forth in section 18-5. 
(Code 1981, § 1-12-4; Ord. No. 2150, § 5, 12-21-2010) 
Chapter 66 - SECONDHAND GOODS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 66-1-66-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - GARAGE SALES 

Sec. 66-31. - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article shall be fined not less than $25.00 and not more than as provided in section 1-9. 
(Code 1981, § 3-12-3) 
Sec. 66-32. - Number of sales; length of sales; restriction on items offered for sale. 
    Any owner or occupant of a dwelling unit may conduct not more than a total of two garage sales (also known as patio sales, basement sales, yard sales, rummage sales, lawn sales, driveway sales, etc.) during any 12 consecutive months. Such sales shall extend not more than three days and shall be limited to household goods and furnishings which have been in use in the dwelling unit located on the premises on which sales are conducted, or which have been in use in another dwelling unit in the same community. No merchandise purchased for intentional sale or resale may be sold at a garage sale. 
(Code 1981, § 3-12-1) 
Sec. 66-33. - Signs. 
(a)  No more than three signs may be erected advertising any garage sale. 
(b)  No sign shall exceed 24 inches by 36 inches in size. 
(c)  No sign shall be erected on private property without the permission of the property owner. 
(d)  No garage sale sign shall be placed any closer than 15 feet to the edge of the pavement. In areas where sidewalks exist, signs shall be placed a minimum of two feet beyond the private property side of the edge of the sidewalk. 
(e)  No sign shall be allowed to remain for a duration of more than four days. 
(f)  The person holding such sale shall remove all signs advertising such sale at the end of the sale. 
(Code 1981, § 3-12-2) 
Secs. 66-34-66-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SCAVENGERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 66-61-66-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES 

Sec. 66-81. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Garbage, refuse and ashes shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to such terms under 65 ILCS 5/11-19-2, provided that the term "garbage" shall be held to include all rejected organic matter of whatever kind. 
    Person means any natural individual, firm, trust, partnership, association or corporation, in his or its own capacity, or as administrator, conservator, executor, trustee, receiver or other legal representative. 
    Scavenger means any person engaged in the collection, removal and disposal of garbage, refuse and ashes. 
(Code 1981, § 3-7-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 66-82. - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this division, in any case where a penalty is not otherwise specifically provided under this division, shall be punished by a fine of not less than $25.00 and not more than as provided in section 1-9 for each such offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed for each day that any such violation shall continue. 
(Code 1981, § 3-7-12) 
Sec. 66-83. - Application. 
    Every application for a license under this division shall be made in writing to the village clerk on a form provided for that purpose. Such application shall contain the name of the person desiring the license and the place of business of the applicant. If the applicant is a partnership or firm, the application shall contain the names and addresses of each of its members. If the applicant is a limited partnership, the application shall contain the names and residence addresses of each general partner thereof. If the applicant is a corporation, the application shall contain the names and addresses of the principal officers. The application shall also state the number and description of vehicles which the applicant intends to use or operate in the business and the method of disposal, and the place where the applicant intends to landfill. 
(Code 1981, § 3-7-3) 
Sec. 66-84. - Issuance. 
(a)  Every application under this division shall be transmitted by the village clerk to the president and board of trustees. No license shall be granted to any applicant therefor except upon approval of the president and board of trustees. 
(b)  Every license so approved shall be issued by the village clerk, and shall be made subject expressly to all the provisions of this division and such additional requirements as the president and board of trustees may impose. 
(Code 1981, § 3-7-4) 
Sec. 66-85. - Limitation on number of licenses. 
    The number of licenses issued under this division shall, from time to time, by the president and board of trustees of the village, be limited by resolution of that body, it being in the best interests of the public health, safety and welfare of the citizens of this community that a limited number of such licenses be issued and be enforced under this division at any one time in the village. 
(Code 1981, § 3-7-5) 
Sec. 66-86. - Term. 
    Every license granted under this division shall be in force for the term of one year, beginning on January 1 and continuing until December 31. The annual fees provided under this division shall be paid irrespective of when the license is issued, and no such fees shall be prorated or refunded. 
(Code 1981, § 3-7-6) 
Sec. 66-87. - Bond or deposit. 
    Every licensee under this division shall execute a bond to the village with good and sufficient sureties thereon as may be approved by the president and board of trustees, in the penal sum of $5,000.00, or such other sum as the president and board of trustees may from time to time prescribe, for the term of the license issued under this division or any renewal thereof, conditioned upon the faithful performance by the licensee of all duties imposed by law or under any agreement made with the village. In lieu of such bond, the licensee may deposit cash or direct general obligation securities of the United States of America with the village clerk, such deposit to be refunded upon full compliance by the licensee with the conditions mentioned in this section. 
(Code 1981, § 3-7-7) 
Sec. 66-88. - Insurance. 
(a)  Every applicant under this division shall submit satisfactory proof, in the form of a certificate of insurance issued by an insurer authorized to transact business in the state, showing that the applicant has procured comprehensive public liability insurance fully protecting the village against any loss, damage or liability that may result from the applicant's proposed operations in the village. Such insurance shall provide for limits of coverage of not less than $500,000.00 for single limit coverage for any general liability for any occurrence resulting from any one accident. 
(b)  The applicant shall also furnish proper proof, in the form of a certificate of insurance issued by an insurer authorized to transact business in the state, evidencing that the applicant has obtained workers compensation and occupational disease insurance fully protecting the village against any and all claims of employees, subcontractors and other persons, by reason of bodily injury or death, that may result from the applicant's proposed operations in the village. 
(c)  The applicant shall also furnish evidence of the expiration dates of the insurance coverages required under this section, and shall duly certify that such coverage shall not be cancelled or modified except upon ten days' written notice given to the village. Upon the cancellation, expiration or modification of any coverages required under this section without prior consent of the village, any license issued under this division to the applicant shall become void. 
(d)  All policies of insurance shall carry the village, a municipal corporation, as an additional insured. 
(Code 1981, § 3-7-8) 
Sec. 66-89. - Duties of licensee. 
    It shall be the duty of licensees under this division to comply fully with the provisions of this division and the terms and conditions of any agreement made by the licensee with the village respecting the collection, removal and disposal of garbage, refuse and ashes. 
(Code 1981, § 3-7-9) 
Sec. 66-90. - Collection vehicles. 
(a)  Any person owning or controlling any vehicle used for the collection and removal of garbage, refuse and ashes in the village shall cause all such vehicles, and all implements used in connection with the loading and unloading thereof, when not in use, to be stored and kept in such place and in such manner as not to create a nuisance, and shall cause all such vehicles and implements to be thoroughly disinfected and put in an inoffensive condition when so stored and not in use. 
(b)  Vehicles used for the collection of garbage, refuse and ashes must be of the all-metal and totally enclosed type. 
(c)  Such vehicles and implements shall be thoroughly disinfected at least once each week, whether in use or not, unless the vehicle or implement has not been used since the last disinfection thereof. 
(d)  No person owning or controlling any vehicle used for the collection and removal of garbage, refuse and ashes in the village shall cause or permit any such vehicle to be so loaded, to be in such defective condition, to be so out of repair, to be of such faulty construction, or to be so improperly driven or managed that any garbage, refuse or ashes with which such vehicle is loaded shall drop or fall out on any public way or other place in the village. Such vehicle, and any box, can or other receptacle carried therein or thereon, shall be constructed as to be strong and virtually airtight and watertight so as to prevent any such garbage, refuse or ashes from emitting any odor and so as to prevent any part of the contents or load thereof from falling, leaking or spilling therefrom. It shall be the duty of every person in possession or control of any such vehicle to replace at once on or in such vehicle any part of the contents thereof which shall or may have fallen, dropped or spilled from such vehicle, or from any box or receptacle conveyed thereon, upon any public way or other place whatever. 
(Code 1981, § 3-7-10) 
Sec. 66-91. - Disposal of garbage, refuse and ashes. 
    The garbage, refuse or ashes collected and removed by any scavenger licensed under this division shall under no circumstances be disposed of in any place in the village, or within one mile of the corporate limits thereof, except by approval of the president and board of trustees and subject to all applicable requirements of the ordinances, rules and regulations of the village and the agencies and instrumentalities thereof. 
(Code 1981, § 3-7-11) 
Chapter 70 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Removal of animal excrement, § 14-16; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 38; storage of combustible refuse, § 42-61; utilities, ch. 94. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 70-1-70-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ACCUMULATION, STORAGE, COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL OF REFUSE 

Sec. 70-31. - Purpose of article. 
    The purpose of this article is to regulate and control the accumulation, removal and disposal of refuse and to eliminate unhealthy, unsanitary and unsightly conditions in the village. 
(Code 1981, § 6-2-1) 
Sec. 70-32. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Landscape waste includes grass, garden clippings, leaves and twigs bundled in no more than four-foot lengths. 
    Recyclable materials means aluminum, tin/steel beverage cans, newspaper print, and clear, amber or green glass bottles and containers. 
    Refuse includes any solid waste, excluding engine blocks, transmissions, axles, tires, heavy metal parts, broken concrete, stone, clay, dirt, metal, swimming pools or refuse resulting from building construction or landscape waste, carpeting or material which will cause damage to equipment or injury to haulers, all of which excluded materials will be collected and removed by contractor; provided, however, that one large item of furniture or an appliance will be picked up if the item is set out on the scheduled pickup date. 
    Village administrator means the village administrator and his authorized agents. 
(Code 1981, § 6-2-2) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 70-33. - Penalty. 
    In addition to all other remedies, any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with any provision of this article shall be sentenced as provided in section 1-15 of this Code for each offense. 
(Code 1981, § 6-2-17; Ord. No. 2192, § 19, 8-22-2011) 
Sec. 70-34. - Accumulations of refuse. 
    No occupant, person, owner, owner's agent or tenant of any private or public premises shall permit refuse to accumulate on such premises except in covered containers or as provided in this article, and all such refuse should be removed once every seven days, or more often if necessary to protect the health of the inhabitants of the village. 
(Code 1981, § 6-2-3) 
Sec. 70-35. - Containers generally. 
(a)  Approved containers. 
(1)  Single-family dwellings. All single-family residential dwellings shall be required to place refuse in an official village prepaid disposal refuse bag, sold exclusively by local retail stores and bearing a logo as depicted in exhibit A to Ordinance No. 821, or by the rental of a village-approved 45-gallon toter from the contractor/hauler employed by the village to collect such refuse. 
(2)  Multifamily dwellings. All multifamily dwellings may utilize a dumpster, obtained from a refuse hauler, for the disposal of refuse. Multifamily dwellings may, at their option, elect, however, on an individual basis, to place refuse in the prepaid disposal refuse bag as provided for in subsection (a)(1) of this section in lieu of the dumpster. 
(3)  Recyclable materials. All recyclable materials shall be placed in a village recycling bin, obtained exclusively from the village and bearing a logo as depicted in exhibit B attached to Ordinance No. 821, on file in the office of the village clerk. 
(4)  Unapproved containers. Refuse and recyclables placed in other than approved containers will not be picked up. 
(b)  Use of containers. It is the goal of the village board of trustees to reduce volume in the area landfills and therefore encourage recycling. The fees for such collection at single-family and multifamily dwelling units shall be such as are set from time to time by the village board of trustees. It shall be unlawful to place refuse generated by residential properties in commercial or industrial property refuse containers. 
(c)  Commingling waste. Only recyclable materials shall be placed in any recycling bin. Refuse material only shall be placed in any refuse bag as described in this article. Only approved yard waste shall be placed in any yard waste containers as described in this article. 
(d)  Recycling encouraged. Recycling by all residents of the village is hereby encouraged by the village board of trustees. 
(e)  Issuance of recycling bins. It shall be the requirement of all residents of the village to recycle. All residential dwellings within the corporate boundaries of the village will initially be issued one recycling bin per residential unit. Thereafter, one bin will be issued per each residential unit at the time of issuance of a certificate of occupancy for new residential construction or at the time of annexation of existing residential property to the village. The cost of replacement of the recycling bin shall be borne by the occupant or owner of the residential unit. 
(f)  Ownership of recycling bins. All recycling bins shall remain the property of the village and shall not be removed from the property on which the dwelling unit is located without the written consent of the village administrator. 
(Code 1981, § 6-2-4) 
Sec. 70-36. - Location of containers. 
    It shall be the duty of every occupant, person, owner's agent or tenant in possession of any house, building, flat or apartment, and industrial, commercial, religious, political, social and nonprofit organizations in the village, to place garbage or refuse containers at a location as established by the village. 
(Code 1981, § 6-2-5) 
Sec. 70-37. - Frequency of collection; location of collection. 
(a)  All household garbage or refuse shall be collected and removed from the premises at least once every week. 
(b)  All refuse shall be collected from alleys wherever possible, and wherever the person desiring to dispose of such refuse owns or inhabits property abutting a passable alley, the refuse shall be deposited at the alley for collection. When no alley abuts the premises where the refuse is to be collected, then the collection shall be made from the curb immediately in front of the premises, unless otherwise specified by village officials. 
(Code 1981, § 6-2-6) 
Sec. 70-38. - Collection schedule; time limits for placing and removing containers. 
    The subdividing or apportioning of the village into various zones or areas for the collection of refuse by the operator or contractor performing the work for the village shall be subject to the board of trustees, and also the specific dates or days of the week upon which collection is to be made from each zone. No refuse which is to be deposited for collection at any curb shall be so placed more than 24 hours prior to the collection day, and no container shall so remain at the curb or alley 24 hours after the collection. 
(Code 1981, § 6-2-7) 
Sec. 70-39. - Refuse collectors to be licensed. 
    No person, except as provided in this article, acting as a private refuse disposal collector shall for compensation or hire remove refuse from any premises in the village, or transport refuse through the streets, alleys or public ways of the village, or dump, incinerate or in any manner dispose of refuse, or contract for any such removal, transportation or disposal of refuse, without first having secured a license for such services from the village clerk. 
(Code 1981, § 6-2-8) 
Sec. 70-40. - Notice to remove garbage or debris; removal by village. 
(a)  Authority of board of trustees. From time to time, as deemed necessary, the board of trustees may direct that garbage and debris be removed from private property within the corporate limits of the village. 
(b)  Service of notice. Upon such direction, the building commissioner shall give written notice by United States mail to the owner of the property upon which garbage or debris exists. If the name of the owner of the property cannot be determined, the building commissioner shall give such notice to the last assessee of the general real estate taxes on the real estate. 
(c)  Contents of notice. The notice to be given by the building commissioner shall designate the real estate, and the garbage or debris thereon to be removed, and shall provide that if the garbage or debris is not removed from the real estate within ten days after the posting of such notice the village will cause the garbage or debris to be removed and collect the reasonable cost thereof from the owner of the real estate. 
(d)  Removal by village. Upon the failure, refusal or neglect of the owner of any real estate upon which garbage or debris exists to remove the garbage or debris within ten days after the posting of notice as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the building commissioner shall notify the appropriate village employees to remove, or cause to be removed, the garbage or debris from the property, and such employees or contractor shall forthwith cause the garbage and debris to be removed. 
(e)  Billing. The building commissioner, after removal of garbage and debris from any private property pursuant to the provisions of this section, shall designate in writing to the village collector the reasonable cost incurred in the removal of the garbage and debris. The village collector shall then bill the owner of the real estate for the reasonable cost of the removal of the debris, posting the bill by United States mail. 
(f)  Filing of notice of lien. If the owner of any real estate from which garbage and debris has been removed pursuant to the provisions of this section fails to pay the cost thereof within 15 days after posting of the bill for the removal, the village clerk shall cause a notice of lien to be filed in the office of the recorder of deeds of the county, which notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out: 
(1)  A description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof; 
(2)  The amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the service; and 
(3)  The date when such cost and expense was incurred by the village. 
(g)  Foreclosure of lien. If the cost incurred by the village for the removal of any garbage or debris from private property pursuant to the terms of this section is not paid by the owner of the real estate within 18 months from the date of the filing of the notice of lien therefor, the village clerk shall advise the board of trustees of the failure to pay such cost, to enable it to designate whether foreclosure of the lien for the cost should be commenced. 
(Code 1981, § 6-2-9) 
Sec. 70-41. - Fees and charges. 
(a)  Pickup of recyclable materials. All owners of residential property within the village will be billed for the pickup and disposal of recyclable materials at a rate of $2.65 per month per single-family or multifamily dwelling unit. 
(b)  Garbage bags and toters. Wholesale and retail charges for official village garbage bags and the price of rental for the 45-gallon village-approved toter shall be set by contract upon the acceptance of a qualified bid and the execution of a three-year contract between the village and the contractor/hauler. 
(Code 1981, § 6-2-10) 
Sec. 70-42. - Depositing waste on public property or property of another. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of his refuse or landscape waste upon the property of another or on public rights-of-way or public property, without the consent of the owner, for the purpose of having such refuse or landscape waste picked up by a scavenger. 
(Code 1981, § 6-2-11) 
Sec. 70-43. - Ownership of waste placed for collection. 
    All refuse, landscape waste and recyclable materials collected in accordance with the terms of this article shall become and be the property of the village as soon as the material is picked up or otherwise placed in the contractor's vehicle. 
(Code 1981, § 6-2-12) 
Sec. 70-44. - Unlawful removal of recyclable materials. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, except a refuse collector contracting with the village, to remove any item of recyclable materials placed in or adjacent to village recycling containers. 
(Code 1981, § 6-2-13) 
Sec. 70-45. - Removing or damaging recycling container. 
    Except as authorized by the village board of trustees, it shall be unlawful for any person to remove any village recycling container from the residential premises at which it is located or to damage any village recycling container. 
(Code 1981, § 6-2-14) 
Sec. 70-46. - Counterfeit refuse bags or toters. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture, sell, distribute, lease, give away or possess a counterfeit or replicated official village refuse bag or village-approved toter. 
(Code 1981, § 6-2-15) 
Sec. 70-47. - Disposal of landscape waste. 
    Landscape waste materials shall not be commingled with refuse or recyclable materials, but shall be disposed of in compliance with state law. 
(Code 1981, § 6-2-16) 
Cross reference- Landscaping requirements, § 106-421 et seq. 
Chapter 74 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance dedicating, accepting the dedication of, naming, establishing, locating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street, alley, public way or public park in the village saved from repeal, § 1-19(3); any ordinance establishing or prescribing grades of the village saved from repeal, § 1-19(7); any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor saved from repeal, § 1-19(8); buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 38; floods, ch. 46; peddlers and solicitors, ch. 58; planning, ch. 62; subdivisions, ch. 78; telecommunications, ch. 86; traffic and vehicles, ch. 90; utilities, ch. 94; vegetation, ch. 98; vehicles for hire, ch. 102; zoning, ch. 106. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 74-1. - Deposit of injurious materials, snow or other substances on street, right-of-way or sidewalk. 
(a)  Definitions. For purposes of this section, the terms "road" and "highway" shall include the paved surface together with the shoulders and ditches adjacent thereto within the road or highway right-of-way. 
(b)  Deposit of injurious materials; deposit of ice or snow.
