(1)  No person shall throw or deposit upon any road or highway any glass, bottles, nails, scrap metal, wire, cans or other substance or material likely to cause injury to any person or damage to any vehicle upon such road or highway. 
(2)  No person shall throw, blow, shovel or plow ice or snow onto any street or public way or onto any sidewalk or property of another person, or onto any other place which would create a hazard to vehicular traffic or a danger to pedestrians. 
(c)  Materials deposited by vehicles. No person shall deposit or permit to fall from any vehicle any garbage, refuse, mud, clay, soil, gravel, rock, stone, sand or similar material upon any road or highway. 
(d)  Removal of materials. Any person who shall violate any provision of subsection (b) or (c) of this section shall immediately remove or cause to be removed from the road or highway any such material or substance specified in this section and shall immediately restore the surface of such road or highway to a clean and safe condition at the sole expense of such person in violation of this section. 
(e)  Penalty. In addition to all other remedies, any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with any provision of this section shall be sentenced as provided in section 1-15 of this Code for each offense. 
(Code 1981, § 7-1-1; Ord. No. 2192, § 20, 8-22-2011) 
Secs. 74-2-74-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CULVERTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 74-31. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates or neglects or refuses to comply with or who resists or opposes the enforcement of any of the provisions of this article shall be fined not less than $10.00 and not more than as provided in section 1-9 for each offense, and every person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for every day on which such violation, neglect or refusal shall continue. 
(Code 1981, § 7-1-2.F) 
Sec. 74-32. - Obstruction of drainage prohibited; culverts required. 
    No person shall, in any manner, obstruct or alter the flow of surface drainage water upon the streets or within the drainage ditches or storm sewers upon the public rights-of-way within the confines of the corporate limits of the village. All persons, before constructing or making any crossing of any such surface drainage ditch with a private driveway, sidewalk or other similar crossing which might or could obstruct the flow of water within any such drainage ditch, shall install at such crossing a surface drainage culvert of sufficient size to carry the water within the drainage ditch. 
(Code 1981, § 7-1-2.A) 
Sec. 74-33. - Inspection; correction of defects. 
    The public works superintendent or his representative shall make an inspection of the site of the culvert to be installed, enlarged, altered, constructed, repaired or removed prior to the issuance of the permit provided for in this article, and shall make such additional inspections as may be necessary and reasonable during the operations for which the permit is issued and shall make a final inspection of the site after the installation, enlargement, alteration, construction, repair or removal provided for in the permit is completed. If such installation, enlargement, alteration, construction, repair or removal of any culvert is not done in reasonable compliance with the application in a good and workmanlike manner so that the culvert shall operate properly, the person to whom such permit is issued shall make such alterations as may be required to cause conformance with the application so that the culvert exists in good operating condition. 
(Code 1981, § 7-1-2.E) 
Secs. 74-34-74-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - INSTALLATION PERMIT 

Sec. 74-51. - Required; expeditious completion of work. 
    No person shall commence the installation, enlargement, alteration, construction, repair or removal of any surface drainage culvert or similar structure, or any part thereof, in or upon the streets or public rights-of-way in the village unless and until a permit for such installation, enlargement, alteration, construction, repair or removal shall first be obtained by the person desiring to do such operations, or his agent, from the building and zoning administrator for new construction and the public works superintendent for replacement culverts. It shall further be unlawful to proceed with such installation, enlargement, alteration, construction, repair or removal unless such permit shall first have been obtained. If, after such permit has been granted, the operations called for by the permit are not commenced within 90 days after the date thereof, or if such operations are not completed within a reasonable time, then such permit shall be void and no operations thereunder shall be commenced or completed until a new permit shall be issued, and fees as fixed in this division for the original permit shall be paid for such new permit. 
(Code 1981, § 7-1-2.B) 
Sec. 74-52. - Application; issuance; plans and specifications. 
    Application for the permit required by this division shall be made by the person desiring the permit, or his agent, to the public works superintendent for replacement culverts and to the building and zoning administrator for new culverts. When such application is made, plans and specifications shall be submitted for examination and approval by the public works superintendent, who shall then issue or cause to be issued a permit and shall file such application. The plans and specifications shall conform with the rules and regulations of the village, as promulgated by the village and the public works superintendent. 
(Code 1981, § 7-1-2.D) 
Sec. 74-53. - Fee. 
    The fee for the issuance of each such permit as provided for in this division shall be $5.00. 
(Code 1981, § 7-1-2.C) 
Secs. 74-54-74-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RIGHT-OF-WAY ENCROACHMENT 

Sec. 74-81. - Definitions. 
    Construction easement area means the area lying between the right-of-way limits and the platted street limits within the village, by concurrence in the establishment of the right-of-way lines, will permit the state to enter to perform all necessary construction operations. 
    Encroachment means any building, fence, sign or other structure or object of any kind (with the exception of utilities and public road signs) which is placed, located or maintained in, on, under or over any portion of the right-of-way or the roadway right-of-way where no right-of-way line has been established. 
    Right-of-way means those areas within the right-of-way lines established jointly by the village and state which will be free of encroachments, except for permissible encroachments as defined in this section. 
    Roadway right-of-way means those areas existing or acquired by dedication or by fee simple for highway purposes; also, the areas acquired by temporary easement during the time the easement is in effect. 
(Code 1981, § 7-1-3.A) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 74-82. - Penalty. 
    In addition to all other remedies, any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with any provision of this article shall be sentenced as provided in section 1-15 of this Code for each offense. 
(Code 1981, § 7-1-3.F; Ord. No. 2192, § 21, 8-22-2011) 
Sec. 74-83. - Encroachments prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or cause to be erected, or to retain or cause to be retained, any encroachment, except as provided in section 74-85, within the limits of the right-of-way, or the roadway right-of-way where no right-of-way lines have been established. 
(Code 1981, § 7-1-3.B) 
Sec. 74-84. - Location of right-of-way lines. 
    Right-of-way lines shall be established along the edge of sidewalks closest to the edge of the roadway. 
(Code 1981, § 7-1-3.C) 
Sec. 74-85. - Temporary encroachments. 
    Revocable permits may be issued by the village for the temporary retention of permissible encroachments. 
(Code 1981, § 7-1-3.D) 
Sec. 74-86. - Additional regulations. 
    This article is intended to and shall be in addition to all other ordinances, rules and regulations of the village concerning encroachments and shall not be construed as repealing or rescinding any other ordinance or part of any ordinance unless in direct conflict therewith. 
(Code 1981, § 7-1-3.E) 
Secs. 74-87-74-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EXCAVATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 74-111. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not less than $25.00 and not more than as provided in section 1-9. 
(Code 1981, § 7-2-14) 
Sec. 74-112. - Restoration requirements for contractors doing work for village. 
    Contractors with the village for the construction of sewers or water mains, or for the laying of sewer or water main pipes, shall not be required to make any money deposit when obtaining permits for excavations, but any moneys at any time due such contractors from the village on their contracts, or so much as may be required to complete the backfilling, filling or refilling of the excavations and the restoration of the street, highway, avenue or alley to good repair and condition, shall be retained by the village and used for such purpose, and no contract for such work shall be finally settled and paid for in full until after the production of a written certificate of the duly authorized agent of the village that the excavation has been properly filled and the surface of the street, highway, avenue or alley at the place of such excavation restored to good repair and condition. 
(Code 1981, § 7-2-8) 
Sec. 74-113. - Removal of material from streets. 
    No person shall remove any material from any street of the village and use the material for any other purpose than the grading or improvement of such street. 
(Code 1981, § 7-2-9) 
Sec. 74-114. - Utility mains, pipes and connections to be installed prior to paving. 
    When any portion of any street, highway, avenue or alley within the village is ordered paved with brick, asphalt, concrete or other material by the village board, it shall be the duty of every person to take notice of such order and promptly, before any portion of any street, highway, avenue or alley is paved, to make all excavations necessary to laying gas, sewer, water or other mains or pipes or connections therewith; provided that every person shall, in the making of any such excavations, comply strictly with all provisions of this article and other ordinances of the village governing excavations in streets, highways, avenues and alleys then existing. 
(Code 1981, § 7-2-10) 
Sec. 74-115. - Restoration by village upon failure of permittee to complete work. 
    All the work of backfilling or refilling excavations and replacing the pavement and restoring such street, highway, avenue or alley to as good repair and condition as it was before any digging or excavation therein, if not completed under supervision of the duly authorized agent of the village within the time specified in granting such permit, shall be done by the village, and the costs thereof shall be deducted from the money deposited as required by section 74-145, and the balance of such money, if any, shall be repaid to the depositor by the village clerk upon the written order, report and direction of the village president, and not otherwise. 
(Code 1981, § 7-2-11) 
Sec. 74-116. - Barricades, lights and other warning devices. 
(a)  Required. It shall be the responsibility of the person making application as prescribed in this article to erect proper barricades, guards, flags and amber lights around all encroachments and/or open excavations in accordance with the Illinois Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices or as directed by the village engineer or his designee. 
(b)  Unauthorized removal. No person shall, without the consent of a duly authorized agent of the village in writing, or without the written consent of the person superintending the alterations, repairs or paving described in subsection (a) of this section, throw down, displace or remove any of the barriers and guards required by subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1981, § 7-2-12) 
Sec. 74-117. - Approval of pavement cuts. 
    No open cut or excavation through the surface of any paved street or alley within the village will be allowed as part of the permit described in this article without approval of the village board of trustees. 
(Code 1981, § 7-2-13) 
Secs. 74-118-74-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 74-141. - Required; fee; term; issuance when ground is frozen. 
(a)  No person shall dig, excavate, auger or tunnel under or within the defined public right-of-way within the village unless such person shall have first obtained a permit therefor. The charge or fee payable to the village for the issuance of any one permit shall be $50.00. The permit defined in this section shall remain in effect for six months from the date of approval by the village engineer unless additional time is specifically requested at the time of application. 
(b)  No permit described in this section shall be granted by the village engineer when the ground is frozen to a depth of 12 inches or more, unless in case of extreme emergency, and then only in obedience to a resolution of the village board duly passed by the village board in an open meeting and approved by the village president. 
(Code 1981, § 7-2-1) 
Sec. 74-142. - Application. 
(a)  Any person desiring to obtain the permit mentioned in this division shall make written application for the permit to the village engineer, stating specifically the place, extent and purpose of such excavation, with full specifications for the excavation, an estimate of the cost thereof, when the work of excavating will be commenced, and the estimated time of completion, together with an agreement on the part of such person that he will furnish and advance to the village a money deposit as required by section 74-145 and that such person will authorize, permit and allow the village, out of such deposit, to repay itself the cost and expense incurred by the village in filling the excavation and restoring the street, highway, avenue or alley to those village standards as detailed in chapter 78. 
(b)  The village engineer shall procure and keep on hand for the use of applicants a supply of printed blank applications for permits, and such other blanks as may be necessary and expedient to the full and complete performance of the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1981, § 7-2-2) 
Sec. 74-143. - Bonds. 
(a)  In all cases when the village has granted to any person the privilege of laying water or sewer mains and services or other pipes or mains in the streets of the village, it shall be the duty of such person to file with the village clerk a bond to the village, with two sureties to be approved by the village president, in such penal sums as the village board may direct, conditioned to safely guard all excavations made in laying such pipes or mains in the manner provided and to fill such excavations as soon as the character of the work will permit and without unnecessary or unreasonable delay, and to permanently restore the surface of such street to at least the same condition as before such excavations were made within five working days from commencement of the excavation. The village engineer may, at his discretion, allow a time extension to the five days due to weather conditions. 
(b)  Upon completion of the street surface improvements, a surety bond or security of 100 percent of the estimated cost of the surface improvements shall be given to the village. The village will hold this for 12 months after final completion of the work as a guarantee against any defect in material or workmanship furnished in connection with such improvement and not discernible at the time of the final approval of such improvement and to guarantee against any damage by reason of settling of the ground or base thereof. After the termination of the 12 months, the surety shall be refunded to the depositor if no defects have developed. If defects have developed, then the balance of such deposit shall be refunded after reimbursement of the village for any amounts expended by it in the curing of such defects. 
(c)  During the course of time from commencement of the excavation to the five-working-day limit for completion of the excavation, the excavated area shall be temporarily maintained on a daily basis by the contractor to provide suitable driving conditions as determined by the public works superintendent. If, in the opinion of the public works superintendent, this area is not properly maintained, he shall notify the person to respond within a reasonable time as determined by the public works superintendent. If the area has not been temporarily maintained to the satisfaction of the village engineer or public works superintendent, village personnel shall perform this work, and all costs in labor and material shall be reimbursed to the village. 
(d)  All excavations which occur under an existing surety bond or security along with other improvements such as subdivision improvements shall be exempt from the requirements of this section. 
(Code 1981, § 7-2-3) 
Sec. 74-144. - Liability insurance. 
    No permit shall be issued or continued in operation unless and until there is in full force and effect a liability insurance policy issued by a responsible insurance company authorized to do business in the state, in the minimum amount of $1,000,000.00 per occurrence, $2,000,000.00 products and completed operations, and a $3,000,000.00 policy aggregate. The policy shall be primary and non-contributory and include a waiver of subrogation. The policy shall name as an additional insured the village, its employees, elected officials, agents and representatives. A 30-day notice shall be given to the village prior to cancellation of the insurance. A certificate of insurance conforming to the requirements set forth in this section shall be deposited with the village engineer prior to the issuance of any certificate, license, or permit as provided in this division. 
(Code 1981, § 7-2-4; Ord. No. 1703, § 1, 11-8-2005) 
Sec. 74-145. - Deposit. 
(a)  The village engineer may grant a permit to any person making application as prescribed in this division to perform such work as described in section 74-141, provided that such person shall deposit with the village engineer such sum of money as the village engineer shall estimate to be the cost and expense of refilling the ditch, trench or excavation proposed to be made, and the repairing of the pavement at the place of such excavation in the street, highway, avenue or alley, so as to restore the street, highway, avenue or alley in accordance with village standards as detailed in chapter 78. 
(b)  This deposit shall be retained by the village for a period of one year after the completion, as approved by the village engineer, of that work described in the application. This deposit shall be retained as surety for the warranty of the work, and may be used by the village as described in section 74-142. 
(Code 1981, § 7-2-5) 
Sec. 74-146. - Records. 
    It shall be the duty of the village engineer to keep a correct record of all permits granted by him under the provisions of this division, which record shall show the name of the person to whom the permit was granted, the place, nature, extent, character and purpose of the excavation, when the excavation is to be made, the estimated cost of refilling, backfilling and repavement, the time required to complete the excavation, the amount of money deposited with the village engineer, and the date of the permit. 
(Code 1981, § 7-2-6) 
Sec. 74-147. - Water and sewer connections. 
    No person shall make any excavation in any street or alley of the village for the purpose of making connection with any water main or sewer pipe, or for the purpose of repairing any such connection, without a permit issued by the village. All excavations for such purposes, and the replacing of the matter excavated, shall be done under the supervision of a duly authorized agent of the village, at the expense of the person requiring such work to be done. 
(Code 1981, § 7-2-7) 
Secs. 74-148-74-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - NUMBERING BUILDINGS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18. 

Sec. 74-171. - Uniform system established. 
    There is hereby established a uniform system of numbering houses and buildings fronting on all streets, avenues and public ways in the village, and all houses and buildings shall be numbered in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1981, § 9-4-1) 
Sec. 74-172. - Baselines. 
(a)  North and south. 
(1)  Frontage of all lots and undivided property facing on streets running north and south shall be numbered from a baseline, which is Haven Avenue running east and west through the village, beginning with number "100" on the north line of Haven Avenue and increasing numerically toward the north and beginning with number "100" on the south line of Haven Avenue and increasing numerically toward the south. 
(2)  The even numbers on streets running north and south shall be on the east side of the street, and the odd numbers shall be on the west side of the street. 
(3)  That portion of streets running north and south lying north of the baseline shall bear the prefix "north," and that portion of such streets lying south of the baseline shall bear the prefix "south." 
(b)  East and west. 
(1)  Frontage of all lots and undivided property facing on streets running east and west shall be numbered from a baseline, which is Cedar Road extending north and south through the village, beginning with number "100" on the east line of Cedar Road and increasing numerically toward the east and beginning with number "100" on the west line of Cedar Road and increasing numerically toward the west. 
(2)  The even numbers on streets running east and west shall be on the south side of the street, and the odd numbers shall be on the north side of the street. 
(3)  That portion of streets running east and west lying west of the baseline shall bear the prefix "west," and that portion of such streets lying east of the baseline shall bear the prefix "east." 
(Code 1981, § 9-4-2) 
Sec. 74-173. - Assignment of numbers. 
(a)  There shall be assigned to each and every block north or south or east or west of the baseline established by this article 100 numbers. The numbers within the first block shall be from 100 to 199 and the numbers in each succeeding block shall increase from the baseline in units of 100, namely, the first block shall be 100 to 199, the second block shall be 200 to 299, the third block shall be 300 to 399, etc. One number shall be assigned to each 25 feet of frontage. 
(b)  Where blocks of different lengths occur on opposite sides of a street, the numbers on both sides shall be assigned on the basis of the shorter block unless the village board shall otherwise determine. 
(c)  Where any building has more than one door serving separate occupants, a separate number shall be assigned to each door serving a separate occupant, provided the building is 25 feet or more in width. If the building is not 25 feet or more in width and the entrances are not that far apart, the next consecutive number shall be marked fractional. 
(d)  Buildings fronting on two or more streets shall have a number assigned only to the main entrance unless other entrances serve different occupants. 
(Code 1981, § 9-4-3) 
Sec. 74-174. - Numbering on streets not extending to baseline. 
    All streets not extending through to the baseline established by this article shall be assigned the same relative numbers as if the street had extended through to the baseline. 
(Code 1981, § 9-4-4) 
Sec. 74-175. - Placement of numbers required; size and location of numbers. 
(a)  The village board shall cause the necessary survey to be made and there shall be assigned to each house and building located on any street, avenue or parkway in the village its respective number under the uniform system provided for in this article. When the survey has been completed and each house and building has been assigned its respective number, the owner, occupant or agent shall place or cause to be placed on each house or building controlled by him the number assigned under the uniform system provided for in this article. 
(b)  Such numbers shall be placed within 20 days after the assigning of the proper number. 
(c)  Each of the figures of each such number assigned to any residence or building shall be not less than 21/2 inches high and (except as to the figure "1") not less than 11/2 inches wide, and such numbers shall be furnished by the property owner. 
(d)  The number shall be conspicuously placed immediately above, on or at the side of the proper door of each building so that it can be plainly seen from the street. Whenever any building is situated more than 50 feet from the street line, the number of each building shall be conspicuously displayed at the street line near the walk, driveway or common entrance to such building so as to be easily discernible from the street. 
(Code 1981, § 9-4-5) 
Sec. 74-176. - Addition of suffix to number. 
    Where only one number can be assigned to any house or building, and the owner, occupant or agent of such house or building desires a distinctive number for the upper and lower portion of any such house or building, or for any part of such house or building fronting on any street, such owner, occupant or agent shall use the suffix "A," "B," etc., as may be required. 
(Code 1981, § 9-4-6) 
Sec. 74-177. - Map. 
    For the purpose of facilitating correct numbering, a plat book or map of all streets, avenues and public highways within the village showing the proper numbers of all lots or houses fronting upon all such streets, avenues or highways shall be prepared and kept on file in the office of the village clerk. These plats shall be open to inspection of all persons during the office hours of the clerk. 
(Code 1981, § 9-4-7) 
Sec. 74-178. - Duty of clerk to provide information. 
    It shall be the duty of the village clerk to inform any party applying therefor of the numbers belonging to or embraced within the limits of such lot or property, as provided in this article. 
(Code 1981, § 9-4-8) 
Sec. 74-179. - New buildings. 
    Whenever any house, building or structure shall be erected or located in the village after the work of establishing a uniform system of house numbering has been completed, it shall be the duty of the owner to procure the correct number from the village clerk as designated for the property and to immediately attach the number so assigned upon the building, as provided by this article. 
(Code 1981, § 9-4-9) 
Sec. 74-180. - Responsibility for placing numbers. 
    It is hereby made the duty of the owner, agent or person in possession of every building in the village to number it in the manner provided in this article. 
(Code 1981, § 9-4-10) 
Sec. 74-181. - Failure to place number. 
    If the owner or occupant of any building required to be numbered pursuant to the provisions of this article shall neglect, for a period of 60 days, to duly attach and maintain the proper number on the subject building, the village building and zoning administrator shall serve upon him a notice requiring such owner or occupant to properly number the building, and if he neglects to do so for a period of ten days after the service of such notice he shall be deemed to have violated this article. In addition to all other remedies, any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with any provision of this section shall be fined as provided in section 1-15 of this Code for each offense. 
(Code 1981, § 9-4-11; Ord. No. 2192, § 22, 8-22-2011) 
Sec. 74-182. - Defacing or removing numbers. 
    In addition to all other remedies, any person who shall willfully deface or remove any number placed upon any building in conformity with this article shall be sentenced as provided in section 1-15 of this Code for each offense. 
(Code 1981, § 9-4-12; Ord. No. 2192, § 23, 8-22-2011) 
Secs. 74-183-74-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PARADES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 90. 

Sec. 74-211. - Violations; penalty. 
    Any person who shall: 
(1)  Participate in a parade, march, procession or race for which a permit has not been issued in accordance with the provisions of this article; 
(2)  Participate in a parade, march, procession or race contrary to or in violation of the provisions of the permit issued for such parade, march, procession or race; 
(3)  Knowingly give false information on the application for the issuance of a permit as provided in this article; or 
(4)  In any other manner violate the provisions of this article; 
shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not less than $25.00 and not more than as provided in section 1-9 for each offense. 
(Code 1981, § 4-5-6) 
Sec. 74-212. - Permit required; fee. 
(a)  No person shall conduct, carry on or participate in any parade, march, procession or race upon the property of the village, or upon the streets, highways, alleys, sidewalks, rights-of-way or parkways within the corporate limits of the village, unless and until a permit for such parade, march, procession or race has been issued in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  The fee for the issuance of each such permit shall be $5.00. 
(Code 1981, § 4-5-1) 
Sec. 74-213. - Application for permit. 
    Any person who shall desire to conduct or carry on a parade, march, procession or race as provided in section 74-212 shall, not less than 20 days and not more than 60 days prior to the date on which such parade, march, procession or race shall take place, cause a written application to be filed with the chief of police for the issuance of a permit for such parade, march, procession or race. Such application shall be signed by the applicant and shall set forth: 
(1)  The name, address and age of the applicant. 
(2)  The date on which such parade, march, procession or race shall take place. 
(3)  The time or hour during which such parade, march, procession or race shall take place. 
(4)  The place of commencement and termination of such parade, march, procession or race. 
(5)  The route which such parade, march, procession or race shall follow. 
(6)  The purpose of such parade, march, procession or race. 
(7)  The name and address of the person sponsoring such parade, march, procession or race. 
(8)  The estimated maximum number of people, vehicles, animals or the like which will participate or take part in such parade, march, procession or race. 
(Code 1981, § 4-5-2) 
Sec. 74-214. - Issuance of permit; contents; conditions. 
(a)  Issuance; contents. The permit provided for in this article shall be issued by the chief of police to the person sponsoring such parade, march, procession or race as disclosed in the application and shall set forth: 
(1)  The date and time during which such parade, march, procession or race shall take place. 
(2)  The point of origin, route and termination of such parade, march, procession or race. 
(b)  Date and time of event; compliance with permit. The permit, when issued, shall be valid for only the date of or alternate day of the event and during the period of time as set forth therein, and the parade, march, procession or race for which such permit is so issued shall be conducted or carried on only upon the route and shall originate and terminate all as set forth in the permit. No such permit shall be issued for a parade, march, procession or race between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. on any day of the week. 
(c)  Identification of traffic control vehicles. For identification purposes, any vehicle used by organizers of an event for traffic control or traffic direction must display a placard or sign on both sides of the vehicle identifying the vehicle as a participant in the event. 
(d)  Approval of route. The requested route of the parade, march, procession or race is subject to approval of the chief of police. 
(Code 1981, § 4-5-3) 
Sec. 74-215. - Liability insurance. 
    In addition to the requirements in section 74-214, the applicant for a permit under this article shall present to the chief of police written evidence that he has obtained insurance providing coverage for bodily injury liability, as well as property damage liability, in the amount of $1,000,000.00 for any occurrence, and such evidence shall name the village as an additional insured. 
(Code 1981, § 4-5-4) 
Sec. 74-216. - Exemption of funeral processions. 
    Anything contained to the contrary notwithstanding, the provisions of this article shall not, nor are they intended to, apply to funeral processions. 
(Code 1981, § 4-5-5) 
Chapter 78 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- The standard details referred to in this chapter are not printed herein, but are on file and available for public inspection in the village offices. 
Cross reference- Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision of the village saved from repeal, § 1-19(9); buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 38; floods, ch. 46; planning, ch. 62; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74; utilities, ch. 94; vegetation, ch. 98; zoning, ch. 106. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 78-1. - Purpose of chapter; statutory authority. 
(a)  This chapter regulating the subdivision of land is hereby made a part of the official plan of the village and contiguous areas. The purpose of these regulations is to provide for: 
(1)  The harmonious development of the village and its environs. 
(2)  The coordination of streets within new subdivisions with other existing or planned streets. 
(3)  The dedication and acceptance of land required for schools, parks, playgrounds and other public uses. 
(4)  The preparation of subdivision plans and the procedure for the submittal, approval and recording of subdivision plats in and about the village. 
(b)  Such regulations shall be provided for in accordance with the authority vested in the village under the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/1-1-1 et seq., as it now exists or is hereafter amended. 
(Code 1981, § 11-1-1) 
Sec. 78-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Accepted public street means any street duly accepted by the board of trustees of the village for maintenance by the village. 
    Alley means a public or private way, at the rear or side of property, permanently reserved as a means of secondary vehicular access to abutting property. Frontage on an alley shall not be construed as satisfying the requirements of this chapter related to frontage on a dedicated street. 
    Approved street means any street, whether public or private, meeting standards and specifications of the village. 
    Building line means a line within a lot or other parcel of land, so designated on the plat of the proposed subdivision. 
    Collector street and secondary street mean those existing streets designated as such on the official plan of the village, and streets proposed as collector streets in new subdivisions which are designed with a right-of-way width of 66 feet to 80 feet, for access of traffic from several minor streets to a major street. 
    Commission means the plan commission of the village. 
    Condominium means any property submitted to the provisions of the Condominium Property Act, 765 ILCS 605/1 et seq., as it now exists or may from time to time hereafter be amended. 
    Construction traffic means any vehicle with a GVW (gross vehicle weight) in excess of 8,000 pounds delivering material or equipment to a construction site. 
    Crosswalkway means a strip of land dedicated to public use, which is reserved across a block to provide pedestrian access to adjacent areas. 
    Cul-de-sac means a street having one open end and being permanently terminated by a vehicle turnaround. 
    Easement means a grant by a property owner for the use of a strip of land by the village, the general public, a corporation or a certain person for a specific purpose. 
    Final plat means the drawings and documents described in article II, division 3 of this chapter. 
    Frontage means all the property on one side of a street between two intersecting streets (crossing or terminating) measured along the line of the street, or, if the street is dead-ended, then all the property abutting on one side between an intersecting street and the dead-end street. 
    Frontage road means a public or private marginal access roadway or paved parking lot containing the necessary driveways or trafficways which are located along the frontage of multiple-family, business or industrial zoning districts with regulations for purposes of establishing minimum distances between points of access to the accepted street and eliminating parking of motor vehicles on the accepted public street. 
    Half street means any roadway, road or street which does not include or is not proposed to include all surface improvements indicated on Standard Detail 16A, 16B, 16C or 16D. 
    Improvement and public improvement mean any facility for which the village or other municipal body may ultimately assume the responsibility for maintenance and operation or which is constructed for general public use or benefit. 
    Industrial street means any street included in any subdivision or plot of ground to be used for industrial purposes as delineated in the zoning regulations of the village (chapter 106). 
    Intersection, street means the area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curblines, or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines of the roadways of two highways which join one another at, or approximately at, right angles, or the area within which vehicles traveling upon different highways joining at any other angle may come in conflict. Where a highway includes two roadways 30 feet or more apart, then every crossing of each roadway of such divided highway by an intersecting highway shall be regarded as a separate intersection. If such intersecting highway also includes two roadways 30 feet or more apart, then every crossing of two roadways of such highways shall be regarded as a separate intersection. 
    Lot means a parcel of land in a subdivision separated from other parcels or portions by virtue of a plat of subdivision recorded with the appropriate county office, and identifiable by reference to such plat of subdivision and not dependent for such identification on metes and bounds. 
    Major street. See Primary street . 
    Marginal access street means a street which is parallel to and adjacent to primary streets and highways, and which provides access to abutting properties and protection to local traffic from fast, through-moving traffic on primary streets. 
    Minor street means a street intended primarily as access to abutting properties. 
    Owner means the individuals, firms, associations, syndicates, copartnerships, corporations, trusts or any other legal entities having sufficient proprietary interest of record in the land sought to be subdivided to commence and maintain proceedings to subdivide the land under the statutes of the state or under the ordinances of the village. 
    Planned development means a tract of land which is developed as a unit under single ownership or control, which includes two or more principal buildings, and which is at least five acres in area. 
    Plat means a map, drawing or chart, either one-dimensional or three-dimensional, on which the subdivider's plans of the subdivision are presented and which he submits for approval and intends to record in final form. 
    Ponding means the creation of pockets or depressions which have no surface drainage provided and which, in the event of a failure on the part of inlets or storm sewers, will contain standing water. That portion of surface waters which are flowing will not be considered as ponding. 
    Preliminary plat means the drawings and documents described in article II, division 2 of this chapter. 
    Primary street and major street mean a street of considerable continuity which serves or is intended to serve as a major traffic artery between the various sections of the New Lenox area, as shown on the general development plan made a part of the official plan. 
    Public agency means any public board created by authority of the Illinois Compiled Statutes. 
    Public street means all primary, secondary and minor streets which are shown on the subdivision plat and are to be dedicated for public use. 
    Roadway and road mean the paved area existing on the street right-of-way, and not the street right-of-way width. 
    Street means the width of the street right-of-way or easement, whether public or private, and shall not be considered as the width of paving or other improvement on the street right-of-way. 
    Subdivider means any individuals, firms, associations, syndicates, corporations, copartnerships, trusts or other legal entities commencing proceedings under this chapter to effect a subdivision of land. 
    Subdivision. 
(1)  Subdivision means a planned development or the division of land into two or more parts, any of which is less than five acres, for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of transfer of ownership or building development, including all public streets, alleys, ways for public service facilities, parks, playgrounds, schoolgrounds or other public grounds, and all the tracts, parcels, lots or blocks, and numbering of all such lots, blocks or parcels by progressive numbers, giving their precise dimensions. 
(2)  Any single-family, multiple-family, business or industrial district included in a zoning district amendment of the zoning regulations of the village (chapter 106) after the effective date hereof, shall be considered as a planned development and shall be deemed a subdivision for the purpose of this chapter regardless of whether the land is divided into parcels for separate sale or is developed on a lease or condominium basis, and such subdivision shall be subject to the improvement and design requirements specified by the plan commission. 
(3)  Except as provided in 765 ILCS 205/1(c), the provisions of this chapter do not apply and no subdivision plat is required in any of the following instances: 
a.  The division or subdivision of land into parcels or tracts of five acres or more in size which does not involve any new streets or easements of access. 
b.  The division of lots or blocks of less than one acre in any recorded subdivision which does not involve any new streets or easements of access. 
c.  The sale or exchange of parcels of land between owners of adjoining and contiguous land. 
d.  The conveyance of parcels of land or interests therein for use as a right-of-way for railroads or other public utility facilities and other pipelines which does not involve any new streets or easements of access. 
e.  The conveyance of land owned by a railroad or other public utility which does not involve any new streets or easements of access. 
f.  The conveyance of land for highway or other public purposes or grants or conveyances relating to the dedication of land for public use or instruments relating to the vacation of land impressed with a public use. 
g.  Conveyances made to correct descriptions in prior conveyances. 
h.  The sale or exchange of parcels or tracts of land following the division into no more than two parts of a particular parcel or tract of land existing on July 17, 1959, and not involving any new streets or easements of access. 
i.  The sale of a single lot of less than five acres from a larger tract when a survey is made by an Illinois registered land surveyor; provided that this exemption shall not apply to the sale of any subsequent lots from the same larger tract of land, as determined by the dimensions and configuration of the larger tract on October 1, 1973, and provided also that this exemption does not invalidate any other local requirements applicable to the subdivision of land. 
(Code 1981, § 11-2-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 765 ILCS 205/1(b)(1)-(9). 
Sec. 78-3. - Penalty. 
    All persons violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in an amount not less than $25.00 and not more than as provided in section 1-9. 
(Code 1981, § 11-1-6) 
Sec. 78-4. - Preliminary plan and final plat required; acceptance of lands offered for public use. 
(a)  Wherever any planned developments, whether residential, commercial or otherwise in nature, and all other developments, whether a subdivision is required or not under the law, are to be within the incorporated limits of the village, or for land within the village's comprehensive plan if outside the corporate limits, the developer thereof or his agent shall submit both a preliminary plan and a final subdivision plat, if applicable, to the village. Such plans and plats, proposed improvements, and all procedures relating thereto shall in all respects be in full compliance with the regulations contained in this chapter. 
(b)  All lands offered to the village for use as streets, highways, alleys, parks and other public uses shall be referred to the plan commission for review and recommendation before being accepted by the village board or by any other governing authority. 
(Code 1981, § 11-1-2) 
Sec. 78-5. - Applicability of chapter; required approvals; interpretation of chapter. 
(a)  No land shall, after the effective date of Ordinance No. 742, be subdivided or filed for record, nor any street laid out, nor any improvements made to the land, until the plat or plans of the subdivision or street improvements shall have been certified to and approved by the action of the plan commission and the board of trustees of the village. This approval must be in writing and placed on the original tracing of the final plats according to the procedures outlined in article II, division 3 of this chapter. 
(b)  No lot, tract or parcel of land within any such subdivision shall be offered for sale, nor shall any sale, contract for sale or option be made or given, until such subdivision plans have been properly reviewed by the plan commission and the final plat approved by the board of trustees of the village. 
(c)  No improvements, such as sidewalks, water supply, stormwater drainage, sewerage facilities, lighting, grading, paving or surfacing of streets, shall hereafter be made within any such subdivision by any owner or his agent until the plats for the subdivision and also the plans for improvements thereto have been formally recommended by the plan commission and the final plat officially approved by the board of trustees. 
(d)  Subdivisions of land lying outside of the village and within 11/2 miles of the village limits shall also be required to conform with the requirements of this chapter. 
(e)  Where a tract of land is proposed for subdivision, which tract is part of a larger, logical subdivision unit in relation to the village as a whole, the village board of trustees may cause to be prepared a possible plan of the entire area, such plan to be used by the plan commission and the village board as an aid in judging the proposed plat. 
(f)  All interpretations of the rules and regulations in this chapter are reserved to the administrative bodies referred to in this chapter. 
(g)  The plan commission may, in accordance with section 78-7, with village board approval, vary and make exceptions as set forth in this chapter in instances where there is sufficient evidence, in its opinion, of hardship caused by topographic conditions, or where any other reasonable deterrents prevail, provided the variations or exceptions are in substantial conformance with the standards of design of this chapter. 
(h)  Whenever the area is divided into lots containing one to three acres, inclusive, and there are indications that such lots will eventually be resubdivided into small building lots, consideration shall be given to the street and lot arrangement of the original subdivision so that additional minor streets can be opened which will permit a logical arrangement of smaller lots. 
(i)  All planned developments, whether residential, commercial or otherwise in nature, and all other developments whether a subdivision or not under the law and whether located in the incorporated limits of the village or outside the corporate limits but within the village's 11/2-mile planning jurisdiction, shall also be required to conform with the requirements of this chapter. 
(Code 1981, § 11-1-3) 
Sec. 78-6. - Prerequisites for issuance of building permits; model home building permits; model home parking lots. 
(a)  General requirements. No building permit shall be issued providing for the improvement of any lot in a subdivision until there has been filed with the building commissioner a certified copy of the plat of subdivision as recorded or registered in the office of the recorder of deeds or registrar of titles, as the case may be. No building permit shall be issued for the improvement of any lot until the plans and specifications for the public improvements have been approved by the president and board of trustees and until cash and a surety bond or security approved by the village board, as provided by this chapter, are posted with the village. 
(b)  Public ways and utilities. No building permit shall be issued until all public improvements required by this title have been installed and approved by the public works department for functional operation, with the exception of final asphalt roadway surface, energizing of the street lights, public sidewalks, and the germination of stormwater detention facilities and open space lands to be donated. In some cases, perimeter sidewalks not directly affecting individual lot construction or crossing major flood routes will be required to be installed prior to building permit issuance and will be identified accordingly. 
(1)  Prior to the expiration of the two-year warranty period for public improvements, except the surface course of asphalt, sidewalks and parkway trees, no further surety is required. 
(2)  After the expiration of the two-year warranty period for public improvements except the surface course of asphalt, sidewalks and parkway trees has expired, a residential home cash surety in the amount of $2,000.00 will be required at the time of application for a building permit for each individual lot. This cash surety will be returned after the issuance of a certificate of occupancy or when the public improvements have been repaired to the satisfaction of the village engineer or designee, whichever is later. 
(c)  Model home building permits. 
(1)  A special class of building permits shall be issued entitled "model home building permit." 
(2)  The model home building permit shall be for the construction of a model home and such construction shall be in compliance with the provisions of the Village Building Code. The premises shall not be occupied until a Model Home Occupancy Permit has been issued. The model home may not be open for inspection to the public until such time that the Village Building and Zoning Administrator issues a certificate for such use. The certificate will not be issued until the provisions of the Village Building Code are complied with and inspection for such use are made. 
(3)  A model home building permit will not be issued until the following subdivision improvements have been installed and approved by the Village Engineer: 
a.  An asphalt road capable of supporting 70,000 pounds. 
b.  The asphalt road must extend a minimum of 50 feet past the model home property. 
c.  The asphalt road must be installed to the minimum width of the road right-of-way cross section. 
d.  The road shall be maintained by the permit holder and shall be kept free of snow and ice accumulation until such time that the Village accepts and maintains the improvements. 
e.  An active fire hydrant shall be located a maximum of 500 feet from the property. 
(4)  The holder of the model home permit may apply for an occupancy permit, which will not be issued unless and until the village building and zoning administrator is satisfied that the provisions of the village building code are complied with and that all public improvements, per the final subdivision plat, have been installed and approved. 
(5)  There shall be a charge of an additional $100.00 for the model home building permit. This is in addition to and above all other permit fees and charges. 
(6)  At any given time, the number of model home building permits shall not exceed the lesser of six permits or ten percent of the number of lots that are final platted for any subdivision. 
(7)  Signs for model homes shall comply with the current Village sign code. 
(d)  Model home parking lots. 
(1)  A special class of temporary use permit shall be issued entitled "model home parking lot permit." 
(2)  The model home parking lot permit shall be for the construction of one model home parking lot to be located on no more than one platted lot in a subdivision containing a minimum of 100 lots. 
(3)  The model home parking lot shall be located on a lot adjacent to an arterial or collector roadway. The model home parking lot shall further be identified as such on the preliminary plat for the subdivision. 
(4)  No model home parking lot permit shall be issued until the applicant has submitted plans satisfactory to the village planning and development administrator in compliance with the provisions of this section, including provisions for adequate drainage of the model home parking lot. 
(5)  The model home parking lot shall have a hard surface constructed of asphalt, concrete or other similar materials resulting in a dust-free surface. All portions of a lot governed by a model home parking lot permit not covered with this hard surface shall be landscaped with grass or other ground cover capable of preventing erosion. 
(6)  The model home parking lot shall not encroach into the required setbacks of the underlying zoning district, and shall not be located within the public right-of-way. 
(7)  There shall be no more than one model home parking lot permit in effect per subdivision, regardless of the number of phases of the subdivision. The model home parking lot shall contain no more than ten parking spaces. 
(8)  There shall be a charge of $100.00 for the model home parking lot permit. In addition, the holder of the model home parking lot permit shall deposit with the village a letter of credit in an amount determined by the village necessary to cover the cost of removal of the model home parking lot. 
(9)  The model home parking lot permit shall remain in effect until the earlier of: a) a final occupancy permit for the last model home permit for the subdivision is issued; b) building permits have been issued for 90 percent of the lots; or, c) two years after the issuance of the model home parking lot permit. A model home parking lot permit may be renewed for one additional period, if the subdivision has not built out per (a) or (b) above. 
(Code 1981, § 11-1-4; Ord. No. 1194, § 2(11-1-4B), 40-28-1998; Ord. No. 1467, § 1, 5-14-2003; Ord. No. 1575, § 1, 9-20-2004; Ord. No. 2074, § 1, 11-9-2009; Ord. No. 2310, § 3, 12-17-2012) 
Sec. 78-7. - Variations. 
(a)  The plan commission may recommend a variation of the application of the regulations of this chapter in harmony with their general purpose and intent and in accordance with the rules contained in this chapter in cases where there are particular difficulties or peculiar hardship in the way of carrying out the strict letter of any of such regulations relating to the subdividing of land, and may recommend to the village board that the village board approve the plat of subdivision in spite of failure to strictly comply with the strict letter of any of the regulations, stating the reasons for such recommendations. 
(b)  Such recommendations for variations shall be communicated in writing to the village board, giving full particulars for the allowance of the variation. Approval of the variation must be received from the village board before the plan commission may give approval to the preliminary plat. 
(Code 1981, § 11-1-5) 
Sec. 78-8. - Petition for hearing on proposed plat. 
    All proposed subdivision plats submitted to the village pursuant to 65 ILCS 5/11-15.1-1 et seq. for consideration and hearing thereon by the village shall be accompanied by a petition requesting the appropriate municipal authorities to conduct the appropriate hearings thereon, such application or petition to be signed by the record fee title owner of the real estate being the subject matter of such proposed subdivision or the duly authorized agent of such owner. If title to the land is vested in a land trust, the petition must be accompanied by an affidavit setting forth the names and addresses of all those having any part of the beneficial interest and power of direction with respect to the land trust on the date of filing of the petition. 
(Code 1981, § 1-12-1) 
Sec. 78-9. - Plat review and inspection fees. 
(a)  Generally. All such petitions submitted in accordance with section 78-8 shall be accompanied by fees in accordance with the following schedule: 
(1)  Filing fees. 
a.  Preliminary subdivision plat: $500.00 plus $15.00 per lot. 
b.  Final subdivision plat: $50.00 per lot. 
c.  A landscape plan review fee for a preliminary planned unit development plat or final subdivision plat in an amount determined as follows: 
1.  Exterior parkway tree plan ..... $100.00 
2.  Stormwater detention facility landscape plan, per detention facility ..... 750.00 
3.  Perimeter landscape area plan, per 500 lineal feet of perimeter area or fraction thereof ..... 500.00 
4.  In the event the village incurs expenses for outside professional services for landscape plan review that exceed the amount collected under sections 1, 2 or 3 above, the village shall bill each developer or applicant on whose behalf the village has incurred such extra expenses on a monthly basis, the balance due 30 days from the date of billing. The village shall reserve the right to stop all reviews, including plan commission, zoning board of appeals and village board reviews, until all fees are paid. 
(2)  Engineering review fees. 
a.  Preliminary subdivision plat: $150.00 plus $5.00 per lot. 
b.  Final subdivision plat: $150.00 plus $25.00 per lot. 
(3)  Plan review and construction inspection fees. In addition, the party applying for preliminary or final plat approval shall be responsible for the following fees: 
a.  For projects in which the public improvements are estimated at less than $500,000.00, the applicant shall be responsible to pay the following: 
1.  In the event the village incurs expenses for outside professional services for plan review and/or periodic construction inspections, the village shall bill each developer or applicant on whose behalf the village has incurred such expenses on a monthly basis, the balance due 30 days from the date of billing. 
2.  In the event village staff reviews the plans and/or conducts periodic construction inspections, the village shall bill each developer or applicant on whose behalf the village has reviewed plans and/or conducted inspections, the balance due 30 days from the date of billing, fees calculated as follows: 
i.  Village engineer, per hour ..... $150.00 
ii.  Civil engineer or development manager, per hour ..... 120.00 
iii.  Public improvements inspector or engineering technician, per hour ..... 95.00 
3.  All payments required pursuant to section 1. or 2. above shall generally be made in full upon completion of each of the following stages: optional sketch plan review, preliminary plat review, final plat review, inspection of subdivision improvements and acceptance of subdivision improvements, before proceeding with work on a subsequent stage. The village shall reserve the right to stop all review and inspection procedures, including plan commission, zoning board of appeals and village board reviews, and such work as is being inspected, until all fees are paid. 
b.  All approved final subdivision plats submitted for execution in which the public improvements are estimated at $500,000.00 or more shall be accompanied by a plan review and construction inspection fee of four percent of the approved estimate of public improvement construction costs. The public improvement construction costs shall include both on-site and off-site improvements as required by this chapter. The construction inspection fee shall be paid in cash or certified check prior to execution of the final plat by the village. 
c.  All approved final subdivision plats submitted for commercial subdivision in which the public improvements are estimated at $5,000,000.00 or more shall be accompanied by a letter of credit in an amount equal to four percent of the approved estimate of public improvement construction costs, with an expiration of one year from the date of approval of the final plat. The developer of said commercial subdivision shall be responsible for making four equal quarterly payments, totaling the aforesaid four percent amount, the first payment due at the time of execution of the final plat, said payments being in the form of cash or certified check. The public improvement construction costs shall include both on-site and off-site improvements as required by this chapter. 
d.  Notwithstanding the provisions of sections a., b. and c. above, if a project of any size exhibits no activity for a period of six months, the village shall have the right to demand payment of fees incurred to date. In the event village demands payment and payment is made for a subdivision in which public improvements are estimated at $500,000.00 or more, said fees shall be deducted from the four percent plan review and construction inspection fee collected at the time of execution of the final plat. 
(b)  Special hearing dates. The filing fees required by subsection (a) of this section shall be applicable if the appropriate hearing upon such submission is to be conducted on the same evening which is a regular meeting date of the appropriate village authority involved, whether the meeting is to be held before the plan commission or the zoning board of appeals. If the hearing is to be held before the appropriate village authority at any time other than a regular meeting date, then the filing fees shall be applicable and such petition shall be accompanied by a $400.00 special meeting fee for preliminary subdivision plat. The plan commission, at its sole discretion, shall determine the date on which it shall conduct a hearing on the proposed plat of subdivision, and it shall cause appropriate legal notices and public meeting notifications to be published and posted as provided for in the Illinois Compiled Statutes, as revised. 
(c)  Hearings before more than one agency. If the village is required to conduct hearings before both the plan commission and zoning board of appeals with respect to multiple matters concerning the same tract of land, i.e., multiple zoning changes on a single tract, rezoning request and subdivision plat approval for the same tract, etc., and the hearings can be held on the same date, the petitioner shall be entitled to have the hearings held upon his payment of the filing fee and security deposit for one such hearing; provided that the plan commission and zoning board are composed of substantially the same members and the meetings are held on the same date. In all other circumstances, the petitioner will be required to make separate payment for each initial hearing. 
(Code 1981, § 1-12-2; Ord. No. 1136, § 1, 4-23-1997; Ord. No. 1479, § 3, 6-25-2003; Ord. No. 1942, §§ 3, 4, 5-12-2008; Ord. No. 1987, § 1, 8-18-2008) 
Sec. 78-10. - Security deposit for expenses of professional assistance. 
    In addition to the filing fees required by section 78-9, the subdivider, developer or owner so submitting such a petition shall deposit with the village a security deposit as set forth in section 18-5. 
(Code 1981, § 1-12-3; Ord. No. 2150, § 6, 12-20-2010) 
Sec. 78-11. - Reimbursement of village for expenses of professional assistance. 
    In accordance with applicable state and local law, the village may require the applicant to execute and deliver to the village a professional fee agreement as set forth in section 18-5. 
(Code 1981, § 1-12-4; Ord. No. 1479, § 4, 6-25-2003; Ord. No. 2150, § 7, 12-20-2010) 
Secs. 78-12-78-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLATS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 78-31-78-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PRELIMINARY PLAT 

Sec. 78-51. - Filing requirements; form and contents. 
(a)  Any person owning land within the limits of the village or within 11/2 miles of such limits wishing to: 
(1)  Divide the land into lots for the purpose of sale; 
(2)  Dedicate a part thereof for streets, alleys or other public use; 
(3)  Redivide land previously subdivided; or 
(4)  Change the boundaries of any lot or parcel thereof; 
shall file 17 copies of his preliminary plat of the proposed subdivision with the village clerk for transmittal to the plan commission and village board of trustees. 
(b)  The preliminary plat shall be drawn to a scale of not less than 100 feet to the inch and contain the following: 
(1)  The proposed name of the subdivision. 
(2)  Its location as forming a part of some larger tract or parcel of land referred to in the indexes of the records of the county clerk. 
(3)  Sufficient information to accurately locate the plat. (Reference to existing streets, plats, etc., may be used. If there are none within a reasonable distance of the proposed subdivision, a vicinity plat on a small scale should accompany the preliminary plat.) 
(4)  The description and location of all survey monuments erected in the subdivision. 
(5)  A certificate showing ownership of the property described in the preliminary plat and adjacent property owners and subdivisions. 
(6)  The boundary lines of the tract to be subdivided, accurate in scale and bearing the total approximate area encompassed thereby. 
(7)  The location, widths and other dimensions of all existing platted streets and other important features such as railroad lines, watercourses, existing easements, exceptional topography, etc., contiguous to the tract to be subdivided. 
(8)  The location, widths and other dimensions of proposed streets, alleys, easements, parks and other open spaces. 
(9)  All parcels of land intended to be dedicated for public use or reserved for the use of all property owners, with the purpose indicated (see section 78-72 and article V of this chapter). 
(10)  North point, scale and date of preparation. 
(11)  Layout, numbers and dimensions of lots. 
(12)  Building setback lines, showing dimensions. 
(13)  Easements for any and all public utilities where alleys are not provided. Property continuity for the utilities from block to block shall be maintained. 
(c)  The fee for filing the preliminary plat is $100.00 for the first five lots and $5.00 for each additional lot in the subdivision, but in no event less than $100.00. 
(d)  The village clerk shall notify the village board of the filing of each preliminary plat and its transmittal to the plan commission. 
(e)  The plan commission shall require the following, when necessary: 
(1)  Contours at an interval of two feet and high-water levels on all watercourses. 
(2)  Sketches, blueprints and other pertinent data on the type of structures proposed to be constructed. 
(3)  Location, size and approximate grades of proposed sewers. 
(4)  Cross sections of proposed streets showing width of roadways, location of sidewalks, proposed street grades and proposed elevations of lot corners. 
(5)  Proposed location of water, gas, electric and telephone outlets and sanitary and storm sewers. 
(f)  There shall be submitted on each plat the name of the subdivider, the subdivision designer and engineer, the owner of the property and, where the property is held in a trust, the owners of the beneficial interest of the trust, and the names of adjoining property owners. 
(Code 1981, § 11-3-1) 
Sec. 78-52. - Procedure for approval. 
(a)  Hearing before plan commission. The plan commission shall provide for an adequate hearing on the preliminary plat and shall notify the applicant by mail at least five days prior to the hearing. 
(b)  Action by plan commission. 
(1)  The commission shall determine whether the preliminary plat shall be approved, approved with modifications, or disapproved, and shall give written notice to the subdivider of its determination within 90 days of the initial hearing. 
(2)  If approved, the commission shall so note on the face of the plat, and shall thereupon forward the plat to the village board, notifying the subdivider of the action. If approved with modifications, or if disapproved, the commission shall attach to the original plat a statement of the reasons for such action and shall return the original of the plat to the subdivider, retaining one copy thereof for its records. 
(c)  Effect of approval by plan commission; time limits. 
(1)  The approval of a preliminary plat by the plan commission is strictly tentative, involving merely the general acceptability of the layout submitted. This approval shall be effective for a maximum period of 12 months, provided that: 
a.  The subdivider shall, within a six-month period of preliminary plat approval, present to the village board a written status report of the progress of the proposed subdivision; and 
b.  The subdivider shall, within 12 months, obtain the plan commission's and village board's approval of the final plat on an area comprising at least 20 percent of the gross area encompassed in the preliminary plat. 
(2)  If final plat approval is not obtained on at least 20 percent of the gross area within 12 months, then the preliminary plat is deemed to have expired. In addition, the subdivider shall obtain final plat approval (on increments of at least 20 percent of the preliminary plat) in succeeding 12-month periods until the subdivision is completed. 
(3)  The village board may, upon the application of the subdivider within the time periods specified in this subsection, grant such extensions of time as it shall deem proper. 
(d)  Action by village board. The village board shall, upon receipt of the report from the plan commission and four copies of the preliminary plat, upon motion and majority vote, approve or disapprove the preliminary plat, and, if approved, give permission to prepare detailed plans and specifications of the subdivision and public improvements in accordance with the preliminary plat, and within the requirements of this chapter. 
(e)  Effect of approval by board. The approval of a preliminary plat by the village board is tentative only, involving merely the general acceptability of the layout as submitted, and must have designated thereon the words "This is a preliminary plat, of no legal effect, and not to be recorded." 
(f)  Revisions. The plan commission may recommend or the village board may require, during consideration of a preliminary plat, such changes or revisions as are deemed necessary in the interest and needs of the community. 
(g)  Proper drainage required. No plat will be approved for the subdivision of land which is subject to periodic flooding or which contains extremely poor drainage facilities and which would make adequate drainage of the streets impossible. However, if the subdivider agrees to make improvements which will, in the opinion of the village engineer, make the area completely safe for residential occupancy and provide adequate street drainage, the preliminary plat of the subdivision may be approved. 
(h)  Distribution of signed copies. One print of the approved preliminary plat, signed by the president and the village clerk, shall be retained in the village clerk's office, and two copies shall be retained in the office of the village engineer, and one copy shall be retained in the files of the plan commission. One signed copy is authorization for the subdivider to proceed with the preparation of plans and specifications for the minimum improvements required in these rules and regulations and with the preparation of the final plat. 
(Code 1981, § 11-3-2) 
Secs. 78-53-78-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FINAL PLAT 

Sec. 78-71. - Contents; supplemental documents; drafting standards; review and approval. 
(a)  Contents of plat. The final plat shall contain the following: 
(1)  Name of the subdivision. 
(2)  Location by township, section and range, or by other legal description. 
(3)  Scale of one inch to 100 feet or larger (shown graphically). 
(4)  Date and north point. 
(5)  Boundary of the plat, based on an accurate traverse, with angles and linear dimensions. 
(6)  Exact locations, widths and names of all streets within and adjoining the plat, and the exact location and widths of all crosswalkways. Streets that are obviously in alignment with others already existing and named shall bear the names of the existing streets. 
(7)  True angles and distances to the nearest established street lines or official monuments (not less than three), which shall be accurately described in the plat. 
(8)  Municipal, township, county or section lines accurately tied to the lines of the subdivision by distances and angles. 
(9)  Radii, internal angles, points and curvatures, tangent bearings and lengths of all arcs. 
(10)  All easements for rights-of-way provided for public services and utilities. 
(11)  All house numbers, lot numbers and lines, with accurate dimensions in feet and hundredths. 
a.  House numbers shall be assigned to each lot per the U.S. Postmaster, New Lenox, Illinois. 
b.  Foundation elevations shall be depicted on the engineering drawings for each lot as established by a licensed engineer in compliance with this chapter or other applicable village ordinances or state law, and approved by the village engineer. 
(12)  Permanent monuments or benchmarks, which shall be placed at all corners and at points of tangency of curve lines along the boundary of the subdivision. 
(13)  Accurate outlines and legal descriptions of any areas to be dedicated or reserved for public use, with the purposes indicated thereon, and of any area to be reserved by deed covenant for common use of all property owners. 
(14)  Building setback lines accurately shown by dimension. 
(15)  An endorsement on the final plat by the county clerk that he finds no delinquent general taxes or unpaid current general taxes against the land shown thereon. 
(16)  A summary on its face of all restrictions applicable to any part of the subdivision relating to building restrictions, use restrictions, building lines or otherwise. 
(17)  A deed of dedication in the form set out in section 78-75(3). 
(18)  A certificate of approval as set out in section 78-75(2). 
(b)  Plat for unit of subdivision. Such final plat may be for a unit of a proposed subdivision, provided that: 
(1)  A preliminary plat has previously been approved as to the whole subdivision. 
(2)  Approval by the village engineer is required as to the feasibility of such unit construction. 
(3)  The public improvements as outlined in article IV of this chapter, for at least one unit, shall be submitted and completed within each calendar year from the date of approval of the final plat for the unit. 
(4)  The plat for each unit shall be submitted to the plan commission for its approval. 
(5)  Failure to comply with the terms of this subsection will require resubmission of the requirements of section 78-51. 
(c)  Accompanying documents. Accompanying documents shall consist of: 
(1)  Approval of the subdivider's preparations for improvements required by sections 78-131 through 78-140, inclusive. 
(2)  Approval by the U.S. Postmaster, New Lenox, Illinois, of the names of the proposed streets and of the proposed system of addresses along such streets. 
(3)  Plan and profile of all streets and alleys in the proposed subdivision drawn to a maximum horizontal scale of 50 feet to the inch. Elevation shall be referred to USGS datum. 
(4)  Certification by a registered surveyor to the effect that the plat represents a survey made by him and that monuments and markers shown exist as located and that all dimensions and geometric details are correct in the form set out in this section. 
(5)  Notarized certification by the owners, and by mortgagees or lienholders of record, acknowledging the plat and the dedication of streets and other public areas. 
(6)  Written approval of village, county and state officials concerned with the specifications of utility installations. 
(7)  Final plans and specifications for the improvements required by sections 78-131 through 78-140, inclusive, in strict conformity with the subdivider's preparations for such improvements previously approved by the president and board of trustees or other appropriate authority and signed by the subdivider and owner. 
(8)  An agreement executed by the owner and subdivider to make and install the improvements provided for in article IV of this chapter in accordance with the plans and specifications accompanying the final plat. 
(9)  A letter of credit as surety for the satisfactory completion of public improvements approved by the village board and processed in accordance with the procedures adopted as Resolution No. 98-13. 
(d)  Drafting standards for plats and plans. 
(1)  The village requires that all construction plans for public improvements and subdivision plats be submitted to the village in hard copy and digital format. The digital format shall be the latest version of AutoCAD software approved by the village. The digital deliverables shall be on 31/2-inch diskettes. 
(2)  This subsection shall serve as the drafting standards for CAD submittals. The goal of this standard is to produce legible drawing sets for construction and an accurate, full-size computer model of the project being built. This full-size computer model shall be inserted into the village's base map upon village approval of the computer file. 
(3)  The model shall be prepared using the village's mapping control for a horizontal and vertical coordinate base. The model shall be drafted at full scale in the village's horizontal coordinate system. Model files shall contain all existing and proposed entities contained in the entire set of construction plans, and shall encompass the entire project being designed. 
(4)  Individual drawing sheet files shall be prepared at the appropriate plot scale, and contain references to the model file. All text shall be labeled on the drawing files, not on the model file.
