(5)  All symbols shall be in accordance with Standard 1686-5 of the state department of transportation and any amendments or revisions thereto. All layering conventions, symbols, line types and colors shall be in accordance with the Village of New Lenox Layering Standards and any amendments or revisions thereto. 
(6)  All consultants preparing plans and plats to be submitted to the village shall be provided with a digital file of the prototype model file. The consultant's model shall conform to the standards set forth in the prototype. 
(7)  All subdivision plats, engineering plans and as-built plans submitted to the village shall be prepared using the village's horizontal and vertical control network as the basis of survey. The horizontal control network consists of the commonly accepted monumentation of the quarter section and section corners in New Lenox Township. The vertical control network consists of approximately 50 benchmarks established throughout the township. The horizontal datum is the datum used for the flood mapping of Hickory Creek, which is NGVD 1929. The purpose of this requirement is to set forth standards by which survey and engineering data can be inserted into the village's digital map without modification or translation. 
(8)  All survey and engineering data shall be based upon the village's established horizontal and vertical coordinates for their respective control monuments. At least one of the village's vertical control monuments shall be used in preparing plats of survey, topographic surveys, engineering plans and as-built plans. At least two of the village's horizontal control monuments shall be used in preparing plats of subdivision and plats of dedication. Horizontal control data sheets, benchmark data and existing control mapping shall be provided by the village to be used by those parties preparing subdivision plats and engineering plans within the jurisdictional boundaries of the village. Surveyors and engineers finding destroyed village control monumentation or recovery ties are required to notify the village. 
Editor's note- The preceding subsection 78-71(d), as established by Ord. No. 1097, shall be in effect and shall apply to any preliminary subdivision plat, final subdivision plat and/or engineering plans submitted after September 1, 1996. 
(e)  Review and approval by village engineer. 
(1)  The final plat and accompanying documents shall be submitted to the village engineer. The village engineer shall review the final plat and accompanying documents for conformance with the preliminary plat, as approved by the plan commission and the village board. 
(2)  If the final plat and accompanying documents are in conformance with the preliminary plat and the requirements of this chapter, the village engineer may approve the final plat and accompanying documents by affixing his signature to the certificate of approval on the final plat and forwarding these documents to the plan commission. 
(f)  Review and approval by plan commission. The plan commission shall review the final plat and accompanying documents by directing the chairman and secretary to affix their signatures in appropriate places on the certificate of approval on the final plat and forwarding these documents to the village board. The plan commission's approval shall not be deemed to constitute or effect an acceptance by the public of the dedication of any street or other proposed public way or space shown in the plat. 
(g)  Submission of copies to village board; deposit for guarantee of improvements. After approval of the final plat and accompanying documents and the forwarding of these documents to the village board by the plan commission, the subdivider and owner shall submit to the village board: 
(1)  One tracing and one copy of the final plat of the subdivision as executed by the plan commission shall be submitted, drawn in ink on tracing cloth. Following execution by the president and village clerk, the subdivider shall provide 15 copies of such final plat bearing the required signatures. 
(2)  A deposit of 15 percent of the estimated cost of surface improvements is to be given to the village prior to any reduction in the subdivider's letter of credit covering surface improvements. Such deposit may be in cash, a bearer negotiable instrument or a negotiable instrument payable to the village, as approved by the village board. The village will hold this deposit in escrow for a period of 18 months after the final completion of such work as a guarantee against any defect in the material or workmanship furnished in connection with such improvement latent in character and not discernible at the time of the final approval of such improvement, and to guarantee against any damage to such improvements by reason of settling of the ground, base or foundation thereof. After the termination of such 18-month period, such deposit shall be refunded to the depositor, or the order of such depositor, if no defects have developed. If any defects have developed, then the balance of such deposit shall be refunded after reimbursement of the village for any amounts expended by it in the curing of such defects. 
(h)  That in any case when village funds have been expended to finance the advance construction of public improvements that would have otherwise been a requirement of this title for the subdivision of land, reimbursement to the village for these costs shall be required as a condition of subdivision final plat approval. Only costs of public improvements that are adjacent to and directly benefiting the property to be subdivision are eligible for reimbursement. Furthermore, the costs of usual and customary maintenance including the improvement of existing infrastructure shall not be considered a reimbursable cost as defined in this section. Said reimbursement amount shall be determined by the village engineer. 
(Code 1981, § 11-4-1; Ord. No. 1194, § 1(11-4-1C9), 4-28-1998; Ord. No. 1316, § 1, 10-24-2000) 
Sec. 78-72. - Reservation of land for public use. 
(a)  Residential subdivisions . 
(1)  Dedications required. As a condition of approval of a final plat of a residential subdivision or planned unit development, each subdivider or developer shall be required to dedicate land and/or make cash contributions in lieu of land and pay other impact fees to serve the immediate and future needs of the residents of the village as set forth in this section. 
(2)  Dedication of land sites and open space. Land sites and/or other open space contributions shall be conveyed to the village fee simple in accordance with the following criteria. The village may subsequently dedicate or lease such land to any local park district, forest preserve district, fire protection district, or library district. 
a.  Required dedication area. The ultimate number of residents that will be generated by the proposed subdivision or planned unit development shall be determined in accordance with table 1 in subsection (c) of this section. The land area required to be dedicated for land sites and/or open space in each subdivision or planned unit development shall be determined by dividing the estimated population of such subdivision or planned unit development by 1,000 and multiplying the quotient by the acre contribution required for each 1,000 people as set forth in the following schedule: 
District Acres/1,000 population Park District 10.0 Village 4.5 Fire District 2.3 Library District 1.2 Police Communications 0.5  
b.  Location of land sites. 
1.  Except for combined multijurisdictional sites, as made by prior agreement, or as defined in the comprehensive plan adopted by the village, the location of sites dedicated pursuant to this section shall be approved by the village board, provided that the village board must give any and all affected park district board(s), county forest preserve district board(s), fire protection district board(s), and/or library district board(s) an opportunity to submit written recommendations regarding the location of such sites. 
If there is not a planned park within the subdivision or planned unit development or the neighborhood in which the subdivision or planned unit development is located, the park site and/or open space contribution shall be so located as to be readily accessible to the people within such neighborhood. Planned athletic fields and large park sites must be conveniently accessible to the community at large. 
2.  Proper modes of ingress and egress and appropriate curb cuts shall be provided for all land sites required under this section. 
For water areas: provisions must be made for pathways or driveways around such water areas for emergency vehicles and police patrols. Provisions for major use of pathways or driveways for bike riding, walkways, jogging trails and pedestrian traffic shall also be made. 
c.  Environmental quality and suitability of land. 
1.  Land to be dedicated for land sites and/or open space shall be approved by the village board according to its environmental quality, as well as its suitability for active and passive recreational activities, village facilities, fire protection facilities and/or library facilities. The land is to be dry and usable at all times and not subject to flooding or used as detention. 
2.  Should a land dedication include a detention/retention area over and above the required minimum acres per 1,000 of ultimate population estimated to be generated by the development, said land may be accepted. No bogs or swamps shall be acceptable as required land dedications. Lakes and native prairie wetlands shall not normally be acceptable, but may be approved where the area offers an exceptional amenity or the chance to protect a significant natural resource. Sites that have been part of an unlicensed landfill or a toxic waste dump shall not be acceptable as required land dedications. 
3.  Every effort shall be made to conserve for public use and enjoyment those areas of significant natural and environmental value. The slope, topography and geology of the dedicated site, as well as its surroundings, must be suitable for its intended purpose and approved prior to approval of the final plat. Grading on sites dedicated for public use shall not greatly differ from the surrounding land and shall be provided with erosion control devices as required by state or village regulations prior to acceptance by the village board. Except in those specific areas designated by the village for development as playfields or other active areas, all trees, other plant materials, streams, and other natural features shall be retained on land to be dedicated for public use, unless specifically cited by the village for removal by the developer. 
d.  Shape of site. Dedicated land sites and/or open space contributions shall be regularly configured to permit efficient programming, security and maintenance. Sites shall be rectangular or nearly rectangular in shape, with no interior angle of the boundary line less than 60 degrees, unless specifically approved by the village. Narrow strips of land, small parcels that intrude into adjacent orderly development, and leftover parcels that are oddly shaped or located shall not be accepted as part of the required land dedication. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the village may accept easements or land dedications for linear parks and/or multi-use trails as determined by the village board. 
e.  Improvements. 
1.  Prior to conveyance, all sites shall be prepared in accordance with this chapter and any water retention/detention requirements set forth in this Code, except as varied by the specific terms of this section. In addition, if a land site and/or open space contribution includes any retention/detention areas, slopes must be mowable and shall not exceed a 5:1 slope. For any area where-by necessity and subject to the approval of the village board-the grade of such slopes exceeds 5:1, the subdivider or developer must provide a covering of paving or vegetative cover (as recommended by the village board or other applicable agency) which will eliminate the need to mow. All other areas must be final graded and seeded to meet village specifications, provided that the village shall allow any affected park district board(s), county forest preserve district board(s), fire protection district board(s), and/or library district board(s) to make recommendations as to seed mixture. 
2.  All sites shall be conveyed in a condition ready for full service of electricity, water, sewers, and streets, including enclosed drainage, curb, and gutter improvements as applicable to the location of the site, or after acceptable provision has been made therefor. In addition, location of hydrants shall be made in conformance with village requirements. Provision for water for watering vegetation and flooding for ice skating shall be made where appropriate. Sewer stubs allowing for the future installation of buildings, restrooms, and/or shelters shall be provided. All connection fees for water and sewer service shall be paid by the developer at time of final plat, and prior to conveyance of the site to the village. 
3.  If a dedicated land site or open space contribution accepted by the village is adjacent to an existing residential developed area, certain landscaping and/or screening may be required of the developer, at his cost, to be installed prior to the conveyance of the land site or open space contribution to the village. 
(3)  Reservation of additional land. Where the comprehensive plan of the village calls for park and/or recreational land in a particular proposed subdivision or planned unit development over and above the requirements of this section, the subdivider or developer shall reserve any and all such land for the subsequent purchase by the village or park district, provided that such acquisition is made within one year from the date of the final plat. If the village or park district fails to make such acquisition within one year from the date of the final plat, this subsection (a)(3) shall cease to apply to the subdivision or planned use development that is the subject of said plat. 
(4)  Combined multijurisdictional school/park/village sites. Consideration will be given to combined school/park/village sites. Where the village determines that such a combined school/park/village site is appropriate, the total land area dedication required shall be equal to the sum of the land area dedication required by this section and the land area dedication required by article V of this chapter (pertaining to dedication of school sites). If the subdivision or planned unit development cannot reasonably be expected to provide the total land area required under this subsection (a)(4), then the village shall determine what land area dedication is reasonable and appropriate and the subdivider or developer shall pay the difference between the total required dedication area and the actual area dedicated in the form of cash contributions as determined under subsection (a)(7) of this section. 
In addition, if the total land needed for a combined school/park/village site exceeds the total land area dedication requirement as set out in this subsection (a)(4), the subdivider or developer shall reserve any necessary additional land area in the same manner, and under the same conditions, as set forth in subsection (a)(3) of this section, supra. 
(5)  Time of conveyance of dedications. 
a.  All required dedications shall be conveyed to the village in fee simple for subsequent conveyance or lease to the appropriate taxing district in which the land is located. Land dedications shall be conveyed by the developer no later than the earlier of the following: 
1.  Within 180 days after a written demand by the village; or 
2.  By the second anniversary of the approval of the final plat of the subdivision or planned unit development by the village. 
b.  All land dedications shall be improved as required under subsection (a)(2)e., supra, prior to conveyance to the village, but in no event no later than the earlier of the following: 
1.  Within 180 days after a written demand by the village; or 
2.  By the second anniversary of the approval of the final plat of the subdivision or planned unit development by the village. 
(6)  Title insurance, survey and assessment plats. Each deed conveying land to the village shall be accompanied by the following: 
a.  A written commitment issued by a title insurer licensed to do business within this state to ensure that the village has good merchantable title to any and all dedicated real estate in an amount equal to the total area of the land dedication multiplied by the then-applicable fair market value as set forth in subsection (a)(7)c., supra, subject only to then-current general real estate taxes as of the date of transfer; covenants, conditions, and restrictions which do not prohibit the use of the subject real estate for park, village, fire protection, or library uses; and utility easements located within 20 feet of the boundary lines of the subject real estate for drainage ditches, feeders, laterals, and underground pipes or other conduits. 
b.  A current boundary line survey, certified by a licensed Illinois land surveyor to be in compliance with the state land survey standards. 
c.  Except in instances where the real estate to be conveyed is a lot in a recorded subdivision, an assessment plat and tax division petition in a form acceptable to the appropriate county authorities so that the land to be conveyed can be assigned its own permanent real estate index number for exemption purposes. 
(7)  Cash contribution in lieu of dedication of land. Criteria for requiring cash contributions in lieu of land dedications are as follows: 
a.  Authority to require cash contribution. Upon a determination of the village board, and as may be recommended by the park district board, county forest preserve district board, fire protection district board, or library district board, that the required land dedication will not be large enough; that the required land dedication is otherwise inappropriate for the purpose intended; or that cash contributions will be more advantageous, the village board shall require the subdivider or developer to pay a cash contribution in lieu of the required land dedication as described in this subsection. 
b.  Intended use. The cash contributions to be paid in lieu of a land dedication shall be expended by the receiving taxing district as prescribed by law. 
c.  Amount of contribution. 
1.  Fair market value. The amount of cash contributions in lieu of land shall be based on the fully improved fair market value of land in the proposed subdivision or planned unit development. The cash contributions in lieu of land shall be based on the "fair market value" of the acres of land in the area improved as specified herein, that otherwise would have been dedicated. It has been determined that the present "fair market value" of such improved land in and surrounding the village is $110,000.00 per acre as of January 1, 2018, and further that it is hereby established for each year effective on January 1 as follows: 
Year Fair Market Value 2018 $110,000.00 2019 115,500.00 2020 121,275.00 2021 127,339.00 2022 133,705.00 2023 140,391.00 2024 147,410.00 2025 154,781.00 2026 162,520.00  
The values set forth in the above table shall be used in making any calculation herein unless the subdivider or developer of a planned unit development files a written objection thereto. In the event of any such objection, the subdivider or developer of a planned unit development shall submit an appraisal showing the "fair market value" of such improved land in the area of his subdivision or planned unit development or other evidence thereof and final determination of said "fair market value" per acre of such improved land shall be made by the village board. 
2.  Annual review of fair market value. The village shall review, on or before December 31 of each year, the fair market value of improved land in and around the village. Based on this review, the village shall revise the fair market value set forth in subsection (a)(7)c.1., supra, as necessary. 
3.  Cash contribution; requirement. The cash contribution as provided for in this section is a requirement of this chapter. The contribution will be payable at the time of application for a building permit on each lot or such other time as required by the village board. The amount due will be calculated based upon the residence to which the application for a building permit applies in accordance with subsection (a)(2)a. of this section. 
4.  Cash contribution; collection. Cash contributions as prescribed herein to the park district, forest preserve district, fire protection district, or library district shall be collected by the designated agency and accounted for on a subdivision by subdivision basis. 
5.  Fund report. The park district, forest preserve district, fire protection district, and/or library district shall submit, on an annual basis, a report in a form and level of detail acceptable to the village board, detailing the collection of funds on a subdivision by subdivision basis and certifying that the expenditure of such funds collected under this section 78-72(a)(7) has been and will be as prescribed by law. 
d.  Criteria for requiring both land and cash dedication. In some situations, the village board may determine that a combination of land dedication and cash contribution is appropriate. In such situations, the village board may, with or without the recommendations of the park district board, forest preserve district board, fire protection district board, or library district board, require the subdivider or developer to provide any combination of land dedication and cash contribution so long as the total does not exceed the maximum required dedication prescribed in this section. 
Situations in which such a combination of dedication and contribution may be appropriate include, but are not limited to, where only a portion of the land proposed as the location for a land site and/or open space contribution is part of the subdivision or planned unit development seeking a final plat. In such a situation, the village board may require the subdivider or developer to dedicate that portion of the land site that is within the subdivision or planned unit development and then make a cash contribution equal to the difference between the actual acreage dedicated and the requirements under this section. 
e.  Taxing district board recommendations. 
1.  All recommendations, reports and supporting information required or permitted by this section shall be submitted to the village board in writing with all necessary exhibits. The receiving agency shall provide written notice of their recommendation to the village board at least ten business days in advance of the anticipated date of any annexation agreement and/or final plat approval by the village. 
2.  The recommendations of each taxing body shall be advisory only, and in no way binding upon the village board. 
3.  If the taxing district board's recommendation includes the acceptance of a park site, the park type, as described in the park district's park district master plan, as amended, shall be identified in the written correspondence to the village board. 
If the taxing district board's recommendation includes the acceptance of cash in-lieu-of land dedications, the taxing district shall also submit a signed certificate stating that all funds collected pursuant to subsection 78-72(a)(7) will serve the immediate and future needs of the residents of the subdivision from which the funds will be collected and that such funds will be expended in a manner prescribed by law. 
(8)  Other fees required. In addition to the land and/or cash contributions-in-lieu of land dedications required under subsections 78-72(a)(2) and 78-72(a)(7), supra, each subdivider or developer of a final plat of subdivision or planned unit development shall be required to make the following contributions to the village: 
a.  Municipal building fee of $851.00 per dwelling unit; and 
b.  Transportation fee of $1,019.00 per dwelling unit. 
c.  The contributions required above shall be payable at the time of application for a building permit on each lot or such other time as required by the village board. 
d.  Annual review-other fees. The village shall review, on or before December 31 of each year, the municipal building fee and transportation fee. Based on this review, the village shall revise the amounts of these fees, if necessary. 
(b)  Reserved. 
_____

(2)  For purposes of calculating the required land dedications for the development or construction of age-restricted adult or senior citizen housing, the estimated children listed in table 1 shall be excluded, provided that: 
a.  All requests for exemption under this section shall be submitted to the village administrator. 
b.  All such housing shall contain a deed or other restriction recorded against the property, in a form satisfactory to the village, which deed restriction shall provide that: 
1.  No person under the age of 18 years old shall reside within any such housing unit; and 
2.  In the event that the restrictions are modified or violated, the owner of the property at the time the restrictions are modified or violated shall pay to the village an amount equal to the then-current cash contribution in lieu of land required for children under this article. 
c.  Such age-restricted adult or senior citizen housing publishes and adheres to policies and procedures that demonstrate the intent of said restrictions in a form satisfactory to the village.

Sec. 78-73. - Inspection of improvements. 
    All public improvements proposed to be made under the provisions of this chapter shall be inspected during the course of construction by the village engineer or a duly designated deputy. All fees and specifications for such improvements shall be paid by the subdivider. 
(Code 1981, § 11-4-3) 
Sec. 78-74. - Time limits. 
(a)  Approval by village board. The village board shall act upon the final plat within 30 days, unless the village board and the applicant agree to extend the period, after the final plat has been submitted for approval. 
(b)  Execution and recording. The final plat shall be executed within 120 days following the passage of such final plat by motion and majority vote of the village board of trustees. If such execution is not completed within the 120-day period, such final plat shall be null and void. Upon execution of the final plat by the village, the developer shall record the final plat with the county recorder of deeds within 30 days. If the final plat is not recorded within this time, the approval shall be null and void. Deposits for surface improvements held by the village shall in that event be refunded to the depositor. 
(c)  Installation of improvements. All improvements required in accordance with the provisions of this chapter shall be completed within two years from the date of approval by the village board of the final plat of the subdivision. However, storm sewers, sanitary sewers, water mains, fire hydrants, road base, curbs, gutters and streetlights shall be installed within one year of recording the final plat of the subdivision. 
(Code 1981, § 11-4-4) 
Sec. 78-75. - Certificates and endorsements. 
    The village board shall, upon motion and majority vote, approve the final plat and authorize the president and village clerk to sign the original tracing. The certificates on the final plat shall be in the following form, with the signature of the president of the county board and the county clerk to be necessary only where the plat covers land in the unincorporated 11/2-mile fringe area: 
(1)  Plat approval. 
Under the authority provided by the Illinois Compiled Statutes, enacted by the State Legislature of the State of Illinois, and ordinance adopted by the Village of New Lenox, Illinois, this plat was given approval by the Village of New Lenox and must be recorded within 30 days of the date of execution by the President and Village Clerk. Otherwise it is null and void. 
Approved by the Plan Commission at a meeting held: ________.

Executed this ________ day of ________, ___. 
_____

_____

(2)  Surveyor's certificate. Each final plat submitted to the village for approval shall carry a certificate signed by an Illinois registered land surveyor in substantially the following form: 
I, (Name), hereby certify that I am an Illinois registered land surveyor in compliance with the laws of the State of Illinois and that this plat correctly represents a survey completed by me on (Date); that all monuments shown thereon actually exist, and materials are accurately shown. 
SEAL___________ 
Signature 
Illinois Land Surveyor No. ___________ 
(3)  Deed of dedication. Each final plat submitted to the village for approval shall carry a deed of dedication in substantially the following form: 
We, the undersigned, (Name), do hereby certify that we are the owners of the real estate shown and described herein and do hereby lay off, plat and subdivide said real estate in accordance with the within plat. This subdivision shall be known and designated as (Name), an addition of the Village of New Lenox, Will County. All streets, alleys and public open spaces shown and not heretofore dedicated are hereby dedicated to the public. Front and side yard building setback lines are hereby established as shown on this plat, between which lines and the property lines of the streets there shall be erected or maintained no building or structure. There are strips of ground, (Number) feet in width, as shown on this plat and marked "Easement" reserved for the use of public utilities for the installation of water and sewer mains, poles, ducts, lines and wires, subject at all times to the proper authorities and to the easement herein reserved. No permanent or other structures are to be erected or maintained upon said strips of land, but owners of lots in this subdivision shall take their titles subject to the rights of the public utilities, and to the rights of the owners of other lots in this subdivision. 
WITNESS our hands and Seals this _______ day of ________, 19___. 
_____

(4)  Other certificates, affidavits, endorsements or dedications. Such other certificates, affidavits, endorsements or dedications shall be included as may be required by the plan commission or the village board in these enforcement regulations. 
(Code 1981, § 11-4-5; Ord. No. 1310, § 1, 9-26-2000) 
Secs. 78-76-78-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DESIGN STANDARDS 

Sec. 78-101. - Street plan. 
    The subdivision of land, including the arrangement, character, extent, width, grade and location of all streets, alleys or other lands to be dedicated for public use, shall conform to the general development plan of the village as approved and adopted by the village board and other responsible governmental bodies, if any; and streets shall be considered in their relation to existing and planned streets, to topographic conditions, to public convenience and safety, and to their appropriate relation to the proposed uses of the land to be served by such streets, and shall be curvilineal, except for primary streets. 
(Code 1981, § 11-5-1) 
Sec. 78-102. - Right-of-way widths; street design standards. 
(a)  Minimum right-of-way widths. The minimum widths of rights-of-way for streets to be dedicated or established after the effective date hereof within the village or the environs under jurisdiction of this chapter shall conform to the following schedule: 
Primary streets, major streets and parkways 100 feet (located in accordance with master street plan) Secondary or collector streets or industrial streets  80 feet Minor streets  66 feet Culs-de-sac  75 feet Crosswalkways  10 feet Utility easements  20 feet (10 feet on each side of lot line)  
(b)  Right-of-way width for multifamily developments. The minimum widths of rights-of-way for multifamily developments shall be 72 feet. 
(c)  Right-of-way width for single-family developments. The minimum widths of rights-of-way for minor streets in single-family developments shall be 66 feet. 
(d)  Width of street pavement; roadways or rights-of-way under jurisdiction of agency other than village. 
(1)  Minimum pavement widths. With the exception of frontage roads and marginal access streets, no pavement less than 28 feet wide as measured from edge of pavement to edge of pavement as indicated on figure 11-5 will be allowed as part of the public improvements indicated in this chapter. 
(2)  Half streets constructed adjacent to existing roadway. Where a half street is proposed adjacent to or on any part of an existing roadway and where jurisdiction of the roadway is or will be transferred to the village as part of the development process, at least one-half of the pavement widths indicated on Standard Detail 16A, 16B, 16C or 16D must be new construction. The existing roadway surface may be combined with the new construction to obtain the 28-foot requirement as indicated on figure 11-5 with the approval of the village engineer. 
(3)  Roadways or rights-of-way under jurisdiction of agency other than village. Where a development abuts a roadway or right-of-way under the jurisdiction of any agency other than the village, and where the jurisdiction will remain with such agency following the development, roadway construction and/or improvements shall be done in accordance with the requirements of that agency. 
(e)  Design of minor streets; location of driveways on through lots. Minor streets shall be so laid out that their use by through traffic will be discouraged. Where a marginal or access street is used as a minor street in a residential subdivision with the lot having frontage on both the minor street and the primary, major, secondary or collector street, the covenants for the subdivision shall prohibit the installation of driveways along the property line of the lot which forms the line of a primary, major, secondary or collector street. 
(f)  Street jogs. Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than 125 feet shall be avoided. 
(g)  Visibility distance. Clear visibility, measured along the centerline of the street, shall be provided for at least 300 feet on all primary streets, at least 200 feet on secondary streets, and at least 100 feet on all other streets. 
(h)  Design of intersections. It must be evidenced that all street intersections and confluences encourage safe traffic flow. 
(i)  Alleys. 
(1)  Alleys shall be required in commercial and industrial districts. The plan commission shall refer any variations to the board of trustees for waiving this requirement if provisions are made for service access, such as off-street loading, unloading and parking, consistent with and adequate for the uses proposed. 
(2)  Alleys shall be prohibited in residential areas, except where topographic or other conditions may necessitate their use. 
(3)  The width of an alley shall not be less than 20 feet or more than 40 feet. 
(j)  Culs-de-sac. The length of a street terminating in a cul-de-sac shall be measured along the centerline of the road from the center of the circle to the near right-of-way of the intersecting street and shall not exceed 500 feet for subdivisions with lots having less than 15,000 square feet, or 900 feet for subdivisions with lots having at least 15,000 square feet and no more than 35,000 square feet, and in no case shall the length exceed 1,200 feet. Where there is a probability of extending a street beyond the present subdivision, a "T" turnaround should be considered, 20 feet wide by 30 feet in length, on both sides of the street right-of-way. Driveways shall not be constructed on "T" turnarounds. 
(k)  Half streets; reserve strips. Half streets shall be prohibited, except where essential to the reasonable development of the subdivision in conformity with the other requirements of this chapter, and where the plan commission and board of trustees find it will be practicable to require the dedication of the other half when adjoining property is subdivided. Wherever a half street is adjacent to a tract to be subdivided, the other half of the street shall be placed within such tract. No strip or area shall be reserved along any portion of a street, half street or alley which will prevent adjacent property owners access thereto, except by consent of the village board. 
(l)  Street names. Street names which are not approved by the plan commission, or which will duplicate or be confused with the names of existing streets in the New Lenox, Joliet and Mokena postal delivering districts, shall not be used. Existing street names must be projected wherever possible. 
(m)  Subdivisions bordering on or containing major streets. Where a subdivision borders on or contains an existing or proposed major street, the plan commission and board of trustees may require a marginal access street or reversed frontage with screen planting contained in a nonaccess reservation, which shall have a minimum width of ten feet along the rear property line, or other treatment as may be adequate for protection of residential properties and to afford separation of through and local traffic. 
(n)  Entrances from highways under state jurisdiction. If the tract of land proposed to be subdivided or any part thereof lies adjacent to a highway over which the department of transportation of the state has jurisdiction with respect to maintenance and upkeep thereof, and an entrance is desired from such highway to lots, streets, roadways or alleys in such proposed subdivision, the subdivider shall submit to the plan commission of the village a written permit from the department of transportation granting its permission to obtain and construct such an entrance. 
(o)  Curves. 
(1)  Roads shall be designed so that all deflections in horizontal alignment will be accomplished through segments of circular curves properly incorporated into the design. The minimum permitted centerline radii shall be as follows: 
a.  Primary or secondary streets: 450 feet. 
b.  Minor (residential) streets: 250 feet. 
c.  All other streets: 150 feet. 
(2)  A tangent of at least 100 feet shall be introduced between two curves either one of which has a radius of 250 feet or less. 
(Code 1981, § 11-5-2) 
Editor's note- Figure 11-5, referred to in the preceding section, is not printed herein, but is on file in the village offices. 
Sec. 78-103. - Easements. 
    Easements across lots or centered on rear or side lot lines shall be provided for utilities, street lighting and drainage, where necessary, and shall be at least 20 feet wide (ten feet on each side of the lot line). The easement shall be so laid out that a proper continuity may be had from lot to lot and from block to block. In addition, due provisions for extension of easements to adjacent areas shall be made. Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainageway, channel or stream, there shall be provided a stormwater easement or drainage right-of-way conforming substantially with the lines of such watercourse, and of such further width or construction, or both, as will be adequate for the purpose and approved by the village engineer. 
(Code 1981, § 11-5-3) 
Sec. 78-104. - Residential blocks. 
    Standards for residential blocks are as follows: 
(1)  Length; crosswalks. The maximum length of blocks permitted is 1,800 feet. Blocks over 800 feet may require crosswalk easements. Crosswalk easements not less than ten feet in width shall be provided where deemed necessary by the plan commission at the approximate centers of the blocks. The use of additional crosswalkways in any instance to provide safe and convenient access to schools, parks or other similar destinations may be recommended by the plan commission. 
(2)  Shape. No specific rule concerning the shape of blocks is made, but blocks must fit easily into the overall plan of the village and their design must evidence consideration of lot planning, traffic flow and public areas. 
(Code 1981, § 11-5-4) 
Sec. 78-105. - Residential lots. 
    Standards for residential lots are as follows: 
(1)  All side lot lines shall be at right angles to straight street lines, or radial to curved street lines, unless a variation to this rule will give a better street and lot plan. Lots with double frontage shall be avoided. All residential lots shall abut on a publicly dedicated street. 
(2)  The minimum area of lots resulting from the subdivision of tracts within the village after the effective date of Ordinance No. 708 shall be 9,375 square feet, and lots shall have a minimum of 75 feet frontage at the required building line, except as otherwise provided in the zoning provisions of this Code (chapter 106). 
(3)  Except as provided in section 78-7, the minimum width of residential lots at the building line shall be as follows, provided the original frontage of the land to be subdivided is 150 feet or more: 
a.  All lots containing an area of 12,500 square feet or more, but less than 15,000 square feet, shall have a minimum frontage of 75 feet. 
b.  All lots containing an area of 15,000 square feet or more, but less than 20,000 square feet, shall have a minimum frontage of 90 feet. 
c.  All lots containing an area of 20,000 square feet or more, but less than 30,000 square feet, shall have a minimum frontage of 100 feet. 
d.  All lots containing an area of 30,000 square feet or more, but less than one acre, shall have a minimum frontage of 125 feet. 
e.  All lots containing an area of one acre, but not more than five acres, shall have a minimum frontage of 150 feet or a frontage equal to 40 percent of the lot depth, whichever is greater. 
(4)  Where the lots front upon a cul-de-sac or curved road or street having a radius of 200 feet or less, the minimum width of the frontage at the lot may be measured at the building line, with the width at the right-of-way line to be not less than 54 feet, with such width being measured on the arc of the street right-of-way line. 
(5)  The area of the street right-of-way, whether dedicated to the public or a private street or easement for street purposes, shall not be included in calculating the area of the lot to be in accordance with the minimum lot area requirements of the zoning district in which the lot is located. Lots with an area larger than the minimum requirements are desirable. The lot shall also have a width and a depth entirely adequate to provide the necessary yard requirements of the zoning regulations of this Code (chapter 106). 
(6)  Where corner lots back upon lots facing the side street, the corner lots shall have extra width sufficient to permit the establishment of front building lines on both the front and the side of the lots adjoining the streets. Extra widths shall be provided on all corner lots irrespective of whether they rear upon lots facing the side streets. 
(7)  Lots upon major highway intersections and at all other acute angle intersections which, in the opinion of the plan commission, are likely to be dangerous to traffic movement, shall have a radius of 25 feet at the street corner. On business lots, a chord may be substituted, with the approval of the commission, for the circular arc. Where grade separation structures are proposed at the intersection of major highways, the lots and improvements in the subdivision shall be arranged so as to make adequate provision for such structures. 
(8)  Lots abutting a watercourse, drainageway, channel or stream shall have additional minimum width or depth as required to provide an adequate building site and afford the minimum usable area required in the zoning regulations of the village (chapter 106) for front, rear and side yards. 
(Code 1981, § 11-5-5) 
Sec. 78-106. - Subdivisions in commercial districts. 
    The minimum standards for design and improvement of subdivisions developed in areas zoned for commercial use after the effective date of Ordinance No. 708 shall be in accordance with the requirements for planned commercial districts as stipulated in chapter 106, article III, division 4. These standards shall apply regardless of whether the subdivision is platted for sale in lots, tracts or parcels or is planned to be held in one ownership and leased. 
(Code 1981, § 11-5-6) 
Sec. 78-107. - Subdivisions in industrial districts. 
    The minimum standards for design and improvement of subdivisions developed in areas zoned for industrial use after the effective date of Ordinance No. 708 shall be in accordance with the requirements for planned industrial districts as stipulated in chapter 106, article III, division 5. These standards shall apply regardless of whether the subdivision is platted for sale in lots, tracts or parcels, or is planned to be held in one ownership and leased. 
(Code 1981, § 11-5-7) 
Sec. 78-108. - Building lines. 
(a)  Minimum building lines shall be shown on plats of subdivisions within the incorporated area of the village which are intended for residential use of any character, and on commercial or industrial lots immediately adjoining such residential areas. Such building lines on lots adjacent to major highways shall not be less than the building and setback lines established by any ordinance of the village board. In all cases, building lines shall not be less than required by any zoning regulation applying to the property. Where the subdivided area is not under zoning control, the subdivider shall establish building lines in accordance with the needs of each addition, but in no case shall such building lines be less than 30 feet from the right-of-way of the street or highway upon which the lot fronts, except, where all frontage on one side of the street between two intersecting streets is to be used for commercial or industrial purposes, the minimum building lines shall not be less than 30 feet from the right-of-way lines of the streets adjoining the commercial or industrial area. 
(b)  Restrictions requiring buildings to be set back to such building lines shall either be shown on the plat or shall be contained in a separately recorded instrument and referred to in the plat. 
(c)  Building lines for territory outside the incorporated limits but within the jurisdiction of this chapter shall conform to the provisions of this chapter, except that in no instance shall the building line be less than 30 feet from the street right-of-way line. 
(Code 1981, § 11-5-8) 
Sec. 78-109. - Grading and seeding of rights-of-way and other public use areas. 
    All improved areas within the dedicated street area or other public use areas shall be graded and seeded in an approved manner. 
(Code 1981, § 11-5-9; Ord. No. 1114, § 1, 11-27-1996) 
Secs. 78-110-78-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 78-131. - General provisions. 
(a)  Applicability of requirements. All subdivisions shall be improved by the subdivider with the improvements enumerated in this chapter, and all such improvements shall comply with the specifications for such improvements adopted by the village. 
(b)  Compilation and filing of specifications. The specifications adopted by the village for the improvements required in this chapter shall be compiled by the village engineer and filed with the village clerk. 
(c)  Standards for road construction. Reference is made to the current edition of the Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction in Illinois, referred to in this article as the "Standard Specifications." 
(d)  Changes to specifications. The village engineer shall also review the specifications for improvements required in this chapter and prepare any additions or modifications of such specifications and submit such additional or modified specifications to the president and the board of trustees for adoption. Upon adoption of any specifications for improvements required in this chapter, the village engineer shall file these specifications with the village clerk. 
(e)  Standards for bituminous concrete surfacing. Whenever this chapter, in the specifications adopted by the village, permits the use of bituminous concrete surfacing, such surfacing shall conform to the Illinois Department of Transportation Specifications for Bituminous Concrete Binder and Surface Courses, Class 1, adopted January 2, 1971, or future supplemental specifications adopted from time to time. 
(f)  Specifications adopted by reference. All specifications adopted by the village for the improvements required by this article are incorporated in the applicable sections by reference, and all improvements shall comply with the specifications adopted by the village. 
(g)  Resubdivisions. In case of resubdivision of areas to be subdivided where any of the improvements are already installed which meet the requirements of this article, no further provisions to duplicate such installations shall be required; provided, however, that where such installations have become worn out, broken or defective or do not meet village standards, the subdivider shall be required to repair and correct such defects. 
(h)  Existing streets not meeting width requirements. If property for which an application to subdivide has been presented abuts on or contains an existing public street which has width or pavement less than required by section 78-133, the subdivider shall be required to dedicate additional land sufficient for and shall provide and construct additional pavement to bring roadway widths up to the minimum standards contained in section 78-133 before the approval of the property for subdivision or resubdivision. 
(i)  Pavement merging adjustments; marking of driving and parking lanes. The village engineer shall determine that proper adjustments are made where the widenings merge with the existing narrow widths of pavement at the boundary of the property and shall require that the lanes be painted to designate driving and parking lanes. 
(j)  Construction traffic routing plan. Any planned development, whether residential, commercial or otherwise in nature, that is proposed to abut an existing active residential area and whose proposed roadway pattern will attach to and extend existing roadways must include a construction traffic routing proposal. This proposed routing should utilize existing alternative access routes, and temporary private roads if necessary, to minimize as much as possible the inconvenient impacts normally associated with development construction to the existing residents. 
(1)  The routing, phasing/sequence of the final platting (if applicable), and construction traffic routing proposal must be shown on the construction plans submitted for review and approval. 
(2)  In those instances where a temporary road is required, the road shall be constructed of a dustfree surface and maintained exclusively by the developer/subdivider. 
(3)  Directional signs to be used in conjunction with the construction traffic routing proposal shall comply with the following standards: 
a.  Color and materials: White, metal. 
b.  Size: 24 inches by 36 inches on white metal posts. 
c.  Lettering: Two-inch black letters, all caps. 
d.  Height: 60 inches above grade at the top of the sign. 
(Code 1981, § 11-6-1) 
Sec. 78-132. - Monuments. 
(a)  Permanent monuments shall be placed at all corners and at points of tangency of curve lines along the boundary of the subdivision. Permanent monuments shall be of concrete with minimum dimensions of four inches by four inches at the top, and six inches by six inches at the bottom, and shall be 36 inches long, with a copper dowel three-eighths inch in diameter, at least 21/2 inches in length, embedded so that the top of the dowel shall be flush with the surface and at the center of the monument. 
(b)  All lot corners not marked by concrete monuments shall be marked by galvanized or wrought iron pipe or iron or steel bars at least 18 inches in length and not less than one-half inch in diameter. The top of the pipe or bar is to be set level with the established grade of the ground. 
(c)  In addition, a minimum of one permanent benchmark shall be established for each 50 acres, or fraction thereof, subdivided, at a location designated by the village engineer. This monument shall be of concrete with minimum dimensions of four inches by four inches at the top, and six inches by six inches at the bottom, and shall be 48 inches long, with a brass plate securely fastened to the surface. On the brass plate shall be inscribed the number and elevation of the benchmark. 
(Code 1981, § 11-6-2) 
Sec. 78-133. - Street construction. 
(a)  Paving and curbs required. All new streets within the corporate limits of the village dedicated or platted after the effective date hereof shall be improved with roadway paving and bordered by Portland cement concrete curbs, in accordance with table 1 at the end of this section. 
(b)  General standards. Reference is made to the Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction, State of Illinois, current edition, however, where detailed specifications contained in this chapter differ from the Standard Specifications, the detailed specifications contained in this chapter shall supersede the Standard Specifications. 
(c)  Designation of street classification. The classification of new streets, as well as variations to street classifications shown in table 1 for a given street, must be submitted to the village engineer for his review prior to submittal of the preliminary plat to the planning commission. 
(d)  Variations. The pavement design and right-of-way chart (table 1 at the end of this section) is intended to show minimum right-of-way widths and the minimum design standards for a particular street classification. If, in the opinion of the village engineer, traffic use or geometric considerations for a road or a part of a road warrant a greater right-of-way width, a wider pavement width and/or greater structural number than listed on the chart, the village engineer shall submit his written reasons to the planning commission prior to the approval of the final plat. Variations to the requirements of table 1 shall be considered only as a variation to this article. 
(e)  Pavement design. All pavement shall be designed in accordance with the Standard Specifications and manuals of the state department of transportation. The design thickness shall be dependent on the soil support value and the projected traffic factor. However, in no case shall structural numbers be less than those shown in table 1 at the end of this section. 
(f)  Subgrade materials. 
(1)  All subgrade materials shall have a minimum Illinois Bearing Ratio (IBR) of 2.5. Subgrade material having an IBR less than 2.5 shall be removed and replaced with a suitable fill material, or the pavement must be designed to compensate for the soil conditions. The soil support IBR values selected for use by the designer shall represent a minimum value for the soil to be used. 
(2)  A copy of all design assumptions and computations on which the proposed design is based shall be submitted to the village engineer. 
(g)  Materials testing. Concurrent with construction of any pavement within the village corporate limits, the developer must furnish the village engineer with copies of the certificates of testing from the state department of transportation or from a testing laboratory which has been prequalified by the state department of transportation for bituminous aggregate mixture and bituminous mixture, class 1, and as shown in table 2 at the end of this section. All material design and mixes shall conform to applicable state department of transportation specifications. 
(h)  Flexible pavements. The design of all flexible pavement shall be based on the following criteria: 
(1)  For streets with an ADT less than 400, the minimum street design shall be seven inches of aggregate base course, two inches of bituminous concrete binder course class 1, and one inch of bituminous concrete surface class 1. 
(2)  For streets with an ADT greater than 400, the street shall be designed around the street classification and structural number as indicated in table 1 at the end of this section. 
(3)  A minimum of three inches of compacted asphalt is required on all pavement with a structural number of 3.00 to 3.99. This surface shall consist of a one-inch surface course, class 1, and two inches of binder course, class 1. Pavement with a structural number of 4.00 to 4.99 shall require four inches of compacted asphalt. The surface course shall consist of 11/2 inches of class 1, and the binder course shall consist of 21/2 inches of class 1. 
(i)  Allowable pavement construction materials. All materials as indicated in table 3 at the end of this section will be allowed for use in roadway construction within the village. Listed with these materials are the coefficients to be used in order to arrive at the structural number. These coefficients, when multiplied by the thickness of the materials, will yield the structural number. 
(j)  Grading, shaping and rolling of subgrade. The subgrade of all roads shall be graded, shaped and rolled to roadway elevations in accordance with section 212 of the Standard Specifications. Testing for subgrade shall be performed in accordance with table 2 at the end of this section. 
(k)  Longitudinal grade. The longitudinal gradient of streets shall not be in excess of four percent on primary, major or secondary streets, or in excess of six percent on other streets, unless approved by the village engineer, or have a minimum grade of less than 0.35 percent. 
(l)  Minimum radius at intersections. The minimum radius at intersections shall be 20 feet for minor streets intersecting with minor streets and 25 feet for all others. 
(m)  Special requirements. Where the gradient of the street warrants installation of vertical-type curbs or other special design improvements, such as double inlets, the village engineer is authorized to require such design. 
(n)  Multifamily developments. Streets within or abutting subdivisions containing multifamily developments shall have sidewalks on both sides of the street and shall have no less than: 
(1)  A 72-foot right-of-way. 
(2)  A 36-foot-wide pavement from back of curb to back of curb. 
(o)  Industrial developments. 
(1)  Where the subdivision plat contains two or more lots having an average of three acres or less, the minimum design standards for the widths of street rights-of-way and paving for industrial subdivisions or developments shall be the same or of a higher specification than required for secondary streets in this chapter, and shall also be subject to such additional design and improvement standards as may be recommended by the plan commission, the village engineer and the board of trustees. 
(2)  Where an industrial tract having more than 20 acres has frontage on an existing primary or major highway shown on the official plan of the village, the driveways serving the principal building may be designed and installed with the same pavement standards required for industrial or secondary streets in articles III and IV of this chapter, provided a circulation plan for driveway design, improvements and direction of traffic flow is submitted to and approved by the village plan commission. 
(p)  Intersections with county, state or federal highways. Where property has frontage on a county, state or federal highway, the spacing and design of the point of ingress and egress to the major highway shall be subject to the approval of the regional engineer of the state department of transportation, or the superintendent of highways, county highway department. 
(q)  Continuity of gradient. 
(1)  Street gradients shall be designed with proper continuity for collector, secondary and major arteries without abrupt changes, and all intersections shall be properly platformed to prevent hazards. The platform shall be subject to review by the village engineer. The adjustment of the grade of private driveways with the public roadways shall be subject to review and approval by the village engineer and shall avoid abrupt changes or drainage pockets. 
(2)  All breaks in street gradient shall be accomplished through suitable vertical curves properly incorporated into the design of street profiles. 
(r)  Maintenance responsibility. 
(1)  The maintenance of all nondedicated roadways shall be the responsibility of the developer/owner or the homeowners' association. 
(2)  All public improvements shall be under warranty for all defects and failures for a period of two years. The guarantee of those improvements which will be dedicated to the village shall be for a period of two years from the date of acceptance of such improvements. Those improvements in private areas shall be guaranteed for a period of two years from the date of the release of the subdivision improvement security. In cases where the entire subdivision is not completed, but the guarantee period has begun on some improvements, the completed improvements shall be measured and documented in a manner acceptable to the village engineer or public works superintendent. 
(s)  State department of transportation permits. The developer shall procure any access permits required for driveways and/or streets which will intersect state highways. 
(t)  Pavement patching. Patching of existing pavement shall conform to the following: 
(1)  Trench backfill material shall be FA-6 or approved stone screenings mechanically compacted in one-foot lifts to within eight inches from the surface and shall be free from all organic and foreign material. 
(2)  Concrete shall be placed on the trench backfill a thickness of six inches to within two inches from the surface. Two three-inch lifts of bituminous binder course may be used in lieu of concrete only when approved by the village engineer. Asphalt prime shall be applied prior to installation of the binder course. 
(3)  The surface shall include a bituminous concrete surface course two inches thick compacted to meet the existing pavement elevations. 
(4)  All edges shall be saw cut. 
(5)  Materials shall be installed as shown on Standard Detail No. 24.
