(Code 1981, § 11-6-3; Ord. No. 2310, § 4, 12-17-2012) 
Sec. 78-134. - Street lighting. 
(a)  Generally. 
(1)  The street lighting system shall consist of poles, mast arms, luminaries, wire and all other materials and work necessary to provide a complete street lighting system. The developer shall provide all labor, equipment and materials necessary to install a complete street lighting system as shown on the engineering plans. 
(2)  Any street lighting system which is to be accepted by the village must be constructed within a dedicated public right-of-way or easement and shall be served by underground wiring with connection to a power supply from the Commonwealth Edison Company. 
(b)  Streetlight locations; time of installation. 
(1)  A streetlight standard shall be located at each street intersection, at the turnaround of each cul-de-sac, and at 400-foot to 600-foot intervals alternating on both sides of the roadway. Each streetlight standard shall be installed in the parkway three feet in back of the curb and shall be coordinated with the development. 
(2)  In all cases, the street lighting system shall be installed before the expiration of the subdivider's letter of credit. 
(c)  Material and equipment specifications. 
(1)  Poles. 
a.  Light standards are to be concrete poles manufactured by Centrecon, Inc., Catalog Number MEO-7.5, Appearance Code Number 112, with Davitarm No. MO-AD-8, as shown on the construction detail. 
b.  Poles shall be embedded into the ground five feet and shall be vertically plumb. The pole shall be set so that the hand hole is located on the opposite side from the luminaire. 
c.  The distance from the finished grade to the center of the hand hole shall be 18 inches. 
d.  Light standards shall be manufactured of concrete, centrifugally cast, prestressed and reinforced with steel. The standards shall have smooth ground and polished surfaces. The light standard shall contain a raceway throughout the entire length of the interior of the standard. 
(2)  Wire. Underground wire from the power source to the lighting standard shall be no. 6 copper stranded XLP-USE direct burial cable. Hand hole to luminaire cable shall be ten gauge THHN copper stranded. 
(3)  Luminaries. Luminaries shall be General Electric Catalog Number M2AC10SON2GMC31 multi 120/240 volt with photo cell Fisher Price 6690B, high pressure sodium, 100 watt LU100 GE Lucalox HPS lamps. 
(4)  Fuses and fuse holder. Fuse holders shall be Buss HEB-AA in-line fuse holder with 1A0512 cover. Fuses shall be Buxx FNM-10. 
(5)  Power closures. Power closures shall be Midwest U065P, 60 amp nonfused disconnect with hasp, 240 volt, single phase, Nema 3R. 
(6)  Installation. All items shall be installed in accordance with the standard detail with the intention of supplying a complete street lighting system. 
(d)  Commercial subdivisions. In commercial subdivisions, streetlight type and location will be determined during the design review of the public improvements for the subdivision in consideration of pavement and right-of-way width and cross section, adjacent land use, roadway classification and illumination requirements in accordance with guidelines established by the Institute of Traffic Engineers. 
(Code 1981, § 11-6-4; Ord. No. 1170, § 1, 11-12-1997) 
Sec. 78-135. - Curb and gutter. 
(a)  Required; placement on subgrade. In subdivisions, Portland cement concrete curb and gutter shall be placed on both sides of the street and shall be placed on a subgrade checked and approved by the village engineer. 
(b)  Specifications for concrete. All concrete shall meet state department of transportation specifications for class X concrete, 3,500 psi in 14 days. Concrete slump shall be from two to four inches. All work shall be in accordance with section 616 of the Standard Specifications unless otherwise noted. 
(c)  Contraction joints. Contraction joints shall be constructed every 25 linear feet and shall be one-eighth inch in thickness and shall penetrate at least two inches below the surface. 
(d)  Expansion joints. Expansion joints shall be three-fourths-inch-thick preformed expansion joint filler cut to the exact cross section of the curb or gutter. Expansion joints shall be placed at a minimum of 200 feet and at every radius point. 
(e)  Type and design. Curb and gutter shall be type B-6.12 on primary or major streets and type M-6.12 on minor streets and shall conform to the standard details. 
(Code 1981, § 11-6-5) 
Sec. 78-136. - Sidewalks. 
(a)  Required; location; width and thickness. In subdivisions, Portland cement concrete sidewalks shall be constructed on both sides of the street, and shall be one foot from the property line of the lots and along such line as extended at intersections, and shall be a minimum of four feet from the street curb or roadway when possible. Sidewalks shall be four feet in width and not less than five inches in thickness. 
(b)  Specifications for concrete. All concrete shall meet state department of transportation specifications for class X concrete, 3,500 psi in 14 days. Concrete slump shall be from two to four inches. All work shall be in accordance with section 624 of the Standard Specifications, unless otherwise noted in the specifications. 
(c)  Subgrade preparation. The subgrade shall be tamped or rolled until thoroughly compacted. At locations where a sidewalk is constructed at entrances, the sidewalk shall be thickened to the thickness of the adjacent entrance or driveway pavement. All subgrade shall be prepared with sufficient granular material to form a level working platform for concrete pavement of three inches minimum depth. Material shall be approved sand, road mix or gravel. 
(d)  Expansion joints. Expansion joints of the thickness specified in this subsection shall consist of preformed joint filler. The top of the joint shall be in place one-fourth inch below the surface of the sidewalk. 
(1)  One-half-inch expansion joints. Expansion joints one-half inch thick shall be placed between the sidewalk and all structures such as light standards, traffic light standards, traffic poles and subway columns which extend through the sidewalk. 
(2)  Three-fourths-inch expansion joints. Expansion joints three-fourths inch thick shall be placed at intervals of not more than 100 feet in the sidewalk. Where the sidewalk is constructed adjacent to pavement or a curb having expansion joints, the expansion joints in the sidewalk shall be placed opposite the existing expansion joints as nearly as practicable. Expansion joints shall also be placed where the sidewalk abuts existing sidewalks, between driveway pavement and the sidewalk, and between the sidewalk and curbs where the sidewalk abuts a curb. 
(e)  Commercial locations. Sidewalks shall be required at all commercial locations within the village upon being granted a building permit to construct the commercial structure or to enlarge, alter or restore a commercial building to an amount equal to or in excess of 50 percent of the cost of the entire building or structure. The 50 percent determination shall be made by the building and zoning administrator, who shall calculate the cost of the current structure and proposed improvement from the BOCA Valuation Data Report (as referenced in exhibit A of Ordinance No. 982), and as adjusted by plus five percent on each subsequent May 1. All sidewalks in commercial locations shall be five feet in width and not less than five inches in thickness, shall be located on the public right-of-way one foot off the property line or at a location approved by the village engineer, and shall conform to all other specifications of this Code regulating the construction of sidewalks. 
(f)  Estate zoning district. Sidewalks are not required as part of subdivision improvements in the estate zoning district provided that walks are not needed to continue a master or regional sidewalk plan that encompasses the development under consideration. 
(Code 1981, § 11-6-6) 
Sec. 78-137. - Water supply, fire hydrants and sanitary sewer system. 
    No subdivision shall be approved without water supply and sanitary sewer and sewage treatment facilities in accordance with the following minimum standards or the posting of surety bonds or security approved by the village board guaranteeing such improvements in accordance with this chapter. Before recommending approval of a subdivision, the plan commission will consider the availability of sanitary sewer facilities, or the lack thereof, to the proposed subdivision. The following shall be the minimum requirements: 
(1)  Where public water supply and sanitary sewers and sewage treatment facilities are available, the facilities shall be designed and installed in the street right-of-way, to connect to the public sewer and water system, and with approval by the village engineer in accordance with the following requirements, regardless of the size of lots in the subdivision: 
a.  Water supply and fire hydrants. Water mains, fire hydrants and services shall be provided to serve all lots and to provide for reasonable expansion of the system. Fire hydrants shall be installed at a maximum of 300-foot intervals on all water mains. Water mains shall be designed using the criteria of the state environmental protection agency, and in accordance with the requirements of the New Lenox Fire Protection District; provided, however, the inside diameter in no case shall be less than six inches. Fire hydrants shall be of Meuller or Traverse City manufacture or their equivalent, with auxiliary valves and boxes (vaults excepted). Fire hydrants shall have a 41/2-inch valve opening and 21/2-inch connections. All valves and fire hydrants shall open counterclockwise. Minimum earth cover for water mains shall be five feet. 
b.  Sewers. Sanitary sewers and services of approved design and capacity with a minimum earth cover of six feet shall be provided to serve all lots and to provide for reasonable expansions of the system. Sanitary sewers shall be designed using the criteria of the state environmental protection agency. Sanitary sewer manholes shall be located at points which will minimize the possibility of submergence in storms. Manholes, frames and grates shall be equivalent to Neenah Foundry R-1015, with self-sealing lids, and shall be imprinted "Sewer." Manholes shall be located at intervals of 400 feet to facilitate maintenance of the sanitary sewer system. 
(2)  All residential lots having an area of less than 20,000 square feet and all commercial and industrial subdivisions or developments shall be required to install public water and sanitary sewer facilities in accordance with subsections (1)a and b of this section. 
(3)  Where lots have an area of 20,000 square feet and a frontage of 100 feet or more in a location where a public water supply or a central water system is available with a capacity of 20,000 gallons per day serving more than ten lots and no public sanitary sewer system is available, the developer shall install water mains and hydrants or post surety bonds or security approved by the village board as stipulated in subsection (1)a of this section, and shall either install or post surety bonds guaranteeing installation of approved individual septic tanks. 
(4)  Where lots have an area of 20,000 square feet and a frontage of 100 feet or more in a location where a public sanitary sewer is available and no public water supply or central water system is available with a capacity of 20,000 gallons per day serving more than ten lots, the developer shall install sanitary sewers or post surety bonds or security approved by the village board as stipulated in subsection (1)b of this section, and shall install an individual well and water supply system or post a surety bond guaranteeing such installation. 
(5)  Where lots have an area of 40,000 square feet or more and a minimum frontage of 100 feet and no public sewer or public or central water supply system is available, the developer shall install individual wells and water supply and individual septic tanks or mechanical sewage treatment systems, or post surety bonds or security approved by the village board guaranteeing such installations. The design, installation and inspection of such individual systems shall be governed by the county sewage treatment and disposal ordinance in effect at the time of application. When conflicts arise between the county sewage treatment ordinance and this Code, this Code shall supersede the county ordinance. Where individual wells and septic tanks are to be used on the same lot, the preliminary subdivision plans for the lots shall show, in addition to the usual data, the following items: 
a.  The proposed location of the water wells for each lot. Where there are existing wells or septic tanks on the lot or on adjoining lots, they must also be shown. 
b.  A circular area with a radius of 75 feet around each well to denote clear space in which no sewage system is to be located. 
c.  The outfall area for soil absorption of the effluent from the septic tank, which must be situated beyond the 75-foot radius and downgrade from the proposed house location, with soil absorption meeting percolation test requirements. 
d.  Swamps, rock outcroppings or flood zones, when they exist on the property or adjacent property. 
(6)  All water supply and sanitary sewer systems which are installed or to be installed in the public ways or in easements serving a central system shall be deemed to be dedicated to the village upon the acceptance of the subdivision. In all cases where a central water supply system and sewer facilities are installed pursuant to the provisions of this section, the water supply system and sewer facilities shall be deemed dedicated to the village upon approval of the plat of the subdivision. 
(Code 1981, § 11-6-7) 
Sec. 78-138. - Storm sewer system. 
(a)  Generally. Every subdivision shall have storm sewers separate and independent of the sanitary sewer system and with an adequate outlet or connection with the existing storm sewer system. The storm sewers shall be provided to accept and convey all stormwaters entering upon the subdivision. They shall be designed on the basis of a ten-year storm and shall be sized to adequately carry all tributary areas at such time as they are developed to the density shown on the master plan of the village. 
(b)  Inlets and outlets; pipe size. Rear inlets shall be provided with a catchbasin bottom having a depth of at least two feet, and the outlet pipes shall be installed in such a manner as to preclude the entrance of floating matter into the storm sewer. Rear yard inlets shall have a frame and grate similar to Neenah Foundry R-2579. Curb inlet frames and grates shall be similar to Neenah Foundry R-3503 or R-3286-8V. Manhole covers shall be similar to Neenah Foundry R-2015, and imprinted "Storm Sewer." Storm sewers shall have a catchbasin type inlet and pipes sized to flow full with a minimum velocity of two feet per second. 
(c)  Use of open channels. Open channels of trapezoidal design may be provided on an optional basis in lieu of enclosed storm sewer pipe where the following acreages and conditions are met: 
(1)  If the channel will serve as the outlet for the enclosed storm sewers from a drainage area of 80 acres or more, the trapezoidal channel shall have a flat base of eight feet or more in width, a side slope of 3:1, and an easement of 15 feet or more in width with sodding on the full width. 
(2)  If the channel will serve as the outlet for a drainage area of 160 acres or more, the trapezoidal channel shall have a flat base of ten feet or more, a side slope of 3:1, and an easement 20 feet or more in width with sodding on the full width. 
(3)  If the channel will serve as the outlet for a drainage area of 240 acres or more, the trapezoidal channel shall have a base of 15 feet or more, a side slope of 11/2:1, and an easement of 30 feet or more, with a six-foot chainlink fence topped with three strands of barbed wire on arms pointing out. 
(4)  Open channels serving a drainage area of more than 360 acres shall be subject to design and easement requirements to be stipulated by the village engineer at the time the subdivider's preliminary plat and preliminary improvement design are submitted. 
(5)  No open channels shall be permitted within 500 feet of any property used for school, church or park purposes. 
(d)  Discharge of subsurface seepage water. Effective on the date of approval of the ordinance from which this subsection is derived, all new subdivisions shall install, as part of their public improvements, individual stormwater services for the discharge of subsurface seepage water per the following criteria: 
(1)  Trunk lines shall be constructed of minimum six-inch SDR 35 type rubber gasketed PVC sewer pipe to be located in the road right-of-way six feet from the front property lines or adjusted as necessary to avoid conflict with public walks. Lines shall have a tracer wire installed immediately above them terminating at the cleanouts, stubs and catchbasin. The wire shall be strapped to stubs and cleanouts with nylon cable ties. 
(2)  Trunk lines shall be installed a minimum of 30 inches below the top of the curb and shall follow the vertical curb alignment. 
(3)  Trunk lines shall originate at the nearest curb inlet or storm sewer manhole. 
(4)  Six-inch stubs shall be provided at every other property line to service two adjoining lots. Stubs shall have a six-inch wye attached to the end to allow connection of two adjacent lots and be a minimum of six feet in length. Stubs shall be left in a vertical position, to permit easier location, until connection by the individual builder. At that time, which must be prior to installation of the public walk, the builder shall trench across the six-foot area between the trunk line and the property line and lower the stub to an acceptable level, maintaining positive grade, and backfill with suitable granular fill to prevent settling of the public walk. 
(5)  Trunk lines shall terminate at the nearest property line of the last lot to be serviced, with a surface cleanout at the proposed sidewalk grade. Upon installation, the sidewalk shall be stamped "clean out" at the appropriate locations. 
(6)  Trunk lines shall be six-inch for up to four homes, and eight-inch for five to ten homes. In no event shall more than ten homes be connected to any one continuous trunk line. 
(7)  All bends will be constructed with sanitary tees and cleanouts. 
(8)  From the subsurface seepage water trunk line stub at the property line to a point directly below the sump pump discharge, the builder will install 4" SDR 35 type rubber gasketed PVC sewer pipes bedded with C7 stone, at sufficient slope to maintain flow and an adequate depth to prevent freezing. At time of connection to the wye fitting at the front property line, the builder shall cap any open remaining parts to prevent soil intrusion prior to the adjacent builder's connection to the system. This line shall not be directly connected to the sump pump discharge. An air gap must be maintained for the unlikely event of trunk line surcharge. A tracer wire shall be installed immediately above this line, connection the main line tracer, and strapped to the exposed end of the line with a nylon cable tie. 
(Code 1981, § 11-6-8; Ord. No. 1356, § 1, 9-19-2001) 
Sec. 78-139. - Grading and drainage. 
(a)  Grading generally; drainage easements. Grading of all lots and streets within the village shall be accomplished in such a manner as to prevent ponding (see the definition in section 78-2) in excess of eight inches in the event of a complete failure of the storm sewer system. Except in special cases, grading on all lots shall be kept within the range of 0.50 percent and 5.00 percent. Drainage easements shall be provided in all cases where surface waters from more than one lot are conveyed down a property line. 
(b)  Drainage plan. A single-sheet comprehensive grading and drainage plan shall be included in the engineering drawings. This drawing shall provide all existing and proposed topographical contour information as well as specified pad or foundation elevations in conjunction with drainage elevations for rear yard and side yard swales. 
(c)  Drainage certificate. A drainage certificate (see the following sample) shall be signed by permittee declaring knowledge and acceptance of drainage and grading for the specified lot. 
SITE ADDRESS: ___________

The undersigned, ___________, hereby affirms and acknowledges as follows, to wit: 
(1)  That I am the applicant, or the authorized agent for the applicant, in Building Permit No. _____ with the Village of New Lenox, Illinois. 
(2)  That certain drainage requirements must be met with regards to the subject lot of Building Permit No. _____ in order to comply with the comprehensive drainage plan. 
(3)  That I have been given the drainage plan for the subject lot. 
(4)  That I have reviewed said drainage plan and that I have been given the opportunity to seek professional review of same. 
(5)  That the drainage plan for said subject lot is understood and approved by me. 
(6)  That, further, I agree to comply with the drainage plan and that I will not alter that plan or interfere with the comprehensive drainage plan.

(d)  Inspection and approval. The village engineer shall thoroughly inspect grading and drainage of the entire subdivision and approve all work before the developer will be allowed a reduction in the letter of credit. 
(e)  Floodplain identification. The engineering drawings shall indicate on the drainage plan any area which is currently in the floodplain boundary as indicated by the Federal Emergency Management Agency report entitled "The Flood Insurance Study for New Lenox, Illinois," dated May 1, 1980, with the accompanying flood insurance rate maps. The drainage plan shall indicate how such areas are to be graded and the foundation elevations of any structures within the floodplain area. 
(Code 1981, § 11-6-9) 
Sec. 78-140. - Telephone and electric service lines. 
(a)  All public utility lines for telephone and electric services shall be placed entirely underground in residential subdivisions. 
(b)  Where telephone and electric service lines are placed underground entirely throughout a subdivided area, the conduits or cable shall be placed within easements or dedicated public ways in a manner which will not conflict with other underground services. Further, all transformer boxes shall be located so as not to be unsightly or hazardous to the public. 
(Code 1981, § 11-6-10) 
Sec. 78-141. - Specifications for materials. 
    All public improvements installed in the village shall be constructed of materials meeting the following specifications: 
(1)  Ductile iron pipe. 
a.  Conform to AWWA C151. 
b.  Minimum thickness: Class 52 standard thickness for mechanical and push-on joint piping. 
c.  Fittings: 
1.  Provide fittings required to provide complete operational system. 
2.  Provide joint fittings. 
3.  Fittings may be ductile or cast iron in accordance with AWWA C110 and AWWA C151. 
4.  Fitting pressure rating: 250 psi. 
d.  Push-on joints: Provide in accordance with AWWA C111, except gaskets shall be neoprene or other synthetic rubber. Natural rubber is not acceptable. 
(2)  Copper service pipe. 
a.  Conform to ASTM B88. 
b.  Type K, copper water tube, soft temper. 
(3)  Stops and fittings. 
a.  Corporation stops Ford Model F600, and curb stops Ford Model B22333M or Mueller No. H15150: 
1.  Brass. 
2.  Suitable for copper connections. 
3.  Curb stops shall be roundway type. 
b.  Fittings: 
1.  Copper. 
2.  Compression type. 
c.  Curb box: Mueller No. H-10300 or equal. 
(4)  Fire hydrants. Acceptable manufacturers: Traverse City with breakaway flange. 
(5)  Gate valves. 
a.  Acceptable manufacturers: Mueller resilient seat gate valve. 
b.  Cast iron, bronze mounted, bronze stems. 
c.  All rated for 300 psi test pressure and 150 psi working pressure. 
(6)  Thrust blocks. Class X concrete in accordance with state department of transportation specifications, section 504. 
(7)  PVC sewer pipe and fittings. 
a.  Four to 14 inches diameter: ASTM D3034, SDR 35; PVC type 1, grade 1. 
b.  Fittings: 18 to 27 inches diameter: ASTM F679, PS46, PVC type 1, grade 1. 
1.  Fittings such as saddles, elbows, tees and wyes shall be factory produced and have joint design compatible with adjacent pipe. 
2.  Provide approved adapters for transitions to other types of pipe materials. 
c.  Pipe joints: 
1.  Rubber gasket: ASTM F477. Bell and spigot joint conforming to ASTM D3212, sealed by rubber gasket so assembly remains watertight under conditions of service including movements resulting from expansion, contraction, settlement and deformation of pipe. 
2.  Assembled joint shall pass performance tests as required in ASTM D3212. 
d.  Pipe markings: 
1.  Manufacturer's name or trademark. 
2.  Nominal pipe size. 
3.  PVC cell classification. 
4.  Legend, "Type PSM SDR 35 PVC Sewer Pipe" or "PS46 PVC Sewer Pipe" as applicable. 
5.  ASTM D3034 or ASTM F679 as applicable. 
6.  Extrusion date, period of manufacture or lot number. 
e.  Fitting markings: 
1.  Manufacturer's name or trademark. 
2.  Nominal size. 
3.  Material designations: PVC. 
4.  PSM or PS46 as applicable. 
5.  ASTM D3034 or ASTM F679 as applicable. 
f.  Tapping saddles: Equivalent to Sealtite sewer tapping saddle system or GENECO split sleeve top saddle system by General Engineering Company. 
(8)  ABS composite pipe materials. 
a.  ABS composite sewer pipe and fittings: ASTM D2680. 
b.  Joints and fittings: 
1.  Attach coupling and saddle fittings and field join pipe sections and fittings by solvent welding in accordance with recommendations of pipe manufacturer. 
2.  Field coat exposed filler material with ABS solvent cement. 
3.  Provide approved adapters for transitions to other types of pipe. 
c.  Pipe markings: Mark at five-foot intervals or less with: 
1.  Name of manufacturer or principal supplier. 
2.  Nominal diameter. 
3.  ABS. 
4.  ASTM D2680. 
5.  Extrusion date, period of manufacture or lot number. 
d.  Fitting and coupling markings: 
1.  Name of manufacturer or principal supplier. 
2.  Nominal diameter. 
3.  ASTM D2680. 
(9)  Reinforced concrete pipe. 
a.  ASTM C76 with bell and spigot joints to strength class shown in article 603.03 of state department of transportation specifications. 
1.  Manufacturer shall mark exterior of each pipe section with pipe class. 
2.  Wall A or elliptical reinforcement prohibited. 
b.  Joints: Rubber gaskets conforming to ASTM C361 or tongue and groove joint. 
c.  Tapping saddles: Equivalent to Sealtite sewer tapping saddle system or GENECO split sleeve saddle system by General Engineering Company. 
d.  Fittings: 
1.  Conform to strength, watertightness, joint type and other requirements of main line pipe to which joined. 
2.  Securely attach fabricated branches for wyes and tees to wall of pipe in watertight manner and flush with inside surface of pipe. 
3.  Tee branch: Axis perpendicular to longitudinal axis of pipe. 
4.  Wye branches: Axis approximately 60 degrees or 45 degrees from longitudinal axis of pipe, measured from bell end. 
5.  Do not interrupt pipe reinforcement beyond radial distance of three inches outside fitting. 
e.  Mastic for tongue and groove joints: Trowelable EZ Stik (butyl rubber base) by Press Seal Gasket Corporation, or equal. 
f.  Lift holes not permitted. 
(10)  Flexible connectors. To be used when joining plain ends of pipes of dissimilar materials. 
a.  Materials: 
1.  Synthetic rubber base compound formulated to resist acids, alkalies, solvents and greases encountered in sanitary or storm sewers and containing no reclaimed rubber. 
2.  Test in accordance with ASTM D543 and not lose weight in 1.0 normal sulfuric acid, 1.0 normal hydrochloric acid or 1.0 normal nitric acid. 
3.  Show no etching, blistering, distortion or other evidence of chemical or bacterial attack and shall show no cracking on rapid cooling. 
4.  Under ASTM D412, ultimate tensile strength shall exceed 750 psi at 80 degrees Fahrenheit and elongation shall exceed 150 percent. 
5.  Under ASTM D570, water absorption shall not exceed four percent. 
6.  Under ASTM D2240, type A hardness shall exceed 55 in five-second reading. 
b.  Material used in fabricating compression bands shall be type 316 stainless steel, and bolts and nuts shall be type 305 stainless steel in accordance with ASTM A167. 
c.  Completed joint: Conform to material and performance standards of ASTM C425 for resilient sewer pipe joints. 
d.  Acceptable manufacturers: Clow, FERNCO, Inc. or equal. 
(11)  Manholes, catchbasins, vaults and inlets. 
a.  Precast concrete conforming to ASTM C478: Sections and component parts to be marked by manufacturer with trade name and/or trademark and ASTM designation. 
b.  Holes: 
1.  Holes shall be smooth, radial to centerline of manhole, and perpendicular to manhole wall. 
2.  Holes for sanitary and storm pipes: Circular. 
3.  Holes for water pipes: 
i.  Integral base vault: Circular. 
ii.  Field poured base vault: Horseshoe shaped or circular. 
4.  Holes shall be cast in initial pouring of section or shall be cored in after concrete cured. Broken out holes or holes cut into green concrete are not permitted. 
c.  Sanitary manholes: 
1.  Integral base: Six inches nominal thickness. 
2.  Pipe connection: Flexible synthetic rubber boot meeting ASTM C923. 
i.  Cast-in or pressed-on type permitted. 
ii.  Cast-in type boot shall be installed in initial pouring of manhole section. 
3.  Provide channels in invert to direct flows from incoming to outgoing pipe. 
i.  Depth of channel equal to diameter of outgoing sewer as minimum. 
ii.  Channels shall be horseshoe shaped in cross sections. 
iii.  May be factory or field installed. 
iv.  Take care in installing channels to preclude interference with operation of flexible boot or hindering installation of sewer pipes. 
4.  Section joints: 
i.  ASTM C361 with synthetic rubber O-ring. 
ii.  Tongue and groove. 
5.  Eccentric manhole opening. 
6.  Cast-in steps 16 inches on center in line with manhole opening. Center steps between incoming and outgoing pipes. Steps to be placed in initial pouring of manhole. 
d.  Storm manholes and catchbasins: 
1.  Integral base: Six inches nominal thickness. 
2.  Pipe connection: Circular hole 11/2 inches to three inches larger than actual outside diameter of sewer pipe being connected. 
3.  Provide invert channels in storm manholes as specified in subsection (11)c.3 of this section. 
4.  Provide flat bottom in catchbasins. 
5.  Section joints: Tongue and groove. 
6.  Eccentric manhole opening. 
7.  For storm manholes only provide cast-in steps 16 inches on center in line with manhole opening. Center steps between incoming and outgoing pipes. Steps to be placed in initial pouring of manhole. Do not provide steps in catchbasins. 
e.  Inlets: 
1.  Integral base: Four inches nominal thickness. 
2.  Pipe connection: Circular hold 11/2 inches to three inches larger than actual outside diameter of sewer pipe. 
3.  Flat bottom. 
f.  Vaults: 
1.  Integral base: Six inches nominal thickness or field poured base. 
2.  Pipe connection: Hole or width of horseshoe 11/2 inches to three inches larger than actual outside diameter of water pipe. 
3.  Flat bottom. 
4.  Section joints: Tongue and groove. 
5.  Concentric manhole opening. 
6.  Do not provide steps. 
g.  Wall thickness: 
1.  For two feet zero inches nominal ID: Three inches minimum wall. 
2.  For four feet zero inches nominal ID: Five inches minimum wall. 
3.  For six feet zero inches nominal ID: Seven inches minimum wall. 
h.  Valve boxes: Mueller No. H-10360 screw type or approved equal. 
(12)  Adjusting rings. 
a.  Precast concrete with steel reinforcement sufficient to prevent cracking in normal handling and use. 
b.  Mating faces: 
1.  Smooth. 
2.  Parallel. 
3.  Free from cracks, chips, spalls or casting irregularities interfering with watertight mating to structure top or casting. 
4.  Provide grooves in faces to contain extrudible preformed plastic gasket material when possible. 
c.  Thickness range: 
1.  Two inches nominal minimum. 
2.  Eight inches nominal minimum. 
(13)  Gasket materials. 
a.  Flexible boots: 
1.  Conform to ASTM C923. 
2.  Synthetic rubber resistant to sanitary sewage. 
3.  Cast-in or pressed-on type acceptable. 
b.  O-ring gaskets: 
1.  Conform to ASTM C361. 
2.  Synthetic rubber resistant to sanitary sewage. 
c.  Extrudible preformed plastic gasket: 
1.  Butyl rubber. 
2.  EZ Stik by Press Seal Gasket Company, or equal. 
d.  Mastic joint sealant: 
1.  Butyl rubber. 
2.  Trowelable EZ Stik by Press Seal Gasket Company, or equal. 
e.  Materials to be new and provided in unopened containers where applicable. 
(14)  Manhole steps. 
a.  Gray cast iron: 
1.  Conform to ASTM A48, class 30. 
2.  Minimum cross-sectional dimensions of one inch in any direction. 
3.  Conform to Neenah R-1981-1 in dimensions and structural capacity. 
b.  Steps and installation into precast concrete manhole sections shall conform to OSHA standards. Embedded portion of steps to be deformed. Grout in steps to withstand 300 pounds live loading applied vertically and 200 pounds pull-out. 
(15)  Castings. 
a.  Conform to ASTM C48, class 35. 
b.  Free from cracks, holes, swells, and cold shuts and patches. 
c.  Do not coat or paint. 
d.  Provide structural capacity, hydraulic capacity, watertightness, interior clearance dimensions, approximate vertical height, and range of adjustment equal to: 
1.  Sanitary manhole and water resistant cover, type 1: 
i.  East Jordon Iron Works with cover, no. 1050 with type A self-sealing solid cover. 
ii.  Neenah equal. 
2.  Storm manhole and solid cover and water valve vault and solid cover, type 4: 
i.  East Jordon Iron Works with cover, no. 1050 with type A solid cover. 
ii.  Neenah equal. 
3.  Storm manhole and slotted cover, type 2: 
i.  East Jordon Iron Works no. 1050 with type M1 grate. 
ii.  Neenah equal. 
4.  Storm manhole with beehive cover, type 8: 
i.  East Jordon Iron Works no. 6527. 
ii.  Neenah equal. 
5.  Curb inlet, type 12, with Bicycle safe grate, type 3: 
i.  East Jordon Iron Works no. 718 with type M2 grate. 
ii.  Neenah equal. 
(16)  Cast-in-place concrete. 
a.  Class X concrete in accordance with section 504 of the state department of transportation specifications. 
b.  Use for field poured manhole bases and inverts. 
(17)  Concrete masonry blocks and bricks. 
a.  Conform to state department of transportation specifications section 707. 
b.  Use for setting poured-in-place base for water valve vaults. 
(18)  Nonshrink grout. 
a.  Use for grouting concrete masonry units. 
b.  Five Star Grout, U.S. Grout Corporation or equal. 
(Code 1981, § 11-6-11) 
Sec. 78-142. - Street signs. 
    After approval of the subdivision plat and installation of public improvements, the subdivider shall purchase and install throughout the subdivision street signs of such number, type and size as shall have been approved by the plan commission and board of trustees. They shall be installed in accordance with the Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices and approved by the public works superintendent. 
(Code 1981, § 11-6-12) 
Sec. 78-143. - Procedure for approval and acceptance of improvements. 
(a)  Where a subdivider plans for development of a subdivision within the corporate limits, or a 11/2-mile radius thereof, the subdivider shall, before submitting his final plat for approval: 
(1)  Make provision for the installation and construction of improvements required by this article. 
(2)  Submit his provisions for installation and construction of improvements required by this article to the village engineer for his recommendation. 
(3)  Submit his provisions for installation and construction of improvements required by this article, along with the recommendations of the village engineer and the plan commission, to the president and board of trustees for their approval. 
(b)  The president and board of trustees of the village shall not approve a subdivider's provisions for improvements unless the provisions for improvements required by this article comply with the specifications for such improvements adopted by the village. 
(c)  All improvements required by this article shall be inspected for compliance with this chapter and the specifications adopted by the village, during construction, by the village engineer. No such improvements shall be accepted by the president and board of trustees unless the village engineer shall certify that the improvement complies with this chapter and the specifications adopted by the village. 
(d)  All improvements, when completed and accepted by the appropriate authority, shall become the property of the village or appropriate authority. 
_____
(e)  Inspections by the village engineer shall be in accordance with the following table 1. All inspections shall be requested a minimum of two working days prior to inspection.

(Code 1981, § 11-6-13)

Sec. 78-144. - Contribution for connection to public water or sewer system. 
(a)  At the time of issuance of a building permit for each new building in a subdivision connecting to the existing water mains of the village, the permit applicant shall pay to the village the applicable connection charge set forth in section 94-271. 
(b)  At the time of issuance of a building permit for each new building in a subdivision connecting to the existing sewer mains of the village, the permit applicant shall pay to the village the applicable connection charge set forth in section 94-143. 
(Code 1981, § 11-6-14; Ord. No. 2608, § 1, 11-28-2016) 
Sec. 78-145. - Parkway trees. 
    All residential subdivisions for which a final plat is approved after September 12, 2000 shall be required to have trees planted in the parkway. This shall be the responsibility of the developer. Trees planted in the parkway shall be in compliance with the following regulations: 
(1)  Number of trees. One tree shall be required for each 40 lineal feet of street length. Cul-de-sac lots shall have at least one tree provided all location requirements of section 78-145(2) are met. 
(2)  Location. Trees shall be planted halfway between the curb and sidewalk, no less than 30 feet apart, at least ten feet from all driveways, manholes and fire hydrants and at least 30 feet from all streetlights. No tree shall be planted closer than 40 feet from an intersection as measured from the adjacent property corner. This distance is necessary to provide the necessary line of sight at the intersection. 
(3)  Size. Trees planted shall be at least 21/2 inches in caliper measured six inches above grade. 
(4)  Species. All trees planted in parkways shall be chosen from the following list: 
a.  Autumn Blaze 
b.  State Street Maple 
c.  Marmo Maple 
d.  Red Maple 
e.  Hackberry 
f.  Thornless Honey Locust 
g.  Kentucky Coffeetree 
h.  Swamp White Oak 
i.  Hill's Oak 
j.  Shingle Oak 
k.  Red Oak 
l.  Littleleaf Linden 
m.  American (Redmond) Linden 
n.  Silver Linden 
o.  European Linden 
p.  Patriot Elm 
q.  Lacebark Elm 
(5)  Parkway tree plan; financial security. 
a.  Parkway tree plan. A parkway tree plan indicating the location of the improvements required by section 78-145(1) shall be submitted as accompanying documents to a final plat in accordance with the provisions of sections 78-71(7). 
b.  Financial security. A letter of credit or security approved by the village board in an amount as determined as follows: 
(1)  Construction costs - approved engineer's estimate of public improvements. 
(2)  Warranty contingency equals ten percent of (1). 
(3)  Inflationary contingency equals 15 percent of (1). 
(4)  Surety amount equals (1) + (2) + (3). 
shall be provided to the village prior to the village executing the final plat. 
(6)  Specifications. 
a.  General. All trees shall conform to the American Standard for Nursery Stock as approved by the American Standards Institute, Incorporated, and issued as ANSI Z60.1-1996 or as amended. 
b.  Shape, size and propagation procedures. All trees shall be propagated by commonly accepted methods (fruit and seed germination, budded, cuttings, grafted, etc.) for the given tree species and cultivar. All trees shall be straight, healthy, uniformly shaped, typical representatives of their normal species or varieties. Each tree shall have a recognizable and definable central leader throughout the entire head of the tree, and shall have typical branch growth in all quadrants of the crown, which shall not be a result of severe pruning. All terminal buds shall be in place. At the time of planting, all trees shall be freshly dug, free of insect pests, plant diseases, sun scald, frost crack, fresh abrasions, and other injuries, and with healthy, well-developed root systems. 
c.  Digging of plant materials and ball characteristics. All plants shall be balled and burlapped. The rootflare of the tree shall be at the top of the ball, and if necessary, surface soil shall be removed to obtain such conditions before digging begins. The balls shall be prepared in a workmanlike manner and firmly bound. Ball diameter shall conform to the ANSI Z60.1-1996 standards. 
d.  Planting holes. All planting holes shall be at least 20 inches larger in diameter than the tree ball to a depth such that the tree when planted will be situated with the root collar at grade. The sides of the hole shall slope inward towards the bottom of the root ball. Planting holes shall be dug no more than 24 hours before planting. 
e.  Tree basins. Water retention saucers (tree basins) shall be formed around each tree planted. 
f.  Mulch. All trees shall be mulched with a four-inch depth of wood chips or other approved mulch. The mulched surface area shall extend from the base of the tree to a point beyond the circumference of the disturbed area. Mulch shall not be placed against the trunk of the tree. 
g.  Removal of materials. All excess excavated materials from the planting holes shall be removed and disposed of by the developer. 
(7)  Installation of trees, guarantee. 
a.  Installation of trees. On an annual or semiannual basis, developer shall contract for the installation of parkway trees for all lots requiring parkway trees and that have received certificates of occupancy during that year. Planting will be done in the spring and/or fall of each year. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, at such time as 90 percent of the lots in a given subdivision or unit of a subdivision have received certificates of occupancy, all parkway trees shall be installed in accordance with the parkway tree master plan required in Sec. 78-145(5)a. 
b.  Guarantee. Developer shall guarantee all parkway trees for a period of one year after installation. If during that time village, in its sole discretion, determines that a tree is in need of replacement due to infestation, mortality or growth not in accordance with the standards of section 78-145(6)b., developer shall replace such tree during the next scheduled planting, but in no case later than six months after written notice by village that the tree is in need of replacement. 
(8)  Prior ordinances. The provisions of ordinance no. 1114 shall continue to be in full force and effect for all subdivisions in which final plat approval was granted between May 23, 1995 and September 12, 2000. 
(Code 1981, § 11-6-16; Ord. No. 1114, § 2, 11-27-1996; Ord. No. 1308, § 1, 9-12-2000; Ord. No. 2074, § 2, 11-9-2009; Ord. No. 2672, § 2, 11-13-2017) 
Secs. 78-146-78-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SCHOOL SITES 

Sec. 78-171. - Dedication of land or cash contribution required. 
(a)  As a condition of approval of a final plat of subdivision or planned unit development, each subdivider, builder, or developer will be required to dedicate land for school sites to serve the immediate and future needs of the residents of the development, or make a cash contribution in lieu of actual land dedication, or a combination of both, at the option of the village, as recommended by the school board(s) serving the land in which the subdivision or planned unit development is located, in accordance with the criteria and formulae as set forth in this article. 
(b)  The dedications of land or cash contributions in lieu thereof required by this article may be required as a condition to the annexation of any land to the village, and provisions therefor may be incorporated into any annexation agreement governing such land. 
(c)  The development or construction of age-restricted adult or senior citizen housing shall be exempt from this article provided that: 
(1)  All requests for exemption under this section shall be submitted to the village administrator. 
(2)  All such housing shall contain a deed or other restriction recorded against the property, in a form satisfactory to the village, which deed restriction shall provide that: 
a.  No person under the age of 18 years old shall reside within any such housing unit; and 
b.  In the event that the restrictions are modified or violated, the owner of the property at the time the restrictions are modified or violated shall pay to the village an amount equal to the then-current cash contribution in lieu of land required under this article. 
(3)  Such age-restricted adult or senior citizen housing publishes and adheres to policies and procedures that demonstrate the intent of said restrictions in a form satisfactory to the village. 
(Code 1981, § 11-7-1; Ord. No. 2684, § 4, 12-11-2017) 
Sec. 78-172. - Criteria for dedication of land. 
(a)  Determination of required land area. The ultimate number of students to be generated by a subdivision or planned unit development shall bear directly upon the land area required to be dedicated for school sites. The land dedication requirement shall be determined by obtaining the ratio of: (1) the estimated number of children to be served in each such school classification to (2) the maximum recommended number of students to be served in each such school classification, as stated in this article, and then applying such ratio to the minimum recommended number of acres for a school site of each such school classification as stated in this article. The product thereof shall be the acres of land deemed needed to have sufficient land for school sites to serve the estimated increased children in each such school classification. 
_____
(b)  School classifications and minimum size of sites. School classifications and the size of school sites within the village shall be determined in accordance with the following criteria: 
School Classification by Grades Maximum Number of Students for Each Such School Classification Minimum Number of Acres of Land For Each School Site of Such Classification Elementary schools, grades kindergarten through 5 600 students 11 acres Junior high schools, grades 6 through 8 900 students 19 acres High schools, grades 9 through 12 2,500 students 50 acres  
(c)  Location of sites. The comprehensive school plan and/or the standards adopted by the affected school district shall, to the extent practicable, be used as a guideline in locating school sites. 
(Code 1981, § 11-7-2; Ord. No. 2684, § 4, 12-11-2017) 
Sec. 78-173. - Criteria for cash contribution in lieu of dedication. 
(a)  Authority to require cash contribution in lieu of dedication; use of funds. Where the development is small and the resulting school site is too small to be practical or when the available land is inappropriate for a school site, the village shall require the builder to pay a cash contribution in lieu of the land dedication required. The cash contributions in lieu of school sites shall, at the time of issuance of building permits, be paid to the appropriate school districts for use in the acquisition of land for a school site to serve the immediate or future needs of children from that subdivision or development or for the improvement of any existing school site which already serves or will serve such needs, or for the construction of any school buildings or additions thereto, or for the retirement of any bonds issued for school construction or improvements. 
(b)  Amount of contribution. 
(1)  Fair market value. The amount of cash contributions in lieu of land shall be based on the improved fair market value of land in the proposed subdivision or planned unit development. The cash contributions in lieu of land shall be based on the fair market value set forth in section 78-72(a)(7)c., supra, that otherwise would have been dedicated unless the subdivider or developer files a written objection thereto. In the event of any such objection, the subdivider or developer shall submit an appraisal showing the fair market value of such improved land in the area of the subdivision or planned unit development, or other evidence thereof, and final determination of the fair market value per acre of such improved land shall be made by the village board. 
(c)  Criteria for requiring both dedication and cash contribution. Situations may arise where a combination of land dedication and a cash contribution in lieu of land are both necessary and appropriate. These occasions generally arise when: 
(1)  Portion of land. Only a portion of the land proposed as the location for a school site lies within the subdivision or planned unit development. In such a situation, the subdivider or developer shall dedicate such portion of the land within the subdivision or planned unit development that falls within the proposed school site location as provided in this section and then make a cash contribution in lieu of further dedication in an amount equal to the difference between the required land area dedication pursuant to this section and the land area actually dedicated. 
(2)  Majority of land. A major part of the school site has already been acquired and only a small portion of land is needed from the development to complete the site. In such a situation, the subdivider or developer shall dedicate only the remaining portions of land required for the school site and then make a cash contribution in lieu of further dedication. Such contribution in lieu of dedication shall be in an amount equal to the difference between the required land area dedication pursuant to this section and the land area actually dedicated. 
(Code 1981, § 11-7-3; Ord. No. 1135, § 2, 4-23-1997; Ord. No. 1191, § 2(11-7-3-A), 4-14-1998; Ord. No. 2684, § 4, 12-11-2017) 
_____

The following table of population density is generally indicative of current and short range projected trends in family size for new construction and shall be used in calculating the number of acres required for dedications of land or the cash contributions in lieu thereof under this article unless a written objection is filed thereto by the subdivider or developer of the planned unit development:
