All persons riding on, operating, or otherwise using any skateboard, roller skates, roller blades or any similar device outside of a designated "No Skateboarding, Roller Skating, or Roller Blading Area" shall exercise due care at all times for the safety of all persons, yield the right-of-way to any person, and not create a danger of injury or cause injury to any person or property. 
(c)  Penalty. In addition to all other remedies, any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with this section shall be sentenced as provided by section 1-15 of this Code for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 1506, § 4, 11-12-2003; Ord. No. 1576, § 3, 9-14-2004; Ord. No. 2192, § 27, 8-22-2011) 
Sec. 90-67. - Designation of private property as no skateboarding, roller skating, or roller blading area. 
(a)  If property is multiple-family (dwelling containing three or more units), or in a commercial or industrial area, the owner may submit a written request for the designation of a "No Skateboarding, Roller Skating or Roller Blading Area". Upon a signed written enforcement agreement by the owner, the board of trustees may, by resolution, designate said private property as a "No Skateboarding, Roller Skating or Roller Blading Area". The board of trustees shall designate such area and the times when such activity would be prohibited and order the posting of appropriate signage in accordance with section 90-69 of this chapter. 
(b)  The village clerk shall cause notice of the board of trustees consideration of the written request by the property owner at the property owner's expense to be published in any newspaper of general circulation within the village at least ten days prior to consideration by the board of trustees. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of the property owner to purchase, post, and maintain all signs prohibiting skateboarding, roller skating, or roller blading. 
(Ord. No. 1576, § 4, 9-14-2004) 
Sec. 90-68. - Designation of public property as no skateboarding, roller skating, or roller blading area. 
(a)  The board of trustees may, by resolution, designate any sidewalk, parking lot, or other public property as a "No Skateboarding, Roller Skating, or Roller Blading Area". The Board of Trustees shall designate such area and the times when such activity would be prohibited and order the posting of appropriate signage in accordance with section 90-69 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1576, § 5, 9-14-2004) 
Sec. 90-69. - Posting of signs required. 
    Prior to the enforcement of the prohibition on skateboarding, roller skating or roller blading, the area so designated shall be posted with signs which provide substantially as follows: 
"No skateboarding, roller skating, scooters or roller blading. Any violation is punishable by a minimum fine of $25.00 for the first offense." 
    Such prohibition shall apply to the property or area so designated once the property or area has been posted with signs in plain view at the entrances to the property or area. 
(Ord. No. 1576, § 6, 9-14-2004) 
Sec. 90-70. - Red-light running. 
    Vehicular traffic facing a steady circular red signal alone shall stop at a clearly marked stop line, but if there is no such stop line, before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection, or if there is no such crosswalk, then before entering the intersection when the traffic signal for the vehicle's direction is emitting a steady red light, and shall remain standing until an indication to proceed is shown. Except when a sign is in place prohibiting a turn, vehicular traffic facing any steady red signal may cautiously enter the intersection to turn right, or to turn left from a one-way street into a one-way street, after stopping. After stopping, the driver shall yield the right of way to any vehicle in the intersection or approaching on another roadway so closely as to constitute an immediate hazard during the time such driver is moving across or within the intersection or junction or roadways. Such driver shall yield the right of way to pedestrians within the intersection or an adjacent crosswalk. Images, such as photographic, video, or digital imaging equipment, shall record the violation. 
(Ord. No. 1859, § 23, 6-19-2007) 
Sec. 90-71. - Seat belts. 
(a)  Each driver and front seat passenger of a motor vehicle operated on a street or highway in the Village shall wear a properly adjusted and fastened seat safety belt; except that, a child less than 16 years of age shall be protected as required pursuant to 625 ILCS 25/1 et seq., the Child Passenger Protection Act. Each driver of a motor vehicle transporting a passenger who is unable, due to infirmity, illness, or age, to properly adjust and fasten a seat safety belt and is not exempted from wearing a seat safety belt under subsection (b) shall secure the passenger in a properly adjusted and fastened seat safety belt. 
(b)  Subsection (a) shall not apply to any of the following: 
(1)  A driver or passenger frequently stopping and leaving the vehicle or delivering property from the vehicle, if the speed of the vehicle between stops does not exceed 15 miles per hour. 
(2)  A driver or passenger possessing a written statement from a physician that such person is unable, for medical or physical reasons, to wear a seat safety belt. 
(3)  A driver or passenger possessing an official certificate or license endorsement issued by the appropriate agency in another state or country indicating that the driver is unable for medical, physical, or other valid reasons to wear a seat safety belt. 
(4)  A driver operating a motor vehicle in reverse. 
(5)  A motor vehicle with a model year prior to 1965. 
(6)  A motorcycle or motor driven cycle. 
(7)  A moped. 
(8)  A motor vehicle which is not required to be equipped with seat safety belts under federal law. 
(9)  A motor vehicle operated by a rural letter carrier of the United States postal service while performing duties as a rural letter carrier. 
(c)  Penalty. In addition to all other remedies, any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with any provision of this section shall be sentenced as provided in section 1-15 of this Code for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 2192, § 28, 8-22-2011) 
Secs. 90-72-90-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SPEED 

Sec. 90-91. - Speed limits established. 
    No person shall operate a vehicle upon any public highway or street within the corporate limits of the village at a speed greater than 25 miles per hour, with the following exceptions: 
(1)  Exceptions shall apply as provided in 625 ILCS 5/11-601(d), (e). 
(2)  On U.S. Route 30 and U.S. Route 6, the speed limit shall be as posted by the state department of transportation. 
(3)  On Francis Road, Gougar Road, Laraway Road, Delaney Road and Spencer Road (Kankakee Street), the speed limit shall be as posted by the county highway department and/or the New Lenox Township Road District. 
(4)  A speed not greater than 30 miles per hour shall be permitted on: 
a.  Cedar Road from Barbara Lane to Illinois Highway (Spencer Road); 
b.  East Joliet Highway from Williams Street to Spencer Road (Kankakee Street); 
c.  Nelson Road from Delaney Road to US RT 30. 
d.  Gear Drive from Mustang to Illinois Highway (Spencer Road). 
(5)  A speed no greater than 35 miles per hour shall be permitted on: 
a.  Haven Avenue from Honey Lane to Gougar Road. 
b.  Schoolhouse (Schmuhl) Road from U.S. Route 30 to Quails Roost Drive. 
c.  West Illinois Highway (Spencer) from Cedar Road to one-half mile west of Nelson Road. 
d.  On Delaney Road from 1300 feet west of Cedar Road to Nelson Road; and from 1275 feet west of Nelson Road to 410 feet west of Royal Drive. 
e.  On Schoolhouse Road from U.S. Route 30 to 105 feet south of Talon Drive; and from 470 feet south of the E J & E Railroad tracks to Illini Drive. 
f.  On Silver Cross Boulevard from Francis Road to Route 6. 
(6)  A speed no greater than 40 miles per hour shall be permitted on Clinton Road from Francis Road to U.S. Route 6 (Maple Road). 
(7)  A speed no greater than 45 miles per hour shall be permitted on Gougar Road from U.S. Route 6 to 1,000 feet south of Bruce Road. 
(8)  A speed no greater than 20 miles per hour shall be permitted on Veterans Parkway between Route 30 and Haven Avenue. 
(9)  A speed no greater than 35 miles per hour shall be permitted on Haven Avenue from Gougar Road to the western most village limits. 
(Code 1981, § 5-5-1.A.2.a(1)-(7); Ord. No. 1117, §§ 1-4, 12-11-1996; Ord. No. 1184, § 1, 2-25-1998; Ord. No. 1190, § 1(5-5-1), 4-14-1998; Ord. No. 1548, §§ 1, 2, 5-11-2004; Ord. No. 1932, § 1, 3-17-2008; Ord. No. 2062, § 1, 8-17-2009; Ord. No. 2606, § 1, 11-14-2016) 
Sec. 90-92. - Alteration of speed limits. 
    If the corporate authorities set, by ordinance, other limits as provided by 625 ILCS 5/11-604, after an engineering or traffic survey, then such limits shall govern the rate of speed on the streets indicated in such ordinance. Appropriate signs shall be posted showing such speed limits. 
(Code 1981, § 5-5-1.A.4) 
Sec. 90-93. - Duty of drivers to decrease speed under certain conditions. 
    The fact that the speed of a vehicle does not exceed the applicable maximum speed limit does not relieve the driver from the duty to decrease speed when approaching and crossing an intersection, when approaching and going around a curve, when approaching a hill crest, when traveling upon any narrow or winding roadway, or when special hazards exist with respect to pedestrians or other traffic or by reason of weather or highway conditions; and speed shall be decreased as may be necessary to avoid colliding with any person or vehicle on or entering the highway in compliance with legal requirements and the duty of all persons to use due care. 
(Code 1981, § 5-5-1.B) 
Sec. 90-94. - Driving too fast for conditions. 
    No person shall drive any vehicle upon any highway of the village at a speed which is greater than is reasonable and proper with regard to the traffic conditions and the use of the highway, or which endangers the safety of any person or property. 
(Code 1981, § 5-5-1.D) 
Sec. 90-95. - Restriction on use of electronic speed detecting devices. 
    Where signs giving notice of the speed limit have been erected, electronic speed detecting devices shall not be used within 500 feet beyond any such sign in the direction of travel. If so used in violation of this section, evidence obtained thereby shall be inadmissible in any prosecution for speeding. 
(Code 1981, § 5-5-1.E) 
Sec. 90-96. - Flag or lamp required on slow-moving vehicles. 
    When any implement of husbandry or road tractor is operated on a highway within the village at a speed of less than 20 miles per hour, there shall be displayed at all times during such operation a red flag at least 12 inches square carried on such vehicle at a height not less than ten feet and not more than 12 feet above the ground, or at least one flashing amber signal lamp mounted as high as practicable, between sunrise and sunset. Such vehicle shall at all times display at least one flashing amber signal lamp mounted as high as practicable and of sufficient intensity to be visible to the rear a distance of at least 500 feet if used in normal sunlight; provided, however, that only the rear vehicle of a combination of vehicles coupled together need display such a flag or lamp. 
(Code 1981, § 5-5-1.G) 
Sec. 90-97. - Ambulances. 
    The speed limits established by this division do not apply to ambulances in motion, which includes any motor vehicle primarily designed and used for conveyance of sick or injured persons, provided: 
(1)  The person operating the ambulance reasonably believes that he is responding to a bona fide emergency call or is specifically directed by a licensed physician to disregard speed limit laws in operating the ambulance during and for the purpose of the specific trip or journey involved. 
(2)  The ambulance shall be equipped with a siren producing an audible signal of an intensity of 100 decibels at a distance of 50 feet from the siren, and with a lamp emitting an oscillating, rotating or flashing red beam directed in part toward the front of the vehicle and visible under normal atmospheric conditions from a distance of 500 feet to the front of such vehicle. The siren and lamp shall be in full operation at all times during such journey. 
(3)  The provisions of this section do not relieve the driver of an ambulance from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons using the street, nor do these provisions protect the driver of any such vehicle from the consequences of a reckless disregard of the safety of others. 
(Code 1981, § 5-5-1.H) 
Sec. 90-98. - Information to be stated on citations. 
    In every charge of violation of a provision of this division by failure to observe an applicable speed limit, the complaint, traffic ticket or notice to appear shall specify the speed at which the defendant is alleged to have driven and the speed limit which is applicable at the place of the alleged violation. 
(Code 1981, § 5-5-1.I) 
Secs. 90-99-90-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TURNS 

Sec. 90-121. - Obedience to U-turn signs. 
    Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no U-turn is permitted, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the directions of any such sign. 
(Code 1981, § 5-5-2.A) 
Sec. 90-122. - Limitations on U-turns. 
    The driver of any vehicle shall not turn such vehicle so as to proceed in the opposite direction upon any street in a business district and shall not, upon any other street, so turn a vehicle unless such movement can be made in safety and without interfering with other traffic. 
(Code 1981, § 5-5-2.B) 
Sec. 90-123. - No right turns. 
    It shall be unlawful for any driver of a motor vehicle to make a right-hand turn onto Roy Street from westbound Joliet Highway at any time. 
(Ord. No. 1399, § 1, 5-29-2002) 
Secs. 90-124-90-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - AUTOMATED TRAFFIC LAW ENFORCEMENT SYSTEM 

Sec. 90-131. - General. 
    The village hereby adopts an automated traffic law enforcement system for the purpose of using photographic, video, or digital imaging equipment to record visual images of vehicles entering intersections in violation of section 90-70 of the Village Code of Ordinances, and using said images as the basis for issuing a "violation notice" to the owners of such vehicles. An intersection equipped with an automated traffic law enforcement system shall be posted with a sign visible to approaching traffic indicating that the intersection is being monitored by an automated traffic law enforcement system. 
(Ord. No. 1859, § 24, 6-19-2007) 
Sec. 90-132. - Enforcement. 
    When the automated traffic law enforcement system records a motor vehicle entering an intersection in violation of section 90-70 of the Code of Ordinances, the recorded image of the violation associated with an automated traffic law violation shall first be reviewed and inspected by a technician employed or contracted by the village, who shall determine: 
(1)  Whether the motor vehicle violated section 90-70 of the Code of Ordinances; and 
(2)  Whether one of the following defenses applies: 
a.  The vehicle entered the intersection as part of a funeral procession or 
b.  The vehicle entered the intersection in order to yield the right-of-way to an emergency vehicle. 
    Upon determination that the recorded image captures a violation and that no defense applies, the village shall issue a written notice of the violation to the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle, which shall be delivered by first class mail within 30 days after the Illinois secretary of state notifies the village of the identity of the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle, but in no event later than 90 days following the violation. 
(Ord. No. 1859, § 24, 6-19-2007) 
Sec. 90-133. - Defenses. 
    A hearing officer may consider, in defense to a violation under section 90-70 of the Code of Ordinances, the following: 
(1)  The motor vehicle or registration plates were stolen before the violation occurred and were not under the control of or in the possession of the owner at the time of the violation, which may be demonstrated through the submission of proof that a report concerning the stolen motor vehicle or registration plates was filed with a law enforcement agency in a timely manner. 
(2)  The driver of the vehicle passed through the intersection in spite of a red light either to yield the right-of-way to an emergency vehicle or as part of a funeral procession. 
(3)  The motor vehicle was being operated by someone other than the registered vehicle owner or lessee at the time of the violation, which shall require written notification to the village and shall only be deemed a valid defense insofar as the registered vehicle owner provides the name and address of the person operating the vehicle at the time of the alleged offense. Failure to notify the village in writing of the name and address of the operator of the vehicle at the time of the alleged offense in advance of the hearing date or date on which the civil penalty is due will result in a presumption that the registered owner or lessee was the operator of the vehicle at the time of the offense and will result in a finding of liability unless one of the other defenses is applicable and duly established. 
(Ord. No. 1859, § 23, 6-19-2007) 
Sec. 90-134. - Administrative adjudication. 
    All automated traffic law enforcement violations are civil in nature and shall be adjudicated through the village's administrative adjudication of municipal code violations. 
(Ord. No. 1859, § 23, 6-19-2007) 
Secs. 90-135-90-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Off-street parking and loading, § 106-271 et seq. 

Sec. 90-151. - Penalty. 
    In addition to all other remedies, any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with any provision of this article for which another penalty is not provided shall be sentenced as provided in section 1-15 of this Code for each offense. 
(Code 1981, § 5-6-21; Ord. No. 2192, § 29, 8-22-2011) 
Sec. 90-152. - Parking in designated no parking areas. 
    No vehicle shall be parked on any street, or street right-of-way, or at any place designated as a no parking area within the village, except under the following conditions: 
(1)  Physicians on emergency call. 
(2)  Emergency vehicles, as follows: 
a.  The driver of an authorized emergency vehicle, when responding to an emergency call, or when in pursuit of any actual or suspected violator of the law, or when responding to, but not upon returning from, a fire alarm, may park or stand, irrespective of the provisions of this chapter. 
b.  The provisions of subsection (2)a of this section shall not relieve the driver of an emergency vehicle from the duty to park or stand with due regard for the safety of all persons, nor shall such provisions protect the driver from the consequences of his reckless disregard for the safety of others. 
(Code 1981, § 5-6-1) 
Sec. 90-153. - Parking in alleys. 
    No person shall park a vehicle within an alley except for the purposes of loading and unloading merchandise, and then not in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic, and no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within an alley in such a position as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting property. 
(Code 1981, § 5-6-3) 
Sec. 90-154. - Removal of illegally parked vehicles. 
    The police department and all members thereof assigned to traffic duty are hereby authorized to remove and tow away, or have removed and towed away by a commercial towing service, any car or other vehicle illegally parked in any place where such parked vehicle creates a traffic hazard, blocks the use of a fire hydrant, or obstructs or may obstruct the movement of any emergency vehicle, or which has been parked in any public street or other public place for a period of more than 24 consecutive hours. Vehicles so towed away shall be stored on any village property or in a public garage or parking lot and shall be restored to the owner or operator thereof after payment of the expense incurred by the village in removing and storing such vehicles. 
(Code 1981, § 5-6-5) 
Sec. 90-155. - Parking position. 
    No vehicle shall be parked with the driver's side of such vehicle next to the curb, except on one-way streets. When the street has curbs, the right wheels of the vehicle must be within 12 inches of the curb. On streets which do not have curbs, no part of the standing or parked vehicle or its load may extend into or be so close to the traveled portion of the roadway so as to interfere with the safe passage of vehicles or persons using the roadway. Vehicles parking on such streets should allow a minimum distance of 12 inches between the edge of the traveled portion of the street and the left wheels of the vehicle parking or standing at the side of the road, except upon one-way streets and streets where pull-in or angle parking is allowed. All vehicles shall park or stand parallel with the curb or street, except in those areas where pull-in or angle parking is allowed. 
(Code 1981, § 5-6-6) 
Sec. 90-156. - Parking for purpose of displaying vehicle for sale or for purpose of selling merchandise. 
    It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle upon any street for the purpose of displaying it for sale, or to park any vehicle upon any street from which vehicle merchandise is peddled or sold. 
(Code 1981, § 5-6-7) 
Sec. 90-157. - Standing in loading zone. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to stand a passenger vehicle for a period of time longer than is necessary for the loading or unloading of passengers in any place designated by ordinance as a loading zone and marked as such. 
(Code 1981, § 5-6-8) 
Sec. 90-158. - Parking prohibited during cleaning of street or snow removal on street. 
    It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on any public street or portion thereof in the village at any time when such street is being cleaned or snow removed. Signs indicating such cleaning or snow removal shall be posted before such work is done. 
(Code 1981, § 5-6-9) 
Sec. 90-159. - General parking restriction during snow removal operations. 
(a)  Any provision of this chapter to the contrary notwithstanding, it shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle on any street in the village when snow shall have accumulated to the depth of two inches or more as measured at the intersection of Maple Street and Cedar Road in the village. This parking restriction shall continue until the snow removal operation is complete. 
(b)  The police department and all members thereof assigned to traffic duty are hereby authorized to remove and tow away, or have removed and towed away by commercial towing service, any vehicle parked in violation of subsection (a) of this section. Vehicles so removed shall be stored in a suitable storage area. The police department shall maintain a record of any vehicle removed so as to provide the owner or operator with information as to the vehicle's location. 
(c)  In addition to any penalty which may be assessed for violation of the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, the owner or operator of the vehicle shall be responsible for payment of the expenses incurred in removing, towing and storing such vehicle. 
(Code 1981, § 5-6-10) 
Sec. 90-160. - Time limit parking. 
(a)  Generally. It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle for a period of time in excess of the amount of time designated by ordinance and so posted. 
(b)  Two-hour restriction. It shall be unlawful for any person to park any motor vehicle on any of the following streets or parts of streets for more than two hours, consecutively: 
(1)  On the north side of Haven Avenue, from Cedar Road to Church Street, and from a point 50 feet east of Church Street to Prairie Road, and also a point 90 feet east of Prairie Road to the east end of pavement. 
(2)  On the south side of Haven Avenue from Cedar Road to a point 178 feet east of Prairie Road. 
(3)  Prairie Road on both the west and east sides from Haven Avenue to Second Avenue. 
(c)  Four-hour restriction. It shall be unlawful for any person to park any motor vehicle on any of the following streets or parts of streets for more than four hours, consecutively: 
(1)  On Church Street between Route 30 (Maple Street) and Haven Avenue, except those portions posted as no parking areas. This limitation shall apply between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. on weekdays. 
(2)  On Pine Street between U.S. Route 30 (Maple Street) and Hickory Street. This limitation shall apply between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. weekdays. 
(3)  On Oak Street between U.S. Route 30 (Maple Street) to 175 feet south of U.S. Route 30. This limitation shall apply between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. weekdays. 
(4)  On the west side of Oak Street from 175 feet south of U.S. Route 30 to Haven Avenue. This limitation shall apply between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. on weekdays. 
(5)  On the north side of Haven from the east curb of Church Street for a distance of 50 feet east, except for those areas designated as no parking zones. 
(6)  On both sides of Hickory Street, from Pine Street to Oak Street. This limitation shall apply between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. on weekdays. 
(7)  On the north side of U.S. Route 30, between Cedar Road and 100 feet west of Pine Street. This limitation shall apply between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. on weekdays. 
(8)  On Haven Avenue, from Church Street to Pine Street, during the hours of 6:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. 
(Code 1981, § 5-6-11.A-C.1-5, 7-9; Ord. No. 1314, § 1, 10-10-00) 
Sec. 90-161. - Resident-only parking. 
(a)  "Resident" defined. For the purposes of this section, the term "resident' shall mean those persons who live on the block of the street upon which parking is limited and which streets are designated as "resident only parking" streets in this section. 
(b)  Limitations; times when in effect. 
(1)  Parking is prohibited for motor vehicles other than those that are owned by residents on the block of the street designated and who have obtained and affixed a parking sticker for the street and block in question and who have purchased a current village vehicle license. Resident parking stickers will be displayed in the rear window of each vehicle, directly behind the driver's position, so as to be plainly visible to a passing police officer. 
(2)  Resident-only parking shall be in effect during the hours of 6:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, except Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays. Cars not in compliance with this subsection and parked on the street are in violation. 
(c)  Visitors and guests. The provisions of the resident-only parking provisions shall not apply to visitors and guests in the homes of the residents of the blocks on the street designated in this section, provided that the resident notifies the village that the car belongs to a guest or visitor of a resident, and also provided that the car is not parked on the street with the permission of the resident for the purpose of commuting, which is specifically prohibited. 
(d)  Applicability. Resident-only parking shall apply to the following blocks and streets within the village: 
(1)  On both sides of Hickory Street between Cedar Road and Pine Street. This limitation shall apply between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. on weekdays. 
(2)  On both sides of Oak Street between Cedar Road and Root Street. This limitation shall apply between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. on weekdays. 
(3)  On both sides of Elm Street between Cedar Road and Root Street. This limitation shall apply between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. on weekdays. 
(4)  On both sides of Pine Street between Hickory Street and Haven Avenue. This limitation shall apply between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. on weekdays. 
(5)  On the east side of Oak Street from a point 175 feet south of U.S. Route 30 (Maple Street) to Haven Avenue. This limitation shall apply between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. on weekdays. 
(6)  On the north side of East Fourth Avenue from Cedar Road to Prairie Road and on the south side of East Fourth Avenue from the east property line of the New Lenox Township Library to Prairie Road. This restriction shall apply at all times. 
(Code 1981, § 5-6-12) 
Sec. 90-162. - Parking in cabstand or bus stand. 
    No vehicle other than a licensed taxicab shall be parked in any area designated by ordinance as a cabstand, and no vehicle other than a bus shall be parked in a place so designated as a bus loading zone. 
(Code 1981, § 5-6-13) 
Sec. 90-163. - Parking on private property without consent of owner. 
    It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle on any private property without the consent of the owner of the property. 
(Code 1981, § 5-6-14) 
Sec. 90-164. - Violations involving leased vehicles. 
    Every person in whose name a vehicle is registered pursuant to state law and who leases such vehicle to others, after receiving written notice of a violation of this chapter, shall, upon request, provide police officers, and the court having jurisdiction thereof, with a written statement of the name and address of the lessee at the time of such offense and the identifying number upon the registration plates of such vehicle. 
(Code 1981, § 5-6-15) 
Sec. 90-165. - Angle parking. 
    Parking at an angle to the road is permitted with the approval of the village board. Angle parking is permitted: 
(1)  Along the east side of Church Street, from Haven Avenue to a point 183 feet north of Haven Avenue. 
(2)  On the north side of Hickory Street, from Pine Street west to a point 246 feet west of Pine Street. 
(Code 1981, § 5-6-16) 
Sec. 90-166. - Parking prohibited on certain streets. 
(a)  Parking is prohibited on that portion of Cedar Road as follows: commencing at the intersection of Cedar Road with the centerline of U.S. Route 30, thence northerly along Cedar Road to its intersection with the southerly right-of-way line of the Chicago-Rock Island-Pacific Railroad, all as is set forth on a plat thereof, which plat shall be and remain on file with the village clerk and is available for public inspection. 
(b)  Parking is prohibited at all times along the west side of Cedar Road between the intersection of Haven Avenue and the intersection of Illinois Highway, also known as Spencer Road. 
(c)  Parking is prohibited at all times along the west side and east side of Kingston Drive, beginning at its intersection with Washington Street and extending southerly to Gifford Place. 
(d)  Parking is prohibited along U.S. Route 30 throughout the village unless posted in designated parking lanes. 
(e)  Parking is prohibited at all times along North Cedar Road between the intersection of Francis Road and the intersection of U.S. Route 30. 
(f)  Parking is prohibited from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, except legal holidays, along the north and south sides of West Haven Avenue, beginning at its westerly intersection with Wildwood Drive and extending westerly to Greenbriar Drive. 
(g)  Parking is prohibited along the west side of Church Street, where posted. 
(h)  Parking is prohibited along the east side of Church Street, north of U.S. Route 30 (Maple Street) to a point ten feet north of the village life station. 
(i)  Parking is prohibited along the south side of Shagbark between Heatherway Lane and Nelson Road. 
(j)  Parking by vehicles of 8,000 pounds or over is prohibited on any street within the corporate limits of the village except as follows: 
(1)  Commercial delivery, maintenance or repair vehicles during the time such service is rendered. 
(2)  Emergency, maintenance or repair vehicles of any governmental agency or public utility during the time such service is rendered. 
(k)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park any motor vehicle west of Cedar Road along both the railroad right-of-way and village property north to Hickory Creek. 
(l)  Parking is prohibited at all times on the north side of Illinois Highway, also known as Spencer Road, between the intersection of South Cedar Road and the intersection of Southgate Road. 
(m)  Parking is prohibited at all times on the north side of Haven Avenue from U.S. Route 30 to a point 400 feet west. 
(n)  Parking is prohibited at all times on the west side of Northgate Road, 50 feet either side of the entrance drive to the Windermere West Unit I condominiums, as posted. 
(o)  Parking is prohibited at all times on the south side of Woodlawn Road, 50 feet either side of the entrance drive to the Windermere West Unit II condominiums, as posted. 
(p)  Parking is prohibited at all times along the north and south sides of Haven Avenue, from Honey Lane to Gougar Road, as posted. 
(q)  Parking is prohibited from 6:00 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. along the south side of Second Avenue between Pine Street and the St. Jude's Church parking lot, on Sunday mornings only, as posted. 
(r)  Parking is prohibited from 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. Mondays through Fridays, and from 8:00 a.m. to 12:00 noon on Saturdays, on the north side of Manor Drive, 25 feet either side of the entrance drive to the Family Care Center, as posted. 
(s)  Parking is prohibited from the corner of North Cedar Road to a point located 40 feet west of such corner on the south side of West Wood Street, and also from the corner of North Cedar Road to a point located 250 feet west of such corner on the north side of West Wood Street, as posted. 
(t)  Parking is prohibited on Nelson Road from U.S. Route 30 south to a point 100 feet south of the Old Plank Road Trail as posted. 
(u)  Parking is prohibited on the south side of East Joliet Highway from a point 365 feet west of the center point of Lake Road to a point 565 feet west of the center point of Lake Road; and also on the south side of East Joliet Highway 50 feet both east and west of the center point of Lake Road. 
(v)  Parking is prohibited on the south side of East Illinois Highway from the center line of South Cedar Road to a point 560' east of this line. 
(w)  Parking is prohibited on the north and south sides of East Joliet Highway from the eastern most boundary of the Old Plank Road Trail to the easterly right of way of the Norfolk and Southern Railroad. 
(x)  Parking is prohibited at all times on either side of Wildwood Drive within 100 feet north and 100 feet south of the centerline of the Old Plank Road Trail. 
(y)  Parking is prohibited at all times on either side of Lake Road within 100 feet north and 100 feet south of the centerline of the Old Plank Road Trail. 
(z)  Parking is prohibited at all times on the east side of Cedar Road from Roy Street to Fourth Avenue. 
(aa)  Parking is prohibited at all times on both sides of Haven Avenue from Greenbriar Drive to Gear Drive. 
(bb)  Parking is prohibited on the east side of Veterans Parkway between Haven Avenue and Livingston Drive as posted. 
(cc)  Parking is prohibited between the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 9:00 a.m., and 2:00 p.m. to 4:00 p.m., Monday through Friday when school is in session, in the following locations: 
(1)  On the north side of Lenox Road from Cedar Road to Edmonds Street; and 
(2)  On the south side of Lenox Road from Cedar Road to Cooper Road. 
(dd)  Parking is prohibited at all times on the north side of Manor Court. 
(ee)  Parking is prohibited at all times on the east and west side of Gougar Road from Route 6 north to the village limits. 
(ff)  Parking is prohibited at all times on the east side of Nelson Road from the northern most right of way of Winter Park Drive to the point 400 feet north of the northern most right of way of Winter Park Drive. 
(gg)  Parking is prohibited at all time on the west side of Nelson Road from a point 75 feet north of the driveway for 1651-1687 Nelson Road to a point 25 feet south of the driveway for 1651-1687 Nelson Road. 
(hh)  Parking is prohibited at all times on the east and west sides of Joliet Highway from Schooner Drive to Westwind Drive. 
(ii)  Parking is prohibited at all times on the east side of Westwind Drive from Schooner Drive to Joliet Highway. 
(jj)  Parking is prohibited at all times on the west side of Martin Court from Delaney Road to Monica Lane. 
(kk)  Parking is prohibited at all times on the east side of Martin Court from its intersection with Delaney Road to a point 80 feet north. 
(ll)  Parking is prohibited at all times on the east and west sides of Tanaga Basin from the intersection with Delaney Road to a point 80 feet north. 
(mm)  Parking is prohibited at all times on the south side of Delaney Road from a point 100 feet west of Martin Court to that point where Delaney Road intersects with Tanaga Basin. 
(nn)  Parking is prohibited at all times on the north side of Delaney Road to points both 80 feet west and 80 feet east of that point where it intersects with Martin Court. 
(oo)  Parking is prohibited at all times on the north side of Delaney Road from that point where it intersects with Tanaga Basin to a point 80 feet west. 
(pp)  Parking is prohibited at all times on the north side of Illinois Highway from the westernmost side of west entrance to the Tyler School to a point 100 feet west; and from the easternmost side of the west entrance to Tyler School to a point 100 feet east. 
(qq)  Parking is prohibited at all times on both sides of Degroate Road from Independence Drive to a point 1,000 feet north. 
(rr)  Parking, except for emergency vehicles, is prohibited at all times on the west side of Manor Drive from a point 30 feet north of the northern curb line of Park Lane (entrance to the New Lenox Park District) to a point 30 feet south of the southern curb line of Park Lane. 
(ss)  Parking is prohibited at all times along Independence Boulevard between (North) Veterans Parkway and (West) Veterans Parkway. 
(tt)  Parking is prohibited at all times on both sides of Spencer Road from Joliet Highway to a point 150 feet south of Terrence Drive. 
(uu)  Parking is prohibited at all times on south the side of Old Hickory Road from Vine Street to a point 65 feet west of Vine Street. 
(vv)  Parking is prohibited at all times on Batson Court from a point five feet on each side of the two-gang mailbox units. 
(Code 1981, § 5-6-17; Ord. No. 1113, § 1, 11-27-1996; Ord. No. 1192, § 1(5-6-17), 4-28-1998; Ord. No. 1202, § 1(5-6-17), 6-23-1998; Ord. No. 1230, § 1(5-6-17), 1-26-1999; Ord. No. 1295, §§ 1-3, 5-23-2000; Ord. No. 1297, § 1, 6-13-2000; Ord. No. 1410; § 1, 8-14-2002; Ord. No. 1381, § 1, 2-13-2002; Ord. No. 1548, § 3, 5-11-2004; Ord. No. 1572, § 1, 5-11-2004; Ord. No. 1687, §§ 1, 2, 9-20-2005; Ord. No. 1715, §§ 1, 2, 12-20-2005; Ord. No. 1773, §§ 1-6, 6-13-2006; Ord. No. 1807, § 1, 10-17-2006; Ord. No. 1843, § 1, 3-27-2007; Ord. No. 2366, § 1, 8-12-2013; Ord. No. 2450, § 2, 10-13-2014; Ord. No. 2488, § 1, 4-13-2015; Ord. No. 2596, § 1, 10-10-2016; Ord. No. 2597, § 1, 10-10-2016) 
Sec. 90-167. - Notice of violation. 
    The registered owner of any vehicle shall be responsible for the parking of any motor vehicle within the village limits, and the police department shall notify the owner by affixing to any vehicle illegally parked a notice to appear in court. The notice shall be in such form and manner as from time to time shall be used by the department. 
(Code 1981, § 5-6-18) 
Sec. 90-168. - Vehicle owner presumed responsible for violations. 
    The fact that an automobile which is illegally operated or parked is registered in the name of a person shall be considered prima facie proof that such person was in control of the automobile at the time of such violation. 
(Code 1981, § 5-6-19) 
Sec. 90-169. - Posting of signs. 
(a)  Appropriate signs shall be posted in all areas where parking is limited or prohibited, indicating such limitations or prohibitions. 
(b)  The chief of police is authorized to temporarily prohibit parking, stopping, or standing on driveways, streets, alleys, parking lots and public streets. Signs and/or barriers shall be posted when the temporary parking restrictions are in effect. 
(Code 1981, § 5-6-20; Ord. No. 2450, § 3, 10-13-2014) 
Sec. 90-170. - Use of commuter parking lot. 
(a)  Location of lot; fee established. Areas for commuter parking have been designated by the village board and are located at Church Street and Village Station Boulevard. Fees for the use of the commuter parking lots have been established by the village board to be paid on a daily basis at a rate of $1.00 per day, and as of May 1, 2012, $1.25 per day. 
(b)  Parking restrictions; penalty for violations; payment of fee. 
(1)  Parking in the following manner is prohibited in the commuter parking lot: 
a.  There shall be no parking in nondesignated areas. 
b.  There shall be no parking except within the white lines of designated parking spaces. 
(2)  In addition to all other remedies, any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with any provision of this section for which another penalty is not provided shall be sentenced as provided in section 1-15 of this code for each offense. 
(3)  Individuals parking in the designated daily fee parking areas shall place the designated daily fee in the pay box coin slot corresponding to the number of the stall in which they are parked. No money placed under windshield wipers or in envelopes, or given to ticket agents or other Metra employees, will be accepted as payment for daily parking. 
(c)  Bike locker policy. Bike lockers have been provided for use at the commuter lot and will be available as follows: 
(1)  A limited number of six bike lockers will be available on an annual basis only. The lockers will be available for use from March 1 to December 31 of each year. 
(2)  Locker keys will be available on a first come basis at the village hall beginning on March 1 of each year. There will be a $25.00 annual fee for each locker. The fee will not be refundable. There will also be a $10.00 key deposit collected at time of key distribution, which will be refunded upon return of the key. 
(3)  Keys must be returned to the village hall before December 31 of each year. The $10.00 deposit will be refunded upon return of the locker key. The key may be returned at any time throughout the year if the locker usage is no longer desired. Keys are not transferable from one party to another. All distribution of keys must be handled through the village hall. 
(4)  Any property left in the bicycle lockers after December 31 will be removed, and if not claimed such items will be auctioned at the next available village auction. 
(5)  The village is not responsible for lost, stolen or damaged property. 
(6)  All key holders are responsible for loss or theft of the key or damage to the locker. Such loss or damage could result in the forfeiture of the $10.00 deposit. 
(7)  At the time of key distribution, each locker user will be required to sign an agreement indicating acceptance of and agreement with the policy stated in this subsection. 
(d)  Village not responsible for insufficient parking. The village is under no obligation to provide parking for everyone, and as such is not accountable to those persons unable to secure a legal parking space at any time. 
(e)  Modification of regulations. The regulations set forth in this section for the operation of the commuter parking facility are hereby established by the direction of the president and board of trustees of the village and are not subject to change, relief or modification by any party other than the president and board of trustees. 
(Code 1981, § 5-6-22; Ord. No. 1133, § 1, 3-26-1997; Ord. No. 1531, § 1, 2-24-2004; Ord. No. 2192, § 30, 8-22-2011; Ord. No. 2249, §§ 1, 2, 4-9-2012) 
Sec. 90-171. - Parking privileges of handicapped persons; use of spaces reserved for handicapped persons. 
(a)  Parking privileges of handicapped persons. 
(1)  A motor vehicle bearing registration plates issued to a person with disabilities as defined by 625 ILCS 5/1-159.1, pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/3-616, or to a disabled veteran pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/3-609, or a special decal or device issued pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/3-616 or pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.2, or a motor vehicle registered in another jurisdiction upon which is displayed a registration plate, special decal or device issued by the other jurisdiction designating that the vehicle is operated by or for a person with disabilities, shall be exempt from the payment of parking meter fees and exempt from any statute or ordinance imposing time limitations on parking, except limitations of one-half hour or less, on any street or highway zone, or any parking lot or parking place which is owned, leased or owned and leased by a municipality or municipal parking utility; but such vehicle shall be subject to the laws which prohibit parking in "no stopping" and "no standing" zones in front of or near fire hydrants, driveways, public building entrances and exits, bus stops and loading areas, and is prohibited from parking where the motor vehicle constitutes a traffic hazard, whereby such motor vehicle shall be moved at the instruction and request of a law enforcement officer to a location designated by the officer. Any motor vehicle bearing registration plates or a special decal or device specified in this section or in 625 ILCS 5/3-616 or such devices as local authorities deem proper as evidence that the vehicle is operated by or for a person with disabilities or disabled veteran may park, in addition to any other lawful place, in any parking place specifically reserved for such vehicles by the posting of an official sign as provided under 625 ILCS 5/11-301. Parking privileges granted by this subsection are strictly limited to the person to whom the special registration plates, special decals or device were issued and to qualified operators acting under his express direction while the disabled person is present. A person to whom privileges were granted shall, at the request of a police officer or any other person invested by law with authority to direct, control, or regulate traffic, present an identification card with a picture as verification that the person is the person to whom the special registration plates, special decal or device was issued. 
(2)  The parking privileges granted by this subsection are also extended to motor vehicles of not-for-profit organizations used for the transportation of persons with disabilities when such motor vehicles display the decal or device used pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.2. 
(3)  No person shall use any area for the parking of any motor vehicle pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/11-1303 or where an official sign controlling such area expressly prohibits parking at any time or during certain hours. 
(b)  Use of reserved parking spaces. 
(1)  It shall be prohibited to park any motor vehicle which is not bearing registration plates or decals issued to a person with disabilities, as defined in 625 ILCS 5/1-159.1, pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/3-616 or 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.1 or 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.2, or to a disabled veteran pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/3-609, as evidence that the vehicle is operated by or for a person with disabilities or disabled veteran, in any parking place, including any private or public off-street parking facility, specifically reserved, by the posting of an official sign as designated under 625 ILCS 5/11-301, for motor vehicles bearing such registration plates. It shall be prohibited to park any motor vehicle in a designated access aisle adjacent to any parking place specifically reserved for persons with disabilities, by the posting of an official sign as designated under 625 ILCS 5/11-301, for motor vehicles displaying such registration plates. When using the parking privileges for persons with disabilities, the parking decal or device must be displayed properly in the vehicle where it is clearly visible to law enforcement personnel, either hanging from the rearview mirror or placed in the dashboard of the vehicle in clear view. 
(2)  It shall be prohibited to park a motor vehicle displaying disability license plates or a parking decal or device issued to a qualified person with a disability under 625 ILCS 5/3-616 or 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.1 or 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.2, or to a disabled veteran pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/3-609, if (i) the person using the disability license plate or parking decal or device is not the authorized holder of the disability license plate or parking decal or device or is not transporting the authorized holder of the disability license plate or parking decal or device to or from the parking location and (ii) the person uses the disability license plate or parking decal or device to exercise any privileges granted through the disability license plate or parking decals or devices. 
(3)  Any person or local authority owning or operating any public or private off-street parking facility may, after notifying the police or sheriff's department, remove or cause to be removed to the nearest garage or other place of safety any vehicle parked within a stall or space reserved for use by a person with disabilities which does not display person with disabilities registration plates or a special decal or device as required under this section. 
(4)  Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of section 90-171(a)(1), (a)(2), (a)(3) or section 90-171(b)(1) shall be fined $250.00 in addition to any costs or charges connected with the removal or storage of any motor vehicle authorized under this section. Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of section 90-171(b)(2) shall be fined $500.00 in addition to any costs or charges connected with the removal or storage of any motor vehicle authorized under this section. 
(5)  Local authorities shall impose fines as established in subsection (b)(4) of this section for vehicles parked in spaces for persons with disabilities that do not display the registration plates pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/3-616 or a special decal or device pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.1 or 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.2 or to a disabled veteran pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/3-609. 
(c)  Designated parking spaces. The area from a point 20 feet east of the east curb of Church Street, to a point 25 feet east of this point, shall be designated and reserved for parking of vehicles identified as belonging to persons with disabilities. Such vehicles must be identified as defined by the secretary of state or authority responsible for issuing special identification plates or markings. 
(Code 1981, §§ 5-6-11.C.6, 5-6-23.A, B; Ord. No. 1720, § 3, 1-10-2006) 
Sec. 90-172. - Moving or removal of certain vehicles authorized. 
(a)  Whenever any police officer finds a vehicle in violation of any of the provisions of 625 ILCS 5/11-1301, such officer is hereby authorized to move such vehicle, or require the driver or other person in charge of the vehicle to move the vehicle, to a position off the roadway. 
(b)  Any police officer is hereby authorized to remove or cause to be removed to a place of safety any unattended vehicle illegally left standing upon any highway, bridge or causeway, or in a tunnel, in such a position or under such circumstances as to obstruct the normal movement of traffic. Whenever the police department finds an abandoned or disabled vehicle standing upon the paved or main-traveled part of a highway, which vehicle is or may be expected to interrupt the free flow of traffic on the highway or interfere with the maintenance of the highway, the department is authorized to move the vehicle to a position off the paved or improved or main-traveled part of the highway. 
(c)  Any police officer is hereby authorized to remove or cause to be removed to the nearest garage or other place of safety any vehicle found upon a highway when: 
(1)  Report has been made that such vehicle has been stolen or taken without the consent of its owner; 
(2)  The persons in charge of such vehicle are unable to provide for its custody or removal; or 
(3)  The person driving or in control of such vehicle is arrested for an alleged offense for which the officer is required by law to take the person arrested before a proper magistrate without unnecessary delay. 
(Code 1981, § 5-6-23.C) 
Sec. 90-173. - Parking enforcement officer; persons authorized to issue parking citations. 
(a)  There is hereby created the position of parking enforcement officer, who shall be appointed by the corporate authorities of the village. 
(b)  Parking enforcement officers, police officers, auxiliary police officers and all employees of the parking section are hereby empowered to issue citations for all parking ordinances of the village. 
(Code 1981, § 5-6-24) 
Sec. 90-174. - No parking places 
    No person shall park a vehicle, except where necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control device, in any of the following places: 
(1)  On a sidewalk; 
(2)  In front of a public or private driveway; 
(3)  Within an intersection 
(4)  Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant; 
(5)  On a crosswalk; 
(6)  Within 20 feet of a crosswalk or within 20 feet of an intersection. 
(7)  Within 30 feet upon the approach to any flashing beacon, stop sign or traffic-control signal located at the right side of a roadway; 
(8)  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within 30 feet of the points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone; 
(9)  Within 50 feet of the nearest rail of a railroad grade crossing; 
(10)  Within 20 feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station and, on the side of the street opposite the entrance to any fire station, within 75 feet of said entrance when properly sign-posted; 
(11)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when such parking would obstruct traffic; 
(12)  On the roadway side of any vehicle parked at the edge or curb of a street; 
(13)  Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or within a highway; 
(14)  At any place where the standing of a vehicle will reduce the usable width of a roadway for moving traffic to less than 12 feet; 
(15)  At any place where official signs prohibit parking. 
(Ord. No. 1398, § 1, 5-15-2002; Ord. No. 2450, § 4, 10-13-2014) 
Sec. 90-175. - No parking or stopping on streets: 
(a)  Upon any street or highway within the village, no person shall stop, park or leave standing any vehicle, whether attended or unattended, upon the main-traveled part of the highway when it is practicable to stop, park or so leave such vehicle off such part of said highway, but in every event a clear and unobstructed width of the highway opposite such standing vehicle shall be left for the free passage of other vehicles and a clear view of such stopped vehicles shall be available from a distance of 200 feet in each direction upon such highway. 
(b)  Subsection (a) shall not apply to the driver of any vehicle which is disabled while on the paved or main-traveled portion of a highway in such a manner and to such extent that it is impossible to avoid stopping and temporarily leaving such disabled vehicle in such position; provided, however, that at least one door of any motor vehicle permitted to stand unattended on the paved or main-traveled part of any highway shall be left unlocked. 
(Ord. No. 1398, § 1, 5-15-2002) 
Sec. 90-176. - Truck, semi trailer, trailer, pole trailer and recreational vehicle parking. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to park any truck tractor, tow truck, semi trailer, trailer, pole trailer, mobile home or recreational trailer, whether licensed or not, and whether connected to a vehicle or not, on any street, highway, or parkway within the village, subject to the following: 
(1)  Semi trailers, trailers, and pole trailers being used in the normal course of construction work may be temporarily parked on village roadways immediately adjacent to a lot where construction work is being performed for a period not to exceed 12 consecutive hours. 
(2)  Semi trailers, trailers, and pole trailers of utility companies used to provide emergency services and providing services within the village may be temporarily parked in residential districts or on any street, highway, or parkway within the village during such time as the utility company employee assigned the use of the trailer is off-duty but on-call. 
(3)  Semi trailers, trailers, and pole trailers utilized in the process of delivering or receiving goods, materials or merchandise may be temporarily parked on any street, highway, or parkway within the village during such time. 
(b)  Residential Streets. All commercial vehicles and trucks with an Illinois State license plate of higher than a B classification (or an out of state equivalent), truck tractors, tow trucks, or trailers mobile home, travel trailer, camping trailer, boat, recreational vehicle, personal water craft or all terrain vehicle, including trailers used to transport any such recreational vehicles, and similar vehicles used for recreational purposes whether laden or unladen, unless in the process of delivering or receiving goods, materials or merchandise, are prohibited from parking on any residential street for more than four consecutive hours within a 24-hour period. 
(c)  Generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to park or drop off any semi trailer, trailer, or pole trailer upon public property within the village or in any area under the jurisdiction of the village without: 
(1)  Requesting permission from the Chief of the New Lenox Police Department or designee for 24-hour parking under special circumstances. 
(2)  Delivering to the chief of the police department or designee the name, residential address and residential phone number of any person from which access may be obtained to the trailer and the trailer's location and contents. 
(d)  No vehicle shall be used for living or sleeping purposes while parked in the village, unless it is located in a mobile home park. 
(Ord. No. 2154, § 3, 2-14-2011; Ord. No. 2538, § 2, 12-21-2015) 
Secs. 90-177-90-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SNOWMOBILES 

Sec. 90-201. - Definitions. 
    The definitions set forth in the Snowmobile Registration and Safety Act (625 ILCS 40/1-1 et seq.), as amended, are hereby incorporated by reference as if fully set forth in this article. 
(Code 1981, § 5-8-1.A) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 90-202. - Penalty. 
    In addition to all other remedies, any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with any provision of this article shall be sentenced as provided in section 1-15 of this Code for each offense. 
(Code 1981, § 5-8-3; Ord. No. 2192, § 31, 8-22-2011) 
Sec. 90-203. - Resisting or obstructing enforcement officers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to resist or obstruct any police officer of the village in the discharge of the duties set forth in this article. 
(Code 1981, § 5-8-1.B) 
Sec. 90-204. - Registration required. 
    No person shall operate any snowmobile within the corporate limits of the village unless such snowmobile has been registered and numbered in accordance with 625 ILCS 40/1-1 et seq. and unless the certificate or number awarded to such snowmobile is in full force and effect and the identifying number set forth in the certificate is displayed on each side of the cowling of such snowmobile in accordance with 625 ILCS 40/1-1 et seq. 
(Code 1981, § 5-8-1.C) 
Sec. 90-205. - Equipment. 
    All snowmobiles operated within the corporate limits of the village shall be equipped as required by the provisions of 625 ILCS 40/4-1 et seq., which is incorporated in this article by reference and made a part of this article. 
(Code 1981, § 5-8-1.D) 
Sec. 90-206. - Operation generally. 
    It is unlawful for any person to drive or operate any snowmobile in a manner prohibited by 625 ILCS 40/5-1 et seq., which is incorporated in this article by reference and made a part of this article. 
(Code 1981, § 5-8-1.E) 
Sec. 90-207. - Use of streets. 
    All operators of snowmobiles shall leave the village by using village streets from their homes to the nearest exit from the village to the snowmobile trail desired to be used. The streets of the village shall only be used by the residents of the village for the purpose of leaving and entering the village. All persons operating snowmobiles on the village streets as set forth in this section shall remain on or as close as possible to the right side of the roadway. There shall be no operation of snowmobiles on Cedar Road (except south of Fourth Avenue) or on Route 30 within the village limits. 
(Code 1981, § 5-8-1.F) 
Sec. 90-208. - Hours of operation. 
    Snowmobiles may be operated within the village as provided in this article only between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight each day of the week. No snowmobile may be operated within the village between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m. on any day. 
(Code 1981, § 5-8-1.G) 
Sec. 90-209. - Obedience to traffic regulations. 
    In addition to the directions for operation of snowmobiles otherwise set forth in this article, operators must obey all traffic regulations as prescribed for motor vehicle traffic and are subject to the same penalties for violation thereof. 
(Code 1981, § 5-8-1.H) 
Secs. 90-210-90-230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - VEHICLE EQUIPMENT, CONDITION, SIZE, WEIGHT AND LOAD 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 90-231. - Emission of smoke or fumes. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle which emits dense smoke or such an amount of smoke or fumes as to be dangerous to the health of persons or as to endanger the drivers of other vehicles. 
(Code 1981, § 5-11-1) 
Sec. 90-232. - Brakes. 
    It shall be unlawful to drive any motor vehicle upon a street unless such vehicle is equipped with good and sufficient brakes in good working conditions, as required by 625 ILCS 5/12-301, or to operate any vehicle which is so loaded that the operator does not have ready access to the mechanics operating the brakes of such vehicle. 
(Code 1981, § 5-11-5) 
Sec. 90-233. - Unnecessary noise. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate a motor vehicle which makes unusually loud or unnecessary noise, or to operate a motor vehicle in such a manner as to cause an unusually loud or unnecessary noise to be made. 
(Code 1981, § 5-11-7.B) 
Sec. 90-234. - Tires. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate on any street any motor vehicle which is not equipped with tires conforming to the requirements of 625 ILCS 5/12-401 et seq. 
(Code 1981, § 5-11-11) 
Sec. 90-235. - Bell or other signaling device required on bicycles. 
    No person shall operate a bicycle unless it is equipped with a bell or other device capable of giving a signal audible for a distance of at least 100 feet, except that a bicycle shall not be equipped with a siren or whistle, nor shall any person use any siren or whistle upon a bicycle. 
(Code 1981, § 5-11-4.C) 
Sec. 90-236. - Parental responsibility for violations by children. 
    The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate any provision of this article. 
(Code 1981, § 5-11-4.D) 
Secs. 90-237-90-250. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SIZE, WEIGHT AND LOAD 

Sec. 90-251. - Truck routes. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purpose of this division, the following terms shall have the meanings given in this subsection: 
    Truck means any vehicle designed or operated for the transportation of property, and whose body weight or whose combined body and load weight exceeds five tons. 
    Truck route means a way over certain streets, as state designated, signposted, or as provided for herein, over and along which trucks coming into and going out of the village must operate, so long as the truck is otherwise legal. 
(b)  Use of designated streets required. All trucks within the village shall be operated only over and along routes as provided for herein and on the other county or state designated streets over which truck travel is permitted. 
(c)  Truck route designated; additional streets for truck traffic. There is hereby established within the village the following truck routes: Old New Lenox Road (Haven Avenue) from Gougar Road west to the village limits and Schoolhouse Road from Route 30 south to Laraway Road. In addition to these streets in the village constituting a part of a truck route as established in this section, unless otherwise provided, all county and state designated streets, and no other streets, shall be used for truck traffic. 
(d)  Route for reaching destination point or leaving point of origin. 
(1)  Trips originating outside village. 
a.  One inside destination point. All trucks entering the village for a destination point in the village shall proceed only over an established truck route and shall deviate only at the intersection with the street upon which such traffic is permitted nearest the destination point. Upon leaving the destination point, a deviating truck shall return to the truck route by the shortest permissible route. 
b.  Multiple inside destination points. All trucks entering the village for multiple destination points shall proceed only over established truck routes and shall deviate only at the intersection with the street upon which such traffic is permitted nearest to the first destination point. Upon leaving the first destination point a deviating truck shall proceed to the other destination points by the shortest direction. Upon leaving the last destination point, a deviating truck shall return to the truck route by the shortest permissible route. 
(2)  Trips originating inside village. 
a.  Outside destination point. All trucks on a trip originating in the village, and traveling in the village for a destination point outside the village, shall proceed by the shortest direction over the streets on which such traffic is permitted to the truck route as established in this section. 
b.  Inside destination points. All trucks on a trip originating in the village, and traveling in the village for destination points in the village, shall proceed only over streets upon which such traffic is permitted. 
(e)  Enforcement. 
(1)  Posting of signs. The truck route, and those streets upon which traffic is restricted, shall be signposted. 
(2)  Authority to weigh vehicles. The department of police of the village shall have the authority to require any person driving or in control of any vehicle not proceeding over a truck route or street over which truck traffic is permitted to proceed to any public or private scale available for the purpose of weighing and determining whether this division has been complied with. 
(3)  Construction traffic routing. All construction traffic whose trip either originates from or terminates in a construction site for which there exists a named posted route will be prohibited on any unposted route that accesses such named site. 
(Code 1981, § 5-12-1; Ord. No. 1484A, § 2, 7-8-2003; Ord. No. 2106, § 2, 5-10-2010) 
Sec. 90-252. - Weight restrictions and permits. 
(a)  Weight restrictions. All streets shall be classified as non-designated unless county or state designated, signposted, as provided by ordinance, or as set forth in this division. The maximum weight permitted on all non-designated streets shall be five (5) ton, except for the following: 
40 ton: 
  Old New Lenox Road (Haven Avenue) from Gougar Road west to the Village limits. 
  Schoolhouse Road from Route 30 south to Laraway Road. 
14 ton: 
  Cedar Road from Francis Road south to Illinois Highway (Spencer Road). 
  Nelson Road from Illinois Highway (Spencer Road) south to Delaney Road. 
  Illinois Highway (Spencer Road). 
  The portion of Spencer Road from Illinois Highway (Spencer Road) south to Laraway Road within the Village limits. 
12 ton: 
  Schmuhl/Schoolhouse Road from Laraway Road south to the Village limits. 
  Delaney Road. 
  The portion of Spencer Road from Laraway Road south to Delaney Road within the village limits. 
(b)  Vehicles with a gross weight in excess of maximum weight limits on non-designated streets. It shall be unlawful to operate a vehicle on any non-designated street with a gross weight, including load, in excess of the maximum weight limits as set forth in subsection (a), or in excess of special weight limits, without having first obtained an overweight permit from the chief of police or his designee. 
This subsection shall not prohibit: 
(1)  The operation of trucks upon any street where necessary to the conduct of business at a destination point, provided streets upon which such traffic is permitted are used until reaching the intersection nearest the destination point and the route is not being used as a thoroughfare between truck routes. 
(2)  The operation of garbage trucks, tow trucks, school buses, ambulances, fire fighting vehicles, snow plows, street maintenance vehicles, and emergency vehicles upon any street in the village. 
(3)  The operation of trucks owned or operated by the village, public utilities, or any contractor or materialman, while engaged in the repair, maintenance or construction of streets, street improvements or street utilities within the village. 
(4)  The operation of trucks upon any officially established detour in any case where such truck could lawfully be operated upon the street for which such detour is established. 
Except that any of the aforesaid vehicles in excess of 80,000 pounds must first obtain an overweight permit from the chief of police or his designee. 
(c)  Vehicles with a gross weight in excess of 80,000 pounds. It shall be unlawful to operate a vehicle with a gross weight, including load, in excess of 80,000 pounds, without first having obtained an overweight permit from the chief of police or his designee. 
(d)  Applications for overweight permits. Applications for all overweight permits shall be submitted in writing to the chief of police or his designee on the form provided and shall include at a minimum: 
(1)  The type of vehicle(s); 
(2)  The weight to be transported; 
(3)  The content to be transported; 
(4)  The number of trips required; 
(5)  The route to be taken by the vehicles; 
(6)  The destination of the vehicles within the village; and 
(7)  The name of the carrier, if different than the applicant. 
(e)  Fee schedule for overweight permit, vehicle with a gross weight in excess of maximum weight limits on a non-designated street. An overweight permit for a vehicle with a gross weight, including load, in excess of the maximum weight limits as set forth in this division, or in excess of special weight limits, but not in excess of 80,000 pounds, may be applied for and may be granted upon submittal of a completed application and in accordance with payment of the fee as set forth in the fee schedule for overweight permits. 
(f)  Fee schedule for overweight permit, vehicle with a gross weight in excess of 80,000 pounds. An overweight permit for a vehicle with a gross weight, including load, in excess of 80,000 pounds, may be applied for and may be granted upon submittal of a completed application and in accordance with payment of the fee as set forth in the fee schedule as set forth in section 90-253. 
(g)  Issuance of overweight permit. Upon receipt of a completed application and proof of payment of the fee, the chief of police or his designee may issue an overweight permit, subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  In consideration of seasonal or other time limitations, the chief of police or his designee shall restrict the number or time of daily trips authorized by each overweight permit, as is consistent with the public safety. 
(2)  In establishing the routes to be traveled, the chief of police or his designee may establish the most direct and shortest route consistent with the public safety, taking into consideration existing traffic, the character of the street or streets, and the configuration of the terrain. 
(3)  All overweight permits shall be nontransferable and shall be valid only for the applicant or his agent or employee and the specific vehicle and load listed on the application. 
(4)  Every overweight permit shall be carried in the vehicle to which it refers and shall be open to inspection by any law enforcement officer. 
(5)  No refunds of the overweight permit fee shall be made to the applicant following the issuance of an overweight permit. 
(6)  The applicant shall comply with all village, state, county, and township ordinances, regulations and requirements. 
(7)  Altering or falsifying a permit will revoke overweight permit privileges for 12 months. 
(Code 1981, § 5-12-2; Ord. No. 1484A, § 3, 7-8-2003; Ord. No. 2106, § 2, 5-10-2010) 
Sec. 90-253. - Adoption of state law. 
(a)  Pursuant to 65 ILCS 5/11-40-1 and 625 ILCS 5/11-208(a)(7), the village hereby adopts ILCS ch. 625, act 5, chapter 15, including its numbering system, size, weight and load regulations, and violations/penalties, by reference and it is incorporated as a part of this Code as if fully set out herein. 
(b)  Pursuant to 65 ILCS 5/11-80-2, 625 ILCS 5/11-208(a)(2) and 625 ILCS 5/11-208(a)(15), the village hereby adopts 625 ILCS 5/3-401(d) and 625 ILCS 5/3-815, including its numbering system, schedules and violations/penalties, by reference and it is incorporated as a part of this Code as if fully set out herein. 
(Code 1981, § 5-12-3; Ord. No. 1484A, § 4, 7-8-2003; Ord. No. 2106, § 2, 5-10-2010) 
Sec. 90-254. - Violations, penalties. 
(a)  Violations, penalties generally. Unless as otherwise provided, any person firm, or corporation who violates any section or provision of this division shall be punished by a fine of not less than $50.00 and not more than as provided in section 1-9 of this code for any one offense. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. 
(b)  Penalty, vehicle with a gross weight in excess of maximum weight limits on a non-designated street. Any person, firm, or corporation who violates any section or provision of this division operating a vehicle with a gross weight in excess of the maximum weight limits as set forth in section 90-252 on a non-designated street, in addition to any other fines, penalties, or restitution, shall be subject to a fine of not less than $500.00 and not more than as provided in section 1-9 of this code; except that a vehicle with a gross weight in excess of 80,000 pounds may be subject to the fines and penalties as set forth in subsection (c). Prior to release of a vehicle with a gross weight in excess of the maximum weight limits as set forth in section 90-252 on a non-designated street, a sufficient bond must be posted. 
(c)  Penalty, vehicle with a gross weight in excess of prescribed weight limits. Any person, firm or corporation operating a vehicle with a gross weight in excess of prescribed weight limits, in addition to any other fines, penalties, or restitution, shall be subject to the following: 
(1)  Weight. Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of 625 ILCS 5/15-111, the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed guilty of such violation and either the owner or the driver of such vehicle may be prosecuted for such violation. Any person charged with a violation of any of these provisions who pleads not guilty shall be present in court for the trial on the charge. Any person, firm or corporation convicted of any violation of the 625 ILCS 5/15-111, as enforced by the village, including but not limited to, a maximum axle or gross limit specified on a regulatory sign posted in accordance with paragraphs (g) or (h) of 625 ILCS 5/15-111, shall be fined according to the following schedule: 
Up to and including 2000 pounds overweight = $100 
From 2001 through 2500 pounds overweight = the fine is $270 
From 2501 through 3000 pounds overweight = the fine is $330 
From 3001 through 3500 pounds overweight = the fine is $520 
From 3501 through 4000 pounds overweight = the fine is $600 
From 4001 through 4500 pounds overweight = the fine is $850 
From 4501 through 5000 pounds overweight = the fine is $950 
From 5001 or more pounds overweight = the fine shall be computed by assessing $1,500 for the first 5000 pounds overweight and $150 for each additional increment of 500 pounds overweight or fraction thereof. 
In addition, any person, firm or corporation convicted of four or more violations of 625 ILCS 5/15-111 within any 12-month period shall be fined an additional amount of $5,000.00 for the fourth and each subsequent conviction within the 12 month period. Provided, however, that with regard to a firm or corporation, a fourth or subsequent conviction shall mean a fourth or subsequent conviction attributable to any one employee-driver. 
State Law reference- Violations; penalties, 625 ILCS 5/15-113(a). 
(2)  Width, height, length of vehicles. Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of 625 ILCS 5/15-102, 625 ILCS 5/15-103 or 625 ILCS 5/15-107, the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed guilty of such violation and either may be prosecuted for such violation. Any person, firm or corporation convicted of any violation of 625 ILCS 5/15-102, 625 ILCS 5/15-103 or 625 ILCS 5/15-107 shall be fined for the first or second conviction an amount equal to not less than $50.00 nor more than $500.00, and for the third and subsequent convictions by the same person, firm or corporation within a period of one year after the date of the first offense, not less than $500.00 nor more than $1,000.00. 
State Law reference- Violations; penalties, 625 ILCS 5/15-113(b). 
(3)  Sentence of permit moves. Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of a permit issued under the provisions of 625 ILCS 5/15-301 through 625 ILCS 5/15-319, as enforced by the Village, by operating under a fraudulent permit or under a permit not specifically covering the move, the owner or driver of such vehicle shall be deemed guilty of a business offense and either the owner or the driver of such vehicle may be prosecuted for such violation. When any person, firm or corporation is convicted of such violation, the permit shall be null and void and such person, firm or corporation shall be fined in an amount not less than ten cents per pound for each pound the gross weight of the vehicle exceeds the gross weight of such vehicles allowable under 625 ILCS 5/15-111. Penalties for violations of this section shall be in addition to any penalties imposed for violation of 625 ILCS 5/15-301(j) as enforced by the village. 
State Law reference- Violations-Sentence of permit moves, 625 ILCS 5/15-113.1. 
(4)  Sentence of permit moves exceeding axle weights.
